HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
ABZUG, BELLA

 BODY:
ABZUG-Bella. The National Women's Political Caucus of New York State mourns the death of Bella Abzug, our leader in the fight for women's rights. As we celebrate the 150th anniversary of the Women's Rights Movement, Bella will be remembered as our history and our strength.
ABZUG-Bella. The Hunter College community is deeply saddened by the passing of Bella Abzug, who spent her extremely productive life supporting a broad range of human rights causes, and was, we are proud to say, a lifelong supporter of Hunter College. She received her B.A. from Hunter in 1942, made her decision to become a lawyer while at Hunter, and went on to become a specialist in labor and civil-liberties law, a political activist who fought for peace and civil rights, and a member of Congress. As a Congresswoman she worked for passage of the Equal Rights Amendment, introduced pioneering legislation promoting women's rights, worked on behalf of a host of laws that sought equality and dignity for all, & became a global symbol of feminism and humanitarianism. After leaving Congress, she concentrated on global women's issues and environmental issues, and in 1990 she joined with other activists to found WEDO-The Women's Environment and Development Organization. She has remained close to her alma mater throughout her life, and our Alumni Association has named her to its Hall of Fame and presented her with its Award for Outstanding Professional Achievement. A lecture series sponsored by our Women's Studies Program is named for her, and she was its first speaker. Her most recent appearance at Hunter was in October 1997, when she gave the College's Millennium Address at our annual Fall Celebration. Her topic was "Celebrating People's Empowerment for the New Millennium"-an apt subject for a woman who devoted her life to working for people's empowerment. We shall miss her deeply, as will the tens of thousands of people whose lives she touched, and we send our sincerest condolences to her daughters, her entire family, and her many friends and colleagues. David A. Caputo, President, Hunter College
ABZUG-Bella. With profound grief & loss, The Womens Environment and Development Organization (WEDO) Board, Staff and Global Network, mourns the death of Bella Abzug, our Co-Founder and President. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved family. Bella was a world-class leader, a brilliant tactician in Congress and the U.N., where she championed the rights of women worldwide. She was a fearless and passionate advocate of women's empowerment, equality and a healthy planet. Most of all, she was a woman of principle who never sold out or gave in. Bella, we love you. You have left a living legacy. We will carry on your brand of passionate politics, fighting for social justice, human rights, peace, and a healthy environment. WEDO Board of Director Thais Corral, Brazil Jocelyn Dow, Guyana Elin Enge, Norway Farkhonda Hassan, Egypt Mim Kelber, USA Brownie Ledbetter, USA Wangari Maathai, Kenya Chief Bisi Ogunleye, Nigeria Maria Eugenia Penon, Costa Rica Vandana Shiva, India Hon. Maxine Waters, USA Faye Wattleton, USA Susan Davis, Exec Director
ABZUG - Bella. The Planned Parenthood family mourns the loss of Bella Abzug, stalwart champion of women's rights and reproductive freedom here at home and around the world. We will miss the sound advice and encouragement of a witty, shrewd, and courageous colleague who illuminated our lives. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Sharon Allison, Chairperson Gloria Feldt, President Planned Parenthood Federation of America
ABZUG-Bella. The Jewish Fund for Justice mourns the passing of Bella Abzug, a friend, supporter and recipient of our Women of Valor award. Bella was a trailblazing feminist and passionate, relentless fighter for social and economic justice in this country and worldwide. She leaves a towering legacy of accomplishments and hope. Our hearts go out to her daughters, Liz and Eve. Ronna Stamm, President Marlene Provizer, Exec Director
ABZUG-Bella. The Alumni Association of Hunter College notes with sorrow the passing of its distinguished member of the Class of 1942 and recipient of the 1996 Alumni Award for Outstanding Professional Achievement. We extend condolences to her family and friends. Helene D. Goldfarb, President, Alumni Association

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
How good is business? It's so good that good workers are very hard to find, and to keep.

BYLINE: By Carol Marie Cropper 

 BODY:
EXECUTIVES at Sicola Martin, an agency in Austin, Tex., have two problems: Business is booming. And their high-technology clients' business is booming, too.
How is that a problem? Just try finding and then holding onto talented workers, they say, echoing a lament heard throughout the advertising industry. 
 "We're often training people only to lose them," complained Barbara Matijevich, a spokeswoman at the $53 million agency. "We lose a lot of people to the high-tech companies themselves."
Sicola Martin -- facing fierce competition for workers from computer companies as well as within the advertising industry -- may be having a particularly tough time. But executives around the country say recruiting good people has been more difficult in the last year to two years.
Many blame the industry itself, in part at least, for the crunch. During the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's, agencies stopped hiring and laid off the middle managers they now need, said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York.
"We're now paying the penalty for that," he said. "We sort of lost a whole generation of new people."
Some of those lost workers became freelancers and are now quite happy on their own, thank you, said Anne Melanson, director of human resources at the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., a $6 billion agency based in New York. About 10 percent of the people her agency would like to hire are freelancing, she said.
As the economy has improved, others have jumped to lucrative jobs at consulting firms and in corporate marketing departments, leaving lagging agency salaries behind, Mr. Drake and others said.
Camille Weas, human resources manager at Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis, an $863 million agency that is majority-owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, said Campbell Mithun stopped shopping for young M.B.A.'s in the late 80's because advertising salaries were no longer competitive.
New York agencies complain about a shortage of talent, but those in Minneapolis and elsewhere in the Midwest are particularly frantic.
"There are certain areas that people don't necessarily want to go to," explained Judy Wald, chairwoman of Judy Wald Partners, an executive search firm in Manhattan that specializes in advertising positions.
Campbell Mithun opened a 15-employee satellite office in New York last year for finicky creative types who are hard to lure to Minneapolis, Ms. Weas said.
In Los Angeles, Brian Morris, president of Dailey & Associates, another unit of Interpublic, said area agencies had found recruiting tough because of "the riots and earthquakes and floods and everything else." Then, as the agencies started to recover, he added, they found themselves in a boom-time scramble for employees.
Agencies all over are adding perquisites to attract employees and offering incentives to those already on staff who bring in new hires.
D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications in New York, the flagship of MacManus Group, doubled its new-worker bounty to $1,000 last year, said Leslie Engel, human resources director. D.M.B.& B. has also added tuition reimbursement and health-related programs, along with referrals for child care and care for the elderly, in an attempt to woo Generation X'ers, she said.
Still, Ms. Engel said, it takes perhaps twice as long to fill a vacancy as it once did, and account supervisors are especially hard to find (an assessment echoed at several other agencies).
All this would seem to be good news for recruiting firms at least -- except for one thing. Robert Herman, of the Robert Herman Company in New York, said he lost about $200,000 in fees last year as prospective hires were lured back by their old agencies.
Ms. Wald, who has experienced the same setback, said: "It shows how hard they try to hold onto their valued people. They know how hard it is to find a replacement."
Even when a hiring appears to be successful, it may not last long-term. Sicola Martin, the Texas agency, spent a year looking for one account director, only to have him leave within six months.

LENGTH: 424 words

HEADLINE: Make the Tobacco Bill Tougher

 BODY:
The tobacco bill drafted by Senator John McCain that will be considered by the Senate Commerce Committee today is far better than the original settlement negotiated between tobacco companies and state attorneys general last June. But it still falls short in deterring smoking among teen-agers.
A key question is whether cigarette prices would be raised sufficiently to curb consumption, particularly among youths. The McCain bill would require the industry to pay some $506 billion over 25 years. That cost would be passed on to consumers in incremental price increases projected to reach $1.10 per pack of cigarettes over five years. 
 Most health economists who have studied this problem believe that a price increase of at least $1.50 a pack is necessary to make a significant dent in youth smoking, and some believe the hike should be even higher. The McCain plan, though it would raise prices more than the 62-cent-per-pack increase contemplated in the attorneys general deal, looks too low to achieve that primary public health goal.
Under this bill, the industry would also have to pay penalties if teen-age smoking rates do not go down by 60 percent over the next 10 years. But the penalties are capped at $3.5 billion annually, an amount that is probably not enough to deter bad conduct from an industry that desperately needs to hook the next generation of smokers. The bill would not provide any immunity from class-action lawsuits or limit punitive damages, but it would cap the industry's payout on civil awards to $6.5 billion in any single year. Damage awards exceeding that amount would be collectible in subsequent years.
The cap could help stabilize tobacco companies if they face gigantic court judgments. But unless the rest of the package is strengthened to insure that the industry will play by the new rules, giving it any financial protection cannot be justified.
The bill would ban outdoor cigarette advertising and a range of aggressive promotional practices. It also gives the Food and Drug Administration full authority to regulate tobacco and nicotine, and would provide more than $28 billion to help tobacco farmers affected by reduced tobacco consumption. These provisions are sensible, but they do not shore up the main weaknesses.
If the bill is approved in committee, President Clinton should be poised to fight for higher payments and penalties when it goes before the full Senate. He should not accept legislation that will leave millions of American youths exposed to tobacco addiction.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Up on Signs of Sound Economy and Scant Price Pressure

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities turned higher yesterday after a regional manufacturing report showed that the economy was remaining strong but without the price pressures that normally accompany such strength.
The Federal Reserve's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee held its second monetary policy meeting of the year, and, as expected, concluded the meeting with no action on interest rates, and consequently little impact on the market. 
 The 30-year bond rose 18/32, to 102 22/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.93 percent, from 5.98 percent on Monday.
The Purchasing Management Association of Chicago's index of manufacturing activity rose unexpectedly for March, while the prices paid index dropped to 48.7 in March from 55.5 in February. It showed that fewer companies were reporting price increases and that employment eased in March.
Traders said the end of the quarter had a muting effect on activity yesterday, with much of the market's attention focused on the March employment report, which is scheduled to be released Friday.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said yesterday's inaction by the Fed was not surprising, "with economic growth expected to moderate and inflation still very restrained."
Mr. Fine added that "although a growing number of market observers feel there is a reasonable chance that the Fed may have reinstated its bias toward tightening in light of the exuberant performance of both consumer spending and housing activity of late," he expected monetary policy to remain on hold for quite some time before economic conditions changed sufficiently to dictate a policy shift.
The Fed last adjusted the Federal funds target rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans a year ago, when it raised it to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent.
Treasury bill prices rose after the Government said yesterday that it would offer $5.75 billion in three-month bills next week, about $500 million less than the previous week.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Contrition

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: GABORONE, Botswana, March 31

 BODY:
The last stop on President Clinton's 12-day trip to Africa will be a visit to Goree Island on Thursday afternoon, just before he boards Air Force One for the flight back to Washington.
It was on Goree, a speck in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Senegal, that millions of Africans spent their last hours on the continent, chained to walls in dank underground cubicles, before beginning the ghastly (and for many fatal) voyage to the New World. In the weighing room of the Slave House, men's muscles were examined, women's breasts measured and children's teeth checked. Then they were fattened to what was considered an ideal shipping weight -- 140 pounds for men. Those who failed to meet specifications were fed to the sharks. 
 Mr. Clinton's visit, fraught with wrenching emotional symbolism, will bring to a climax the politics of contrition he has practiced in Africa.
Although his main focus has been on the continent's future, especially his hopes that political and economic reform will make possible an increase in American trade and investment here, he has apologized for what he depicted as excessive concentration on cold-war imperatives in past United States relationships with African nations. He has also apologized for American inattention to the continent.
But he has not explicitly apologized to Africans for slavery, as some African-Americans would like him to, though the issue has lurked in the background throughout the trip. Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, has been asked repeatedly about the subject, and has replied that the United States long ago made clear by word and deed that it considered slavery repugnant.
As he seeks in the months ahead to sell his policy of greater engagement with Africa to Congress, business and the American public, Mr. Clinton needs the backing not only of black voters but also of white moderates and conservatives. His efforts to increase aid to and trade with Africa would not be helped by a debate over apologizing for the benefits the United States derived from slavery or even paying reparations to modern African-Americans, as some have asked.
"Going back to the time before we were even a nation, European-Americans received the fruits of the slave trade," the President said in Mukono, Uganda, in his most explicit comments on the issue so far. "We were wrong in that as well, although I must say, if you look at the remarkable delegation we have here from Congress, from our Cabinet and Administration, and from the citizens of America, you can see there are many distinguished African-Americans who are in that delegation who are making America a better place today."
Mr. Clinton returned to the subject in a weekend interview, released today, with correspondents for black-oriented news organizations.
"Most of my African-American friends and advisers don't believe that we should get into what was essentially a press story about whether there should be an apology for slavery in America," he said. "They think that that's what the 13th, 14th and 15th Amendment was, they think that's what the Civil Rights Amendment was and they think we need to be looking toward the future.
"So I think we've drawn the right balance and I feel good about it."
The facts of slavery are complex, as are the reactions of African-Americans to efforts to bring it into discussions of modern United States policy toward African nations.
It was not only European slave traders and ship captains who profited for three centuries from the shipment of Africans to the United States, the West Indies and South American countries like Brazil (where many voyages from Goree ended). Arab agents played a major role, as did African chiefs and clan leaders, especially in the territories stretching south from modern Senegal and then east along the bulge of West Africa to present-day Nigeria and beyond.
The Arabs seldom ventured far from the coast. But African leaders in the hinterland, sorely tempted by products newly introduced to the continent by Europeans, sold their people into bondage for cloth, beads, tobacco, firearms and especially cheap liquor. It was the beginning of the plunder of Africa's riches by the outside world, starting with the most basic, its human resources.
President Clinton's advisers, notably the African-Americans among them, have expressed conflicting views on the relevance of slavery to his trip.
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, a special Presidential envoy to Africa, took traveling reporters (and by extension the American people) to task at a briefing for what he described as their failure to appreciate the emotional links of African-Americans to their homeland and to the experience of slavery.
He said Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's trip to the Prague ghetto last September was far more widely noted than the trip of the President's entourage to the castle in Accra, Ghana, once used to protect slave traders. For people like himself, Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater and Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman, Mr. Jackson said, "It was a big emotional day," and that had been missed.
Mr. Jackson also outlined an unusually Afrocentric view of American history, arguing that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had more to do with modern democracy than Thomas Jefferson. He asserted that the American economy was built by slaves who were not paid and blacks who were underpaid, making the United States the real debtor nation rather than the countries of Africa.
Susan Rice, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, sat glowering through much of Mr. Jackson's briefing. When her turn came she commented, "As an African-American, I would like to say that I think slavery is largely irrelevant to what we are about here."
As if to smooth over the disagreement, Mr. Jackson said later, "We're not really wallowing in the emotions, even at the high points."
But those are unlikely to be the final words on such a vexed topic. Mr. Jackson has a wide following among African-Americans, and some other black leaders -- such as Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Nation of Islam -- take an even stronger stance on slavery than he does. Mr. Farrakhan travels often to Africa.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A quarter of rich mergers dilutes the Asia effect on Wall St.

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin 

 BODY:
WALL STREET, which began the year wondering if Asia was going to upset its apple cart, needn't have worried.
Helped by falling interest rates, the securities industry raised a record $472.7 billion in American financial markets in the first three months of 1998, up more than 62 percent from the same period a year ago and 27 percent higher than the previous record of $372.5 billion, set in the third quarter of last year. 
 The performance was buttressed by a mergers-and-acquisitions market that remained white-hot.
During the period, a total of $240.2 billion worth of mergers was announced, according to the Securities Data Company. That is well down from the $325.6 billion in American deals announced in the fourth quarter of last year, but is still the second-best quarter on record. Globally, $469.6 billion worth of mergers were announced in the first quarter, down somewhat from the record $543.5 billion in the last three months of 1997.
Over the last three months, Merrill Lynch & Company retained its position as the leading manager of United States securities issues with a 16.3 percent market share. Merrill, the world's largest securities firm, was followed by Salomon Smith Barney, a unit of the Travelers Group; Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company; Goldman, Sachs and Lehman Brothers.
Merrill was also the top adviser in global mergers and acquisitions, followed by Goldman, Sachs and Lehman Brothers. But Lehman was the top adviser on American deals, topping Merrill and Goldman.
Wall Street's bottom line will be helped by the mergers business, but fees generated by its underwriting activities were nowhere near as plump as the overall underwriting volume figures might suggest.
In the quarter, underwriters received $2.1 billion in fees for their services in selling stocks and bonds, up just 10.5 percent from the same period a year ago.
The reason for the disparity is that in the quarter Wall Street sold many, many more bonds than stocks, and fees from bond sales are much lower than they are from stocks.
Rankings of the firms that earned the biggest underwriting fees showed a fairly significant shift in the quarter.
Goldman, Sachs, which has not led the underwriting tables in years but which often earns the highest fees, saw its fees shrink substantially from the corresponding period a year earlier.
Goldman, which ranked second in last year's first quarter to Merrill Lynch in disclosed fees, fell another notch. It earned $209.5 million in fees during the period, down sharply from $296.5 million in the first three months of 1997. Merrill Lynch earned the biggest fees -- a total of $347 million.
"Fixed income was stunning," during the quarter, said Sallie Krawcheck, a senior research analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "Mergers and acquisitions was unbelievable, but equity was slow in getting started."
Common stock offerings were up a healthy 19 percent from the same period a year ago, at $25.8 billion. But sales of so-called straight debt, which excludes securities like mortgages and asset-backed securities, rose by more than 94 percent, to $232.1 billion.
"As a proportion of overall issuance, in the first quarter equity was at its lowest level since the fourth quarter of 1990," said Richard J. Peterson, a spokesman for Securities Data.
To some degree, the stock market's concerns about Asia persuaded some companies not to price new equity offerings, particularly in January and the early part of February.
"Nervousness about Asia principally impacted the mid-cap and small-cap market for equities," said Jes Staley, head of global equity capital markets at J. P. Morgan & Company.
"But for much of the quarter, the average deal size in the equity market was up a lot. Offerings from companies like Gillette, Tyco and Chancellor Media were all bigger than $800 million."
J. P. Morgan, which has struggled to gain a solid foothold as a leading underwriter of common stock, saw its position improve significantly from a year ago.
During the quarter the firm was lead manager on seven deals totaling $1.7 billion, a performance that vaulted it to seventh place from No. 14 among equity underwriters.
According to the Securities Data figures, Morgan Stanley topped the list with 12.5 percent of the market.
To be sure, the Asian economic troubles and their impact on the United States economy have worried stock issuers as well as investors. Still, the crises in the region have led foreign investors to pour billions of dollars into the relative safety of American debt markets, pushing down interest rates sharply. Corporate treasurers responded to the lower rates by flooding the fixed-income market with new securities.
"January made a great quarter in and of itself," said Mark Siegel, a managing director and head of worldwide debt syndication at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
"The confluence of lower rates, stable markets and significant investor demand led to a record month in fixed-income issuance. February and March did not keep pace, but by historic standards the level of activity was still very high."
In what should be a positive sign for the second quarter, market participants say that conditions in emerging debt markets, unglued in the wake of the Asian crisis, are improving.
Yesterday, Merrill Lynch priced a $1.25 billion deal for Brazil, the largest transaction since the Asian troubles began last summer.
"I think the Brazil deal is a very positive sign for the Republic of Korea deal, which will be the biggest of the year so far and is the one everyone is concerned about," said Keith Horn, head of Latin American debt capital markets at Merrill Lynch.
The South Korean offering, which could be as large as $5 billion, is being co-managed by Salomon Smith Barney and Goldman, Sachs and is expected to be priced early this month.
Similarly, there seems to be nothing that will slow down the flow of merger deals.
In the quarter that just ended, blockbusters like the $13.1 billion combination of Waste Management and USA Waste Services, AT&T's $11.3 billion purchase of Teleport Communications and the Compaq Corporation's $9.6 billion purchase of the Digital Equipment Corporation were the largest American deals. Many more are likely.
"In conversations we are having with management teams, there is nothing that would suggest there is any less motivation to do transactions," said Jack Levy, global head of mergers and acquisitions at Merrill Lynch. "Our European business is as strong as it has ever been, and a lot of people are doing a good deal of preparatory work for what may be soon be an active period in Asia."

HEADLINE: Great-Grandmother, 88, Charged in Man's Death

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: FRANKLIN, Va., March 30

 BODY:
Almost everybody here knows Virginia B. Davis.
Among the paper mill workers, peanut farmers and small-business owners who make this a prosperous and pleasant town of 8,500 people in southeastern Virginia, Mrs. Davis cuts a dashing figure as an 88-year-old great-grandmother, running errands around town in her red Camaro, the one with the Washington Redskins banner on the radio antenna. 
 Townspeople say she is a little eccentric, what with her passion for feeding animals, wearing skirts above the knee when fashionable and cheering for the Redskins.
But now, Mrs. Davis is known for something else. The authorities here in Southampton County say she is a murderer. After a yearlong investigation, leading to a county grand jury indictment on March 16, she was charged last week with killing John E. Wimbrow, a 52-year-old unemployed man who had lived in her house for about 20 years, until he died on March 8, 1997.
An autopsy report indicated that Mr. Wimbrow suffered injuries to his chest and neck and died as the result of a blunt-force injury. With the Franklin police still investigating the death, the authorities have not said what evidence they have that would prove that Mrs. Davis killed Mr. Wimbrow. Nor have they speculated on a possible motive.
Richard C. Grizzard, the Commonwealth Attorney for Southampton County, did not reply to a telephone message that was left for him, seeking comment.
Mrs. Davis, the widow of an insurance executive, denied the charge and was released on $20,000 bail. But if she is convicted she would become would become a rarity in the American justice system. Statistics from the Federal Bureau of Investigation for 1996, the most recent available, show that less than 1 percent of 12,359 murders -- 125 -- were committed by people 75 or older, and just 3 of them were by women.
In Virginia, the state police say 24 people 65 or older were arrested on charges of murder from 1992 to 1996; the data are not broken down by sex.
The charge against Mrs. Davis, a frail woman who weighs 100 pounds and has trouble hearing, has captured the town's attention like nothing else in recent memory. Even now, two weeks after the indictment, "people are still talking about it," said David Rabil, whose family has owned Fred's Restaurant on Main Street for more than 50 years. "Most people can't believe she did it."
The accusation has also left Mrs. Davis and her family stunned and frightened. Wearing a Redskins vest that one of her daughters made, and a Redskins necklace and bracelet, Mrs. Davis today joined her daughters, Ginger Britt and Margaret Gibbs, at Mrs. Britt's home before driving to Virgina Beach to meet with Mrs. Davis's lawyer.
Her blue eyes twinkled in the sunlight. But later, sitting inside, it was apparent that the episode has taken a toll. In an interview, her eyes welled with tears several times as she tried to convey how upset she feels. "I can't sleep," she said. "I don't have much of an appetite. I'm just devastated."
"The part that worries me is that everybody tells me everything is going to be all right," she continued. "But I can't help but lie awake at night and think about it."
Under the advice of her lawyer, Richard G. Brydges, she declined to discuss the matter, other than to say, "To think I could bludgeon somebody to death -- I couldn't kill anything."
She expressed sorrow over Mr. Wimbrow's death. He was a good friend, she said, a man who opened her life to many new experiences.
"He got me hooked on the Redskins, car racing, fishing in the Chesapeake Bay and rock concerts," she said. "I've seen Rod Stewart, the Rolling Stones, the Bee Gees, Eric Clapton. Lord, I love rock concerts. I'd go right now if I had someone to take me."
Mr. Wimbrow, a former shipworker, real estate salesman and exterminator from Virginia's Eastern Shore, was not so well known in Franklin as Mrs. Davis, whose grandfather, a doctor in the Civil War, went on to become the first public school superintendent of Franklin and later the town's Mayor. While many people in town said they knew that Mr. Wimbrow lived in her house, few said they ever saw them together or saw him on his own.
Sandra Finney, Mr. Wimbrow's sister, who lives in the Eastern Shore town of Onley, said in a separate interview that her brother was a "quiet, kind and caring" man who later in life suffered from alcoholism. She said he and Mrs. Davis met after Mrs. Davis's husband died, when "she just wanted a young man on her arm. And he, with his drinking problem, was real enthusiastic that an old lady was interested in him, so he stuck by her."
Mrs. Britt said her mother's relationship with Mr. Wimbrow was platonic. But Ms. Finney disagreed, asserting that "it was romantic, definitely, at least in the beginning." She also said she was convinced that Mrs. Davis killed her brother after getting angry at him for planning to move to Florida, where his parents lived part of the year.
"He lost jobs and felt frustrated," Ms. Finney said. "He wanted to move away from Franklin. He was going to move to Florida and stay there in the winter, hoping to find work. She was angry about that."
It was not until early this month that Mrs. Davis had any idea the police were considering foul play in Mr. Wimbrow's death. Until then, she and members of her family had met with investigators three times since last year to answer questions about the night Mr. Wimbrow died, but always assuming that his death came as a result of his drinking.
Mrs. Britt, whose husband, Grady, retired in 1990 after 10 years as Franklin's police chief, said she had been at her mother's house two days before the death and found blood "all over the kitchen." She said she thought Mr. Wimbrow had fallen and hit his head.
"I think John fell repeatedly, and he died from his falls," she said.
Two days after her visit, as Mrs. Britt recalled, her mother telephoned, looking for Mr. Britt. "She said John was sick and needed to go to the hospital," Mrs. Britt said.
The Britts drove to Mrs. Davis's house, which is just a few blocks away, and when they arrived at about 7:40 P.M., Mrs. Britt said they found Mr. Wimbrow in his bed, his eyes closed and blackened.
"My husband said, 'Hey, John, do you need some help?" Mrs. Britt said. "I heard him say yes."
Help from a nearby fire and rescue station arrived quickly, and medical personnel worked on Mr. Wimbrow for 45 minutes, Mrs. Britt said, before transporting him to Southampton Memorial Hospital, where he was pronounced dead.
Mrs. Britt said the episode has been "like a nightmare" for the family even though Mrs. Davis is maintaining her usual daily regimen of driving to the grocery store for food and the post office for mail, which has picked up considerably in recent days.
"I can't tell you the hundreds of people who call me, send cards and stop me on the street when I go out for food," Mrs. Davis said. "When I went to the post office today, a number of people told me they were on my side. Nobody who knows me believes this. They just don't believe it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Virginia B. Davis, an 88-year-old woman charged with murder, with her daughters, Ginger Britt, left, and Margaret Gibbs, on Monday. (Amy Toensing for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Corporate Son Remakes Danone;
By Focusing on Best-Selling Brands, French Food Maker Grows Globally

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 28

 BODY:
When Franck Riboud was named at a shareholders meeting in 1994 to eventually succeed his father as the head of Danone S.A., France's largest food company, the room rocked with catcalls.
Though he had spent 13 years working his way up Danone's corporate ladder, Mr. Riboud had never shaken his reputation for being something of a beach bum after college. Nepotism had won him the job, plain and simple, the critics said. How else, they argued, could he beat out such young, well-connected Danone managers as Henri Giscard d'Estaing, a finance executive and the son of the former French President, Valery Giscard d'Estaing? 
 But less than four years later, the catcalls have largely turned to coos. The ex-surfer, it seems, has managed to transform his father's scattershot collection of food businesses into a lean and focused company with a worldwide reach, one that puts it in the running with the likes of Bestfoods, Nestle S.A. and Unilever.
"Shareholders were a bit disappointed at first, thinking he was his father's son," Edouard de Boisgelin, who follows Danone (pronounced dah-KNOWN) for Merrill Lynch in London, said. "It turned out the guy is good -- he was the right choice."
What Franck Riboud has done is not so original, his newfound supporters say. It is just that he has executed well, as any athlete would.
By taking a page from John F. Welch Jr.'s playbook at the General Electric Company, Mr. Riboud (pronounced ree-BOO) focused Danone's energy and capital on expanding businesses in which it was No. 1 -- fresh dairy products like Dannon yogurt; cookies and snacks, including the Lu brand, and beverages like Kronenbourg beer and Evian mineral water.
A tousled and boyish-looking 42, Mr. Riboud also shed underperforming businesses, like soups and pasta, and expanded aggressively into Eastern Europe, South America and Asia. And he has sculptured the name Danone -- Dannon in the United States -- into a global brand.
"I'm always under pressure to succeed," Mr. Riboud said in an interview here. "But you need pressure to achieve. You try harder."
Now the question is not whether Mr. Riboud is up to the job, but whether he can continue to maintain the company's steady pace.
Some analysts are skeptical. It is one thing, they say, to make sense out of a mishmash of a conglomerate and quite another to keep the momentum going for the long term.
"The problem for a group like Danone," said Jean-Marie L'Home, who follows the company for Banque Nationale de Paris, "is that opportunities for growth in Asia and Latin America are more and more rare. Either you build businesses yourself, which is time consuming, or you buy small and big companies and merge them, which is costly."
That Mr. Riboud would wind up anywhere near the chairman's desk, let alone behind it, seemed a preposterous idea two decades ago when he finished technical school as an engineer but decided to follow his real passion -- windsurfing -- and shun the empire his father built from scratch.
Even after exchanging the windsurfer for the office, Mr. Riboud stuck close to another outdoor passion, skiing, signing on with the French ski maker Rossignol to work at a factory planned for Vermont. As it turned out, several snowless winters torpedoed Rossignol's American plans, and Mr. Riboud joinedhis father's company, then known as the BSN Groupe, in 1981.
Over the years, he held a variety of jobs, helping for instance with the $2.5 billion takeover in 1992 of RJR Nabisco's European biscuit and snack activities and running Evian. In 1992, he took over the company's international expansion strategy.
Indeed, having studied in Switzerland and not at a classic French ecole, Mr. Riboud, an easy English speaker, is in many ways a picture of the new young French executive.
Still, the reception was decidedly chilly in 1994 when his father, Antoine, named him to the No. 2 position, with the implicit right of succession. Antoine Riboud responded angrily to critics that he could "not understand why it's a handicap to have the name Riboud."
The cold shoulder treatment continued in 1996, when Antoine stepped down at 77. The Riboud family owned less than 1 percent of the shares, it was noted, and, at 40, Franck Riboud was considered by many to be too young to run Europe's third-largest food company, after Nestle and Unilever.
And even as recently as last year, when the Agnelli family of Italy, major shareholders in Club Mediterranee, ousted Serge Trigano, the chief executive and son of Club Med's founder, stock market rumors had it that Franck Riboud would be the next father's son to get the ax from the Agnellis, who own 5.8 percent of Danone. Only a statement of confidence in Franck Riboud by the Agnellis and Michel David-Weill of Lazard Freres, the French investment bank that is another major shareholder, quieted the talk.
Last October, Mr. Riboud took Danone to Wall Street, selling three million American depository shares, not so much to raise capital as to show the Danone flag. The shares have risen strongly from the initial offering price of $31. They closed Tuesday at $48.125. The stock got its latest lift in January on news that Danone's revenues in 1997 rose 5.4 percent, to 88.47 billion francs, or $14.7 billion, with profits rising 8.3 percent, to 3.66 billion francs.
In part, Danone is simply riding the wave of restructuring, as European food manufacturers and distributors reinvent themselves to overcome consumer stagnation and break out of narrow national boundaries. In 1996, Unilever, known in the United States for products like Lipton Tea and Wishbone dressings, announced it was shedding about 20 percent of its $50 billion of businesses in a major restructuring. Last December, two of France's biggest food distributors, Promodes S.A. and Casino S.A., agreed to an informal alliance; that followed the $3.2 billion takeover a year earlier of Docks de France by another giant food retailer, Auchan S.A.
It was in the early 1990's, when Danone was still the BSN Groupe and Antoine Riboud was running it, that the company realized that its strategy needed tuning. When recession throttled Europe in 1993, revenues contracted for the first time ever; operating margins slipped below 10 percent, beginning a slide that was not arrested until 1996.
"The main criticism was strategy," Joseline Gaudino, an analyst at Societe Generale in Paris, said. "They were too much in Europe, and they had too many activities. Results were suffering, and the share price was depressed."
To regain momentum, Franck Riboud raised $850 million in 1997 by scrapping less valuable product lines, selling Danone's soup business to the Campbell Soup Company, and selling subsidiaries that made sauces, pasta and ready-to-eat meals to a group of investors. At the same time, he concentrated on yogurt, beverages and other products in which Danone was a leader.
To revamp management following the defection of executives like Mr. Giscard d'Estaing, Mr. Riboud brought in new faces, hiring a former Procter & Gamble executive, Jan Bennink, a Frenchman, to run the key dairy products division, and Simon Israel, another Frenchman who once headed Sara Lee's operations in Asia, to build Danone's businesses in the Far East. Both men, like Mr. Riboud, are in their early 40's.
Part of the strategy has been to follow the broader trend to branded products by shaping the Danone name into a global trademark, including changing the company name from BSN Groupe in 1994. In Europe, Mr. Riboud added Danone to local brand names on products like mineral water and crackers; in North America, he started a new Canadian spring water under the Dannon brand.
"People are asking: 'Should I buy instead of make? What's my market share? What's the value of my brands there?' " said Jean-Pierre d'Estienne d'Orves, chief economist at the National Association of Food Industries, in discussing the trend. "Companies want to know what their business is, and adjust cash flow to focused activities."
The conglomerate Franck Riboud inherited needed focusing more than most, since it was essentially cobbled together over more than two decades by his father.
In 1968, Antoine Riboud was running a glass products group called Boussois-Souchon-Neuvesel, or BSN, when he made an unsuccessful hostile bid for Saint-Gobain, the leading French glass maker. Disenchanted with glass, he embarked on a string of takeovers of food businesses to find products for his bottles. The group became the country's largest food company in 1972, when it acquired Gervais-Danone, a yogurt and cheese maker.
(Danone yogurt was made in France until World War II by a Frenchman named Daniel Carasso, who fled to the United States, where he made yogurt under the anglicized Dannon brand. The business was later bought by the Beatrice Foods Company, which sold Dannon to Antoine Riboud in 1981, thus returning it to the French fold.)
Some analysts believe that Antoine Riboud recognized early on the need to shape the company, but felt a younger person would have to take on the task. "Perhaps he tried to accomplish through his son what he dreamed of doing, but did not have the chance" because of age, said Mr. L'Home of Banque Nationale.
Franck Riboud denies that his father planned for one of his children -- Franck is the youngest of four -- to succeed him. "My father's position was, 'Do what you want, but do it best,' " he said.
As for the future, Mr. Riboud is looking to expand mostly outside Europe. Last year, roughly one-fourth of Danone's revenues were generated outside Europe, against 5 percent five years ago.
"I need people with increasing buying power -- in Mexico, Brazil, Argentina, Asia," he said. The recent turmoil in the Far East does not upset him. While economies in Southeast Asia, like Indonesia, are hardest hit, roughly half of Danone's $865 million of annual revenues in Asia and the Pacific region come from China, and most of the rest from India and New Zealand.
In the United States, sales in 1997 totaled about $1 billion, from roughly $200 million five years ago, and Mr. Riboud says his strategy there is to "build around our existing activities."
Despite all those good intentions, Mr. L'Home switched Danone's stock late last year from an outperform ranking to hold. He said he made the decision, in part, because the share price touched target levels, but also because he saw "no strong reason to recommend it," given the challenge of finding ways to produce more growth.
It is the kind of challenge that Mr. Riboud thinks he can handle.
It shouldn't be too difficult to keep growing, he said cockily. After all, the ex-surfer added, "I'm a competitor."

HEADLINE: For Middle Class, New York Shrinks as Home Prices Soar

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Todd Neuhaus, an advertising executive, and his wife, Christina, didn't want much. They wanted to rent a Manhattan apartment for less than $3,000 with a bedroom for themselves and one for their two boys. They wanted it to be near good public schools, because private school was beyond their means.
Most of all, the Neuhauses wanted to believe it could happen, because they are financially comfortable, their bank account buoyed by the economic tide that has rolled into the New York region. 
 But after a few disheartening weeks, they gave up looking for two bedrooms. The living room could be a second bedroom, right? After another month, they gave up completely. "We said, 'You got us. We're beaten,' " recalled Mr. Neuhaus, 38, who lives in a modest house in New Canaan, Conn.
"This economy has done a strange thing to New York City," he said. "I guess it's good for the tourists who come here and see it, but what about the people who want to live here?"
It is one of the crueler paradoxes of the city's economic boom and bright new image: even as middle-income families tend to earn more, they are finding themselves priced out of dozens of neighborhoods in and around Manhattan, say real-estate brokers and legions of frustrated apartment seekers.
The phenomenon of middle-income neighborhoods' morphing into upper middle-income or wealthy enclaves is, of course, an old story in New York. It gathered steam in the late 1960's and slowed during the 1970's fiscal crisis.
By the high point of the 1980's boom, swatches of several neighborhoods -- Chelsea, Clinton, Yorkville, Brooklyn Heights -- had gentrified beyond the means of many middle-income families.
But housing experts say the present squeeze reflects a deeper problem that will endure long after the economy cools and apartment prices plateau or drop: builders are creating new housing only for the city's wealthiest residents and, using government subsidies, for a comparatively small number of its poorest.
But they say that for various reasons -- chiefly the high cost of land and construction -- the housing supply is not growing and, in fact, may be shrinking, for those in the middle. They are the city's teachers, nurses, civil servants, small-business owners, even mid-level executives, who want basic, affordable housing near their jobs.
Mary Nance-Tager, a 35-year-old teacher frustrated in her search for a home for her family in brownstone Brooklyn, echoed a widespread sentiment: "We don't want extravagance, but I guess our extravagance is wanting to live in New York City."
Brokers say that over the last two years, typical rents for nondoorman, one-bedroom apartments in many Manhattan neighborhoods have risen to more than $2,000 from $1,800. On the cooperative market -- where monthly maintenance can vary from a few hundred dollars to more than $1,000 -- a similar apartment, with about 800 square feet, could sell for anywhere from $150,000 to more than $200,000 now, an increase of 30 to 40 percent from two years ago.
For basic two-bedroom apartments, the most sought-after by families, typical rents have risen to $3,000 from $2,400 in two years and sales prices have risen to more than $300,000 from $240,000. And these prices are for what are known as type B apartments: no outdoor space and little detail or other extras. Add a washer and dryer, fireplace or terrace and the prices can jump by tens of thousands.
 
Requiring Earnings Of 52 Times Rent
For many rentals, landlords now make a special security demand: applicants must earn 52 times the rent to qualify for the lease -- to be able, in other words, to pay one month's rent with one week's paycheck. That means a tenant would need $104,000 for a $2,000 apartment.
Only a few years ago, the multiple was as low as 40, said Andrew S. Heiberger, who owns Citi Habitats, a rental brokerage. "I get kids coming out of Harvard," he said, "who get offered $90,000 plus bonus, and they're having a hard time finding a decent place to live."
As the pressure propels renters and buyers outward, the percentage price increases have been even higher in parts of Brooklyn -- Carroll Gardens, Cobble Hill, Fort Greene, Park Slope, Windsor Terrace -- narrowing the gap with Manhattan.
In all the neighborhoods, the costs dangle tantalizingly just out of reach of many in the middle class, if it is defined as many policymakers define it in New York City: families with income from $50,000 to $120,000, depending on household size.
Figuring what those prices would buy in other cities -- a popular, if masochistic, pastime of space-starved New Yorkers -- is now more heartbreaking than ever.
For roughly the same money it takes to buy and maintain a one-bedroom cooperative in Manhattan, a family could, for instance, grab a newly-minted four-bedroom brick Georgian house in Houston. Incomes for comparable jobs are higher in New York, but not enough to explain that kind of difference.
"It's the kind of thing you've been able to say about New York for a very long time now," said Frank Braconi, the director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a housing advocacy group normally associated with low-income development that has joined other advocates in warning of a middle-income crisis.
"It's hard to generate sympathy for people who make this kind of money," he added. "But that's not the point. The point is: Ultimately it begins to affect the city's competitiveness. The fact is that educated, upwardly mobile people have a lot more choices these days about where they can live to do what they want to do."
Angela M. Mitchell, an operations manager and consultant in Cleveland who is weighing a job offer in Manhattan, said she had not decided whether she could afford a likely doubling of her $800 rent to move with her 10-year-old daughter. "Making sixty thousand here goes a lot further than sixty thousand there," Ms. Mitchell, 37, said in a telephone interview. "And I'm sure I'll make more in New York, but not double."
When she started looking at two-bedroom rents on the Internet, she said, "I felt incredibly sick."
For Mr. Neuhaus, an associate creative director at an advertising agency in midtown, New York is still the place he needs to be. But he and his wife, a 36-year-old photographer, say they will have to make hard decisions soon about whether they can stand to stay in the region.
They live in New Canaan, Conn., in a small Victorian house that they bought seven years ago for $220,000. But Mr. Neuhaus has to commute more than an hour each way, his hours are grueling and he has little time to spend with his boys, 6 and 3. His biggest fear is becoming the weary, lifelong "commuter in the raincoat," he said. "I've seen it."
But with an income of about $95,000 and plans to rent out their house, the family discovered that any place big enough and close to work would break them. He said he and his wife might try again, looking near Manhattan, or they might leave the area. "It's just discouraging," Mr. Neuhaus said, "to realize that you can't afford to live anywhere near where you work."
Housing policy analysts warn that rising prices near Manhattan and rundown housing in many borough neighborhoods may already be driving out middle-income families who would have made New York their home in years past. They worry that this could undermine public schools, erode the city's tax base and further widen the sizable gap between rich and poor.
 
A Million People Have Left in the 90's
While there are no hard numbers, Census figures released this month found that a little more than a million New Yorkers left the city so far this decade. (Because of the number of births, 937,000, and new immigrants who moved to the city, 677,000, as well as newcomers from elsewhere in the nation, the overall population has grown slightly.)
Census figures from 1990 show that proportionately, the New York region is losing out in the competition to draw other Americans. While 8.6 percent of the region's residents reported that they had lived elsewhere in the nation within the previous five years, the equivalent number in the region of Raleigh-Durham, N.C., was 24.8 percent, for example, and in Atlanta 18.6 percent.
John Watts, a keyboard player, and his fiancee, Debora Santos, a pharmacist, say they want to stay in the city but probably will not be able to afford to raise a family.
Mr. Watts, 35, lived in a 400-square-foot studio in the West Village that his parents owned. He and Ms. Santos, 29, began looking last summer to buy a one-bedroom apartment for less than $200,000, and quit in disgust after three months. They moved into Ms. Santos's one-bedroom rental in Astoria, Queens, and if they have children they will look to buy "in Westchester or Yonkers, probably," Mr. Watts said.
Of Manhattan, where he had lived for a decade, he said mournfully: "I left a place that I really honestly felt was the best place in the world, a place where people like me used to live." When his parents were young -- his father was a salesman and his mother was a secretary -- their salaries easily paid the rent for a roomy one-bedroom on 63d Street off Second Avenue. And they bought all the furniture already there, including a brand-new Wurlitzer piano, for $500.
"Those days are long, long gone," Mr. Watts said.
Residential developers, for their part, say it takes only a glance at the math to understand why they are not creating middle-income apartments: Land prices and construction costs are higher than ever. So, it does not make sense to build except in areas where the market will guarantee a profit. And in rent-regulated buildings, landlords say they have little incentive to invest in renovations to turn dilapidated buildings into middle-income ones.
David J. Wine, the president of residential development for the Related Companies, one of the city's most active luxury rental builders, insists that in many Manhattan neighborhoods it could cost $225,000 to $250,000 to build a typical apartment in a building with studios, one-bedrooms and two-bedrooms.
"Someone's also got to pay for the debt service and the real-estate taxes and the maintenance of that building," he said. Add in a profit and that could mean $2,700 a month rent for a one-bedroom apartment.
There is a growing consensus among housing experts and policy makers that the only way to solve the problem is for the city or state to do what it has long done to stimulate low-income building: provide subsidies to help house the middle-class.
The last subsidized middle-income development, in the so-called Mitchell-Lama program in the 1960's and 1970's, built about 135,000 apartments for families making $30,000 to $90,000. Qualified applicants now wait more than a decade to get in.
The city recently announced a modest program to help finance the construction of a dozen middle-income apartment buildings outside prime Manhattan locations. But housing advocates say that a dozen buildings, even a dozen huge buildings, will hardly make a dent in middle-income demand.
"I think the real question is: Does New York become a place only for those who have already made it?" said Mr. Braconi, the housing advocate. "Or do we still have room for those who are coming here to make it? Isn't that what's made New York great?"

HEADLINE: House, by Narrow Margin, Votes Money for Military

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The House today narrowly approved $2.9 billion for emergency military spending and aid to disaster victims, but the White House said President Clinton would veto the bill because money to pay for it would come from cutting some of the Administration's prized domestic programs.
The vote was 212 to 208 -- surprisingly close given lawmakers' usual support for troops in the field and constituents hurt by natural disasters. Seventeen Republicans -- moderates opposed to the domestic cuts and conservatives against American military involvement in Bosnia -- voted with 190 Democrats and one independent against the legislation. Seven Democrats joined 205 Republicans in support of the bill. 
 The slim margin undercuts House Republicans' bargaining leverage going into what is expected to be a contentious conference committee with the Senate late next month when lawmakers return from their spring recess.
"No one can dispute the fact this is a difficult bill, start to finish," Representative Robert L. Livingston, a Louisiana Republican who heads the House Appropriations Committee, told reporters after the vote.
The House legislation provides $2.3 billion for military spending, primarily $487 million for troops in Bosnia and $1.3 billion for troops in the Persian Gulf, and $575 million for disaster relief.
Senators completed work last week on an emergency spending bill, but it is vastly different from the House legislation approved today. The Senate was more generous -- approving $5 billion for disaster aid and military operations in Bosnia and the Persian Gulf -- and senators did not cut domestic spending to pay for it.
The Senate, by a vote of 84 to 16, had also attached $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund to refill the fund's treasury, which has been strained by the Asian financial crisis.
House Republican leaders have separated the I.M.F. monies and $505 million in dues that the United States owes the United Nations in a separate spending bill, which will not come up for a vote until late April, if at all, a spokeswoman for Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House Republican leader, said today.
Moreover, House Republicans have vowed to attach an anti-abortion provision to the I.M.F. financing, which has drawn a veto threat from Mr. Clinton.
Today Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin issued a public appeal for Congressional support, saying the nation's economy and national security were at stake.
Pentagon officials have warned lawmakers for weeks that military readiness could suffer if Congress did not assure them by mid-April that the emergency financing was on the way.
The military does not budget for unforeseen missions, so when they happen the Pentagon borrows from other accounts to pay for troop deployments. Pentagon officials say these accounts will dry up in the next few months if Congress does not refill them.
Pentagon officials are concerned that the House and Senate might not reconcile their competing emergency spending bills in time, so Mr. Cohen has ordered the armed services to consider deferring maintenance on equipment, temporarily closing non-essential operations and temporarily laying off thousands of civilian employees.
The Joint Chiefs of Staff met today for 45 minutes to discuss the problem, and senior Defense Department officials will meet next week to review their options.

HEADLINE: New Reports Show Little Reason Not to Be Optimistic on Economy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Consumer confidence fell in March, but only slightly from a level that was the highest in 29 years, a business research group reported today.
The group, the Conference Board, said its consumer confidence index fell to 134.3 points in March from 137.4 in February. Meanwhile, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its monthly index of manufacturing activity in the Chicago region, seen as a bellwether for the economy, unexpectedly rose to 59.5 points in March from 57.8 in February. 
 Taken together, the numbers indicate that the economy remains on a roll, analysts said.
"These numbers are still remarkable," said Kathleen Stephansen, economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities. "The expectation is that income will continue and buying plans will hold up."
With inflation nearly absent, the Federal Reserve's policy makers, as expected, held interest rates steady today at a meeting of the Open Market Committee, which has not changed borrowing costs for more than a year.
Adding to the evidence that prices are not threatening to accelerate, the Chicago purchasing managers reported that the index of prices paid by factories for materials fell to 48.7 in March from 55.5 in February, indicating that more companies reported price declines than increases.
A separate Conference Board index measuring consumer expectations for the next six months fell to 108.6 in March from a revised 114.5 in February. Still, March's overall index was almost 16 points higher than it was in March 1997. February's index reading was the highest since June 1969.
"There are no signs of any significant downturn in optimism," said Lynn Franco, a Conference Board economist.
Consumers are flush with cash given steady income growth, big tax refunds and a resilient stock market. Personal income rose six-tenths of 1 percent in February after a six-tenths of 1 percent increase a month earlier, the Commerce Department said last week.
As confidence rises, so does retailer activity. Apparel stores like Gap, Talbots and Limited, which introduced their lines of spring clothing in February, have shown significant sales strength. Sales at discount stores like Wal-Mart also rose more than expected in February.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Consumer Confidence Slips But Remains Robust
Consumer confidence fell in March, but only slightly from a level that was the highest in 29 years, the Conference Board reported.
In another sign of economic strength, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its monthly index of manufacturing activity in the Chicago region unexpectedly rose. As expected, the Fed left interest rates unchanged. Page D8. 

The prices of Treasury securities turned higher as the Chicago manufacturing report showed no signs of inflationary pressure despite the economic strength. The 30-year bond yield fell to 5.93 percent from 5.98. D9.
 
Sticking With the Tried and True
On the eve of a broad financial liberalization, the Japanese Government showed that old ways die hard: it poured money into the stock market in an effort to manipulate share prices so that banks would end their fiscal year in reasonable shape. D4.
 
Record Quarter for Wall St. Firms
Helped by falling interest rates, the securities industry raised a record $472.7 billion in American financial markets in the first three months of 1998, up more than 62 percent from a year earlier. Market Place. D9.
 
Motorola May Streamline Structure
Motorola said it was discussing a possible reorganization under which its businesses would be grouped into two divisions, one geared toward consumer goods and the other aimed at industrial customers. Its shares soared. D2.
 
Health Care Bill Introduced
Democrats, with support from consumer groups, unions and the American Medical Association, introduced legislation that they said would protect patients by regulating the practices of health insurers and health maintenance organizations. Republicans oppose the measure. A19.
 
Shareholders Reject a Merger
Stockholders of Iwerks Entertainment rejected a plan to acquire Showscan Entertainment, a rare instance in which shareholders overturned a merger that had been approved by both boards. D4.
 
Lockheed's Uphill Battle
Lockheed Martin has scored some minor legal victories in defending itself against the Government's effort to block its proposed takeover of Northrop Grumman. But winning early skirmishes and winning the war are two different matters. News analysis. D2.
 
In the Air, A Growing Divide
There have long been clear class distinctions in the air, but the divisions are growing ever wider as airlines invest millions of dollars to pamper their best customers, enticing them with everything from more leg room to extra frequent-flier miles to fancier V.I.P. lounges. Often, passengers with discount tickets lose out. Business Travel. A1.
 
Agencies Watch Help Wanted Ads
Advertising agencies say they are having trouble finding and then holding onto talented workers. Advertising. D7.
 
BMW Warning Over Rolls-Royce
Angered by a report that Volkswagen still wants to buy Rolls-Royce, BMW -- which has agreed to buy the luxury car maker -- warned that it would stop delivering supplies to Rolls-Royce if its parent company sold it to anyone other than BMW. D4.

HEADLINE: Suffolk Legislature Orders Lilco Takeover on Ballot

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., March 31

 BODY:
In a slap at Gov. George E. Pataki, the Suffolk County Legislature voted today to authorize a November referendum on his plan for the state to take over the Long Island Lighting Company's electricity service.
In a tumultuous meeting here, the audience shouted and hooted, one legislator wept and votes changed at the last minute. When it was over, the sides disagreed on whether today's vote would block the takeover. 
 Although Suffolk County government has no direct say in the takeover, the County Legislature would be required to continue its opposition to the plan in court and regulatory proceedings if directed to do so by the voters. So far, the Pataki plan has cleared most of its legal hurdles.
Governor Pataki says that the deal would cut electricity rates about 20 percent for all the utility's customers. He and other backers have long argued that their plan has widespread support, but they have opposed a referendum, calling it a distraction that could complicate efforts to complete the deal.
Opponents say they do not believe the promised rate cuts would be sustained and that the deal would bring more benefits to stockholders. These foes were jubilant today. They said that the mere prospect of the referendum would stymie the final regulatory approval and bond sales needed for the takeover. Wayne Prospect, a Hauppauge Industrial Association lobbyist against the plan, said, "This freezes everything."
The Governor's aides scoffed at that notion, however. "It's not going to stop the deal," said Richard M. Kessel, Mr. Pataki's appointee as the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, the agency that would buy part of Lilco. "We're moving forward," he said. "The referendum is moot. It's our intention to close the deal in the late spring or summer."
One Wall Street utility analyst agreed with Mr. Kessel. Edward J. Tirello of BT Alex. Brown, said: "Don't they realize it's all over? By the 15th of May, we expect this deal to be signed, sealed and delivered."
Mr. Kessel did concede, however, that concern about the referendum might drive up interest rates on the bonds to finance the takeover. Critics of the Pataki plan say that the referendum should also give pause to Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the State Assembly, who controls one vote on a panel that must unanimously approve the bond sale. Asked today if the prospect of a referendum would delay his decision, Mr. Silver declined to comment.
Governor Pataki, who is campaigning for re-election, would like to avoid any more hurdles to his plan. He is eager to complete the takeover before the election so he can lower the island's electricity bills nearly 20 percent and send every customer a refund of $101 in Suffolk, and $232 in Nassau and the Rockaways in Queens. The plan would also resolve a $1.5 billion judgment that Lilco won for excess property taxes levied on its Shoreham nuclear power plant, which never opened.
Thus Mr. Pataki hopes to solve the island's long-vexing problem of having the highest electricity rates in North America, which raises the cost of living and discourages business.
But critics dispute the projected rate cuts, and say the plan would crush Long Islanders with $23 billion of debt while giving huge profits to Lilco stockholders and bailing out its Shoreham plant. Because Lilco would continue to run the system for several years under a contract, critics say the island would be locked into a monopoly while the rest of the nation is being opened to energy competition through deregulation.
If the plan is as good for Long Island and as popular as Mr. Pataki says it is, the critics argued today, why not let the people vote on it?
A spokesman for the Governor, Michael McKeon, replied in a statement: "We wouldn't want to do anything that would jeopardize the savings for the ratepayers." The Long Island Power Authority plan "will save ratepayers nearly $500 million a year while also protecting taxpayers from a $1.5 billion property tax bill," Mr. McKeon said. "We're confident the plan will continue to move forward so Long Islanders get the savings they need and deserve."
While the Pataki plan enjoys bipartisan support among elected officials in Nassau County, neighboring Suffolk has long been the hotbed of opposition to Lilco and the Shoreham plant. Last year, the County Legislature hired lawyers and experts to fight the Pataki plan and also authorized a referendum in the last election, but the courts threw it off the ballot on technical grounds.
This year's referendum has been revised to withstand a challenge, legislators say. John V. N. Klein, who filed the suit against the prior referendum for a developers' group, the Association for a Better Long Island, said today he doubted whether the new referendum was worth challenging.
The final tally was 12 in favor with 6 abstentions -- exactly enough votes to override the veto that County Executive Robert Gaffney has promised to issue. Although he supported the referendum last year, Mr. Gaffney said a vote this year would be pointless, because the deal is expected to close soon.

HEADLINE: A Dated War, a Modern Peace

 BODY:
Now that virtually all wars are internal conflicts, most of them ethnic or religious, the hostilities between Peru and Ecuador are a throwback. Their clash, which last erupted in 1995, was the last time the armies of any two governments fought each other. Since 1942 Peru and Ecuador have gone to war three times over border areas that both claim. Now, however, this traditional war may be coming to a very modern end, since the two countries have agreed on the outlines of a peace treaty that would set up trade, commerce and joint access to the disputed land that started the war.
The two nations have been arguing over the territory since Spanish colonial times. In 1942 a treaty called the Rio Protocol awarded the land to Peru. Ecuador ratified the pact but then repudiated it, and its maps still show the old borders. The land matters symbolically, as it is the basis of Ecuador's proud claim to be an Amazon country. 
 The 1995 fighting killed dozens of people and wounded hundreds. Since then Peru has bought more jet fighters and bombers. Nationalist politics on both sides could push the countries back to war.
Fortunately, this ancient dispute is now facing some modern solutions, including regional diplomacy and cooperation, and the decision of both nations that trade and growth are more important than nationalist symbols. The two stopped fighting when leaders of Brazil, Argentina, Chile and the United States organized peace negotiations. In January both nations signed an agreement setting May 30 as a target for a peace treaty, and four committees are working out the details.
The basics are already there. Ecuador will give up its quixotic claim to the disputed land. In return it will have permanent access to the Amazon, which is closed to it today. The two countries would also work together on development projects, such as roads, irrigation and hydroelectric plants.
The Peruvian negotiator has rightly said the two countries should focus on their common enemies of poverty and underdevelopment. The apparent success of regional diplomacy shows how Latin America's pursuit of a business-friendly climate has changed the continent. Such a focus has had mixed results, often pushing aside the poor. But one of its positive aspects is that Latin America now wants to make money, not war.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Emergency! Emergency! Senate Needs More Pork!

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund, maple syrup producers in New England, American troops in Bosnia and motorists in Honolulu are all facing an "emergency."
So says the United States Senate. The four disparate groups would all receive money set aside in a special $5 billion "emergency spending" bill the Senate completed work on last week. 
 What started out as a fast-moving legislative vehicle to pay for unforeseen military operations, refill the monetary fund's dwindling treasury and quickly help flood and storm victims soon offered senators an opportunity they could not resist to tack on pet projects to must-pass legislation.
But does $4.5 million to replace ice-damaged maple sugar tap-and-tubing in Vermont or $3 million to study the transit patterns in Hawaii really qualify as an emergency, much less make a case for shoring up United States national security?
Pure pork, cry critics of the add-ons.
"None of these items were requested as emergency disaster relief requirements, and most bear no relation to disaster relief at all," Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said in a floor speech last week.
Mr. McCain has waged a lonely, battle against pork before. And in almost every case, he loses. So it was no great surprise last week when the Senate voted 61 to 31 to defeat his proposal to cut $78 million in what Mr. McCain he called "low-priority, unnecessary or wasteful" spending from the bill. After all, one senator's pork is another's bacon.
"To deal with a bill of this type, you have to come back to the concept of the eye of the beholder," Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee, said in response to Mr. McCain.
Just what that might be probably will not be settled until House and Senate negotiators hammer out a compromise of their competing emergency spending bills (with competing add-ons, of course) late next month.
The House today approved a slimmer version of the disaster aid and military spending bill. But the House made sure to make farmers who raise ostriches and other flightless birds eligible for $4 million in livestock assistance.
The list of Senate add-ons is as rich and varied as the Senate's many constituencies.
Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, obtained $151 million in additional financing for research on anti-missile systems, one of his keen interests.
Some $2 million was tucked into the bill at the insistence of Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, to soften the economic impact in rural areas of Idaho and Montana and other Western states, from the Clinton Administration's moratorium on road-building in national forests, and with it the loss of timber revenue and jobs.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, had $10 million inserted in the legislation to aid dairy farmers in the Northeast who could not get their milk to market on time because of ice storms.
Northern California's wine country suffered a beating at the hands of El Nino-driven storms, prompting Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, to win for her home state much of the $8.7 million designated for trees and vineyard damage.
Senators know they can offer these add-ons with virtual impunity because no one is going to vote against dubious expenses when they are attached to such essentials as beans and bullets for the troops.
"Those who add unrelated provisions to disaster relief measures are engaging in a game of chicken -- daring the body to oppose the emergency relief that may be desperately needed," Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, said on the floor last week.
That, of course, just emboldens senators to keep piling on.
"Supplemental appropriations legislation has routinely become a Christmas tree," Senator Rod Grams, Republican of Minnesota, said in the debate. "The rush to spend reminds me of the free-for-all that results when you toss a piece of raw meat to a pack of hungry dogs."
But senators championing the add-ons said they and their causes were misunderstood. Take the $4.5 million in relief for New England's $24 million-a-year maple syrup industry.
"These maple sugar producers in northern New England have fallen through the cracks of our traditional disaster assistance program," said Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine. "They need our assistance."
