HEADLINE: Afghans Meet With U.N. Official Who Is, er, a Woman

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 1

 BODY:
Confronted with growing hostility in Afghanistan, the United Nations told the radical Islamic movement Taliban today that unless harassment of international officials stops and more attention is paid to the rights of women, the organization could sharply reduce its assistance. This is the only substantial aid flowing into this country, one of the world's poorest and least developed.
The message was delivered by Carol Bellamy, executive director of Unicef and one of the highest ranking Americans in the United Nations system. Her arrival here today, after meetings in Geneva over the weekend with Secretary General Kofi Annan, sent another message: that a woman has the power to affect Afghanistan's national development and cannot be ignored. 
 Today for the first time the No. 2 man in the Taliban hierarchy, the Acting President, Mullah Mohammed Rabanni, agreed to meet a foreign woman publicly.
The movement's chief of protocol, Dr. Abdul Sattar Paktiss, then entertained Ms. Bellamy and other United Nations officials at a relatively lavish lunch, complete with white linen and an abundant floral centerpiece laid out under bullet-riddled picture windows at the skeletal Kabul Inter-Continental Hotel. Ms. Bellamy spent the day dressed conservatively in slacks, a long-sleeved sweater, a raincoat and a headscarf.
In recent months, as fissures in the Taliban seemed to be widening, Afghan officials in some regions have stepped up a campaign of harassing United Nations staff members with unexplained searches, threats and generally confrontational behavior
The incidents culminated last month in an assault on a United Nations worker in Kandahar by the regional Taliban governor, who was apparently annoyed that money for flood relief had not been delivered. The United Nations withdrew all its staff from Kandahar, the religious headquarters of the Taliban.
The United Nations is studying a general cutback to only "life saving" activities, which could gut already modest programs in health, narcotics control and other areas. Unicef's education projects are on hold because girls are denied equal access to schooling.
More worrying in the long term than isolated acts of violence, Ms. Bellamy told the Taliban today, was the edict issued recently forbidding Muslim women from working and traveling in Afghanistan without a husband or other close male relative.
International aid workers see that as an attempt to curtail the influence of women from more moderate Muslim countries like Malaysia, Indonesia, Bangladesh or Turkey. United Nations officials had welcomed such women's involvement in Afghanistan, seeing them as a cultural bridge. The edict effectively bars them from working.
The Taliban leadership continues to bar girls from education beyond primary school, citing a lack of buildings and safety concerns. Many girls are enrolled in often-secret home schools run by teachers who became unemployed when the movement sharply limited the right of women to work outside the home.
At the same time, in the absence of foreign aid from traditional sources, the Taliban leadership has become increasingly demanding of United Nations attention and money. The Taliban controls more than three-quarters of Afghanistan but has almost no international recognition because of its human rights record. Its politically inexperienced religious fighters, drawn from Islamic schools, have not developed economic policies for lifting the war-ravaged country out of extreme poverty.
"Our country needs support," Dr. Paktiss, the chief of protocol, said before meeting Ms. Bellamy, whom he welcomed as "an honored guest." He added that he asked only that Islamic culture be respected.
Mr. Rabanni, the Acting President, told Ms. Bellamy, "Everything is negotiable," adding that the edict on women's work and travel was being reviewed.
Afghan and United Nations officials say the edict was apparently issued by extreme conservatives in Kandahar without the knowledge of less radical officials in Kabul.
Ms. Bellamy said Afghan culture would not be ignored, but that this was not an excuse for unacceptable behavior.
"The United Nations works in more than 180 countries around the world, in many different cultures, in many different environments," she said. "But there are basic principles that are followed. We respect different cultures. But there is a level of response that will be necessary.
"We want to work with the authorities to improve conditions for the people of Afghanistan. But there needs to be agreement about how we will be able to work in this country."
Ms. Bellamy said that the Taliban understands the seriousness of the United Nations position, and that the Taliban and the United Nations are choosing negotiating teams to resolve outstanding issues. "There is an indication that the upcoming negotiations will be taken quite seriously," she said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Securities in a Rebound After Some Early Volatility

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities ended sharply higher yesterday after some early volatility from an unexpectedly strong manufacturing report and a large Fannie Mae debt sale.
Some traders said the dismissal of the sexual harassment lawsuit by Paula Corbin Jones against President Clinton may also have helped bond prices late in the afternoon by removing some political uncertainty surrounding the White House. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly index of manufacturing rose to 54.8 in March from 53.3 in February.
Market forecasters had expected a decline to 53.0, and the surprise gain suggested a modest acceleration in economic growth that caused some investor concern about inflation, even though the economy shows few price pressures. Bond prices fell on the purchasing report before rebounding.
The Treasury's 30-year bond rose 25/32, to a price of 103 15/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.88 percent, from 5.93 percent on Tuesday and the lowest in a week. Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, partly attributed the market's recovery to a realization among sellers that there was little evidence in the purchasing report of rising inflation.
Bond market participants are now beginning to turn their attention to the Labor Department's report tomorrow on March unemployment, with specific attention directed toward payroll growth to see if its recent strong pace will continue.
The bond market also overcame some selling pressure yesterday caused by Fannie Mae, one of the largest debt issuers in the United States outside the Treasury, which sold $4 billion of five-year notes through various securities dealers at a price to yield 5.814 percent, or about 18 basis points more than the 5.5 percent Treasury note due March 2003. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The Treasury was also in the market yesterday to auction $19.1 billion of 13-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.45 percent. The cash management bills are used to meet the Treasury's short-term cash needs, in addition to its regular schedule of debt sales. It announced that it will sell $8 billion of 30-year inflation-indexed bonds next Wednesday, making it the latest addition to the number of inflation-indexed securities it will be selling in the future.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Socialism and its long lines are alive and well at Disneyland.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif.

 BODY:
ATTENTION demoralized commissars: Dismayed by the failure of perestroika, goulash communism and other attempts to find a "third way" between mindless central planning and soulless capitalism? Don't waste your time searching for inspiration in Stockholm or Santa Monica, Calif. Come to Disneyland, where socialism really does have a human face.
A tasteless joke, you say, at the expense of that late, great archconservative, Walt Disney? Perhaps. But the closer one looks at the Magic Kingdom, the more parallels one sees with economies that use a "first come, first serve" approach as a substitute for market forces. And unlike Eastern Europe's hapless experiments with a third way, this one can boast of smiling workers, fresh vegetables and even clean public bathrooms. It even boasts a "gray market" that was not so evident in a visit by this columnist two years ago. 
 In the capitalist world, scarce goods and services are allocated with prices. Want a new car? Make General Motors an offer.
In socialist economies like Disneyland, scarcity is resolved with queues. Want to test your mettle against the spiders, lava pits and falling boulders on the Indiana Jones Adventure ride? Or share a spooky moment with the holographic ghosts in the Haunted Mansion? Get in line.
In the former Soviet Union, queues were widely seen a symbol of social and economic failure. The hours frittered away waiting to buy shoes or sausage or vodka were hours away from work and family. In Disneyland, by contrast, 90-minute queues only seem to reinforce the view that the prize is worth the sacrifice -- that, against all evidence to the contrary, the Matterhorn Bobsleds are the equal of the gut-busting roller coasters at Six Flags, or that Splash Mountain offers thrills unavailable from other water flume rides.
One reason is that the Walt Disney apparachiks simply do a better job than their cynical counterparts in the former Soviet bloc. To generate the illusion of progress, the lines are single file and their length is concealed in mazes of tunnels and passageways. To maintain morale, the customers are distracted with dioramas -- cuddly George Lucas androids repairing spaceships at the Star Tours simulation, a nifty African Queen set for the Jungle Cruise. Meanwhile, strolling barbershop quartets, Dixieland bands, story tellers and Disney characters keep the 5e-year-olds from chewing on their Mickey ears.
Look a bit closer, though, and all does not appear well in this socialist paradise. For starters, the vacationing proletariat can't be entirely pleased with the arrangement since it spends a lot of effort gaming the system. Indeed, a whole cottage industry has sprung up to provide counsel on how to beat the lines. "Bob Sehlinger's Unofficial Guide to Disneyland" (2.5 million copies in print) offers some hundred pages of tips for minimizing the tedium.
More ominous, scarcity has led to the creation of gray markets in which money is legally used as a substitute for time in line. Those willing to buy a hotel package or five-day Flex Signature Passport are permitted to enter the park an hour or two before each day's official opening -- what Disney calls "magic morning" admission. Concierge service, an expensive option at the most expensive Disney-owned hotels, includes guaranteed access to breakfasts with Winnie-the-Pooh, Pinocchio and the gang. Guided tours ($60 a hour for a minimum of four hours) get you reserved seating at jam-packed street and stage performances such as the Fantasmic laser light show.
Disney has thus far been careful to minimize the visibility of this gray market. And for good reason: Nothing undermines the egalitarian ethic as swiftly as preferential access to the salad bar.
But capitalist rot does seem to be spreading as -- shades of the Soviet Union -- managers look to outside cash and technology to speed modernization. Corporations, including Eastman Kodak, AT&T and Federal Express, get backdoor access to the various Disney rides or exhibits they sponsor through private lounges. And according to The Wall Street Journal, these sponsors, in turn, offer back-door privileges to employees of other Disney corporate sponsors, creating what amounts to a first-class deck on the good ship Disney.
Could socialism, Disney-style, follow the Soviet Union into the ash can of history? Don't get your hopes up: the old theme park is still a money machine. And it is about to get a face lift that among other things will update the embarrassingly quaint vision of the future known as Tomorrowland.
But it's still fun to imagine. Perhaps the day is not far off when the Mouse's cult of personality will be denounced at Congressional hearings, speculators will hawk tickets to Pirates of the Caribbean to the highest bidders, and gangs of disillusioned Disney characters will extort protection money from the shops on Main Street.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Sales Slip Despite Sport Vehicle

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 1

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation's sales slipped 1.8 percent in March, with strong sales of the latest brawny sport utility vehicle to hit the market nearly offsetting a sharp decline in car sales.
Chrysler said today that its car sales last month dropped 12,470, or 16.8 percent. But the company sold 12,283 Dodge Durangos -- the new sport utility vehicle -- nearly offsetting the drop in cars. Trucks fared better: combined sales of sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks rose 6.3 percent in March, compared with 1997. 
 "The Dodge Durango has proven itself to be a runaway hit," said James P. Holden, Chrysler's executive vice president for sales and marketing. "We continue to be impressed by the strong demand for our trucks and sport utility vehicles," he said, noting that sales of Dodge Dakota pickups rose 16.0 percent.
The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company are expected to announce their sales on Friday. Wall Street analysts expect that for the industry as a whole, sales will fall 3 to 4 percent from the strong sales last March.
So far, the results seem to be following a familiar pattern. While sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans are selling briskly, cars are selling slowly.
"The light-truck business continues to boom, the passenger car business continues to suffer, and over all we're having continued strong sales," David B. Healy of Burnham Securities said.
The 10 auto makers reporting results today saw a combined drop of 8.7 percent. "It looks a little weaker than last year, but we're looking for G.M. to report a strong number, and to lift the overall sales somewhat," Nicholas J. Colas, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York, said. He said G.M. sales might be up as much as 5 percent, compared with the strong levels a year earlier and were expected to be no worse than flat. He cited an aggressive advertising campaign and rebate push from the company last month.
Foreign auto makers reported mixed sales results today. Toyota sales fell 13.4 percent, with truck sales up 1.8 percent and car sales down 20.4 percent. Toyota's flagship Camry sedan recorded another month of weak results -- sales fell 24.4 percent in March. The only models with sales increases were Toyota's four newest -- the Sienna mini-van, the Lexus GS300 and GS400 performance sedans and the Lexus RX300 sport utility vehicle. Sales declined for the rest.
Nissan sales plunged 42.3 percent, partly because its sales were so strong during the 1997 period. Mitsubishi sales dropped 27.8 percent. Land Rover sales fell 20.2 percent.
Others fared better. Despite weak truck sales, overall sales at Honda rose 5 percent in March. Car sales rose 8.1 percent, led by a 24.5 percent increase for the Honda Accord. Even the Honda Civic -- one of the only small cars selling well in a slump for that segment of the market -- saw its sales rise 8.6 percent.
"Civic sales continue to defy the trend, while demand for the new Accord shows no signs of letting up," said Richard A. Colliver, Honda's senior vice president for sales.
Honda's sales of sport utility vehicles and mini-vans fell a combined 12.4 percent, hurt by a 27.3 percent drop in sales of the Odyssey mini-van and a 19.8 percent fall in sales of the CR-V sport utility vehicle, but helped by a 55 percent rise in sales of the Passport, Honda's larger sport utility vehicle.
Subaru sales rose 20.7 percent last month, compared with March 1997, helped by strong sales of its popular Forester sport utility vehicle and its Legacy "sport utility sedan."
Mazda sales jumped 17.3 percent, helped by strong sales of its 626 sedan. Two Korean auto makers, Kia and Hyundai, reported hefty sales increases after offering steep discounts on cars. Kia sales rose 96.6 percent, while Hyundai's rose 27.6 percent.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Auto Sales Down in Japan
 TOKYO, April 1 (Bloomberg News) -- Japanese auto makers reported their 12th consecutive monthly decline in domestic sales, as record unemployment and lower wages kept buyers out of showrooms.
Domestic vehicle sales fell 20.7 percent from March 1997, to 658,997, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said. The decline followed a 22.4 percent drop in January.
Sales of imported vehicles for the month plunged 34.6 percent, to 37,845, following a 39.8 percent decrease in February.

HEADLINE: Early Sign of March Growth As Purchasers Index Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Growth in the nation's manufacturing sector expanded smartly in March, well ahead of analysts' expectations, without showing signs of rekindling inflation.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its monthly index of business activity, compiled from interviews with corporate purchasing executives nationwide, surged to 54.8 percent last month from 53.3 percent in February. 
 Economists had expected the trade group's figure to be unchanged or slightly lower, reflecting a slowing of the economy because of Asia's financial woes.
But there were no immediate signs in that report or in two other economic reports released yesterday that the Asian fallout was hitting the American economy significantly.
"New news is no news," said Rob ert A. Brusca, chief economist at the Nikko Securities International Company. "Whether there's an Asian effect or not, there's no dramatic evidence of it yet."
The economy, he said, "is still growing very well and still isn't producing much inflation."
In Washington, the Commerce Department reported that construction spending rose in February for the third consecutive month, with increases in housing and government construction offsetting a decline in commercial projects.
The increase, three-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $622 billion, followed stronger gains of seven-tenths of 1 percent in January and eight-tenths of 1 percent in December.
In the third report, an important projection of future economic activity was up a sharp four-tenths of 1 percent in February, the strongest rise in a year.
The index of leading indicators for February stood at 105.0, said the Conference Board, a private research group. Economists had expected the measure to gain a more modest two-tenths of 1 percent. It advanced one-tenth of 1 percent in January.
In its report, the purchasing managers group said its measure indicated that prices paid by manufacturers were still declining. Production and new orders were up in March, it said.
New export orders contracted last month for the third month in a row, while imports of materials by manufacturers increased at a faster rate than in February, it said.
The group's report is widely followed by economists because it is usually the first indicator of how the economy fared in the previous month. Any reading over 50 percent in the index is a sign that manufacturing is growing.
In its report, the Commerce Department said the strength in construction spending in February was led by a 1.1 percent increase in residential construction, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $278.8 billion. Single-family construction advanced 1.9 percent and remodeling grew by one-tenth of 1 percent, while apartment building declined eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Government construction rose 1 percent, the largest increase in four months, to a rate of $140 billion. Commercial construction fell 2.6 percent in February, the biggest drop since August 1995, to a rate of $158.9 billion.
The third report, from the Conference Board, said eight of the 10 components of the leading index rose in February, led by money supply, stock prices and building permits. The biggest decliner was new orders for nondefense capital goods.

HEADLINE: Anger Over Bank Merger Spills Onto Web

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
The joke tellers said that UBS stood for "Unemployed Before Summer" and that Union Bank of Switzerland might as well be the Titanic. But the sarcasm about the proposed merger of the company and the Swiss Bank Corporation was not just limited to conversations in corporate hallways.
A Web site critical of the proposed merger reflected the depths of Union Bank employees' resentment about the prospect of dismissals in one of the biggest banking mergers in history. But this time, unlike other mergers where emotions run high among employees, the authors vented their anger in public. 
 The Web site, housed on America Online, vanished over the weekend after an article about it was distributed on Friday by Bloomberg News.
But Swiss Bank took some lumps, too.
"What's SBC stand for?" one joke read referring to the Stamford, Conn., offices of SBC Warburg Dillon Read, Swiss Bank's United States investment banking unit. "Severance Beats Connecticut."
The Web site included a mock newspaper front page, complete with headlines and a picture of the Titanic, according to the Bloomberg News report. There was a section for job hunters, a place to post E-mail and a list of things to do in Stamford, a suburban community not well known for its hip nightspots.
The $25 billion union between the two companies was never billed as a marriage of equals. Swiss Bank is, in effect, the acquirer, and the combined companies expect to eliminate 13,000 jobs worldwide. Defections at the United States investment banking units were expected because of the overlap between the companies' operations. But many employees at UBS Securities in New York, the Union Bank unit, were not waiting for dismissal notices.
On Monday, for instance, 23 bankers from UBS Securities left for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Among them was Richard Barrett, the former managing director of UBS's financial institutions group. The same day, Furman Selz hired David MacCallum, UBS's global head of the life sciences group. Last Friday, Salomon Smith Barney hired three former UBS energy specialists. And several equity traders are expected to join Lazard Freres & Company this month.
Industry watchers say the relationship between the United States arms of the Swiss rivals has been unusually testy compared with other recent mergers, including those of Salomon Smith Barney and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
"This one gets the soap opera, bang-for-the-buck award," said one stock analyst who has heard complaints from friends at UBS. "Instead of seeing individuals leaving, you are seeing whole departments."
Andrea de Cholnoky, head of the global securities and wholesale banking practice at Spencer Stuart, said, "What we see as recruiters is a ton of people calling us up scrambling to find jobs."
Tricia Primrose, a spokeswoman for America Online, confirmed that the Web site was shut down, but not by America Online. "It was taken down by the account," she said.
Ms. Primrose, citing privacy concerns, would not identify the authors or confirm whether they were employees of either of the companies. She said America Online had received no complaints about the site. "Anybody has a right to create what they want," she said.
In a statement, UBS said the Web site reflected "unproductive comments of a few disgruntled employees." It went on to say, "We do not know the source of the Web site, the reason it was created or why it was shut down." An official from SBC said the company had no comment.
One of the main reasons UBS Securities' employees are upset is the lack of information about the merger from management. One investment banker, who recently landed a job at another firm and asked not to be identified, said he first heard about the merger not from his UBS bosses but from a friend at SBC a few days before the announcement.
Another investment banker who left and also asked not to be identified, said he met an SBC executive in mid-December who told him he would be assigned a new job in the company by month's end. But the banker said he did not hear from the executive until the end of February, after he learned most of the top jobs would be filled by SBC professionals. "And they were trying to keep me," he said. "What about the people they didn't like?"
Mitchell Lee Marks, a consultant in San Francisco who advises chief executives on how to handle the cultural aspects of combining companies, said poor communication between management and employees was all too common in most mergers. "The irony here is executives will spend a lot of money on investment bankers and lawyers to advise them on a merger but not spend a lot of money integrating the companies," he said. "The first thing I tell executives is know what you are going to do."
That is especially important now that disgruntled employees have easy access to a worldwide audience over the Internet and are eager to voice their complaints. Samuel Hayes, a professor of investment banking at the Harvard Business School, said, "This could well be the beginning of a new chapter in employees' capacity to express their views about how they don't like their companies being merged."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Deregulation Starts Amid Bad News

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, April 2

 BODY:
Japan entered a new era of financial-market deregulation on Wednesday as its fiscal year began, but the opening was overshadowed by chronic economic symptoms: a pioneering property broker declared bankruptcy, stocks plummeted and a global trading company disclosed its first loss in nearly a half-century.
Other news of economic weakness also marked the beginning of Japan's financial changes. The Nissan Motor Company, the nation's No. 2 auto maker, said it would suffer an annual loss on its stockholdings in other companies. And forecasters said the quarterly business-sentiment survey of the Japanese central bank would confirm that most companies believe that the nation's economic problems are worsening. 
 The survey, released this morning, showed that corporate managers are scaling back on capital investment and see little hope for a turnaround before summer.
An index derived from the results of the survey, known as the Tankan, fell to minus 31, the most pessimistic level since July-September 1994. "It's a grim situation," said Takeshi Matsui, executive vice president of Daikin Industries, which makes commercial refrigeration equipment.
Securities traders said the biggest negative development affecting the markets on Wednesday was the bankruptcy of the Dai-Ichi Corporation, a real estate broker with 37 billion yen in liabilities, or about $277 million, because of falling property prices.
"It's bad news," said Jason James of HSBC Securities Japan. "People were thinking bankruptcies were held up until the fiscal year-end, and now axes will start falling."
The developments sent Japanese stocks lower, led by Dai-Ichi's main creditors -- the Mitsui Trust and Banking Company, Yasuda Trust and Banking, Nippon Credit Bank and Chuo Trust and Banking.
The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 285.51 points, or 1.73 percent on Wednesday, to 16,241.66, erasing Tuesday's gains from year-end Government buying. Early today, stocks tumbled 394.51 points more, or 2.43 percent, to 15,847.15, the lowest since mid-January.
Dai-Ichi said its four main banks had refused to reschedule loans. Its bankruptcy is further evidence that Japanese banks, weakened by soured property loans, have reduced their willingness to lend.
In another consequence of Japan's anemic stock market, which finished the fiscal year down 8.2 percent, the Marubeni Corporation said it would report the first annual loss since 1952. The main reason given by Marubeni, a big trader of metals, machinery and food, was an estimated loss of 51 billion yen on its holdings of shares in other companies.
Japan's financial-system changes, to be completed by 2001, are aimed at dismantling barriers between banks and other financial companies and reducing the regulations that restrict how Japanese can invest their enormous pools of savings. The aim is to increase competition with vibrant markets in New York and London. But these systemic changes are beginning just as the economy is effectively in a recession, the first in more than two decades.

HEADLINE: SENATE COMMITTEE MAKES FAST WORK OF CIGARETTE BILL

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
Sweeping aside challenges favorable and unfavorable to cigarette manufacturers, the Senate Commerce Committee gave a strong bipartisan vote of approval today to legislation that would raise the price of cigarettes and stiffen regulations on tobacco.
No other measure before Congress this year could lead to such fundamental changes in society. If the sponsors are right, it could reduce the number of teen-agers who smoke by as much as 40 percent and prevent millions of early deaths from smoking-related illness. 
 The vote was 19 to 1. The only "no" vote came from Senator John Ashcroft, Republican of Missouri, who argued that other industries were entitled to the same annual limit on damage claims that the bill would give the tobacco companies.
But the ease with which the bill cleared the committee today without substantative change belied the extent of the opposition and the many obstacles that lie ahead.
No one disagreed when Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, called the tobacco question "as contentious an issue as you can get in Congress."
Nor did anyone challenge Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, when he said, "This is nothing like what the final project will be."
Senator John McCain, the committee chairman, said that he hoped the bill would be before the full Senate before Memorial Day. He said that before the Senate could take up the bill, intense negotiations would be needed with other committee chairmen, with the party leaders in the Senate and with the White House.
The House of Representatives has been treading water on the issue, waiting to see what happens in the Senate. White House officials have said that the Senate bill is basically satisfactory, but was not perfect.
The bill would force up the price of a pack of cigarettes by $1.10 over the next five years, penalize cigarette companies if the number of teen-age smokers did not fall to specified levels and limit the civil liability of the industry to $6.5 billion a year. It also would require the manufacturers to accept strict limits on their advertising and marketing in order to retain the liability ceiling.
Money would be set aside to buy out tobacco farmers who wanted to get out of the business and to help communities that would suffer economically if fewer people smoked.
The bill would be much tougher on the tobacco companies than the settlement they reached with state attorneys general last June.
Former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop and other public health authorities oppose the measure because they say it is too generous to the tobacco industry. Spokesmen for the industry, on the other hand, say the measure is unacceptable because it would force companies into bankruptcy and lead to a contraband market in cigarettes.
The White House maintains that the penalty imposed on the industry if the rate of youth smoking does not fall enough is too low. The bill would require payments of no more than $3.5 billion a year.
"This is not a perfect document," declared Senator McCain, the person most responsible for putting together a package that satisfied no one entirely but kept the various factions on the committee from bolting.
Mr. McCain, Republican of Arizona, implored his colleagues to vote for his bill just to push the legislative process along. "If we are ever to complete our mission," he said, "we have to move this through the committee."
With the committee's regular meeting room much too small to handle the crowd, the drafting session was held in a mammoth room in the Hart Office Building, across Constitution Avenue from the Capitol. The room was jammed with lobbyists representing a spectrum of interests -- tobacco companies, public health organizations, convenience stores, vending machine owners, trial lawyers and countless others.
During the breaks, they compared notes and talked softly into cellular phones. Whatever their motives, many of them stood and cheered at the final vote.
When disputes arose today, like whether to lift a ceiling on the tobacco industry's annual legal liability or to place a limit on lawyers' fees, the senators accepted Mr. McCain's plea to leave his bill alone and plan to settle the matter on the Senate floor.
Proposals to raise and to lower theamount by which cigarette prices would be driven up were handily rejected. The price increase would be obtained by placing a steadily rising fee on the cigarette manufacturers for each pack they produced.
To avoid excessive controversy, Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, who has fought the tobacco companies for years, withdrew his amendment that would have stiffened the penalties on the industry if annual goals for reducing youth smoking were not met.
Similarly, "in deference to the chairman," Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, withdrew a proposal that would have limited to $250 an hour the fee that lawyers who successfully sue the tobacco companies could charge. Approval of the McCain bill intact, said Senator Brownback, "moves us toward a final settlement."
The committee did not deal with the critical question of how to spend the more than $500 billion the bill would raise from the cigarette companies over the next 25 years. And measures to limit smoking abroad were set aside to be debated later.
Senator McCain called this "kicking the can down the road."
Despite the committee comity that Mr. McCain fostered, considerable opposition to his bill was expressed.
Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, said that his mother had died of lung cancer from smoking and that he had no tobacco interests in his state. But he said he worried that instead of concentrating on how to stop young people from starting to smoke, the committee was "engaging in a rush to see who can be the hardest on tobacco."
Senator Wyden said that the bill should "do more to help protect kids."
But in the end, the consensus was to save the attacks for another time. For example, Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, said that he had been prepared to vote against the bill on the ground that it was too soft on the cigarette companies. But he said he had changed his mind.
"We can only do the best we're able to do," he declared, expressing the sentiment that carried the day.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator John B. Breaux, foreground, a Louisiana Democrat, spoke yesterday at a hearing on tobacco legislation. The bill cleared the Senate Commerce Committee, but faces obstacles on the Senate floor. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)(pg. A22)
 
Chart: "CLOSER LOOK: What the Tobacco Measure Would Do"
 
These are the main provisions of the tobacco legislation:
 
COST -- Tobacco manufacturers would pay a fee to the Government that would be passed on to smokers, increasing the cost of cigarettes by 65 cents a pack in 1999, rising to $1.10 in 2003. The money raised, $506 billion over 25 years, would go into a Government trust fund. The legislation does not specify how the money would be spent.
 
CIVIL LIABILITY -- Damages would be limited to $6.5 billion a year. Claims exceeding that would be paid in later years. No further protection against lawsuits would be given.
 
MARKETING AND ADVERTISING Outdoor advertising would be banned as would advertising containing human images, animal figures and cartoon characters. Color advertisements would be outlawed except in adult publications. If the tobacco companies challenged these restrictions in court, the limit on liability would be eliminated.
 
YOUTH SMOKING -- The goals for reduction in the number of teen-agers who smoke would be 15 percent after three years, rising to 45 percent after 10 years.
 
PENALTIES -- If these targets are missed, the tobacco companies would be assessed penalties not to exceed $3.5 billion a year.
 
REGULATION -- The Food and Drug Administration would be given broad latitude to regulate tobacco, including advertising and youth access. If the agency decided to ban nicotine or a tobacco product, the ban would not go into effect for two years, giving Congress time to pass legislation overturning it.
 
INTERNATIONAL -- Federal money could not be used to promote tobacco exports. A nonprofit corporation would be established to oversee international tobacco control programs.
 
LEGAL FEES -- A three-member arbitration panel would decide the fees that lawyers for successful plaintiffs could receive.
 
FARMERS -- The Government would buy out some tobacco growers and compensate others who continued to farm if demand for tobacco dropped. Grants would be provided to offset economic losses in some communities and to retrain farmers and tobacco workers.
(pg. A22)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Tough Tobacco Legislation Endorsed by Senate Panel
The Senate Commerce Committee gave a strong bipartisan vote of approval to legislation that would raise cigarette prices and stiffen regulations on tobacco.
Senator John McCain, the committee chairman, said he hoped the bill would be before the full Senate before Memorial Day. But the bill's advance through the committee without substantative change belied the opposition and obstacles ahead. Page A1. 

Stocks Start Quarter With Rally
Stocks rose broadly on the first day of the second quarter. The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 11 percent in the first quarter, rose 68.51 points yesterday to finish at 8,868.32. The Nasdaq composite index reached its second straight record. D10.
 
Treasury securities ended sharply higher. The 30-year bond yield fell to 5.88 percent from 5.93, the lowest in a week. D10.
 
Japan's 'Big Bang' Is Blunted
Japan entered a new era of financial-market deregulation, but the "Big Bang" effort was overshadowed by chronic economic symptoms: a pioneering property broker declared bankruptcy and a global trading company disclosed its first loss in nearly a half-century. The Nikkei fell 1.73 percent, erasing gains from the previous day when the Government bought shares. D4.
 
MCI Delays Financial Report
MCI Communications delayed releasing its full 1997 financial report because of an accounting dispute with the S.E.C. D2.
 
Manufacturing Growth Expands
Growth in manufacturing expanded smartly in March, well ahead of analysts' expectations, with no signs of rekindling inflation, a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management showed. Other reports showed stronger construction spending and an advance in a widely watched economic forecasting gauge. D8.
 
House Supports Credit Unions
The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly to give credit unions authority to expand their memberships. The measure, if approved by the Senate, would represent a defeat for many small and medium-size banks. D5.
 
Insider Trading Scheme on Mergers
The S.E.C. and U.S. Attorney's office filed insider trading charges against a former Salomon Smith Barney investment banker and others, accusing them of profiting illegally from secrets about pending mergers. D11.
 
Corporate Advice for the O.E.C.D.
Greater independence for board members and increased disclosure of financial information are among recommendations an international advisory group is expected to give the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today. D4.
 
Inquiry on Nazi Loot in U.S.
A Government commission will seek to determine if any Holocaust-era assets are still in banks in the United States. A8.
 
Power Competition In California Debut
After a five-year effort, California became the first state to achieve utility deregulation. A complex system that allows customers to bypass their local utilities and buy power directly from other sources functioned flawlessly. D4.
 
Dim Euro Hopes for Greece
Greece, the poorest country in the European Union, is intent on joining Europe's common currency in 2001. But there is much skepticism about its ability to meet the criteria. A8.

HEADLINE: Control Sought On Districts For Businesses

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY and THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
After years of questioning the powers of the city's private business improvement districts, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is about to propose some stringent measures that would give his administration significant control over the semiautonomous agencies.
The new rules would require the city's 39 districts, which provide services like street cleaning and security, to clear virtually every major undertaking with the Department of Business Services, from the staging of street fairs to the purchase of new computers, said several officials from the districts and others who know of the city's plans. 
 They would also prohibit anyone from serving as the president of more than one improvement district, a rule apparently aimed at Daniel Biederman. Mr. Biederman heads three districts, including two of the most powerful in Manhattan, the Grand Central Partnership and the 34th Street Partnership.
Mr. Biederman, who is also the president of the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation, declined to comment yesterday. But several other district officials, speaking only under the condition of anonymity, said the proposed bureaucratic oversight would undermine the very purpose of the private organizations: to work more efficiently than city government can, and to augment government services.
The districts fulfill their mission by levying special taxes on property owners. The money is used for several purposes, including promoting businesses, hiring security guards, and picking up garbage.
"There is a fundamental point here," said a senior executive at a large Manhattan district. "BID's have been established so the private sector can step up to the bar and do what the government wasn't doing.
"I don't think property owners are going to want to pay these kinds of assessments to be a subagency of city government," the executive continued, adding that some improvement districts may go out of business rather than abide by the Mayor's new rules.
Administration officials declined to comment on the proposals, the language for which is still being worked out. But a person familiar with the discussions between the administration and the districts said the city plans to announce the proposal soon, possibly next week. It was unclear last night whether the plan would require approval of the City Council. The Council authorized the creation of such districts 15 years ago, and in recent months, Council leaders have also expressed concerns about the management practices of districts and their lack of oversight. In November, Council leaders introduced some proposals that would more closely regulate existing districts and make it harder to create new ones.
Officials of several of the business improvement districts said yesterday that they were informed last week of the Mayor's plan by the Department of Business Services, which told them that they would be receiving letters detailing the new rules within a day or two. But no letters have been received, leaving some BID officials frustrated and angry.
There have been several notable successes among the city's many improvement districts. The ones in Times Square and in lower Manhattan have been credited with helping to make those areas more appealing to tourists and developers. But others have received unflattering attention.
Several years ago, workers for the Grand Central Partnership were accused of harassing homeless people as a way of keeping them away from cash-machine lobbies and other locations. And last month, Judge Sonia Sotomayor of the Federal District Court of Southern New York ruled that the Grand Central and the 34th Street districts had violated minimum wage laws by hiring homeless people as guards and sanitation workers at $1 to $1.50 an hour.
The Giuliani administration has also prohibited improvement districts from selling bonds or receiving large loans to finance projects, arguing that the city might be held liable if the districts defaulted.
The question of the power of improvement districts resurfaced in February, after the Police Department agreed to put a substation near Wall Street, which would be financed in part by payments of $700,000 a year by the Alliance for Downtown New York, an improvement district in lower Manhattan. That agreement, which also included a plan for the improvement district to aid in the creation of a police museum, raised questions about the influence of the self-taxing agencies and the inequities between districts in rich and poor neighborhoods.
After a dispute arose about the substation, the Mayor directed Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington to study the guidelines governing improvement districts. Mr. Washington's inquiry has led to the guidelines now being hammered out by the administration.
The person familiar with those discussions said some suggestions have been incorporated and others rejected. For example, the city may require the districts to provide weekly logs of all contacts that they have with city agencies, on everything from potholes to 911 calls. But a proposal that the districts first inform the Department of Business Services before getting in touch with elected officials has apparently been dropped.
From their inception a decade ago, the districts have been a hybrid of governmental and private control and influence. Although they receive no money from the city, and are financed entirely by contributions from the property owners, the districts have contractual agreements that obligate the city to collect their assessments and return the money to them.
As part of its commitment to each district, the city promises to collect from property owners who fall behind in their assessments, and can use the same legal means in its collection procedures as it would if it were collecting back taxes. Decisions about how to spend the district's money are approved by boards composed largely of the property owner members in each district.
The proposed guidelines have unnerved several district officials, but only Peter Malkin, the chairman of the Grand Central Partnership and the 34th Street Partnership, would speak for the record.
"I would call for an appointment to speak with the Mayor to clarify what is going on, and come up with a workable solution," he said. But Mr. Malkin, a lawyer who, with Mr. Biederman, has been at the center of some of the controversies surrounding the improvement districts, said he did not intend to challenge the Mayor's new regulations in court.

HEADLINE: Public Works At Record Sum In House Vote

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
The House today overwhelmingly approved the largest public works bill in the nation's history, despite objections from both President Clinton and conservatives that the bill threatens the fiscal discipline of last year's balanced budget agreement.
The transportation legislation, which passed by a vote of 337 to 80, calls for spending $217 billion over six years on projects from highways and bridges to mass transit systems and bicycle paths. And it is packed with special projects, like $3 million for a public television documentary on "infrastructure awareness," or $7 million for transportation enhancements to a Pennsylvania waterfront development project that includes a brew pub. 
 Though strongly supported by the House Republican leadership, the bill still touched off a divisive debate among Republicans over whether their party stood for fiscal prudence or was simply practicing pork-barrel politics. The transportation bill breaks the spending limits set by last year's budget deal by at least $26 billion.
"I hope and pray that somehow this Republican majority finds its roots again," said Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican who serves on the budget committee, "because I believe that right now -- this is it -- we're losing it."
Other Republicans called the repair of the nation's decrepit roads and bridges a party priority, far more worthy than social programs favored by Democrats. "I am not a big spender," said Representative Bud Shuster, the Pennsylvania Republican who, as chairman of the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, did more than anyone to write the bill.
"I'm a fiscal conservative," Mr. Shuster said, "but there's a fundamental difference between spending money to build assets and pouring money down a rat hole."
With election-year projects spread through virtually every Congressional district -- and doled out with special largesse to members of Congress of both parties who are likely to face tough races -- the public works measure was considered irresistible.
Its approval signals that far more will be spent on highway and transit projects than could have been conceived of just a year ago, before the prospect of Federal budget surpluses began to appear. The Senate has already overwhelmingly approved similar legislation, which proposes spending $214 billion. The previous largest public works transportation bill was $151 billion, enacted in 1991.
Mr. Shuster said that all the money to pay for the highway projects would come from the Federal gasoline tax that Americans pay at the pump. "The cold-hard fact remains we are simply spending the revenue coming in," he said.
But since the balanced budget agreement had anticipated using some of that revenue to reduce the deficit, the spending called for in the bill would need to be offset by other domestic spending cuts -- or else would threaten the emerging surpluses.
House Republicans made no effort to identify those cuts, even though earlier this week they insisted on cutting domestic programs dear to Mr. Clinton to offset his own request for $2.9 billion in emergency disaster relief and peacekeeping operations in Iraq and Bosnia.
The White House expressed concern that the public works spending would crowd out other domestic programs. "It will not only squeeze out the President's priorities, it will squeeze out Congressional priorities," said Franklin D. Raines, the President's budget director. "You can't vote for all of this spending and still be able to vote for education in September."
But he stopped short of the threat of a Presidential veto, with the overwhelming support for the bill indicating that the President could not prevail in such a fight.
Only a small number of fiscal conservatives were willing to stand against the bill. Representative Lindsey O. Graham, a South Carolina Republican, sought to eliminate more than $9 billion for more than 1,400 special projects that were added to the bill for lawmakers' districts. His amendment failed by a vote of 337 to 79.
By a vote of 225 to 194, the House also defeated an amendment offered by Representative Marge Roukema, a New Jersey Republican, and supported by Speaker Newt Gingrich, to eliminate a Federal program that would set as a goal the award of at least 10 percent of construction contracts to women and minorities.
For the most part Republicans and Democrats alike took turns today praising the public works measure as an economic development project that would create new jobs and reduce traffic fatalities.
"I was called the king of pork because I got five bridges funded," said Representative James A. Traficant Jr., an Ohio Democrat. He said that attitudes changed, however, when one of the exiting bridges collapsed. "I don't apologize for any damn thing," Mr. Traficant said. "You could call me anything you want on this House floor. But if you don't take care of your district, no one's going to take care of your district."
A number of issues, including several of importance to New York, will now be resolved in a House-Senate conference committee that will reconcile the two versions of the bill. The Senate version contains about $41.3 billion for mass transit programs across the nation, while the House has $36.7 billion. New York receives 20 percent of the transit money.
The House, however, gave New York a somewhat greater share of the highway money than the Senate did. Under the House bill, New York would receive about 5.37 percent of the total $180 billion in highway money. The Senate gave New York 5.1 percent of the highway money.
The conference will also decide the fate of the $9 billion in projects added into the bill by the House. New York would receive $652.2 million of those projects.
The Senate bill also includes penalties for states that do not enact laws setting the legal limit for drunken driving to a blood-alcohol level of 0.08 percent, as opposed to most states' standards of 0.10 percent. The House version gives states incentives for imposing stricter levels. But House leaders would not allow a vote on an amendment like the clause in the Senate measure.
And only the Senate bill contains a change in the tax code that would make it easier for employers to offer their workers tax-free transit benefits of up to $65 a month.
