SECTION: Section D; Page 4; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 359 words

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Drop Sharply As Boeing Falls

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Orders to American factories fell sharply in February, though the decline was caused by a big drop in the volatile aircraft industry, the Commerce Department reported today.
Though orders fell by nine-tenths of 1 percent, excluding transportation equipment, hurt by a drop in orders at the Boeing Company, they were up two-tenths of 1 percent. That indicated that the economy continued on a path of steady growth. 
 Adding to the picture, the Labor Department said that the number of people applying for state unemployment benefits fell by 5,000 last week, to 309,000, suggesting steady job creation.
"It's safe to say that we've got a very solid growth outlook right now," said Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York.
With the economy robust but inflation still at bay, the Federal Reserve has consistently -- most recently at a policy-making meeting this week -- kept interest rates steady. At the previous meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee, on Feb. 3 and 4, Fed policy makers unanimously voted to leave rates unchanged, deciding to wait to see whether Asia's downturn slows the American economy, minutes from the meeting that were released today show. The committee also kept a neutral bias with regard to rates, instead of moving to a tilt in favor of raising rates, which some analysts had expected.
The factory orders report offered further evidence demand for American goods had not deteriorated as much as expected amid the Asian crisis.
For example, orders for nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft, rose 1.9 percent in February, marking the third monthly increase. In addition, factory shipments, a gauge of current demand, rose 1.2 percent in February, after declining nine-tenths of 1 percent in January.
The drop in overall durables orders came because Boeing, the world's largest manufacturer of commercial aircraft, reported only 9 new orders in February, down from 62 in January. That was inflated by a 59-plane order from the Southwest Airlines Company, said Shawn Griffin, senior manager of public relations for Boeing's commercial airplane group.

HEADLINE: Indonesia to Sign 3d I.M.F. Rescue Pact

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Indonesia is within days of signing its third accord in five months with the International Monetary Fund to try to rescue its collapsing economy, and the fund's leadership is already fending off criticism that it is giving in too much to the demands of President Suharto, the country's authoritarian leader.
The new accord greatly delays the imposition of earlier requirements that Indonesia end its subsidies on electricity, gasoline and a number of basic food items, according to American and fund officials familiar with its details. Indonesian officials insist that the fund's attempt to terminate those subsidies quickly, part of a January economic plan that has never been carried out, are stoking anti-Government protests that have broken out across the country. 
 Today, at another such protest, in Jogjakarta,where Mr. Suharto made his name as a military commander more than three decades ago, Indonesian policemen fired tear gas and threw stones to break up a student protest. Reuters quoted witnesses as saying 40 people were wounded.
Speaking in Washington today, Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the I.M.F., insisted that he would walk away from negotiations with Indonesia if it did not agree to a strong reform program. "The markets will not buy" a weak agreement, he said, a reference to the need to stop the flight of foreign money from Indonesia.
But as Mr. Camdessus spoke, his deputy, Stanley Fischer, was arriving in Jakarta to put the final touches on a new accord, one that American officials say Indonesia must begin adhering to before it gets its next installment of aid.
Some economists and Congressional critics of the monetary fund have said that the fund is easing too many of the terms of its $43 billion loan program in an effort to get Mr. Suharto to accept reforms.
Among other things, the fund and Mr. Suharto's Government have already agreed on new financial goals for the country's budget, which in turn will allow Indonesia to spend more than $1 billion on food subsidies and run relatively large budget deficits. The fund's new aid program also reflects the rapid deterioration of the Indonesian economy: inflation in the first quarter of the year was estimated to have run at 25 percent.

HEADLINE: The Mayor vs. the BID's

 BODY:
One of the engines of New York City's renaissance has been the business improvement districts. The BID's have been responsible for much of the cleanliness, improved security and revitalized spirit of commercial areas in all five boroughs. But now Mayor Rudolph Giuliani appears determined to emasculate the BID's by limiting their ability to plan and advocate on behalf of their members. This is a puzzling development that seems to go counter to Mr. Giuliani's own vision of government.
There are 39 BID's in the city, each financed by fees from local commercial property owners, including The New York Times. City law requires that the BID's operate as democracies controlled by the ratepayer, and that all their operations be open to city scrutiny. The city is responsible for making sure the BID's operate properly, and Mr. Giuliani has expressed concern that some BID executives are running the districts like petty fiefs, borrowing too much money or cutting ratepayers out of the decision-making process. 
 The Mayor has every right and duty to make sure the districts are following those rules. But he has reacted instead by throwing the baby out with the bathwater. The administration's new directives suggest that the city wants the right of prior approval over everything the BID's do. It has told district executives that from now on all ideas for new activities, contracts or expenditures must be vetted with the Department of Business Services, even before representatives of the ratepayers are brought into the discussion.
The department also wants to be informed before any discussion with other city agencies takes place -- an awful burden for BID staffs who are in constant contact with city employees on issues ranging from law enforcement to permits for street fairs.
Mr. Giuliani has identified a narrow problem, and attempted to solve it by smothering the BID's with a blanket of new bureaucracy. For a Mayor who preaches the gospel of lean government, privatization and keeping power and responsibility as close to the grass roots as possible, this is a strange and unwelcome development.

HEADLINE: A Would-Be Yeltsin Heir Faces Big Test in Siberia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: ACHINSK, Russia

 BODY:
Aleksandr I. Lebed stood in the Siberian chill in nothing more than a dark business suit and told the voters his iron hand could turn their region around.
The overflow crowd in the auditorium was bundled up in bulky coats and fur hats. Siberia may be rich in natural resources, but Achinsk is too strapped to pay its heating bills. 
 "It is not an economist who is needed today," Mr. Lebed declared. "It is an expert on crisis management. Nobody can tell me the name of an economist who has had any success in our huge country."
A year and half after he was dismissed by President Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Lebed is running for governor of the huge Krasnoyarsk region in a bitter race that could make or break his political career.
Victory would give the former general a powerful base for his campaign to capture the presidency. Defeat could be cataclysmic. So far, it is very much an uphill battle.
"If I lose this election there is nothing for me to do in the Presidential elections," Mr. Lebed conceded in an interview. "And if I win the election and don't prove to be a good governor there will also be nothing to do at the presidential elections."
President Yeltsin's decision to dismiss his Cabinet has intensified the infighting over the 2000 presidential race. With two years to go, it seems as if the starting gun has already gone off.
Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the stolid former Prime Minister, is a contender. Mayor Yuri Luzhkov of Moscow has been rushing around the country, striking nationalist poses.
The Communist leader, Gennadi Zyuganov, has been trying to revive his party's sagging fortunes by portraying Mr. Yeltsin's shake-up as a national crisis.
Then there is Mr. Lebed, a raw political talent who seems to speak with the dull roar of a Russian bear. Standing ramrod straight, Mr. Lebed looks a bit like his own bodyguard.
A shallow opportunist to his critics and a charismatic crusader to his supporters, Mr. Lebed became a national sensation by coming in third in the 1996 presidential race. He worked briefly as President Yeltsin's national security adviser before being cast out for coveting Mr. Yeltsin's job too openly.
Mr. Lebed, 47, is no stranger to adversity. As a Kremlin aide, he risked the wrath of Russian nationalists by negotiating an end to the conflict in Chechnya. But Siberia is proving to be his toughest test.
To understand why Mr. Lebed is putting a high-stakes gamble on a province 2,400 miles from Moscow, think of a region that extends from North Dakota to Texas. (Krasnoyarsk is one-fourth the size of the United States.)
Then imagine that the governor of the region is also a representative in the national legislature. (The governor of Krasnoyarsk is a ranking member of Russia's upper house of Parliament)
Also consider that the region has some of the nation's largest factories and richest resources. Krasnoyarsk has the country's biggest metallurgical complex -- Norilsk Nickel -- as well as chemical plants, aluminum factories and two closed nuclear cities, off-limits to Russians without special permission.
Further, imagine that it has often been a barometer of political trends. Krasnoyarsk only has a population of 3.4 million, but the 1996 voting results closely paralleled the national outcome.
The timing of the governor's race is also convenient for a politician with presidential ambitions. While Mr. Lebed was born in the southern region of Rostov and later served as a parliamentary deputy from the Tula region near Moscow, he did not have to worry about a residency requirement. To run for governor of Krasnoyarsk, a candidate simply has to produce a long list of voters' signatures.
Mr. Lebed, to be sure, has several things going for him. He is famous. Krasnoyarsk has an anemic economy, which is just beginning to turn around.
Mr. Lebed has retooled his image. He rarely growls like a nationalist. Instead, he has assumed the role of a decisive manager and populist, who promises, if elected, to hold visiting hours for disgruntled citizens twice a week.
His small motorcade races from town to town in politically-correct Russian-made Volga sedans and Lada compacts. The shiny Mercedes and BMW cars that prowl Moscow's streets are conspicuously absent.
Running for governor also seems to be kind of a family business. Mr. Lebed's older brother reigns over neighboring Khakassia, one of Russia's 20 ethnic republics. The Russian press has charged that he won thanks to his support of corrupt businessmen in the aluminum industry.
But Krasnoyarsk is a much tougher fight. The incumbent is Valery M. Zubov, a former sociology professor who spent two years teaching at the University of Oklahoma. He has painted Mr. Lebed as an outsider with dubious financial backers who views Krasnoyarsk as a stepping-stone on his march to the Kremlin.
Mr. Zubov is also supported by Mr. Luzhkov, a Lebed rival who subscribes to the axiom that the enemy of my enemy is my friend. He is planning a trip to Krasnoyarsk to stump for Mr. Zubov.
The Communists have been hammering away at Mr. Lebed, too. They would like to have the monopoly on the downtrodden and disaffected.
The Communist candidate is Pyotr Romanov, who was born in a prison camp after his father was jailed by Stalin but who became a Communist anyway. An experienced politician and former factory director, Mr. Romanov tells voters that if Mr. Lebed is elected "it will take him at least six months to understand the situation."
If no candidate wins a majority of votes in the April 26 balloting, there will be a run-off between the two leading candidates. Most observers expect the race to come down to Mr. Zubov and Mr. Lebed.
Mr. Lebed's meetings in Achinsk, a factory town 150 miles northeast of Krasnoyarsk, show the obstacles his campaign faces.
While wage arrears and layoffs are a big problem, weary resignation, not anger, seems to dominate. Data collected by the Lebed campaign also indicate that the voters tend to prefer the devil they know and that Mr. Zubov is ahead of the pack.
While Mr. Lebed sought to tap the voters' anxiety, he has no economic program to speak of and instead talks in vague homilies.
"Instead of giving you fish every day, I will give you a fishing rod," he told the voters here. "Catch as many as you can."
Mr. Lebed also brandished his patriotism and military service to counter the charge that he was a newcomer who does not have Krasnoyarsk's interests at heart.
Still, some questions here were as frosty as the weather. Workers and pensioners wanted to know what a military man could do about the economy. Others asked about reports that Mr. Lebed's campaign is being financed by Boris Berezovsky, as part of a strategy to draw votes away from Mr. Luzhkov, or by the magnates in Krasnoyarsk's aluminum industry.
Mr. Lebed was not always adept with his answers. He denied that Mr. Berezovsky was his financial backer but insisted he could not reveal his contributors because they cheated on their taxes and would be hounded by the tax police.
The comment seemed to inadvertently capture the moral ambiguities of Russia -- and of its politicians.
"It is so-called 'gray' money," Mr. Lebed told his listeners. "Like you, they are a little bit of a swindler."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
At an association meeting, agency executives survey competition from a host of challengers.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

 BODY:
PROVOCATIVE and challenging examinations of the competitive threats to Madison Avenue dominated the general session here yesterday of the 80th annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
Speakers at the conference explored why rivals as disparate as management consultants, Hollywood talent agencies and brand strategists are gaining success at encroaching on the turf that has been traditionally been trod by advertising agencies. 
 "Adding value to clients' goods and services through application of ideas is a sort of alchemy," said Martin Sorrell, chief executive of WPP Group P.L.C., which owns agencies like Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and the J. Walter Thompson Company. "That is what advertising and advertising agencies at best do well and at very best make a contribution that is priceless."
However, he added, there is what he termed a "marketing myopia" among agency executives that has "blinded them to the real nature of what they provide and has opened the doors to new and unexpected competitors."
As a result, Mr. Sorrell said, many advertisers "don't think we're smart enough" to hire for projects.
Agencies may not be making the case for their services boldly enough to fend off "rapacious consultants," Mr. Sorrell said, like McKinsey & Company and Deutsche Bank A.G.'s Bain & Company unit, as well as such other usurpers as Goldman, Sachs & Company and "flashy idea factories."
"Agencies need to be a lot more adventurous," he added. "At exactly the time traffic is getting faster and louder, the middle of the road may be an extremely uncomfortable place to find ourselves."
Mr. Sorrell suggested that agencies aggressively recruit M.B.A. students the way the consultants do, calling the present dearth of interest in them "pitiful." He also proposed that they cultivate relationships with creative talent at universities, theaters, special effects production companies and computer game design firms.
"If we don't do it," he said, "somebody else will -- and they'll probably be named Spielberg or Disney."
Mr. Sorrell also criticized agencies that "give away free with the layouts and storyboards" the expertise they have developed in "understanding the whole of a client's business" through studying consumer behavior and attitudes.
That was echoed by Ralph Rydholm, the 1997-98 chairman of the association, which is also known as the Four A's.
"I believe we do not value our work as much as we once did or as much as we should," said Mr. Rydholm, who is also chief executive of Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago, a unit of Havas Advertising. "And therefore, we do not charge for our product the way we should."
"We are people who not only point out problems" the way consultants do, he added, "we solve problems, and that should be worth even more money."
"What we do is the single most powerful thing that anyone can do," Mr. Rydholm said, "and that is to create an idea that can move people to action."
"All too often, we don't necessarily look at ourselves with the same sharp eye that we look at a marketing problem with," he added, "or value ourselves the same way we value our brands. We are worth it. We are underpaid."
O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the association, whose contract was recently extended through 2002, also addressed the issue of how agencies are valued.
"Given the recent earnings reports from the publicly traded advertising agency holding companies," Mr. Drake said, "one might think I've got a hell of a nerve talking about increasing agency profits and margins. Yet I can assure you that we have to do this if this industry is going to survive as we know it."
"Ideas that grow brands and generate sales for clients will continue to be the most important contribution agencies make to a client's business," he added. "To achieve that, agencies need to be fairly paid and they must not sacrifice their right to look after the health of their own business."
To help accomplish that, Mr. Drake said, the association is "working on a number of initiatives, including a major study by experts outside our industry as to just what constitutes a fair margin and return on investment in an increasingly complex, global and technology-driven business."
Mr. Drake also outlined a proposal to increase attendance at the annual meeting, which has declined this decade to a range of 400 to 450 people a year. An estimated 440 are attending the 1998 management conference, being held at this desert resort through tomorrow.
Mr. Drake proposed to combine the annual meeting of his association with that of its corresponding marketers organization, the Association of National Advertisers.
"The economics of running a first-class meeting like this, with top-notch speakers and entertainment, look a lot better when you have 700 attendees than when you have 400," Mr. Drake said.
However, Mr. Drake deflated his own trial balloon when he disclosed that the executives of the advertiser association had not embraced his proposal.
Indeed, John J. Sarsen Jr., president and chief executive of the advertiser association, who was here for the Four A's annual meeting, said in an interview after Mr. Drake made his proposal: "It's an area we'll continue to discuss, but I don't see it happening in the short term. We do a number of things together in areas like media and new technology. But we have separate and distinct agendas."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Investors Push Dow Near 9,000 as Inflation Fears Wane

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Waning fears of rising inflation helped major stock market indexes charge to record highs yesterday for the second consecutive day and pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to within three points of breaking 9,000.
Much of the gain came toward the close of trading. After moving as high as 8,997.11 within the last 10 minutes, the Dow closed at 8,986.64, up 118.32 points, or 1.33 percent. 
 So far this week, the blue-chip index has risen 190.56 points, with more than 186 points of the gain coming in the last two days.
In taking stocks higher, investors seemed to indicate that they expected few surprises from today's employment report, analysts said.
"The market's not worried something is going to come out of left field," Andrew M. Brooks, vice president in charge of equity trading at T. Rowe Price Associates, said.
"Our view hasn't been gyrating the way the market has," George M. Cohen, a principal at Cohen Kligenstein & Marks, a New York-based investment management firm, said. "Corporate profits are still strong, the economy is healthy and inflation is low. The situation is really O.K."
Bonds also surged late in the day on optimism that the unemployment data would not signal higher inflationary pressure. Such a strong move "shows a lot of bravado on the part of the bond market ahead of the report," Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko International in New York, said.
"It's not really the strength of the report that matters, what's really important here is inflation," Mr. Brusca said. "If we don't get evidence of inflation, I think the market will do well."
Stocks and bonds may also have gained some strength from midafternoon comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, at a meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors in Washington.
Asked about the current level of stock prices, Mr. Greenspan said that they were not out of line and that they reflected investor expectations of improved productivity and rising corporate profits. The tone of his remarks contrasted with his now-famous "irrational exuberance" assessment of investor psychology in December 1996, which briefly sent stocks falling sharply.
Besides the Dow average, the Standard & Poor's 500 index also hit a new high yesterday, rising 11.86 points, or 1.07 percent, to 1,120.01.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite picked up 5.30 points, to a record 1,852.96, a 0.29 percent gain.
The buying spree aided a number of issues. Cor Therapeutics rose 78 percent after the biotechnology concern received news that regulators are close to approving its new heart drug. Speculation that Mattel could begin distributing the Ohio Art Company's toys such as Etch A Sketch sent shares of the toy maker, based in Bryan, Ohio, up 53 percent. Ohio Art closed at 33 1/2, up 12.
Despite the strong gains yesterday, investors also showed they could react swiftly to negative news, as they did in taking down the prices of several stocks which forecast earnings disappointments yesterday.
"If you come in light, the market's taking no prisoners," Mr. Brooks said. "Expectations are pretty high, so if you don't deliver people are quick to say, 'Let's move on to something else.' "
Stocks such as Security Dynamics Technologies and Respironics were examples of this. Security Dynamics fell nearly 37 percent after the computer security software concern said first-quarter earnings will fall short because sales did not match forecasts. Respironics also fell nearly 37 percent after the respiratory medical product designer said quarterly profits would falter on low demand and Medicare reimbursement issues.

Treasuries Rise in Price
 
 The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, as investors expected that today's report on employment in March would contain favorable numbers from the bond market's standpoint.
The 30-year bond was up 17/32 , to 104. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.84 percent, from 5.88 percent on Wednesday and represented its lowest level since 5.83 percent Feb. 18. Traders apparently expected that the employment report might show some slackening of the job market; such news often buoys the bond market, where inflation fears are paramount.
Elsewhere yesterday, the Philippines sold $500 million of 10-year notes, the first public bond sale by an Asian country since the financial crisis there deepened last year. The Government sold the notes at a yield of about 8.9 percent, or 3.375 percentage points more than 10-year Treasuries, with orders for twice as many bonds as were available.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Dream for Africa: Many Snags to Overcome

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: DAKAR, Senegal, April 2

 BODY:
Quite apart from the good legal news he received here, President Clinton has had an African trip to remember.
In a speech today on Goree Island, where for centuries Africans were crammed into the holds of ships for awful voyages into slavery, Mr. Clinton said he believed more than ever that a renaissance was sweeping this continent. Echoing the "I have a dream" cadences of Martin Luther King Jr., a descendant of slaves, he waxed rhapsodic about the "beauty and intelligence, energy and spirit" that he had seen in African faces, "the faces of Africa's future." 
 With the waves of the Atlantic at his back, the President insisted that "democracy is gaining strength" and "peace is making progress" here, and vowed to build "a bright common destiny" with the countries of Africa.
He has been greeted warmly by Ghanaians in a city square and Senegalese on dusty byways, by East African leaders little known outside their own countries and by a South African leader, Nelson Mandela, known in the world's every nook and cranny. Those whom he talked with told him that they were amazed and pleased that an American President had invested 12 grueling days in their continent.
Patrick Lekota, the chairman of the Council of Ministers in South Africa, spoke for many when he said of the President's visit, "An event of this nature gives us a sense of how far we Africans have traveled." Mr. Clinton, for his part, talked about American companies earning 30 percent a year on their investments and said that that showed the benefits of real partnership.
Now it remains to be seen how the trip pays off -- whether or not ordinary Americans, who have seen and heard more about Africa than ever before, much of it positive, will demonstrate the short attention spans for which they are famous, and forget all about the place; whether or not the African resurgence of which Mr. Clinton spoke so enthusiastically will gain momentum and come to involve more leaders of more nations; whether or not more American business executives will take the risk of investing in countries still beset with problems.
The President's men and women have ambitious plans for following up his work here. Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater and Commerce Secretary William M. Daley both plan to return to Africa at the head of trade delegations later this year, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, a former chairman of Goldman, Sachs, and as such a symbol not only of Washington's power but of Wall Street's, is reportedly considering adding other stops to a trip to South Africa.
Susan E. Rice, the 33-year-old Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, a former Rhodes Scholar who has shaken up a dozy corner of the bureaucracy, will work to keep African issues on the front burner.
But passage of the African trade bill by the Senate is far from certain, especially since Mr. Mandela pronounced it unacceptable. The President's pledge to increase aid levels will be equally difficult to fulfill, given the tenor of Congressional sentiment. And many things lie beyond American control.
The world economy will inevitably encounter another recession one day, like the one that hit in the 1970's, when oil prices shot up, penalizing energy-poor African countries more than most. Because Africa exports mostly raw materials and imports mostly finished goods, it remains highly vulnerable when demand for commodities like copper and palm oil sags, driving down prices.
Mr. Clinton and his advisers believe, however, that Africa is starting to build a solid foundation that will make it easier to weather global economic storms. Among the positive developments that they discerned here are the emergence of a new generation of leaders who understand the need to participate in free markets; the decline of once-pervasive corruption in some countries; the muting of the North-South and East-West polemics that once absorbed so much of the continent's energies, and a waning of the psychological and financial dependence that shackled the former colonies here in their first decades of independence.
The need for regional cooperation -- or, better, unification -- remains one of the continent's pressing needs. Most countries are too small to support industrialization on a competitive basis.
It is true enough, as Mr. Clinton noted in his speech today, that the United States now imports more oil from Africa than from the Middle East and exports more goods to Africa than to the nations that once formed the Soviet Union. But that trade accounts for only 0.9 percent of total United States exports and only about 2 percent of total United States imports; furthermore, it is confined to a few countries, while the rest remain economic backwaters.
South Africa alone produces a third of the continent's gross domestic product and generates no less than half of its electricity.
Poverty remains a plague, not only in poor countries like Mali, east of Senegal, whose liberal-minded leaders complain bitterly of the difficulty of making democracy stick when there is not enough to eat, but in comparatively well-off places like Senegal and Botswana.
Forty years ago, African countries like Congo, with fabulously rich mineral resources, had per capita incomes roughly equal to Asian countries like South Korea. Now South Korea's is more than 50 times as large as Congo's, and Congo's leader, Laurent Kabila, strikes Americans who know him as a frightened man, over his head in his new responsibilities. Mr. Clinton talked privately with him for an hour in Entebbe, Uganda, trying to persuade him, as one member of the President's entourage said, "to change his stripes and pursue democracy."
Congo is one of Africa's big potential winners. Another is Kenya, a success story when Uganda was a mess, a mess now that Uganda is a success story. And then there is Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, which along with Gabon and Equatorial Guinea supplies a quarter of the oil imported by the United States.
Mr. Clinton talked about Nigeria with almost every leader he met this week, seeking advice. They all said that "if Nigeria explodes, it's a disaster for every country in Africa," reported Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, but they disagreed on how to persuade the country's military dictator, Gen. Sani Abacha, to hold honest elections and free political prisoners. Some favored a tough line, some favored appeasement.
"Every avenue we have tried to deal with the Government of General Abacha has been frustrating to us," Mr. Clinton confessed at a meeting with human rights activists this morning. "What should we do? It is an incredible tragedy. You have this huge, diverse, rich country being driven into the ground by political oppression and mismanagement."
Only South Africa, among the big countries, has taken the path of economic liberalism and political pluralism followed by such smaller nations as Mali, Senegal, Ethiopia, Uganda and Botswana. And even there, one person in three, according to some figures, is out of work, with the predictable consequences of high crime and social disorder.
"Mandela is trying hard, and Clinton said good things -- mostly platitudes, but very good platitudes," said Helen Suzman, an admirer of both men and a longtime voice for human rights in South Africa. "The problem is, high birth rates and people flooding in from neighboring countries mean that we need foreign investment and foreign aid, both in large quantities, and quickly."

HEADLINE: Republican Puts New Hurdle In Path of I.M.F. Financing

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
In a new threat to one of President Clinton's top foreign policy goals, the House majority leader today urged fellow Republicans to reject the Administration's request for $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund.
In a seven-page memorandum sent to lawmakers, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the second-ranking House Republican, said the financing would encourage an unchecked expansion of the fund's lending that would cost the United States billions of dollars and weaken financial systems worldwide. 
 "If, under the Clinton Doctrine, we sanction a policy of ever-expanding bailouts and futile and inept attempts to manage other economies, the resulting system will be fragile, susceptible to sudden economic stops and starts, crashes and panics," he said.
Mr. Armey, who acknowledged that his view "may well be a minority position in the House," proposed delaying a vote, expected later this month, on the $18 billion increase. A delay would undercut I.M.F. supporters who are trying to attach the financing to a popular disaster-relief bill.
His memo offers the latest evidence of divisions among Republicans over whether to support the new financing, which the Administration says the fund needs to refill a treasury strained by the Asian financial crisis.
Much of the Republican leadership favors the new financing. Speaker Newt Gingrich said in an interview today that the House needs to hold more hearings on the issue, but he disagreed with Mr. Armey's memo, saying, "I don't think you should just dive into it."
Senate Republicans, with most of their Democratic colleagues, overwhelming approved the $18 billion last week; Republicans backed the measure by nearly three to one.
Mr. Armey sent his memo just as House members headed home on a two-week recess, during which many legislators will undoubtedly hear concerns from farmers and businesses who may support the I.M.F. request because they are worried about losing markets overseas.
Mr. Armey said he would consider supporting the new financing only if the fund first made make public its documents and decision-making procedures, and stopped offering loans at below-market rates.
These arguments parallel those made by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. But Mr. Rubin has said the United States cannot impose its will on the 182-member organization, and that doing so would jeopardize the fund's ability to cope with the Asian crisis.
"The United States is working actively to strengthen the architecture of the international financial system," said Mr. Rubin's spokesman, Howard M. Schloss. "The key is not to put at risk the plans in place in Asia, or put at risk U.S. jobs and businesses."
The Senate bill would require the Treasury Secretary to certify that the Group of Seven leading industrial nations insure that borrowing countries live up to their trade obligations and eliminate subsidies. The House bill would impose tighter restrictions that the Administration says are unworkable. Mr. Armey's conditions would be even more restrictive.
In a speech here today, the fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, said, "I am confident that your great country, as our largest shareholder, will maintain its leadership by supporting the I.M.F."
Aides said Mr. Armey's memo was inspired by a recent meeting with such prominent critics of the fund as George P. Shultz and William E. Simon, both former Treasury Secretaries. It is both an analysis by a former college economics professor, Mr. Armey, and a rallying cry for party conservatives who distrust American involvement in international organizations.
Since it was established 50 years ago, the I.M.F. has been forced to change to meet the needs of the fast-moving global economy.
"No longer are they providing needed cash to basically sound enterprises," Mr. Armey said. "They are bailing out the bankrupt."
This trend, he continued, only encourages more risky investment. Secretary Rubin shares this concern, but has said the repairs cannot be made at the expense of the aiding troubled Asian nations.

HEADLINE: Auto Makers Seeking to Avoid Fines Over Mileage Rules

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 2

 BODY:
With full-sized sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks increasingly popular, auto makers are falling short of Federal fuel-economy standards and scrambling for ways to avoid the embarrassment of paying millions of dollars in fines.
Regulations imposed two decades ago to reduce reliance on imported oil require an average of 20.7 miles per gallon this year for each auto maker's fleet of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans, known collectively as light trucks. Auto makers are subject to fines if their mileage average over seven years is below the Government standard. 
 The light-truck standard is much easier to meet than the 27.5 miles per gallon required for cars. But the popularity of big sport utilities and pick ups that manage only 15 miles or less per gallon has created serious problems for the Big Three auto makers.
The Ford Motor Company is predicting an average fuel economy of 20.1 miles per gallon for the 1998 model year and the Chrysler Corporation is forecasting an average of 20 miles per gallon, according to a new Federal statistical report. Both auto makers are close to falling below the Government standard for the last seven years, but officials at both companies said they would not actually fall below or pay fines.
The General Motors Corporation has had the most fuel economy problems in recent years and is the closest to paying fines. But according to the Federal report, G.M. is predicting that its light trucks will have an average fuel economy of 21.2 miles per gallon this year, beating the Government standard and up from 20.2 miles per gallon in 1997. Sam Leonard, a senior G.M. fuel-economy official, said the jump in 1998 fuel economy would allow G.M. to avoid paying fines for now.
But to achieve its increase from 1997, G.M. has resorted to some unorthodox moves that improve its average without actually raising the fuel efficiency of its vehicles.
For example, G.M. has already cut short its 1998 model year for its biggest sport utility vehicles -- the Chevrolet Tahoe, the GMC Yukon and the Chevrolet and GMC Suburbans -- after less than six months of production. The company declared all such vehicles built after Jan. 31 to be 1999 models. Because fewer large vehicles with poor fuel economy are counted as 1998 models, the average mileage for G.M.'s light trucks rises.
G.M. plans to introduce large pickup trucks for the 1999 model year that are slightly more fuel efficient than the models they replace. This would allow the company to sell more of the four full-sized sport utility models that it has converted early to the 1999 model year. Ford and Chrysler have not moved any vehicles early into the 1999 model year.
G.M., the world's largest auto maker, is taking several other actions. It quietly notified dealers last month that it planned to extend the 1998 model year for its mini-vans and small pickup trucks, which tend to increase the fuel-economy average.
Last autumn, the company also quietly strengthened the suspensions on even the smallest Suburbans with four-wheel drive. The stronger suspensions give the Suburbans the capacity to carry enough weight to qualify as medium-duty trucks. Medium-duty trucks are exempt from fuel-economy calculations, so the four-wheel-drive Suburbans no longer drag down G.M.'s average. Mr. Leonard said customers were demanding more heated seats and other options on Suburbans, so the stronger suspension was needed.
All three auto makers are looking at ways to install more diesel engines, which improve fuel economy by up to 30 percent.
But environmentalists remain leery of diesels. While the cleanest diesels now meet Federal clean-air standards for light trucks, and may soon even meet the standards for cars, they cannot be made as clean as the cleanest gasoline engines. Widespread adoption of diesel engines could prevent regulators from tightening standards someday, said Roland J. Hwang, director of the transportation program at the Union of Concerned Scientists, a research and lobbying group in Washington.
Chrysler is selling light trucks that can run on both gasoline and ethanol; Ford plans to follow suit soon. Such vehicles, because they can run on ethanol, an alcohol commonly made from corn, qualify for Government credits that allow the auto makers to sell more gas-guzzling light trucks. Yet only 44 service stations nationwide sell ethanol.
Fuel economy averages used by the Government are calculated by driving a vehicle on a test track under ideal conditions, not on roads where mileage would be lower. By this method, 20.7 miles per gallon on the test track translates to about 18 miles per gallon on the road, the number used on window stickers, according to regulators.
United States auto makers have never been fined for fuel economy violations. They have consistently met the fuel economy standard for cars and forecast that they will continue to do so, while Japanese auto makers consistently meet the car and light truck fuel-economy standards, according to the report by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Many European auto makers have fallen short of the car standards and paid penalties.
Federal law sets the fines at $5 per vehicle for every tenth of a mile per gallon that a company's average fuel economy falls below the standard. If G.M. fell a tenth of a gallon below the standard, as would have been possible if nothing were done, it would have owed close to $10 million -- a pittance for G.M., the world's largest company, with $177.68 billion in sales last year.
But the American auto makers worry that paying any penalties would be perceived as having flouted the law. This could hurt their image and increase political pressure to improve fuel efficiency. They also worry that they could be vulnerable to lawsuits by American shareholders if they knowingly violate a Federal law.
Environmentalists and some members of Congress say the auto makers should do more to improve fuel economy, particularly for sport utility vehicles, which are used much more than pickups simply for shopping and commuting.
"That is an area where the industry can and should do much more," said Senator Richard H. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada.
Concerns about American dependence on foreign oil prompted Congress to enact the fuel economy rules in 1975, but the impact of growing gasoline consumption on global warming is now a major issue.
Auto makers respond that they are working on electric vehicles and other technologies that may improve fuel economy early in the next century. Auto executives and many economists also contend that the fuel-economy rules are a highly inefficient way to reduce gasoline consumption, forcing auto makers to sell small cars and small light trucks at a loss to meet the overall averages. They also point out that unlike gas taxes, the rules do nothing to discourage Americans from driving ever more miles and burning ever more gasoline.
The system of fuel economy regulation "just introduces distortions to the marketplace, and that's disastrous for the auto companies," John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said in a recent interview.

HEADLINE: Albany Legislative Leaders Quickly Agree on Most of Budget

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 2

 BODY:
Moving with remarkable swiftness for a Legislature notorious for its slowness in producing budgets, legislative leaders reached tentative agreement today on almost every part of the state budget, including the contentious areas of school construction and tax cuts.
Just eight days after opening budget negotiations to the public for the first time, Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, and Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, said late this afternoon that they had agreed to include $743 million in tax cuts more than what Gov. George E. Pataki recommended in his $71.6 billion election-year budget plan. And they agreed to add $500 million to the $858 million Mr. Pataki proposed spending on school construction and renovation. 
 Mr. Bruno, a Republican, and Mr. Silver, a Democrat, said they hoped to complete their budget plan by early next week, after nine legislative conference committees work out the details of spending in areas like education and economic development.
The bipartisan committees, which include members from both houses, were created last week in an unusual attempt to open New York State's notoriously secretive budget process to the public and speed it up. In the past, the process was subject to long delays as the Governor and the two top legislative leaders negotiated behind closed doors. But legislative leaders, facing election-year pressure and frustration among rank-and-file members who have long been excluded from the negotiations, abandoned that much-maligned process.
While the two houses have all but agreed on a plan just two days into the new fiscal year, it remains unclear whether Mr. Pataki will go along with it. The Governor has repeatedly said that the Legislature is overestimating revenues and underestimating expenses by $600 million. Mr. Pataki, who lost considerable power over the budget process when the Legislature decided to form the conference committees this year, has vowed to reject any plan that spends more than his proposal of $71.6 billion. That proposal is 7 percent larger than last year's, with a substantial increase in education spending.
Mr. Pataki has line-item veto power over budget bills, and legislative leaders said today that they did not have enough votes to override a veto. Although he would not comment on specific details of the Legislature's spending plan, the Governor again threatened to veto the plan in a statement tonight.
"If the budget the Legislature sends me spends even one dime more than I have proposed, I will veto it," he said. "I urge the Legislature to complete its deliberations and send me a fiscally responsible budget that continues to build on our success in cutting taxes, controlling spending and insuring the fiscal soundness of the state."
Mr. Bruno insisted that the Legislature's budget plan would not be more expensive than Mr. Pataki's, even though it adds several hundred million in spending. But until all the details are put on paper, it is impossible to know whether that will be the case.
Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver approved requests from the conference committees to spend $243 million more than what the legislative leaders recommended earlier this week in nine categories. That includes an extra $30 million for education, $6 million for mental health and $31 million for human services. They said the extra money would come from a reserve fund that they estimated to be worth $350 million.
Most of the remaining work will fall to the conference committees that oversee education spending and tax cuts, Mr. Bruno said. While legislators know how much they want to spend on school aid to local districts -- they are proposing an increase of about $1 billion, nearly double the rise Mr. Pataki is recommending -- the education committee must decide how to divide the funds between school districts' general budgets and special programs like pre-kindergarten and bilingual education.
The $500 million for school construction and renovation would not be included in the $1 billion school aid amount. Legislative leaders said the construction money would be distributed based on student enrollment, which means that New York City, which enrolls about 37 percent of the state's public-school children, would receive about $190 million of the $500 million.
Meanwhile, the committee in charge of taxes and economic development must decide over what period the $743 million in tax cuts would be phased in. Mr. Bruno said he expected the cuts to be phased in over four years. They include a $50 million personal income tax cut, a $250 million corporate tax cut and a $105 million clothing sales tax cut that would include a repeal of the sales tax on shoes.
(In the best example of the theatrics of today's meeting, Mr. Bruno played down the hole in the bottom of his worn-out shoe to demonstrate his support for the repeal of the shoe sales tax.)
While the proposal for school construction spending was the subject of heated debate earlier this year, only one member of the general budget conference committee run by Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver criticized the proposal today. That member, Republican Assemblyman John Faso of Kinderhook, said legislative leaders were being overly optimistic in their prediction of extra state revenues.
"I've made my point all along that I'm skeptical about some of the numbers," Mr. Faso, the new Assembly minority leader, said.
But Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno waved away the criticism and declared the new budgeting process a smashing success. Ignoring the possibility of opposition from the Governor, they predicted that the Legislature could vote on a final budget by April 13.
"From all that we've accomplished together at this point, it's clear that we should reach closure shortly," Mr. Silver said. "The committees have worked, this is how the budget should be done and I can say with some confidence that hopefully, we will never go back to three men in a room."

HEADLINE: Everest, and Sherpas, Are in Vogue;
New York's Cool New Guys, Thanks to Books and Films

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The Sherpas are bemused.
When they began settling in New York City, the famously trustworthy mountain people from Nepal who have hefted supplies (and not a few Western climbers) to the summit of Everest, fully expected the immigrant's struggle of hard work and homesickness. 
 But they never expected to be cool.
"Thanks to the new Everest boom, the Sherpas are very much in vogue," said Dr. Vincanne Adams, a Princeton University anthropology professor who has been studying them since 1982. "After all the books and movies, there is kind of a celebrity aspect to being a Sherpa."
This has provoked no little astonishment and a measure of delight among the nearly 500 Sherpas living in New York City, the largest settlement in the United States. Until now, the city's newest microcommunity had grown so quietly that it was off the scope of most demographers.
But in recent weeks, Sherpas have loomed large in the glow of The Movie, as they call it: the Imax film "Everest," which chronicles an expedition to the 29,028-foot summit of the world's tallest mountain. The film has racked up the highest per-screen attendance gross -- $54,099, according to Variety -- of any film playing in the country. Thus far, "Everest" has taken in a record $662,000 at the Imax theater at Sony Lincoln Square in Manhattan as of April 1.
The film is just the latest manifestation of Everestmania. There is also the book "Into Thin Air," by Jon Krakauer, which chronicles the May 1996 blizzard that claimed the lives of eight climbers. It has been on the best-seller list of The New York Times for 47 weeks and became an ABC Sunday Night Movie. And the National Geographic Society's $35 coffee-table book on the Imax expedition, "Everest: Mountain Without Mercy," has sold 150,000 copies since October.
"The Imax film is a very big event for us," said Dhamey Norgay, a Sherpa who works in Manhattan as a program coordinator at Philip Morris. "It was very moving for so many of us to see our mountains again, and our culture portrayed on the big screen."
The 28-year-old Mr. Norgay is the youngest son of the most illustrious Sherpa, the late Tenzing Norgay, who made the first ascent of Everest with Edmund Hillary on May 29, 1953. The younger Norgay remembers the cold and the wind of Everest more than 20 years later, when he hiked there at age 9 with his father up to the 13,000-foot level. "We've lost a lot of family members on that mountain," he said. All told, 53 Sherpas have died on Everest.
"People have been coming to the store and talking about the movie," said Gelmu Sherpa, the owner of Tibet, a tiny, artifact-rich Himalayan gift shop on West 80th Street in Manhattan. "I think there is much curiosity about Sherpas now. I'm thinking of opening a second store."
Paradoxically, most of the city's Sherpas have no Everest experience. "When people hear that I'm a Sherpa, they ask how many times I've climbed Everest," said Tsewang Sherpa Lama, president of the United Sherpa Association in New York. He laughed gently. "They're disappointed when I tell them that I've seen Mount Everest -- from a very long distance."
Mr. Norgay and Mr. Sherpa Lama spoke on a recent evening in a rented banquet room at St. Vartan's Armenian Cathedral on East 34th Street in Manhattan. They and 600 other Sherpas from across the land -- nearly all the current population in America -- had gathered to celebrate Lhosar, the Sherpa equivalent of the Chinese New Year.
A red, yellow and green banner proclaimed "Happy Lhosar 1998, Year of the Earth Tiger 2125." Standing before it was Ang Babu Lama, a Buddhist monk in saffron shirt and maroon robes who chanted Tibetan prayers invoking the presence of the Buddha and other deities, and asked for blessings in the new year.
"I came for a short visit last month and the Sherpas won't let me go," Mr. Babu Lama said with a broad smile, after the ceremony.
In New York, there are no monks to perform birth-and-death services, and the nearest Buddhist monasteries are hours away in the Hudson Valley. The Sherpa association is now looking for space and contributions to create their first monastery in New York City.
"When I came to New York, I was the only Sherpa in the phone book," said Lakhpa Thundup Sherpa, who arrived in 1979 and now works as a clerk in the Australian Consulate in Manhattan.
By 1982, "there were only four Sherpas in New York, and perhaps 15 in all the country," said Mr. Sherpa Lama, the association president, who arrived that year as a student with financing from a trust set up by Sir Edmund Hillary. "The community began growing dramatically only after 1990."
"These days the joke is that if you're looking for a Sherpa in Nepal, you'll find him in New York," said Sonam Sherpa, who has been here for 13 years and works as a treasury analyst at Metro North. "Thanks to the movie and the books, people look at us with new attention when they hear we're Sherpas."
Sherpas are scattered throughout the boroughs, though there are concentrations in Queens and Brooklyn, and for some it can be a lonely life. As they work in the United States to save money to buy land or businesses back in Nepal, they are separated from spouses and children.
"Many Sherpas here miss their families at home," said Lakhpa Sherpa Pinasha, a computer-science student at Hunter College who has been in the United States for the last year and a half. "I certainly do. After I graduate, I intend to return to look for a job."
As in Nepal and in Darjeeling (where there is a large Sherpa community), "the Sherpas in New York tend to stick together," said David Breashears, the veteran Everest climber who directed the Imax film. "Pretty much literally, since they often cluster five or so to an apartment."
Amid the struggling economy of Nepal, "the image of America is of a place where you can pick money off the sidewalk," said Jangbu Sherpa, 26, who helped carry the Breashears team's cameras and film up through the final 3,000 feet, the "death zone" to the Everest summit. "I think more Sherpas would like to move here."
But many work for a while and leave. "I lived in the United States for nine years," said Jamling Tenzing Norgay, "but I decided to go back to my homeland because I missed my people."
Mr. Norgay, at 33 the second-oldest son of Tenzing Norgay, is a focal point of the Imax film as he assaults the Everest summit to honor his father, who died in 1986. Now Mr. Norgay runs an adventure-travel business in Nepal, and visits the United States three times each year.
Sherpa means "Easterner," and refers to an ethnic group that began migrating to the Everest region of Nepal from eastern Tibet nearly 500 years ago.
As a group, New York City's Sherpas are accomplished polyglots: in addition to Sherpa, they know Nepalese, English and Hindi, and even French and Japanese if they worked in international tourism back home.
Mountain bumpkins they are not. "In Nepal many live and work with elite and wealthy climbers from America, Europe and Japan," Dr. Adams said. "They form close bonds with them, and they know of every trend from cell phones to the Internet."
Required to take the name Sherpa on Nepalese passports, many have used the designation here on drivers' licenses and credit cards. But all Sherpas have other clan, village and family names.
Many Sherpas have clustered in the health-food store business and city construction work; some drive taxis and do domestic work and others toil here in the trekking business.
Mr. Sherpa Lama got his first job at a health food store in 1982 by offering to work free for two weeks. "After the second week," he said, "the owner began paying me and then asked if I knew any other Sherpas so he could hire them." He did and the owner did. Now Mr. Sherpa Lama is the manager of Healthy Pleasures, believed to be the largest health food store in the city, on University Place in Greenwich Village.
Although Sherpas' mountain upbringing stresses humble generosity, many express a pride that "we do things that others cannot do," as several Sherpas put it.
Their culture and Tibetan Buddhist religion have long attracted intense interest in the United States. "I think Americans have always been interested in the Tibetan peoples -- you know, the land of Shangri-La," said Dawa Tsering, the United States representative of the Dalai Lama. "But the 'Everest' film and the recent books, and movies like 'Kundun' and 'Seven Years in Tibet,' have created a new wave of interest in the culture and traditions."
Those traditions are up for grabs here and in Tibet, where "the Sherpas and Tibetans share a common danger that their culture is being assimilated," Mr. Tsering said.
This hardly seemed an issue at the Lhosar party in the Armenian Cathedral. Volunteers passed around plates of khapsey, sweet little New Year's cakes fried in butter. And hundreds of Sherpas imbibed chaang, a rice wine similar to sake.
Married women wore intricately colored pangden, traditional aprons of lamb's wool, and many women wore coral and agate "dze beads," necklaces passed from generation to generation, some of them worth tens of thousands of dollars. Soon, three dozen revelers joined in a rendition of "Happiness and Prosperity."
Their admirers wish them both. "You cannot but have a sense of awe about these indomitable mountain people who have been the backbone and engine of every Everest expedition since the 1920's," Mr. Breashears said. He employed 24 Sherpas during his ascent to the summit of Everest, and he was instrumental in organizing rescue efforts after the 1996 tragedy.
"I would trust them with my life," he said, "and have."

But the report noted some press self-censorship and said the administration continued to keep a close watch. (Reuters)

Canada Rules for Gay Rights
Canada's Supreme Court ruled that Alberta's human rights code must specifically protect homosexuals. The ruling was a triumph for Delwin Vriend, who lost his job as a college lab instructor because he was gay and was then told by Alberta's Human Rights Commission that he had no ground for a complaint. (AP)

HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES BUDGET BLUEPRINT CURBING TAX CUTS

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
After calming recalcitrant conservatives, the Senate tonight approved a Republican budget blueprint for the new fiscal year that would hold tax cuts to $30 billion over five years and reject nearly all of President Clinton's proposals for new spending.
The $1.73 trillion spending plan, approved on a near-party-line vote of 57 to 41, provides the chamber's guideline for spending and taxes for the 1999 fiscal year as the parties look for new footing in dealing with the first Federal budget surpluses to appear in a generation. 
 The week of debate -- and scores of amendment efforts -- leading to tonight's vote showcased not just the differences between the two political parties but also internal Republican divisions over how to approach fiscal policy in the new era of surpluses.
Conservative Republicans have sharply criticized the Senate for abandoning their party's signature issue of tax cutting at a moment when surpluses allow new boldness. Even Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, has said he would like to see at least $45 billion in tax cuts by the time the year's budget drafting is complete.
The passion for tax-cutting is running much higher in the House, where Republicans will be fighting in the November elections to keep majority control. The majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas has said the House would look for tax cuts in the range of $60 billion across five years when it starts assembling its budget proposal in late April or early May.
The two visions of the House and Senate will still have to be reconciled, and President Clinton has the power, should he choose, to veto the tax and spending bills that will be drafted this year to put the final budget plan into place.
The plan approved by the Senate reflects in part how successfully Mr. Clinton boxed in Republican tax cutters by calling in his budget for the preservation of surpluses until the nation agreed on a way to shore up the Social Security system, which will run short of money once the baby boom generation begins to retire early in the next century.
The Senate plan, drafted primarily by Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, accepted Mr. Clinton's call to protect the surplus. The plan envisions only slightly more in tax cuts than the $24 billion called for by Mr. Clinton in his own budget. It also projects steady surpluses beginning with $8 billion this year and growing to $59 billion in 2003.
But while Mr. Clinton counted on revenues from any tobacco settlement to pay for new programs in education, child care and health care, the Senate plan eliminates those initiatives and sets aside any tobacco money for Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly.
Mr. Domenici said Senate Republicans looked for what programs they thought most needed money.
"They are Social Security and the Medicare system," he said.
His stance would allow Republicans to head off traditional efforts by Democrats to campaign as the protectors of programs dear to retirees.
Democrats opposed the Senate plan after their effort to restore money for education, child care and health care initiatives failed in an afternoon of voting. Sounding likely election themes, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said the Republican budget said "no to education, no to child care, no to comprehensive solutions to teen smoking."
With Democrats planning to vote against the blueprint, Senator Lott, a Mississippi Republican, had to work to quell a brief rebellion by as many as six conservatives, led by Senator John Ashcroft, a Missouri Republican who is likely to seek his party's Presidential nomination. Seeking sweeping tax cuts, the Republican defectors could have handed their leaders an embarrassing defeat.
But the conservatives agreed to vote for the Senate plan after Republican leaders assured them that when it came time to negotiate the differences between the House and Senate the party would accept the proposal with the higher tax cuts. The rebels said that one of their group, Senator Rod Grams of Minnesota, was promised a seat on the committee that would reconcile the two proposals.
Voting for the measure were 54 Republicans and three Democrats, Senators Max Cleland of Georgia, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Charles Robb of Virginia. Senators Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Daniel Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, did not vote. All 41 other Democrats voted no.
How much of the Senate budget plan survives the next few months is far from clear. The Senate Commerce Committee has already come up with an alternate plan for using money from a tobacco settlement.
In the House, the chairman of the budget committee, Representative John Kasich, Republican of Ohio, has said he will use proceeds from a tobacco settlement to cut taxes. But the House's desire for tax-cutting has also been made more difficult by the passage tonight of a massive $217 billion public works bill that breaks the spending limits set in last year's balanced budget agreement by at least $26 billion.
After the two houses pass their budget resolutions, they have to reconcile the plans and then begin the months-long process of devising individual tax and spending bills that put the budget in place. The President cannot veto the budget plan but he can veto the individual bills.
No matter how much of the Senate budget plan is ultimately embraced, the week of voting on amendments allowed both parties to position themselves for the campaigns ahead. In one such nonbinding test vote, the Senate voted 59 to 48 today to support a Republican plan to cause the Federal income tax code to expire after 2001. The proposal also called for the revamping the Internal Revenue Service.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "At a Glance: Highlights of the Republicans' Budget"
These are the main provisions of the Senate budget plan:
 
SPENDING -- Would rise from $1.67 trillion in 1998 to $1.73 trillion in 1999 and to $1.95 trillion in 2003. Under President Clinton's plan, it would grow from $1.75 trillion in 1999 to $1.98 trillion in 2003.
SURPLUSES -- $8 billion in 1998, $8 billion in 1999, $59 billion in 2003. Mr. Clinton has projected surpluses of $4 billion in 1999, growing to $43 billion in 2003.
TAX CUTS -- At least $30 billion in tax cuts over the next five years. Mr. Clinton proposes $24 billion.
HIGHWAYS -- $26 billion in highway and mass transit spending beyond levels agreed to in the five-year balanced-budget deal.
PRESIDENT'S INITIATIVES -- It rejects plans to expand child care, hire teachers, build and repair schools and let people age 55 to 64 buy into Medicare.

HEADLINE: Why Literature Draws a Yawn;
Economic Realities

 BODY:

To the Editor:
If John M. Ellis (Op-Ed, March 28) would like to see more humanities majors, I suggest that he consider the financial realities of students' lives.
The students I teach in a community college in Southern California are not driven away from the liberal arts by trends in scholarship. What drives them away is a brief trip to the campus career center. There they compare the cost of transferring to a four-year university with the financial aid available (mostly loans), the salaries they can expect to earn and the majors that employers commonly require for entry-level positions. 
 Very few are willing to risk a major that virtually guarantees a more difficult job search -- and a lower income -- than one more obviously vocational.
 
KELLY FULLER
San Diego, March 29, 1998

HEADLINE: The Clintons as Teammates, Dovetailing in Africa

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: GOREE ISLAND, Senegal, April 2

 BODY:
Over the last 12 days, Bill and Hillary Clinton have treated Africans -- and Americans watching from home -- to a full dose of the buy-one-get-one-free Clinton partnership, sprinkling images of a fun-and-policy-loving First Couple across the continent.
This trip, which was longer in gestures than new proposals, was intended to produce a partnership "that will outlive my Presidency," Mr. Clinton said before flying home today. But the partnership most vividly spotlighted here was not between Africa and America but that of the Clintons. And it was shown to a degree not seen since Mrs. Clinton presided over her husband's failed health care plan in 1994. 
 Together, the Clintons danced with schoolchildren in a sun-splashed Ugandan meadow; together, they roamed the Kalahari, pointing out the big game to one another and merrily describing their adventures to reporters; and today, they stood hand-in-hand in a former slave house here, gazing somberly out through a gaping doorway at the gray Atlantic and the forced route of Africans to the New World.
Not just the symbol-conscious but the substantive Clinton & Clinton was on display today. This morning, the Clintons met in Dakar with activists from across Africa to discuss democracy and human rights. It was the last of what seemed an unbroken stream of transcontinental round-table talk, during which the Clintons discussed recovering from genocide with Rwandans, fighting poverty with South Africans, and protecting the environment with Botswanans.
"I look forward to the conversation," Mrs. Clinton said, in greeting the group today.
On this tour, one Clinton adviser said, "There's been one schedule, rather than two."
On Wednesday, the Clintons appeared in the isolated village of Dal Diam, swept with dust by the hot wind off the encroaching desert, to admire work done there over four years by the Agency for International Development and private groups: a well dug, cattle bought, reading taught, and a village store started with a small loan.
Taking a microphone to perform an introduction for the villagers, Mrs. Clinton referred to a song some of them had just sung. "I liked the song very much where he was called Hillary's husband," she said, "but, usually, we call him the President of the United States."
In return, Mr. Clinton, wearing an ankle-length silver gown over his shirt and tie, invoked his wife's book, "It Takes A Village," which took its title from an African proverb. "Your village has lifted our hearts," he told the crowd.
On Wednesday night, the Clintons received word that Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct case against the President had been thrown out. The news provided an unexpected personal and political lift, helping Mr. Clinton to return to the United States on a high note, his aides said. But for the most part, such matters did not intrude on the African trip; watching this couple tour Africa, one would have little idea that back in the United States, the husband was being buffeted with new charges of extramarital affairs, which the White House has angrily denied.
White House aides acknowledged that the Clinton partnership had been more visible in Africa than it had been since 1994. Mrs. Clinton kept a lower profile at home after the health care plan collapsed, concentrating on less hotly debated issues like foreign development and education. But in her foreign travels, Mrs. Clinton never stopped campaigning on behalf of women, declaring over and over that women's rights were also human rights.
Like the trip itself, the display of the strength of the Clintons' marriage came at a propitious time, with accusations about the President's personal conduct still at a boil in Washington despite the decision in the Paula Jones case. But White House advisers said Clinton & Clinton became more prominent on this trip simply because, in Africa, Mrs. Clinton's cherished issues moved to the fore. "She clearly has been a primary tutor of him" on Africa, said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary.
Mrs. Clinton, who traveled in Africa a year ago, lobbied her husband to make this trip and guided him to sites she visited before, like a South African housing cooperative and this small island of sandy lanes and pastel-colored colonial houses. "It was so important for her to have him do this," said one of her advisers.
Staff members who have watched the Clintons in private over the last two weeks said they continued their policy chatter away from the cameras, swapping impressions and ideas. "There are times you can see tension between them, when they're not agreeing," one Administration official said. But in Africa, this official added, "the two of them seem incredibly happy with each other."
As is generally the case abroad, Mrs. Clinton has been a political asset to the President here, partly because of her previous trip and her advocacy of foreign development. "Thanks for visiting us Hillary," read one sign in the Senegalese village on Wednesday.
The President has been invoking Mrs. Clinton since his arrival in Africa, in Ghana on March 23. "We need to come to know Africa as a place of new beginnings and ancient wisdom from which, as my wife, our First Lady, said in her book, we have so much to learn," he said in a speech to hundreds of thousands there.
Mrs. Clinton accompanied the President to nearly all of his public events. While she spoke at many of the same events as the President, Mrs. Clinton also spoke on her own, always to highlight women's issues. At a day care center in Ghana, she declared, "We must speak out to insure that no girl is ever denied an education" and "to end violence against women in all forms."
Today, Mrs. Clinton met with a group of activists here to condemn the practice of female genital cutting.
In the village of Dal Diam on Wednesday, the Clintons, in the presence of reporters, lingered despite staff protestations to have their pictures taken with the family of Amadou Sou, whose compound of thatched huts they were visiting. "Should we take pictures with each group?" Mrs. Clinton asked.
"We can if you like," Mr. Clinton replied.
With his wife beaming nearby, Mr. Clinton was then presented with a baby goat, which he cradled in his arms and kissed repeatedly on its forehead, baahing back as it cried to him. "What's the name of this goat?" he asked, and was told, inevitably, that it was Bill Clinton -- a Billy goat.
"You must take very good care of this goat!" Mrs. Clinton declared.
 
Clinton Returns to U.S.
 WASHINGTON, April 2 (Agence France-Presse) -- President Clinton returned to Washington from his 12-day tour of Africa, an official at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland said late tonight.
