HEADLINE: Companies Oppose Disclosure of Detail On Gifts to Charity

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
Big publicly held companies are bridling at proposed Federal legislation that would require them to disclose how much money they give individual charities, warning that such a law would have a chilling effect on corporate philanthropy.
In letters to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is studying the potential effect of the bill, dozens of companies and many not-for-profit organizations say that such a requirement would add costs and invite pressure from special interest groups and shareholders, both of which would result in less giving. 
 Disclosure "would dangerously expose corporate philanthropy to a broad range of special-interest groups, which could be expected to descend like locusts on such an opportunity to pursue their singularly focused agendas in this new arena," Federated Department Stores wrote in a typical letter.
Representative Paul E. Gillmor, Republican of Ohio, introduced the bill a year ago, but only in recent months has the request for comments from the S.E.C. drawn dozens of new letters, most of them critical of the bill. Representative Gillmor said that shareholders had a right to know how managers were distributing corporate assets and that disclosure would discourage managers from making hard-to-justify donations to pet charities. He added that his interest in the subject stemmed from many years of investing his own money and serving on the boards of several private companies, and that he had noticed a tendency on the part of some other companies' management to ignore shareholders.
Many experts in corporate law agree that companies should disclose their charitable donations. "The problem with today's corporate philanthropy is that it sometimes functions to promote and aggrandize corporate management, who generally take credit for the donations," wrote Charles M. Elson, a professor at Stetson University College of Law in St. Petersburg, Fla., which conducted a symposium on the topic in November. In cases where there is no clear benefit to the company, he added, "it is a waste of corporate property and constitutes self-dealing."
Companies donated $8.5 billion, or 5.6 percent of the $150.7 billion in total charitable donations in 1996, according to Giving USA, a report from the AAFRC Trust for Philanthropy, an arm of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel.
Many companies give through foundations, which offer tax benefits to the corporation, and details of those donations are disclosed in tax filings that are available to the public. Typically, though, companies make most of their donations to philanthropic organizations directly, and there is no requirement to disclose those gifts.
Whether companies should disclose their donations is part of a broad and long-running debate about the role of corporations in society.
Some economists and corporate executives believe, for example, that companies should give nothing to charities. They argue that the role of managers is to maximize returns for shareholders, who can then donate their money as they wish. They add that if top executives want to give to their favorite charities, they should use their own money, not that of their companies.
"Corporate charity exists so that C.E.O.'s can collect awards, plaques and honors, so they can sit on a dais and be adored," Albert J. Dunlap, chairman of the Sunbeam Corporation, wrote in his book "Mean Business" (Simon & Schuster, 1996). "That is not what the shareholder is paying them a million bucks a year -- plus stock options and bonuses -- to do!"
But many executives say that corporate contributions are both good business and are a hallmark of corporate citizenship. Computer manufacturers and software companies like I.B.M. and Microsoft, for example, donate tens of millions of dollars' worth of products each year to schools, both to improve the quality of technology education and to attract new customers.
Many companies have also long embraced the notion that they have a duty to many "stakeholders" beyond their investors -- including the communities in which they operate.
"Corporate contributions often represent the key to new approaches for community problems," the CSX Corporation wrote in one of more than 180 letters submitted to the S.E.C. by a variety of companies, organizations and individuals. Its donations, the transportation company noted, have included seed money for a program to help recovering drug users in Richmond, where it is based. CSX wrote that it was opposed to the disclosure bill because the total amounts of its charitable giving were not material to the corporation's business, and therefore shareholders would not benefit by having the information disclosed to them.
Yet while many companies told the S.E.C. of their pride in their charitable programs, almost all, for a variety of reasons, denounced Representative Gillmor's suggestion that they disclose them to shareholders.
Some said such contributions were business decisions best left to management. One company, Anheuser- Busch, said disclosure would give competitors insight into its strategy.
One commonly mentioned concern is that such a requirement would create a costly administrative burden to gather the information and that those costs would come out of their donations. Proponents of the bill and many corporate executives noted that companies already gathered the data for tax deductions.
Another concern cited by many companies was that disclosure would provide new fodder to special-interest groups. Some corporate gifts have drawn criticism from advocacy groups in the past. In 1990, for example, the AT&T Corporation ended 25 years of donations by its foundation to Planned Parenthood, a decision prompted largely by a letter-writing campaign and boycott threat by anti-abortion groups.
The Capital Research Center, a conservative group in Washington, has for years studied data disclosed by companies about their charitable giving. It concluded after analyzing data gathered from 142 large companies that they gave three-and-a-half times as much to what it termed "liberal and left-of-center advocacy groups" as to "right-of-center and pro-free market groups." The center's latest findings were detailed in its 1996 book "Patterns of Corporate Philanthropy," the subtitle of which is "Funding Enemies, Forsaking Friends."
Many not-for-profit organizations wrote to the S.E.C. to express concern that the bill, if it became law, would prompt companies to pull back from contributing to smaller organizations in favor of national charities less likely to stir controversy. "Just because all stockholders do not see the value to the community of some causes does not mean that they should not be funded," wrote Sharon M. Gilbert, executive director of the Caring Place, which assists victims of domestic violence and sexual abuse in Valparaiso, Ind.
Sometimes, though, disclosure has allowed shareholders to police what they consider excesses in corporate largess. In 1988, for example, Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, announced that he intended to build a museum to house his well-known art collections. Only later did Occidental shareholders learn that tens of millions of company dollars were used for construction. Many shareholders filed lawsuits against the company, which Occidental settled in part by placing a cap on contributions to any charities affiliated with Dr. Hammer.
Nor was that the only case of shareholders objecting to a corporation's donations. In 1995, Merck & Company announced that it would donate $20 million over 10 years to the United Negro College Fund, of which Merck's chairman continues to be a director. The next year, Alan M. Rice, a shareholder, placed a resolution in Merck's proxy that would have required shareholder approval for any donation over about $25,000. The measure won little support.
"This has nothing to do with the merits of the college fund, nor is it about race," Mr. Rice, a full-time investor, said in a telephone interview. "But it has everything to do with propriety of making such a sizable donation to a single charity."
Many companies wrote to the S.E.C. that legislation was unnecessary because they provided detailed information about their contributions to anyone who requested it. Some companies even publicize the data in annual reports or on the Internet. The J. C. Penney Company, for example, provides details in its 1996 annual report about the $30.7 million it gave away that year. And Chevron publishes information on its Web site about the approximately $25 million it donates each year. Both companies said that shareholders had never complained about their donations.
But such policies are far from universal. Some investors complained to the S.E.C. that all their efforts to get such information were turned away. One company mentioned in those letters, Delmarva Power and Light, which is now known as Connectiv, said it was not the utility's policy to disclose the data.
"While you have to respect the interests of one investor, we do have a board of directors that looks after the interests of all the shareholders," said Michael Ratchford, a spokesman for the utility.
Although they were in the minority, some companies and charities did write in support of Representative Gillmor's bill. The American Red Cross, for example, said that it supported disclosure as a matter of public policy. The National Society of Fund Raising Executives said disclosure would improve the credibility of the philanthropic community, which has been hurt in recent years by scandals involving top executives of organizations like the United Way of America.
Strong support for disclosure came from Warren E. Buffett, the investor and chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, who wrote that he thinks managers "should be held accountable for the charitable dollars they dispense."
Berkshire Hathaway is unusual in that it lets shareholders pick which charities will receive their respective share of the money the company sets aside each year for donations.
Representative Gillmor introduced a second bill last year that would give shareholders a similar right at all publicly held companies, though he acknowledged that such a system might be unworkable for most large companies, which typically have far more shareholders than Berkshire Hathaway. Indeed, in their comments to the S.E.C., most corporations were sharply critical of that proposal.
In any event, Representative Gillmor, who is vice chairman of the House Commerce Committee, said his real focus was on disclosure. "I don't think companies get much sympathy if they can't defend what they're doing with shareholders' money," he said. His disclosure bill is co-sponsored by Representative Michael G. Oxley, Republican of Ohio, and Representative Thomas Manton, Democrat of New York.
Part of the controversy surrounding the bill stems from its intentionally vague wording, which raises the possibility that donations to "local charities" could be exempted from disclosure but fails to precisely define a local charity. Nor does the bill set a minimum for the size of donations that would have to be disclosed.
The S.E.C. is considering such details now and is expected to file a report to Congress later this year. Although the official comment period on the disclosure bill has ended, the S.E.C. said it was still accepting letters on the issue.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Tracking the '68 Parallels Of King and Kennedy

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
The public journeys of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy come together tomorrow in "Assassinated: The Last Days of King and Kennedy." As the unequaled black leader and the untested white politician moved toward their early deaths, they found themselves united in the causes of peace, racial equality and economic uplift.
The men emerge through the memories of those who worked with them, were inspired by them, loved them. They may not be the coolest historians, but for millions of others, too, King and Kennedy represented a hope of reconciliation even as the nation seemed to be unraveling. This first documentary by Oliver Stone's new television production team establishes their place amid the drama and turmoil of the times. (Rest easy; despite Mr. Stone's reputation, no conspiracy theories are promoted in these two hours.) 
 Moving back and forth between King and Kennedy, "Assassination" brings back the events that shook the nation and transformed the men: the murder of John F. Kennedy; the war in Vietnam; the race riots. As the war kept escalating, King divided the civil rights movement by attacking the Johnson Administration. Robert Kennedy found his cause in visits to impoverished sections of Mississippi.
From family members, we get King's shifting moods of exhilaration at the victories of nonviolence and depression at mob riots, and Kennedy's energy and passion once he was caught up in a cause. If King was a prophet, Kennedy was a crusader. The young politician's calculations for entering the 1968 Democratic primaries are played down by these friendly observers; his aspirations to moral leadership are emphasized and perhaps exaggerated.
The documentary is particularly sharp at catching the perilous times, the high emotions, the craziness in the air. Both men knew the risks they courted in their public appearances. Warned of threats, Kennedy insisted on carrying on with his Presidential campaign. King's reflections turned to mortality; in a famous speech that only increases in power with the years, he tells his followers of seeing the promised land: "I may not get there with you."
In the program's inspiring ending, Kennedy is seen walking behind the mule wagon in the King funeral procession. A few weeks later, mourners are lined up along the 200-mile train route of his own last journey.
A mourner for both men says, "Suddenly within a few weeks the two bright lights that were shining in this country had gone out, and hell, we were in the dark."

HEADLINE: Oscar Awards to Get Their Own Theater

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, April 3

 BODY:
A permanent home for the Academy Awards show has been announced by Mayor Richard J. Riordan and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
The 3,300-seat theater, designed by the New York architect David Rockwell, is to be in the heart of Hollywood, on Hollywood Boulevard and Highland Avenue. It is part of a $350 million development project by the TrizecHahn Corporation that is to include restaurants and retail stores. Groundbreaking is scheduled for this summer, although the complex does not have all the permits it needs to go forward. Mayor Riordan said he hoped the new theater would be ready by 2001. 
 "I'm proud to welcome the Academy Awards back to their birthplace, he said on Thursday at a news conference at the Hollywood Roosevelt, where the academy had its first awards dinner on May 16, 1929. He added: "Hollywood is not just back. It's better."
Since their founding, the Academy Awards have had no permanent site, switching in recent years between the Shrine Auditorium, near the University of Southern California campus, in South-Central Los Angeles, and the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in downtown Los Angeles. Academy officials said there was a possibility that the new theater would also be used for theatrical shows like Broadway musicals.
Mr. Rockwell's company, the Rockwell Group, is known for its entertainment architecture and the notion of architecture as theater. Clients have included Disney, Sony, Radio City Music Hall and the Bronx Zoo and restaurants like Nobu, Vong and the Monkey Bar.
The Hollywood Boulevard area, once glamorous, has been crumbling in recent years, resembling the Times Square area in the 1970's and 80's before its recent redevelopment. Los Angeles officials have pointed to $1 billion in planned development in Hollywood as part of the effort to revive the area. They say the Academy Awards theater is a further sign of that planned revival.
"This is a historic day, the beginning of a new era in Hollywood history," Robert Rehme, president of the academy, said shortly after the announcement.
Although more city approvals are needed, Mr. Riordan and Councilwoman Jackie Goldberg, who represents the area, said that they expected no major opposition.

HEADLINE: From the Ground Up in East New York

BYLINE: By Samuel G. Freedman; Samuel G. Freedman is the author of "Upon This Rock: The Miracles of a Black Church."

 BODY:
Nearly 20 years ago, a visiting mayor walked through the slums of Brooklyn's Brownsville neighborhood. The abandoned blocks along one main street, Blake Avenue, were lined with fields of scrub grass and saplings. Concrete blocks and plywood planks boarded up the few tenements along the fringes to keep out vandals, squatters and thugs. "I have seen," the mayor declared, "the beginning of the end of our civilization."
Those same streets today throb with life -- life restored by tidy row houses built under the Nehemiah program, which makes home ownership affordable for the teachers, parole officers, subway motormen, nurse's aides and other members of the nonwhite working and middle classes. Why, then, is Mayor Rudolph Giuliani preventing this urban renewal from spreading to other parts of New York? 
 The Nehemiah program has erected more than 2,700 homes in Brownsville, East New York and the South Bronx over the last 15 years -- with the foundation already laid on 300 more -- and it has done so with only a small proportion of public money. Religious organizations and socially aware banks have lent the entire $12 million construction fund.
So one might assume that Mr. Giuliani would gladly honor his own administration's commitment to spend $10 million on building sewers in the undeveloped Spring Creek area of East New York, which would allow the construction of 500 more Nehemiah homes. But Mr. Giuliani has cut the development of Spring Creek out of the budget, even though that $10 million, plus another $10 million already pledged by the city to subsidize construction, would have the potential to generate $46 million worth of private houses, which in turn could bring the city millions of dollars in property taxes.
Evidently, it matters little to Mr. Giuliani that the Nehemiah homes embody the values of religious belief and social conservatism -- ideals he espouses.
The Nehemiah program is run by local affiliates of the Industrial Areas Foundation, which since the days of its founder, Saul Alinsky, has been based in urban churches. To the consternation of more leftist community groups, the Alinsky organization embraces the virtues of piety, property and familial obligation. And a sizable share of Nehemiah homeowners have moved directly out of public housing, a symbol of the failures of big-government liberalism.
The Nehemiah program relies on the city and state only to provide subsidies and low-interest mortgages and to condemn and clear property. A Nehemiah home costs one-third less per square foot and uses a smaller public subsidy than houses built by the New York City Partnership, a much-ballyhooed nonprofit group.
The city government owes its citizens the rejuvenation of slums it played a part in creating. Not only the ravages of street crime and drug abuse turned Blake Avenue from a vital enclave of the working poor into a miserable ghetto. Changes in public policy in the 1960's meant that welfare families were dumped into a neighborhood already unsettled by sudden integration. In the 1970's, under the policy of "planned shrinkage," the city reduced municipal services, driving away decent families.
The Nehemiah program, supported by the administration of Edward Koch, helped return a measure of stability and social order to Blake Avenue and its like. In budgeting the $10 million that will allow ground to be broken in Spring Creek, Mayor Giuliani could continue this legacy and elevate New York's quality of life in a way that is literally and figuratively concrete.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Crosses 9,000 for the First Time, Then Backs Away

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average passed 9,000 points yesterday before retreating and ending slightly lower as investors took profits.
The Dow, which rose as high as 9,030.49, closed down 3.23 points, at 8,983.41. For the week, the Dow was up 2.1 percent. 
 Weighing on the Dow were Chevron, which dropped 1 1/2, to 8115/16 . Procter & Gamble fell 17/16 , to 88 1/8, and Eastman Kodak dropped 1 13/16, to 64 9/16 .
But broader market measures eked out small gains and finished at record highs. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.69 points, to 1,122.70, and the New York Stock Exchange composite gained 1.04, to 583.08. Although the gains in technology stocks were modest, the Nasdaq composite index, which is laden with technology issues, edged up 2.44, to a record 1,855.40.
The market opened modestly higher this morning, quickly gaining enough momentum to cross through the 9,000 milestone. But the Dow ran into some resistance.
"It looks like it's having some trouble with the 9,000 number," said Jim Benning, a trader at BT Brokerage. "I think it's just a question of someone seeing a round number and saying it's time to take some profits."
The stock market was bolstered by the March employment report, which suggested that the job market was cooling down. The data pointed to continued restrained inflation and steady interest rates.
The Labor Department reported that employers cut payrolls by 36,000 last month, the first decline since January 1996, and much less than the 235,000 gain that economists expected.
"We had pretty good economic news here this morning, and we're dealing with the psychological barrier of 9,000," said Bill Allyn, director of listed equity trading at Jefferies & Company in Short Hills, N.J. "We're going to get through it. I just think there's going to be some backing and filling before we do get through. There's no reason other than profit taking for it to be down."

Treasury Prices Surge
Treasury securities rallied sharply yesterday on news of the surprising drop in employment last month.
"The jobs report is likely to convert many Asian-slowdown disbelievers into ardent supporters of this view and ignite fresh hope that the central bank is not likely to even think of raising rates any time soon," said Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio.
Indeed, Mr. Chan said, Fed policy makers are now likely "to open debate on when, not if, they should consider lowering short-term rates."
The price of the 30-year bond rose 23/32 , to 104 23/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 5.79 percent, from 5.84 percent on Thursday -- the lowest since 5.79 percent on Feb. 17.
Jack Ablin, president of Barnett Capital Advisors Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla., said market concerns heading into the second quarter had been over the Asian crisis and wage pressures. "The issue the market needed to grapple with was whether the Asian crisis was going to be enough to help offset the wage and inflation pressures we were facing," he said. "To date, while the Asia situation is still there, the employment numbers today went a long way to alleviate those concerns."
Elsewhere in the market, in when-issued trading yesterday ahead of next week's $8 billion auction of 30-year inflation indexed bonds on Wednesday, the bonds were being offered at a price to yield 3.64 percent, down 3 basis points from the previous day. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: U.N. Teams Find Nothing At Iraqi Sites

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 3

 BODY:
United Nations arms experts inspected each of the 1,058 buildings inside President Saddam Hussein's eight presidential compounds but found no prohibited material during eight days of searches, an American weapons inspector said today.
The inspectors, however, had not expected to find much at the sites and repeatedly said they wanted to set a precedent of entering sites that Iraq had long said were off limits as symbols of national sovereignty. 
 The visits, which began on March 26, were a key test of the accord between the United Nations and Iraq intended to "establish our right to unrestricted access," said Charles Duelfer, the deputy chairman of the United Nations Special Commission, which is charged with dismantling Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.
Iraq said the fact that nothing was found contradicted American and British accusations that the sites contained stockpiles of illegal weapons. It urged the Security Council to lift the sweeping United Nations sanctions imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990.
"What has been achieved is a triumph for the truth over falsehood," Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz was quoted as saying by the official Iraqi News Agency. "The visit has verified Iraq's credibility."
The work of the inspectors at other, less sensitive sites is far from over. Richard Butler, the chief arms inspector, has said Iraq still needs to provide more proof to back its claim that it has destroyed all of its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons.
Until the inspectors confirm that Iraq has destroyed or has dismantled all its long-range missiles and major weapons, the Security Council will not lift the economic sanctions.
The inspections began with a visit to the Radwaniyah palace in Baghdad. They continued in the north and south and ended in the capital with inspections on Wednesday and Thursday of the Sijood Palace and the Republican Palace, which serves as the seat of Government.
Most of the buildings were empty except for a few in the main Republican Palace compound, Mr. Duelfer said. There, inspectors came across furniture and office supplies, he said, but he declined to be more specific.
Mr. Duelfer also refused to speculate on why the buildings were bare. But Iraqi officials said many of the buildings were emptied months ago when tension rose over Iraq's refusal to grant access to the palaces and Iraq feared an attack on the sites.
The 71 United Nations arms monitors who took part in the survey had "access to every building that we wanted," Mr. Duelfer said.
The most sensitive site was the Republican Palace, a one-square-mile compound that houses Mr. Hussein's main office, overlooking the Tigris River.
The Iraqis opened parts of the compound only to Mr. Duelfer, two other senior arms experts and Jayantha Dhanapala, the leader of a diplomatic group monitoring the visits, Mr. Duelfer said.
High-ranking Iraqi officials, including Mr. Aziz, were present during most of the inspections, he added.
Under the agreement, reached on Feb. 23, Mr. Dhanapala's diplomatic group had to escort the inspectors, who spent about 10 hours at each site. Mr. Duelfer said their presence was essential to solving "a number of problems," but he did not elaborate.
The United Nations Secretary General's envoy in Baghdad, Prakash Shah, said that "some blips did occur" during the inspections, but that they were sorted out in the presence of the diplomats.
The diplomats are to leave Baghdad on Saturday after completing a report that Mr. Dhanapala will submit to Secretary General Kofi Annan in New York next week. The inspectors are also to leave on Saturday, and no date has been announced for future visits.
Mr. Butler is to present a progress report to the Council next week.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Rises (With an Asterisk)

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
After months in overdrive, the great American jobs engine seems suddenly to be idling.
In March, for the first time in more than two years, the economy added no new jobs, the Labor Department reported yesterday. Payrolls actually edged down by 36,000 jobs, and the unemployment rate, which had been at a 24-year low, ticked up from 4.6 percent, to 4.7 percent. The department also reported that February's stunning job gain was revised sharply downward. 
 Even though most economists were expecting job growth to moderate, the sharply different job market picture conveyed by yesterday's report caught them by complete surprise.
The Labor Department warned, however, that the report was somewhat suspect. Last month's dip in jobs -- the first since January 1996, when snowstorms shut down businesses in the Northeast -- may reflect the abnormal weather patterns of the last few months more than actual changes in the labor market. Unseasonable cold during the survey period last month, following unusually warm temperatures in January and February, may have skewed the seasonal adjustments the Labor Department makes to raw job survey figures.
Katherine Abraham, Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said, "There's a lot in this report that you have to discount."
The jobs report nonetheless warmed the hearts of investors who welcome any sign that the labor market is finally cooling. The economy had been adding jobs at a pace of more than 300,000 a month, fanning fears that the economy was running out of workers and the Federal Reserve would move to raise interest rates.
Now, such threats seem more remote and stock and bond prices responded accordingly. Stocks finished mostly higher, while a rally in bonds pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury to 5.79 percent, the lowest since Feb. 17.
"It's further reason for the Fed to do what it does best: absolutely nothing," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI.
On the other hand, few believe that the job market is cooling as abruptly as the Labor Department's data seemed to imply.
"This is nothing to worry about," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch.
Just as El Nino and unseasonably warm temperatures in January and February exaggerated the job market's strength in the winter, the unseasonable cold is probably exaggerating the weakness now.
"Large numbers of construction workers normally are laid off during the November-to-February period," Dr. Abraham said. "During the recent winter, however, fewer workers than normal were laid off. With so many construction jobs already filled, early spring hiring fell short of its usual pace."
Job growth averaged 205,000 jobs a month in the quarter ended March. That was not as strong as the 356,000 rate of last quarter of 1997, but it was still robust by any measure.
"We're still probably growing above trend," said President Clinton's chief economist, Janet L. Yellen. Like most private forecasters, she said, the Council of Economic Advisers expects job growth to be more moderate than last year. "As we go toward the end of the year we'll be looking at numbers more in the 100's," she said. "We've gotten a little spoiled." A pace of 125,000 new jobs or so a month would keep the jobless rate about where it is now.
The Labor Department reported that in March, after seasonal adjustment, 88,000 jobs were lost in construction, 43,000 in restaurants and 16,000 in temporary-help firms. Business tells a different story.
Mitchell Fromstein, head of Manpower Inc., the largest temporary-help service, confirmed this. "The demand for people is still very high at every level," he said. "We don't sense any downturn in our business."
Similarly, home building and office construction are still booming. "We've had more and more reports from builders that their big problem is finding qualified labor," said Michael Carliner at the National Association of Home Builders. "We have no inclination that there's been a decline in employment."
And while McDonald's recently announced that it would invest in labor-saving technology and Pepsi is spinning off its restaurant chains, help wanted signs are still much in evidence at drive-in counters around the country.
Indeed, the National Federation of Independent Business, which issued its monthly survey yesterday, still reports that the No. 1 problem facing small businesses is finding qualified workers. Twenty-eight percent of the respondents, a near record, said that they had job openings they could not fill.
The Labor Department reported strong job gains in computer and data processing, engineering and management services and financial services, which are benefiting from a boom in home buying and stock investing.
Manufacturing hiring remained surprisingly strong, suggesting that the Asian crisis has not yet made its full impact felt. Manufacturing employment, vulnerable to weakness in Asian markets and more intense competition from Asian imports, actually rose by 3,000 last month.
Total hours worked declined 0.7 percent from February. But, for the quarter, they were still 4.9 percent above the previous quarter's level. That suggests that economic growth in the first three months this year was fairly solid.
Despite the rise in unemployment, there were still classic signs of tightness in the labor market. Long-term unemployment -- defined as joblessness among those who are out of work for 27 weeks or longer -- was at its lowest since the current economic expansion began in 1991. And the average duration of unemployment declined sharply, from 7.2 weeks, to 6.8 weeks.
Hourly earnings rose 4 cents last month, to $12.63. But the previous month's increase, originally reported as 8 cents, was revised down to 6 cents. "Wages aren't accelerating as fast as was feared," Mr. Wyss said.

HEADLINE: Campaign Ad By Kennelly Stresses Schools

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 3

 BODY:
With education emerging as the pivotal issue in the state elections this year, United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, a Democrat running for governor, has made "Education comes first" the slogan of her campaign's first television commercial, which began appearing today.
The 60-second advertisement tries to define the candidate while focusing on an issue on which Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, appears to be vulnerable. With crime rates going down and the economy improving, education stands out as an issue that can benefit a challenger. 
 "I've taught my four children that education was the key to success," Mrs. Kennelly, who has served eight terms in the House, said in the ad. "I've spent a career working to improve education, and as your governor, I'll make our education system the model for the country."
Mr. Rowland's campaign disputed this image of Mrs. Kennelly. "Her sudden interest in education is very interesting given her lack of interest in the past," said Fergus P. Cullen, Mr. Rowland's deputy campaign manager. "In 16 years, Barbara Kennelly introduced not one piece of legislation having to deal with primary or secondary education."
But in a news release accompanying the text of the commercial, the Kennelly campaign described a record of efforts to improve education. It said that Mrs. Kennelly, 61, had worked to obtain more money for Head Start, lobbied for increased Internet access for classrooms and fought for President Clinton's effort to reduce class sizes in early grades.
Records from three Connecticut television stations showed that Mrs. Kennelly spent at least $81,700 to have the commercial televised through April 13. The amount would pay for roughly 50 spots, and it could increase in the next few days if the campaign elects to buy even more television time.
The broadcast of the commercial is another sign that the governor's race here remains competitive, one of the few such races this year in which a Republican incumbent faces a serious challenge. Although polls show Mr. Rowland with a substantial lead, his position is not as strong as those of Republican incumbents like Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, said Jennifer Duffy, an analyst with the Cook Political Report, a nonpartisan newsletter in Washington that handicaps races.
The commercial was a critical step for Mrs. Kennelly. Mr. Rowland began advertising about five months ago and has widened his lead since last fall, when he and Mrs. Kennelly were in a virtual dead heat in polls.
A Quinnipiac College poll of 1,014 Connecticut residents who said they were registered voters was released Wednesday, and it showed that 55 percent supported Mr. Rowland and 31 percent supported Mrs. Kennelly. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
The poll also found that about 4 of every 10 of those polled said they had not heard enough about Mrs. Kennelly to form an opinion. The ad was clearly intended to change that.
Mrs. Kennelly narrates the ad, talking about the need for smaller and safer classes, tougher academic standards, greater classroom access to the Internet and college scholarships for all students who graduate in the top fifth of their class.
The commercial makes no mention of Mr. Rowland.

HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY TO DESPOTISM: A special report.;
Nigeria, in Free Fall, Seethes Under General

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ABUJA, Nigeria

 BODY:
From the eerily calm streets of this newly created capital, a visitor might be excused for concluding that Nigeria's President, Gen. Sani Abacha, is a revered figure.
Army officers and office workers alike sport lapel pins bearing the likeness of the general, smiling benignly, but as always peering at the world from behind tinted glasses. Billboards proclaim "Abacha Is the Answer!" And a proliferation of street names, housing developments and public works projects carry the name of the President or his wife, Maryam. 
 Few Nigerians would openly contest this carefully created image of adulation, especially in this minutely policed town, where any conversation might be monitored, where plainclothes agents haunt every hotel and restaurant, and where crack troops are never more than a moment's call away.
But it takes little time to discover, in talks with dozens of Nigerians from the streets of Lagos to cities like Abuja and Enugu in central and southeastern Nigeria, that the people of this country, Africa's most populous, are seething with discontent.
"The generals seem to want to stay in power forever," said Adimabua Obafemi, an angry motorist in Lagos who had spent the night in his car waiting for gasoline because of an acute shortage in one of the world's largest oil-producing nations. "Some of us would gladly grant them that if they could point to one thing they have done for this country. All they have proven is that they know how to arrest people and to steal."
General Abacha, 54, seized power in 1993, at the head of the third successful army coup in which he had played a key role. His predecessor had annulled an election widely believed to be the most democratic vote ever organized in Nigeria. The general jailed the presumed winner, suspended the Constitution and declared a state of emergency. He pledged that he would hand over power to a civilian government, and even set a date to do so.
But he has violated that promise and is now poised to become the elected President in carefully scripted elections set for Aug. 1, running against two little known candidates who many Nigerians suspect were encouraged by the military to provide symbolic opposition.
He will win not because he is widely popular, Nigerians and diplomats say, but because he exercises absolute control through a reign of terror.
General Abacha has detained, jailed and on occasion executed most of the leading Nigerians who could form a credible opposition, including members of his own Government. Many prominent Nigerians, from journalists and Nobel Prize-winning authors to dignitaries of past governments, have been forced into exile.
He operates a 2,000-man personal security service that inspires deep fear. Nigerian rights groups charge that more people have been arrested in his four years in power than during five decades of British rule.
In the 1980's Nigeria was hailed as a model of African democracy and prosperity. But now it is a country in steep decline. Electricity and water supplies in most cities are unreliable at best. Unemployment, though difficult to measure, is sky-high, and inflation has reduced the purchasing power of most people to bare subsistence.
Nigerians who look back over a history dominated since independence by military rule often remark that there has never been a leader like General Abacha.
 Inaccessible even to his own ministers and senior army staff, the President rarely ventures out of his marbled official mansion, known as Aso Rock. He is said to work through the night and sleep much of the day, summoning officials only as he needs them.
Obsession with security to the point of paranoia is another watchword of General Abacha's rule. While Lagos, the bursting-at-the-seams former capital, remains a place of surprisingly outspoken criticism, Abuja is heavily guarded by soldiers and thoroughly policed by plainclothes agents.
To help guarantee his control, General Abacha commands his own parallel security service. These Special Bodyguards, who diplomats say were trained by North Korean and Libyan experts, fall outside the normal army chain of command, answering directly to the President and a single trusted aide, Maj. Hamza el-Mustapha.
"The thing that distinguishes Nigeria is the extent to which this is a military regime unlike any other," said Walter Carrington, until last year the United States Ambassador. "Abacha has less support than any previous military leader, but he manages to run things tightly."
 
A Precipitous Turn
Liberty and Riches Quickly Fell Apart
Beyond the artificial calm of Abuja, Nigerians say that by almost any measure, General Abacha's rule has been an unmitigated disaster for a country accustomed to thinking of itself as Africa's richest and most powerful nation.
Rebounding quickly from a devastating civil war that nearly broke up Nigeria in the late 1960's, in the space of 10 years the country became a confident and even boastful society eager to claim what its leaders liked to say was the rightful place on the international stage for the "world's largest black nation."
Of its own accord, Nigeria was experimenting with one of the most freewheeling versions of democracy in modern Africa. Nigerian arts were the envy of the continent. Its press was among the freest anywhere.
Nigerian diplomacy, strengthened by the nation's emergence as a leading oil producer, forcefully challenged the United States and Britain over issues like apartheid and support for guerrillas in Angola.
Nigeria in the oil boom of the 1970's had the 33d-highest per-capita income in the world, but by last year it slipped to the 13th-poorest nation, according to United Nations figures. At the same time, foreign diplomats and Nigerian critics of military rule say the top generals have siphoned off billions of dollars in oil revenue for personal profit.
In the late 1970's, the national currency, the naira, was worth twice as much as the dollar. Nowadays, it is worth about one cent. In business surveys, the country ranks as one of the most corrupt.
Nigeria's economic decline may have begun with the shoddy management and corruption of the democratic period, which lasted only from 1979 to 1983. But the country's free fall began in earnest under the generals who seized power promising to set things right.
With its large army, Nigeria still throws its weight around its immediate region, but its interventions in Liberia and Sierra Leone have been supported only grudgingly by neighbors, which shudder at the risk of a political breakup of Nigeria.
"It is not because we like what is going on in Nigeria that we try to be supportive," said one senior official in Ghana, Nigeria's closest friend in the region. "But if things start to fall apart in Nigeria, we and every other country in this region will be submerged with their people fleeing and their problems."
 
A Security State
Enemy List Reads Like a Who's Who
The list of supposed enemies who have been neutralized during General Abacha's rule reads like a Who's Who of distinguished Nigerians. In 1995, the President announced that he had uncovered a plot involving a past military President, Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, and his Vice President, Gen. Shehu Musa Yar'Adua -- both long retired from the army. General Obasanjo is a respected figure who handed power over to a democratically elected government
Few foreign diplomats or well-informed Nigerians give any credence to the charges, but say General Abacha is haunted by the specter of a coup and is intolerant of anyone who could cast a shadow over him.
Starting with the imprisonment of the presumed winner of the country's 1993 elections, General Abacha's rule has been widely seen as the expression of hard-line northern military elite bent on maintaining its longtime hold on the country's politics.
General Obasanjo, a Yoruba who is the only southerner to have enjoyed executive power in the country, was a logical target, given his criticism of General Abacha's rule.
General Yar'Adua, however, was a member of a distinguished northern elite family, and even in retirement enjoyed the strong respect of northern officers and politicians. His fate was sealed when, as a leading member of General Abacha's Constitutional Conference, he pushed for an early handover date to civilian rule and for other restrictions on the President's power.
When he convened the conference in 1994, General Abacha pledged to the delegates, "We in the present Government in Nigeria are committed to ensuring that there is speedy and uninterrupted transition to a civil democratic rule in which we shall not be participants."
General Yar'Adua, who was the first prominent convention member to warn that these goals were being subverted, died in detention on Dec. 6. Human rights groups and newspaper reports here said he had repeatedly been refused medical care.
A leading human rights lobbyist, Beko Ransome-Kuti, was arrested in the same purported plot and remains in jail, as do several journalists, including Chris Anyanwu, who was convicted of being an accessory to the plotters after publishing articles debunking the idea of a conspiracy.
Meanwhile, the presumed winner of the elections of 1993, Moshood K. O. Abiola, remains in detention, largely shut off from visitors. Mr. Abiola's senior wife, Kudirat, who was an outspoken critic of the Government, was gunned down in Lagos in an execution-style killing in June 1996 that has gone unclaimed and unpunished.
A few months earlier another prominent critic of the Government, the noted playwright and community rights advocate, Ken Saro-Wiwa, was executed on charges stemming from his campaign to have Nigeria's huge oil revenues shared with the communities where petroleum is produced.
"Can you mention one constituency that Abacha has not offended?" asked Kola Ilori, an editor of the weekly Tell. "Abacha has desecrated the military, he has desecrated the office of head of state, he has mercilessly persecuted the south, but he has also deeply offended the north. It is hard to see how a man like that could safely retire."
Like many other newspapers and magazines, Tell is no longer published out of a conventional office, but instead holds clandestine editorial meetings in mosques, churches and taxis so its editors and reporters can avoid the constant threat of arrest.
On Dec. 21, General Abacha's purges reached his own innermost circle, with the arrest of his own second-in-command, Lieut. Gen. Oladipo Diya, the last senior southerner in the ruling military council, on charges of plotting a coup. Dozens of other officers, many of them Yoruba, were also held.
The extraordinary extent of the President's security apparatus became widely known for the first time when, reacting to widespread doubts that there was a coup plot at all, the Government arranged special screenings for selected traditional leaders, diplomats and journalists of scores of audio and video tapes painstakingly recorded over a period of weeks in which the alleged conspirators could be seen or heard discussing General Abacha's overthrow.
In one of the tapes, a sobbing General Diya can be seen begging, prostrate at General Abacha's feet, to spare his life.
By the opening of his trial, however, a composed General Diya was accusing his accusers of concocting a fake coup in order to entrap him and scores of other officers distrusted by General Abacha.
"This is a clear case of setup," General Diya said. "I am the target, and it is organized right from the top." From that point, the trial, which was recently concluded, was conducted behind closed-doors.
Those who have seen them say the tapes suggest that there may indeed have been a plot against General Abacha.
 
Manipulating the Vote
Opponents Survive Steamroller Tactics
Not even open fissures in his army appear to have deterred General Abacha from a program that seems determined to insure that the general succeeds himself in the elections this year. Throughout his rule, Nigeria has been under limited economic sanctions imposed by the United States and others, and an election victory could give him an argument to bolster his regime's legitimacy..
In addition to Abacha lapel pins, now considered obligatory for army officers, the President's campaign has begun distributing deeply discounted color television sets and sacks of rice emblazoned with the general's name and image.
New publications have begun weaving tales of the miraculous birth and heroic deeds of the President, while billboards bearing the slogan "Abacha Is the Answer" have been cropping up here and in other cities.
In recent weeks, well-funded groups sporting names like Youths Earnestly Ask for Abacha have begun organizing rallies seeking to create the appearance of a popular draft. One of the marches flopped badly, however, when after promising to turn out two million people with the help of hired buses and free food and drink, fewer than 100,000 people showed up in Abuja.
When opponents of General Abacha from a variety of political and rights groups began organizing a countermarch in Lagos the next week, the Government responded by banning "unauthorized" political gatherings and dispatched rapid-response police units known as "kill and go" squads to patrol the streets.
"We cannot guarantee the life of anybody who takes part in the Lagos rally," warned the Lagos State Police Commissioner, Abubakar Tsav. "We will deal with them crudely."
For now the steamroller tactics may have stopped people from demonstrating in the streets against the President. But they have already begun to generate opposition in other forms, many times from constituencies that collaborated with the general in the past.
An open letter to the President published in March by a number of citizens who had served as his ministers or associates reminded General Abacha of his own pledge to step down, warning that his candidacy would be "morally unjust and ethically dishonest."
Some previous ministers who have broken with General Abacha have been shot or otherwise attacked, and, as one of the signers explained, "our hope in being so blunt, was that there would be safety in numbers."
"All of Nigeria has become aware of the danger of a continued Abacha presidency," said Emma Ezeazu, a leader of a rights group known as Democratic Alternative, who arranged for friends to trail him to a secret meeting place with a journalist in case he was kidnapped. "All of Nigeria will have to come together to stop it."

HEADLINE: Clinton Warns Japan: Fire Up Economy to Stem a Decline

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
President Clinton warned in unusually explicit terms today that Japan must change course if it hopes to pull its economy out of a long-running decline that has worsened markedly in recent weeks.
He made his comments as evidence mounted that Japan, already languishing in recession, is headed into one of its worst downturns since the end of World War II, and the yen fell to a six-and-a-half-year low against the dollar. 
 While Mr. Clinton issued his warning to Japan in response to a question at a news conference, he was clearly ready to send a strong message, saying, "You simply can't stay with a strategy that is clearly not appropriate to the times and expect it to get the results that are needed for the country."
For months American officials have become increasingly specific about what they believe Japan must do, advocating huge tax cuts and old-fashioned deficit spending to spur an economy that many experts say could shrink by 2 percent this year.
The President was careful to praise Japan's embattled Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, as "an able man," but he said there was clearly "an ongoing struggle" with an entrenched bureaucracy.
His comments stepped up the pressure from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and leaders from several of the world's biggest economic powers, who have said repeatedly that Japan's economic decline and its inability to absorb imports from neighboring countries threaten to hurt Asia's fragile recovery.
American officials have a more specific concern: the risk that a collapse of more major Japanese banks and securities dealers could imperil Wall Street, just as the Dow Jones Industrial Average crossed 9,000 for the first time.
That is hardly a foregone conclusion. But American companies are already reporting that their exports to Asia are dropping drastically, and a collapse in Japan, many say, could start a new round of economic contagion that could reach further than the crises in Southeast Asia and South Korea.
In London today at a summit meeting of Asian and European leaders, Mr. Hashimoto once again promised that that would not happen and that Japan would take strong action. But he offered no specifics. While he expressed some optimism that the rest of Asia had seen the worst of its troubles, he said Japan's economy was "probably facing some of the worst factors since World War II."
Administration officials made clear that Mr. Clinton's comments today had been carefully planned.
"He's been building to this for a long time," one senior official said. "We're looking at an economic actor, the world's second-largest economy, whose decisions affect the globe, and there is a growing sense that they are not up to the task, that they do not understand the gravity of the situation for Japan and the rest of the world. There is simply a loss of confidence."
On Thursday the chairman of Sony Corporation, Norio Ohga, warned that Japan's economy "is on the verge of collapsing," and compared Prime Minister Hashimoto to President Hoover on the eve of the 1929 stock market collapse.
But the sharp reactions in Japan's stock and currency markets seem to have been driven by two different events. The first was the end of the Japanese fiscal year on Tuesday. For days before that deadline, the Japanese Government was investing heavily in the country's stock market, trying to boost the price of stocks held by Japan's banks, which are burdened with hundreds of billions of dollars of bad debts.
The goal was to make year-end balance sheets appear far sounder than they really were, so banks would meet international requirements for lending around the world. But the stock prices never rose as far as Japanese officials had hoped, and as soon as the deadline passed, prices dropped steeply.
The second alarm came from Moody's Investors Service, one of the world's leading financial rating agencies, which issued an unusual warning about Japan today.
While Moody's did not drop the Japanese Government's triple-A rating, the highest it grants to any country, it altered its outlook to "negative." Although there is virtually no fear that Japan could default on its Government debt -- the country has hundreds of billions of dollars in reserves -- the warning made investors who fear rising bankruptcies extremely skittish.
The United States has been warning Japan to take far stronger economic action for more than 18 months now. A year ago, when Mr. Hashimoto visited the White House, he made a detailed economic presentation to Mr. Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and top economic officials, arguing that a 3 percent tax increase that Japan was imposing would not send the economy into a tailspin.
He was wrong. In November, Mr. Hashimoto admitted that the tax increase, which had been pressed by bureaucrats in Japan's Finance Ministry, had been a major mistake. But he has not moved to repeal the tax, and so far the economic programs he has announced to spur the economy have been a murky mixture of new and previously announced ones.
Japan's Ambassador to Washington, Kunihiko Saito, said today that he had no problem with the mounting pressure from Mr. Clinton. "We Japanese now realize that the old system that worked in the past doesn't work anymore," he said today. "We have to reform ourselves, and change our system." But, he added, "sometimes public statements can be counterproductive, and we have been asking U.S. officials to be careful in their public statements."

Dow Briefly Exceeds 9,000 As Stocks End Strong Week
Stocks finished mostly higher yesterday, capping a strong week of gains that briefly pushed the Dow Jones industrial average past the 9,000 level for the first time. 
 The Dow average rose as high as 9,030.49 before investors taking profits pushed it down to close at 8,983.41, off 3.24 points for the day but up 187.33 points, or 2.1 percent, for the week. Broader market indexes eked out small gains and finished at record highs. Page D3. .
 
Treasury securities rallied sharply on news of a surprising drop in March employment. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.79 percent from 5.84, the lowest since Feb. 17. D3.
 
$1.8 Billion Long Island Bank Deal Seeking to enlarge its presence in the New York metropolitan region, Astoria Financial agreed to buy Long Island Bancorp in a $1.8 billion stock swap. The deal will make Astoria the No. 2 bank in affluent Nassau County, behind Chase Manhattan. B5.
 
Luxury Cruise Line Merger
The Carnival Corporation and a group of investors plan to buy the Cunard cruise ship line from the Norwegian shipbuilder Kvaerner for $500 million. The deal will create the world's largest luxury cruise line. D3.
 
Moody's Warning Jolts Japan
The most creditworthy borrowers in Japan faced a new challenge when Moody's Investors Service issued a pessimistic outlook about the nation's pristine credit rating. Japan's currency, the yen, tumbled to a six-and-a-half-year low and its stock and bond markets fell on the decision by the ratings agency to change its view on the triple-A-rated country from "stable" to "negative." D2.
 
President Clinton warned in unusually explicit terms that Japanese policy makers must change course if they hope to pull Japan's economy out of a long-running decline that has worsened markedly in recent weeks. A1.
 
Cooper May Quit Auto Business
Cooper Industries, maker of automotive products like Champion spark plugs and Anco wipers, said it might exit that business to focus on electrical products, tools and hardware. Cooper's shares rose 7 percent. D3.
 
Swiss Central Bank in Fight Switzerland's central bank vowed to fight a planned lawsuit in the United States that accuses it of accepting looted assets from Germany during the Nazi era. A lawyer for Holocaust victims and heirs said a suit had been prepared but not yet filed. A4.
 
Impotence Pill's New Issues
Publicity about Pfizer's new impotence drug, Viagra, has prompted women and researchers to wonder whether the drug could improve women's sex lives if they also took it. A1.
 
Second Term for Levitt
The nomination of Arthur Levitt Jr. to a second term as chairman of the S.E.C. was approved by the Senate. Mr. Levitt, whose five-year term expires in June, enjoys broad bipartisan support. D14.
 
Call Toll Free, 877-QUICKLY
A third toll-free area code begins tomorrow, giving Americans 8 million more numbers to call to reach operators standing by, consult the Thanksgiving turkey hot line and order those special offers on late-night TV. But demand for numbers in the new area code, 877, means they will likely all be taken in 18 months. It took 30 years to use up the 8 million numbers in the original 800 code and only two years to consume the 8 million in 888. A10.
 
Permanent Oscar Home
A $350 million development project by the TrizecHahn Corporation in the heart of Hollywood includes the first permanent home for the annual Academy Awards Show. The 3,300-seat theater was designed by the New York architect David Rockwell, whose Rockwell Group is noted for its entertainment industry architecture. B12.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
What the World Needs Now

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
You can learn a lot about President Clinton's predicament by studying the news conferences he recently held with two other world leaders, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Nelson Mandela of South Africa.
The Blair-Clinton press conference was held a few weeks ago in the East Room of the White House. The contrast between the two men was most telling. Tony Blair was so relaxed. He was smart, articulate, assertive, with an obviously masterly grasp of a wide range of domestic and international issues. Mr. Clinton, by contrast, was edgy, tight, defensive, treating every question with all the relaxation of a man catching live grenades. 
 It was hard not to look at Mr. Blair and think: "There goes Bill Clinton -- without Gennifer Flowers, Paula Jones, Monica Lewinsky, Kathleen Willey, Whitewater, Travelgate . . ." That is, Tony Blair reminds us of the President Bill Clinton could have been, could have looked like, had he not been weighed down, scarred and wounded by so many self-inflicted moral gunshots.
Lord knows, Mr. Clinton has his political shortcomings. He has never had much feel for traditional, balance-of-power security issues. But he intuitively grasped, far better than any of his challengers, the issues involved in the great transition we're now in from the industrial age to the information age to the global age, which is changing everyone's job, workplace and community. With his political skills, and the strong economic winds at his back, Mr. Clinton could have been spending all his time, energy and the peace dividend retooling the New Deal welfare state into one fully designed for this new era. He could have been presiding over one of the most exciting and prosperous turning points in American history. Now, instead, he will be lucky to limp out his term. It's hard to use the bully pulpit from the witness stand.
Still, if Tony Blair reminded us who Mr. Clinton could have been, Nelson Mandela reminded us who Mr. Clinton still needs to be: President of the United States. As the South African leader said, in gently chiding Mr. Clinton at their meeting in Cape Town to reach out to America's foes, "The United States, as the leader of the world, should set an example to all of us to help eliminating tensions" by saying to its enemies, "let's sit down and talk peace."
Whether or not one agrees with Mr. Mandela about the wisdom of the U.S. reaching out to Libya or Iran, his basic point is indisputable. The U.S. President today is, in many ways, the President of the world. At a time when most members of Congress don't even hold passports, when many senators really did learn their foreign affairs at the International House of Pancakes, and when the Republican Party has no foreign-policy vision or leadership whatsoever, there is a foreign-policy vacuum in America. In that context, strong Presidential direction is vital -- not only for U.S. interests, but for world stability. Nothing important happens today without U.S. leadership.
Whatever his personal flaws, the President still has the ability to make things better for a lot of people. But if Mr. Clinton doesn't assert U.S. leadership -- in assisting China in its transition from Communism, in expanding Nafta, in advancing the Arab-Israeli peace process, in bolstering reform in Russia, in increasing funding for the I.M.F., in supporting the U.N. and in taking up Mr. Mandela's challenge (but in a more subtle way), by sorting out which of the formerly oppressed nations really merit a U.S. handshake (Cuba) and which are just evil meddlers who merit a fist (Iraq) -- no one else will.
On a lot of foreign-policy issues, Mr. Clinton has the right instincts. But those who deal with him regularly say he clearly is not focused -- even with Paula Jones out of the way. And who can blame him? If I were accused of everything he still is, I would be hiding in the closet. Though Mr. Clinton is not hiding, the affair surrounding his affairs has clearly produced a tentativeness, as in: "If I push expansion of Nafta to Chile, will Democrats in Congress abandon me? If I push hard on the peace process, will American Jews abandon me? If I bomb Iraq, will I squander my approval ratings when I need them the most?"
Bill Clinton can't now remake himself as a fresh young messenger. But as President, he's still the only one who can carry the message of America into the world. It may be too late for him to inspire, but it's not too late for him to lead.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Clinton Signals Showdown With G.O.P. Over Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
Eager to shift the spotlight from Paula Corbin Jones back to the business of government, President Clinton today lambasted the Republican Senate budget proposal and warned tobacco companies to go along with a proposed settlement.
Tired but buoyant in his first day back at the Oval Office after 12 days in Africa, Mr. Clinton immediately assembled his economic team in the White House Rose Garden this morning and signaled an election-year showdown with Congressional Republicans over the budget for the 1999 fiscal year. While clearly emboldened by a Federal judge's dismissal of Ms. Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit on Wednesday, the President vowed not to be distracted by such matters, saying, "I am going on with my business." 
 Instead, Mr. Clinton castigated Senate Republicans for approving a $1.73 trillion spending plan on Thursday night that calls for modest tax cuts and excludes virtually all of the President's proposals for new spending. And Mr. Clinton scolded members of the House for passing a six-year, $217 billion transportation bill packed with projects for almost every Congressional district.
"I am very concerned that the budget plan now working its way through the Senate will squeeze out critical investments in education and children," he said.
"I'm also determined that highway spending, though it is quite important and though our budget provides for a very impressive increase in investment in highways and mass transit, must be within the balanced budget and not crowd out critical investments in education, child care, health care or threaten our budget discipline."
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, dismissed the President's comments, asserting: "We have our priorities, he has his priorities. Education is a high priority for us." Asserting that it was Republicans, not Mr. Clinton, who sought more money for education training, Senator Lott said, "He needs to check his figures before he starts complaining."
Moving from one domestic priority to another, the President called on tobacco companies to go along with the bill that was approved this week by the Senate Commerce Committee, even though it was tougher on the companies than the proposed settlement they agreed to last summer.
"I am determined to seize this historic opportunity to pass bipartisan legislation to protect our children from the dangers of tobacco," Mr. Clinton said. "This Congress can be the Congress that saves millions of children's lives."
The cigarette companies, he said, need to "reverse the record of the past, to try to put this unforgivable chapter behind them."
Mr. Lott, meanwhile, said that if the tobacco settlement did not reach the Senate floor by June 1, "it's going to be pretty hard" to bring it to a vote this year. "I'm not saying it's impossible," the Senator said. "But I think that the best time to do it would be before we go out for the Memorial Day recess."
Mr. Clinton was unusually jaunty at his White House homecoming event. Trying to put the best face on figures showing a slight rise in unemployment, made public shortly before his Rose Garden appearance, he said, "While there will be ups and downs, our economy continues to be one of the strongest in history."
White House officials said today's appearance was the prelude to a number of events next week -- on such diverse issues as Social Security, crime and school construction -- to showcase the President's domestic agenda and turn the focus from allegations about sex and cover-up at the White House.
"The American people want us to use this sunlit moment not to sit back and enjoy, but to act," Mr. Clinton said firmly. "We were hired by the American people to act."
Questioned about Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern suspected of having a sexual relationship with Mr. Clinton, he said: "I am not going to comment on that. I am going to try to do what the Supreme Court said I should do, which is not to be in any way deterred by this."
The President was in such high spirits that he teased Vice President Al Gore, who turned 50 while Mr. Clinton was in Africa.
"I hope all of you noticed the increased gravity and maturity of his aura," Mr. Clinton said. "I personally am greatly relieved. Not long before he turned 50, as I told him when I called him, an elderly lady came up to me and said, 'I think you and that young man are doing such a good job.' And it's nice to have a middle-aged team now at the White House."
Soon after the event, the President took an early slide and went golfing with his wife's brothers, Hugh and Tony Rodham.

Rubin and Labor Secretary Alexis Herman. (Lonnie Schlein/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: China Arrests Another Prominent Democracy Advocate

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Saturday, April 4

 BODY:
One of the most outspoken democracy advocates remaining in China was arrested at his home in southern Beijing early on Friday morning and held for more than 20 hours before he was released this morning with a warning to restrain his activities.
The detention of the dissident, Xu Wenli, 54, came just two days after American officials said China had agreed to release another dissident, Wang Dan, and during a period in which Washington has cited several small signs of progress by China on human rights issues, including the release last fall of another important prisoner, Wei Jingsheng. 
 Speaking to reporters by telephone from his Beijing home this morning, Mr. Xu said the police had not accused him of any wrongdoing. "They clearly warned me not to cross the line, for instance telling me not to publish my materials without first seeking approval," Mr. Xu told Reuters.
Mr. Xu, who has recently made public calls for free labor unions and an independent human rights monitor in China, was detained by agents of the Public Security Bureau who rifled his home and took his computer, fax machine, copier and political books, his wife, He Xintong, said. His belongings were not returned today.
"They said he has been engaged in illegal activities," Ms. He said in a telephone interview.
While Mr. Wei's release and other developments emboldened dissidents like Mr. Xu to speak out, those who did have often been harassed by the police, and several have been jailed. Mr. Xu spent 12 years in prison, from 1981 to 1993, for his role in the Democracy Wall movement of the late 1970's, in which large wall posters were put up in central Beijing criticizing the Government and calling for political freedom.
The movement was briefly tolerated, then suppressed.
American officials preparing for President Clinton's visit to Beijing in late June have taken steps to support what they describe as China's progress on human rights. Most notably, at an annual United Nations meeting in Geneva last month the United States agreed to drop sponsorship of a resolution condemning China's human rights performance.
The plan to release Mr. Wang, a student leader during the 1989 Tiananmen Square demonstrations, into exile for medical reasons was part of that agreement. He is serving an 11-year prison sentence for subversion.
Among the signs of progress the United States cited were China's announcement that it would sign a United Nations covenant on civil and political rights, and its apparent tolerance of more "open letters" from scores of democracy advocates here that are generally faxed abroad for distribution to the news media.
But some crucial elements of the Chinese system remain unchanged. The security forces can still arrest anyone considered a threat to Communist Party rule at any time and imprison them for up to three years without trial.
Mr. Xu had issued strong protests recently about the sentencing of Yang Qinheng, 44, an engineer in Shanghai, to three years in a labor camp. He was accused of "disturbing public order" for writing a public letter to national legislators about the treatment of laid-off workers.
Mr. Xu and another veteran of the Democracy Wall movement, Qin Yongmin, from Wuhan, in central China, have led a small movement here to hold China to the spirit of the United Nations human rights covenants that China says it will adopt.
This winter, noting that China had signed the International Covenant on Economic and Social Rights, which calls for free labor unions, Mr. Xu, Mr. Qin and several others inside and outside China started publicizing the covenant through the Internet and calling on the Government to allow independent unions. Currently, the only legal workers' organizations are run by the Communist Party.
Mr. Qin has since defied a warning from security officials that he should leave China, and last weekend he was held for questioning overnight.
Last month China said it planned to sign another international covenant on civil and political rights, which calls for freedom of assembly and speech. Mr. Xu soon issued his own request for permission to form an independent human rights group to monitor compliance. China has not said when it will sign and ratify the accord on civil and political rights, and has said it will file reservations in areas where the covenant is inconsistent with Chinese law.
In a recent interview, Mr. Xu said that after so many years of political activity, he felt he had a "special feeling" for when it was safe to speak out. He said that in the interval between President Jiang Zemin's visit to Washington last fall and the expected Clinton visit to Beijing this summer, "things seem to be a little looser." Asked about the plan of some exiles to form a clandestine political party inside China, Mr. Xu said: "I don't approve of secret organizations. Democracy should be open: you should let your opponent know what you are doing."

HEADLINE: Astoria Financial to Buy Long Island Bank in $1.8 Billion Deal

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Seeking to expand its presence in the New York metropolitan region, the Astoria Financial Corporation has agreed to buy Long Island Bancorp Inc. in a $1.8 billion stock swap, a rich price that provides yet another barometer of how eager banks of all sizes are to merge.
The acquisition would give Astoria Financial, the holding company for the Astoria Federal Savings and Loan Association, $16.6 billion in assets, making it the second-largest savings institution in New York State, behind Dime Bancorp Inc. and ahead of the Greenpoint Financial Corporation. 
 In terms of market share in affluent and densely populated Long Island, the transaction would make Astoria Financial the second-largest bank in Nassau County and the fourth largest in Suffolk County, according to SNL Securities, a research firm in Charlottesville, Va.
The leading bank in Nassau County is the Chase Manhattan Corporation, with 13 percent of the market. In Suffolk County, the leader is Fleet Financial Group, with 20 percent of the market.
George L. Engelke, Astoria's chief executive, said the bank planned to increase its focus on "providing banking and home mortgage expertise to better serve the financial needs of low-to-moderate-income families and individuals."
Astoria, based in Lake Success, N.Y., said that the merger would lead to layoffs but that it had not yet determined how many jobs would be lost.
Analysts expect the agreement to touch off a new round of consolidation among savings banks in the New York region as the industry struggles to compete with more aggressive retail banks like Chase and Citicorp.
"It really sends a signal that in order to compete you have to be larger and have economies of scale," said Martin Friedman, an analyst with Friedman, Billings, Ramsey & Company.
Some unusual jockeying for Long Island Bancorp, the Melville, N.Y., parent of the Long Island Savings Bank, preceded yesterday's agreement. North Fork Bancorp, also of Melville, sent a letter to Long Island Bancorp's board on Thursday offering to pay about $74 a share for the bank, higher than the $69.30 a share offered by Astoria Financial.
North Fork, which lost out to Astoria last year in a bid for the Greater New York Savings Bank, declined to comment on its offer. Long Island Bancorp did not return phone calls seeking comment on why the higher offer was rebuffed.
North Fork owns about 4.6 percent of Long Island Bancorp stock, and North Fork's chief executive, John A. Kanas, said "it was under study" whether his bank would contest the merger.
Mr. Kanas is known as a determined cost-cutter, a reputation that has not sat well with some banks, like Greater New York Savings, that have avoided merging with North Fork.
It was not clear whether Mr. Kanas's cost-cutting proclivities played a role in scuttling his overtures toward Long Island Bancorp.
The battle to take over Long Island Bancorp began in mid-February when North Fork asked the New York Federal Reserve to permit it to raise its stake in the bank to 9.9 percent, a clear sign that it wanted to play a more significant role in the bank's future.
For now, however, it appears that Astoria Financial will take over Long Island Bancorp. The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter.
