HEADLINE: News Summary

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-5
 
Inquiry on Whether Firms Gave China Missile Help
A Federal grand jury is investigating whether two American companies illegally gave China space expertise that significantly advanced Beijing's ballistic missile program, according to Administration officials. Officials said the criminal inquiry was dealt a serious blow two months ago when President Clinton quietly approved the export to China of similar know-how by one of the companies under investigation. A1 

China Detains a Dissident
Xu Wenli, an outspoken democracy advocate in China, was arrested in Beijing, but he was later released with a warning, he said, "not to cross the line." Mr. Xu has recently urged the authorities to establish a human rights watchdog group and release another dissident. A3
 
Clinton Gives Japan a Warning
President Clinton warned that Japan must change course if it hopes to pull its economy out of a long-running decline that has worsened markedly in recent weeks. He made his comments as evidence mounted that Japan was headed into one of its worst downturns since World War II. A1
 
U.N. Iraq Team Finds Nothing
United Nations arms experts inspected each of the 1,058 buildings inside Saddam Hussein's eight presidential compounds, but found no banned material, an American inspector said. A4
 
Israel Tries to Deal with Arafat
Israel sent its top intelligence officer to Gaza to persuade Yasir Arafat that Israel had nothing to do with the assassination of a suspected bomb maker. The threat of a Hamas attack to avenge the death has spurred israel to seek Mr. Arafat's aid. A3
 
Fine for Nazi Accomplice
Maurice Papon, a French civil servant who was convicted of having been an accomplice to Nazi crimes against humanity during World War II, was ordered by a criminal court to pay nearly $750,000 in damages and legal fees. A4
 
Germans Seek to Try Le Pen
Prosecutors in Munich began an effort to bring Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the far-right in France, to trial in Germany for violating laws there against trivializing or denying the Holocaust. A state prosecutor said he had asked the European Parliament, of which Mr. Le Pen is a member, to lift his immunity from prosecution. A4
 
Swiss Bank Will Fight Suit
Switzerland's central bank served notice with unusual bluntness that it would fight a class-action lawsuit in the United States that accused the bank of accepting looted assets from Germany during the Nazi era. The Swiss National Bank also disputed the competence of American courts to judge its actions. The suit alleges that the bank cooperated with Nazi Germany in the receipt of looted assets, according to a Washington lawyer representing Holocaust victims and heirs. A4
 
NATIONAL A6-10
 
A Former C.I.A. Officer Is Arrested on Spy Charge
A veteran officer of the Central Intelligence Agency who was dismissed, Douglas F. Groat, 50, tried to extort $500,000 from the C.I.A. in exchange for his loyalty, officials said, and, when the agency would not buy his silence, told two foreign nations how the United States spied on them. A1
 
Clinton Criticizes Senate
President Clinton castigated the Republican-led Senate for approving a $1.73 trillion budget plan that called for modest tax cuts and excluded virtually all of the President's proposals for new spending. Mr. Clinton also warned tobacco companies to go along with a proposed settlement. A8
 
Lewinsky's Mother Questioned
Investigators for the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr questioned Marcia Lewis, the mother of Monica S. Lewinsky, outside the grand jury room, lawyers close to Mr. Starr's inquiry said. In February, Ms. Lewis appeared distraught after her questioning before the grand jury, which generated wide sympathy for her and her daughter. A8
 
Police Officer Is Convicted
Maj. Aaron Campbell of the Miami-Dade Police Department, a black man who asserted that racial stereotyping had led to his being stopped by white deputies near Orlando, Fla., was convicted of resisting arrest. A9
 
A New Toll-Free Area Code
A third toll-free area code, 877, goes into service tomorrow, providing for an additional eight million telephone numbers. A10
 
Man Confesses to Bias Killings
The man who says he shot the publisher of Hustler magazine, Larry Flynt, and Vernon E. Jordan has confessed to two 1979 killings that he says were racially motivated. The man, Joseph Paul Franklin, 47, who is on death row in Missouri for murder, confessed to killing Mercedes Lynn Masters, 15, and Harold McIver, 27, in DeKalb County, Ga., prosecutors there said. In a prison interview, Mr. Franklin said he had had a sexual relationship with Ms. Masters, who was white, and killed her after she told him she had sex with blacks. Mr. McIver, who was black, was killed by a sniper. (AP)

Doctor Is Found Guilty In Daughter's Death
A Queens doctor who had fought a court battle to keep his 5-month-old daughter from being taken off a respirator was found guilty of causing her death, by shaking her so violently that she was left brain dead. B1
 
Bomber Is Given 240 Years
Eyad Ismoil, the driver of the bomb van in the World Trade Center explosion that killed six people and injured hundreds in 1993, was sentenced to 240 years in prison. B2

One of John Gotti Jr.'s co-defendants has agreed to testify against him. According to court papers, the witness implicated Mr. Gotti in the extortion of a topless nightclub and of a construction company. B5
 
Defense Counters Claims
Defense experts testified that there was virtually no medical evidence to support a woman's claim that she was tortured by a Columbia University graduate student whom she met on the Internet. B3

The economy added no new jobs in March, the Labor Department reported. Payrolls actually edged down by 36,000 jobs and the unemployment rate, which had been at a 24-year low, ticked up to 4.7 percent from 4.6 percent. The department also revised February's stunning job gain sharply downward. A1

HEADLINE: Stuyvesant Needs Equal Admissions Policy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The most disturbing thing about your April 2 front-page article on three students who tried to get into Stuyvesant High School is not the fact that the Asian and white students passed while the black student did not. It is the fact that the two students who passed paid $500 to $700 for preparatory courses while the student who received free preparation from the Board of Education did not. 
 Maybe Stuyvesant and the other elite public high schools need to change their system to be more accommodating to people with different cultural and economic backgrounds.
 
HENRY WONG
New Haven, April 2, 1998

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
ELKIN, DAVID B.

 BODY:
ELKIN-David B. On March 28, 1998. Beloved husband to Margot Turitz Elkin, loving father of Charlotte and Sam Elkin, cherished brother of Ethel Elkin and devoted son-in-law to Zitha Turitz. David was an economist, former Vice President of W.R. Grace and Co, adjunct professor, and economic consultant. He grew up in the Bronx, later lived in Manhattan, and settled in White Plains. His intelligence, vast knowledge, political conscience, wry humor and sensitivity will be deeply missed. Contributions to James Parkinson Fund for Research, Department of Neurology, University of Medicine and Dentistry of N.J., New Brunswick, New Jersey 08903.

HEADLINE: Report Card

BYLINE: By Richard Rothstein; Richard Rothstein is a research associate of the Economic Policy Institute. His history on student achievement, "The Way We Were?," is to be published this spring.

 BODY:

Class Struggle
 What's Wrong (and Right) With America's Best Public High Schools.
 By Jay Mathews.
 312 pp. New York:
 Times Books/Random House. $25. 
 There's a wide achievement gap between public school students in middle-class communities and those in poor urban neighborhoods. Many Americans believe that inner-city schools fail to bring out the best in disadvantaged youth because of bureaucracy, lack of resources, inadequate curriculums or low expectations. Others argue that students' learning potential is largely determined by their parents' child-rearing practices, education and socioeconomic background, and that schools have little impact. The debate has largely centered on the performance of the nation's worst schools, but in "Class Struggle," a Washington Post reporter, Jay Mathews, approaches the subject from an entirely different angle: he looks at "elite" suburban high schools -- "brain farms" in places like Scarsdale, N.Y., New Trier Township, outside Chicago, and Beverly Hills, Calif.
Mathews can't quite decide if nature or nurture is responsible for these schools' success but his ambivalence is just as well. He has provided rich reporting about the texture of the nation's suburban systems, detail that will be news even to many well-informed readers. Although these schools are known for their challenging courses, ambitious academic projects, advanced placement classes and their high admission rates to Ivy League or comparable liberal arts colleges, less publicized are their not-so-successful students, warehoused in classes like "photography" or basic math, who are bound for lower-middle-class jobs upon graduation, or at best junior college.
These young people, Mathews insists, would do better if only the schools demanded more of them. Yet any attempts by progressive educators to integrate them into a more demanding program is met with fierce resistance from administrators. They are accountable primarily to school boards representing upper-middle-class parents who block any move they believe (wrongly, Mathews argues) will dilute the college preparation programs for their successful progeny. Indeed, many of these school officials see their roles as "gatekeepers," who must exclude youngsters with lesser destinies from honors programs. Mathews estimates that each year nationwide, 100,000 students who could thrive, given the opportunity, are either denied admission to advance placement courses or discouraged from enrolling because schools are unwilling to take chances on those whose backgrounds and records don't guarantee success.
He makes a straightforward argument for "detracking" at the top, giving an honors curriculum to all students who can be persuaded to sign up for it. He devotes considerable attention and praise to a controversial multidisciplinary curriculum for the ninth grade at Mamaroneck High School, outside New York City, where "honors" students excel by the strengths of their research projects while remaining integrated with their less accomplished peers, who are also challenged to pursue project-based research. And Mathews cannot disguise his disappointment in a compromise -- worked out with some parents who feared their Ivy League-bound offspring might be insufficiently challenged if thrown together with regular students -- to retain a small and selective honors class for those who refused to be part of the new program.
In a previous book, Mathews profiled Jaime Escalante (the model for the character played by Edward James Olmos in the movie "Stand and Deliver"), who led a surprising number of Mexican immigrant youths in a poor East Los Angeles high school to passing scores on the College Board's Advanced Placement calculus test. In the current book, he argues that Escalante's achievement is attainable in far more schools than most Americans believe. Mathews has painstakingly compiled a "challenge index" of the public high schools in the United States that administer at least one advanced placement test per graduating senior. (Because many elite students take this test in more than one subject, a school's place on the index does not necessarily mean that each of its students has access to a high quality curriculum, but Mathews's list is a first approximation of such an indicator.) On the list are not only predictable upper-middle-class suburban high schools, but also Newman Smith High School in Carrolton, Tex., which alone accounts for 10 percent of black students in the entire state who pass the advanced placement calculus test, and several inner-city schools that drill their advance-placement students "as if they were football teams preparing for the homecoming game."
But Mathews's reporting also suggests that there is more to the story than the failure of public schools to challenge more students. He claims that it is "difficult to justify pedagogical segregation in elite schools where there are no significant differences in the family backgrounds of the lower-track and upper-track children," but his narrative reveals that things are not so neat. In Mamaroneck, for example, a disproportionate number of students in the "dumbed down" courses come from a low-income neighborhood known as the Flats, where parents have working-class jobs. And not surprisingly, a disproportionate number of students in the honors program come from families in which college-educated professional parents with six-figure incomes consider their real estate taxes and big mortgages the equivalent of private tuition, helping to assure their children's admission to Ivy League schools.
Mathews argues forcefully that we can do a better job of making high levels of academic achievement accessible to even the most disadvantaged students, fulfilling, for at least some of them, the dream of education as an engine of social mobility. But then he jumps to the conclusion that we should make four-year college degrees a reality for all students.
Yet no school with a working-class enrollment has succeeded in this goal for all or even for most of its students. No matter how "detracked" our high schools become, differences in family ambition and comfort will still result in different average achievement for rich and poor children. Contemporary education debates often assume that, if only schools did it right, they could bequeath to us a classless society. Mathews shows how schools can get us closer to that goal, but unanswered is the question of exactly how much closer.

HEADLINE: Red Ink and the Rising Sun

BYLINE: By Richard J. Samuels; Richard J. Samuels is the Ford International Professor of Political Science and director of the Japan program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His most recent book is "Rich Nation, Strong Army: National Security and the Technological Transformation of Japan."

 BODY:

THE MINISTRY
 How Japan's Most Powerful Institution
 Endangers World Markets.
 By Peter Hartcher.
 310 pp. Boston:
 Harvard Business School Press. $24.95. 
 While we cannot express Schadenfreude in a single English word, Americans certainly know how to wallow in it when the talk turns to Asia's economic crisis. This is particularly true in the case of Japan, where stock market and land prices have collapsed, bad debts and bankruptcies have soared and growth has leveled off at near zero. American triumphalism has rarely had a larger following. "The Ministry: How Japan's Most Powerful Institution Endangers World Markets" gives more cause for that sort of perverse celebration.
Peter Hartcher is an Australian economic journalist who was in Japan just as the economic bubble burst in the early 1990's. His book's Grishamesque title masks a sober presentation of how Japan's elite Ministry of Finance bureaucrats bungled management of the world's second-largest economy.
Did they ever. By 1996, Moody's Investor Services gave Japanese banks an average rating of D, a grade usually reserved for third-world financial institutions. And today Japan's fiscal deficit is the highest among industrial democracies.
At one level, "The Ministry" is the well-known story of high-powered bureaucrats who "descend from heaven" to control the Japanese economy. There is nothing new here in the depictions of "administrative guidance" or the grooming of Tokyo University mandarins, but Hartcher's narrative unfolds inexorably. After beginning as a rather tired chronicle of familiar Japanese practices, it builds momentum through its often stunning accounts of betrayal of the public trust to become a searing indictment of Japanese bureaucrats lost in deep denial.
Hartcher provides a fairly intimate description of how the Ministry of Finance designed a macroeconomic machine that first inflated and then punctured Japan's economic bubble. He explains how Ministry policies encouraged imprudent behavior by insouciant firms convinced of their own insulation from market forces. The banks the Ministry supervised were allowed to collude in setting rates. The brokerage firms it regulated guaranteed the investments of large clients. Insurance companies were permitted to slice pension fund payouts.
Hartcher gives this giant shell game a human face. He tells of one particularly venal bubble surfer, Harunori Takahashi, whose personal connections got him a blank check for billions of dollars from an underregulated bank to build an empire of hotels, golf courses, personal jets and French paintings. Takahashi stands as the personification of Japan's collective excesses in the 1980's. Then there are Hartcher's accounts of Ministry bureaucrats bullying Singaporean and American stock exchange officials, refusing to report violations of United States law by Japanese firms operating in New York and openly threatening American Congressmen and the Secretary of the Treasury with economic warfare.
Its picture of greed and arrogance aside, Hartcher's story shows that laissez-faire never meant much in Japan. By his account, the Ministry of Finance has relentlessly and reflexively resisted market forces. Its bureaucrats, he says, are more comfortable with cartels than with competition; they prefer collusion and control. It has never been an article of Japanese faith to trust markets to deliver the greatest good for the greatest number.
But if economic management is at base a matter of ideas, the Ministry of Finance may have run out of them. In late 1996, with the London of Margaret Thatcher in mind, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto announced plans for a sweeping Big Bang liberalization to make Tokyo financial markets globally competitive by 2001. This may work, but skepticism surrounds any Japanese declaration of imminent reform, and many who understand the Ministry of Finance's ideas are anticipating a Big Whimper instead.
The Ministry has regularly substituted half measures for serious change. Its formal interventions have repeatedly morphed into cartel-based regulation. Hartcher coins an apt term: "virtual regulation." But he misses the larger point about Japan's economic ideology: bureaucrats at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, and elsewhere, have been intervening and faking liberalization for just as long as bureaucrats at the Ministry of Finance. Adam Smith's invisible hand has always been visible in Japan.
Hartcher's subtitle notwithstanding, he never seems quite sure where power resides in Japan. He presents the case for a powerful financial bureaucracy, but he also tells how politicians have moved to make the central bank more independent and to relocate some of the functions of the Ministry of Finance in the Prime Minister's office. His larger contribution is his insight into how the Ministry develops strategic plans and mobilizes political attacks, how its "guardians" protect their fiscal castle -- though if they were truly indomitable, they might have avoided the recent humiliating visit by prosecutors, who crossed the moat to arrest several of their number for bribery and force the resignation of both the Minister and the Vice Minister.
Hartcher's book works best for those who are willing to ignore an important part of his central thesis. For the finance mandarins cannot be as foolish as they are influential. They cannot be as incompetent as they are prescient. Hartcher concludes that they have lost their way. He might have done better to recognize that they remain on the same path they have always sure-footedly trodden, but that this path is currently leading them into uncharted and dangerous territory. Nonetheless, it is best to hold the Schadenfreude for now. These "guardians" are more resourceful than they are corrupt.

LENGTH: 1075 words

HEADLINE: Medical Waste

BYLINE: By Roy Porter; Roy Porter teaches at the Wellcome Institute for the History of Medicine, in London.

 BODY:

False Hopes
 Why America's Quest for Perfect Health Is a Recipe for Failure.
 By Daniel Callahan.
 330 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $24. 
 Daniel Callahan's analysis of the American health care crisis is uncannily timely. Precisely 200 years ago, Thomas Malthus, the first great modern prophet against progress, exploded human perfectibility as an impossible dream. Against the French Revolution's utopian hope that a free and fair society would infinitely improve and prolong human life, he countered that rising living standards would lead to population growth, which would inevitably breed new poverty. No escape was possible from the Malthusian trap. Malthus turned out to be wrong, and mistakes like his arouse suspicions against doom-mongers: maybe they don't actually want progress, or perhaps they suffer from gut misanthropy.
 Callahan would, I am sure, hate to be linked with such Jeremiahs, but "False Hopes" certainly pours cold water on expectations of ever-improving health. Lethal epidemic diseases are back with a vengeance: not just AIDS and superbugs but tuberculosis and pneumonia. What is more, it is unlikely that the foreseeable future will bring major victories in the struggles against cancer, stroke, Alzheimer's disease and other chronic killers. Despite past successes and present cheerleaders, there are thus, he contends, no good biomedical grounds for anticipating dramatic increases in longevity soon.
Of course, high-tech procedures save lives, but mostly they don't actually cure diseases. And "Band-Aid" medicine is always inordinately expensive. In 1970, the United States was channeling a little more than 7 percent of its gross national product into health care; the figure has leapt to nearly 14 percent. Given no clear correlation between health and health care spending, before it doubles again, throttling other sorts of vital social investment, isn't it time to say enough is enough?
Writing as a philosopher, Callahan maintains that the root of the problem lies in mistaken mentalities: healthy perfectionism, the technological imperative, the Promethean drive to conquer death. He calls us back to basics. Since we all die sometime, it makes sense to map out limits. Today's average life span, already exceeding the biblical threescore years and ten, is quite enough for us to accomplish our reasonable life wishes. Hence our first priority should be to insure that as many citizens as possible make it to that age threshold in good health. And the best way to secure that, given limited funds and scarce medical resources, is to turn our attention from late-stage interventions to prevention, above all to public health in its widest sense (e.g., campaigns against smoking) and to personal responsibility (prudent life styles).
If people are urged, financially induced and occasionally even forced to lead healthier lives, no crippling increases will be needed in the prosperous societies of the West to secure for most of them long, healthy lives. Callahan, the director of international programs at the Hastings Center, questions the need for the huge outlays on research called for by scientists and by medical interests and fueled by the logic of "healthism" and competition (which in medicine, at least, has always served to increase, not pare, costs). In place of such a spiral of demands and dollars, he proposes what he terms -- by analogy with environmentalist thinking -- a "sustainable" health policy, one that would be both equitable and efficient.
FOR someone who lives in the Old World, as I do, it is easy to cry "Amen" to Callahan's prayer. A European cannot help noticing that the United States sinks almost twice as much of its G.N.P. into health as most Western European nations. While this may betoken a touching commitment to well-being, it doesn't result in a significantly healthier nation. The populations of the Netherlands and Scandinavia live longer, and most European states have notably better neonatal mortality rates. Money may buy health for some, but it doesn't look from this side of the ocean as if Americans at large are getting value for money.
Callahan gives qualified approval to European health care, with its rationale of a centrally directed equitable provision of basic health for all. He expresses the fear that the philosophy of welfare states is being eroded by fiscal pressures and political change. He need not worry too much. Even Margaret Thatcher, that great worshiper of Reaganomics, recognized it would be political suicide to dismantle the National Health Service; and it is significant that in Tony Blair's Britain, even financial stringency and growing waiting lists result not in calls for privatization but in rallying round the existing system.
"False Hopes" offers a voice of sanity, but for all its persuasive reasoning, it is somewhat disappointing. It weakens its argument by being needlessly silent about costs. There's not a table or a graph in the whole volume, and scarcely a single hard-cash sum is mentioned. How much money actually goes to tobacco advertising, antismoking education and terminal care for lung cancer? Money talks, and balance sheets would surely strengthen Callahan's case. And far too little is said on how to bring change about. As we are reminded several times, many key players seemed to want reform in the early 90's, yet Bill Clinton's much-vaunted schemes came to nothing -- and since then the tally of the uninsured has risen from more than 36 million to 41 million. So what is needed? A truly gigantic crisis -- or an act of public will far greater than Clinton could command? Unless the practical politics of reform are addressed, all else will indeed remain yet another bubble of well-meaning false hopes.
All too often exposes just create fresh anxieties, giving another twist to the macabre merry-go-round of panic and futile medicine. Callahan's forte lies in soberly addressing how much health we can reasonably expect to buy. Here he squarely faces a fact of life pointed out years ago by the English politician Enoch Powell: "There is virtually no limit to the amount of health care an individual is capable of absorbing."
Callahan is no Luddite, no professional pessimist in the Malthusian mode. Negotiating sensible limits is central to his plea for sustainable medicine. He talks straight about priorities. He writes with clarity and humanity. He deserves a hearing.

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber

 BODY:

TURNING STONES: My Days and Nights With Children at Risk
By Marc Parent. Fawcett Columbine, $13.95.
The author is a former caseworker for Emergency Children's Services in New York, the agency that responds to reports of suspected abuse. His memoir reveals how overburdened the system is, and how the best intentions do not always save the helpless. "The only weapon we have against failing our children is consciousness," Kathryn Harrison wrote here in 1996. This book "is an admirable step toward" it.
 
AMERICAN PASTORAL
By Philip Roth. Vintage International, $14.
The tale is told by Nathan Zuckerman, Roth's recurring fictional spokesman and an unreliable narrator at best. But it is the kind of story that could easily be true. The subject is Swede Levov, Zuckerman's former high school classmate, a man so blessed with good fortune that God seems to have been tempted to wreak horrible revenge. Swede's undoing is his only child, Merry, who as a teen-ager in 1968 takes part in a terrorist bombing that kills a man and ruins the life her parents had built. Selected as one of the best books of 1997 by the editors of the Book Review, the novel offers a "mixture of rage and elegy," Michael Wood said in these pages. "You have only to pause over the prose to feel how beautifully it is elaborated." The same publisher has also reissued Roth's first novel, LETTING GO ($15), which explores the life of a young Korean War veteran and his efforts to connect emotionally, especially with the troubled couple he befriends. In 1962 our reviewer, Arthur Mizener, called it "a powerful book as well as an often brilliantly perceptive one."
 
LIFE ON THE LINE
By Faye Wattleton. Ballantine, $14.95.
In her autobiography, the former president of Planned Parenthood, the daughter of a fundamentalist minister, reflects on her struggles to maintain the rights to birth control and abortion. In 1996 our reviewer, Samuel G. Freedman, said, "The strongest pages . . . show Wattleton's internal campaign to reshape Planned Parenthood." Another outspoken advocate gives her history in JOYCELYN ELDERS, M.D.: From Sharecropper's Daughter to Surgeon General of the United States of America, by Joycelyn Elders and David Chanoff (Avon, $13). Elders relates her journey from an Arkansas farm to the Government with "appealing humility," Freedman wrote in the same review.
 
LOVE WARPS THE MIND A LITTLE
By John Dufresne. Plume, $12.95.
Lafayette (Laf) Proulx, the feckless narrator, has just left his job and his wife, hoping to succeed at writing fiction. But after his girlfriend is told she has cancer, Laf learns the real power and limits of love and the imagination. This is a "funny, wise and powerful novel," Karen Karbo said in the Book Review last year.
 
DEAD SEASON: A Story of Murder and Revenge
By Alan Berlow. Vintage Departures, $14.
A correspondent for National Public Radio examines the circumstances surrounding the massacre of several members of a poor farm family on the Philippine island of Negros in the late 1980's. He concludes that the political and economic climate that led to the deaths is not so different from the one produced by the former government. This is "the kind of book . . . that so many reporters wished they could leave their daily routines to write," Seth Mydans wrote here in 1996.
 
ALLIGATOR DANCE: Stories
By Janet Peery. Picador USA, $12.
These tales take place mostly in the Southwest, often among blue-collar people who do not have a wide knowledge of the world but display a remarkable understanding of how they fit into it. In 1994 our reviewer, Dorothy Allison, called this book "one of the best first collections I have ever read."
 
MUSORGSKY: Eight Essays and an Epilogue
By Richard Taruskin. Princeton University, $19.95.
This book re-evaluates the career of Modest Mussorgsky (1839-81), finding in the Russian composer less a champion of the common people than an aspiring patrician. "It is unlikely that this year will see the publication of a more engrossing or a more valuable book about music," Donal Henahan wrote in these pages in 1993. Another important study of music, THE CLASSICAL STYLE: Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven, by Charles Rosen (Norton, $17.95), has also been reissued. This expanded edition includes a new preface and a new chapter on Beethoven. It is "a book for which both musicians and music lovers should be grateful," Edward T. Cone said in the Book Review in 1971.
 
PEERLESS FLATS
By Esther Freud. Ecco, $14.
The scene is London in the 1970's, and Lisa, this novel's 16-year-old heroine, lives in public housing with her little half brother and irresponsible mother. But although Lisa seems to be following a path of total freedom, she soon realizes that there is something to be said for restraint. The author (yes, she's one of the Freuds) has a "deft and gentle comic touch," Zophia Smardz wrote here in 1993. Ecco has also reissued Freud's first novel, HIDEOUS KINKY ($13), whose plucky narrator is only 5. In Marrakesh with her sister and hippie mother, she survives the 60's with more sense than the adults. "The book evocatively renders the breathless static of vagabond life," Sarah Ferguson said in these pages in 1992. Laurel Graeber

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Shopping Spree

BYLINE: By DAVID HOCHMAN; DAVID HOCHMAN, a senior writer for Entertainment Weekly, lives in Los Angeles.

 BODY:
FOR a few minutes in January, it seemed to really matter that my right shoulder leans forward slightly more than my left. I was in Hong Kong, being fitted for a suit at W. W. Chan and Sons, one of the last of the city's great custom tailoring shops. As soon as I announced I wanted a suit made, it appeared that neither chicken flu nor crashing stock markets nor the return of the Chinese Government could keep these master craftsmen from working their measuring-tape magic. Suddenly, I was at the center of a storm of white chalk, straight pins and perspiration. Tang Yan Choi, a stout, tough-looking man, who -- like many of the best Chinese tailors -- claims Shanghai as his place of origin, tapped me in eight or nine places and grunted out something in Cantonese, while Raymond K. K. Kiang, the manager of the 41-year-old shop, took furious notes.
"That's his secret method," Mr. Kiang told me. "He reads your body." 
 Thirty-one measurements later, I was ready to receive Mr. Tang's assessment: my chest is full, my stomach is flat, I have a rounded right calf and I tend to wear my trousers two inches lower at the waist than I should. The hardest news to hear, though, was that my right shoulder stoops forward ever so slightly. "But we take care of that," Mr. Kiang promised. "That's why you've come to us."
If truth be told, I never really intended to come to Hong Kong at all. But when my girlfriend, Ruth Kennison, arrived home one December night ecstatic over a two-for-one Super Saver package on Cathay Pacific Airways for $999 -- one week, hotel included -- we set our sights on Asia. We knew that the handover of the former British territory to the Chinese, combined with the general economic crisis in Southeast Asia, has not been kind to Hong Kong. Tourism is down sharply, several banks have collapsed, unemployment is rising, and real estate development is virtually stalled. But the city's problems can be a boon, albeit a bittersweet one, for American visitors. And shopkeepers, we believed, would probably be glad to have eager customers like us.
With that in mind, shortly after checking into our plain room at the vast, modern Regal Riverside Hotel in the New Territories, we set out for the city's fabled shopping districts, calculator in hand, to see if the gods of retail still smile on this crowded little megalopolis on the South China Sea.
If you work your way to the end of Hollywood Road in Central, past the curio shops selling vintage foot-binding shoes and Maoist insignia badges, past the high-end antiques dealers with their $20,000 Ching Dynasty bowls and $100,000 jade rats, past the weather-worn Man Mo Temple where three-foot-long coils of incense smolder for weeks on end, you'll arrive at a dusty, packed-to-the-rafters shop, right next to the coffin factory, called Wing Tei Curios and Carvings. Peter Lee, the smiling proprietor, will tell you that the wooden grates, doors and archways, with their impossibly intricate pastoral scenes and screaming dragons, were salvaged from Buddhist and Taoist shrines built before the Cultural Revolution of the 1960's. The objects now range in price from $25 to more than you can believe. Two browsing antiques dealers from San Francisco said they buy these pieces by the boatload because the quality of the craftsmanship simply does not exist anymore.
Luckily, by that point on our trek down Hong Kong's wallet-clobbering antiques row, we had come to our senses. Hollywood Road, we realized, has a supernatural effect on one's shopping impulses. Things we never realized we wanted suddenly began looking like must-have objects: the lacquered cricket cage at the antique bird-cage shop around the corner at 55A Peel Street; the handpainted snuff bottles at True Arts and Curios at 89-91 Hollywood Road; the grimacing Chinese puppets from nearby Arch Angel Antiques (we bought one for $45, after some haggling), not to mention the dried shark fins, wall-sized propaganda posters and centuries-old opium pipes.
The embroidered Chinese baby hats finally brought us to our knees. Upstairs at Windsor House, nearby on Po Hing Fong, we knelt before a chest full of them, convincing ourselves that a tiny hand-sewn cap shaped like a puffer fish or a Bengal tiger was exactly the life-affirming, home-altering purchase we needed to take back to Los Angeles. Plus, they were marked down from $200 each to $40, so how could we refuse? We carefully picked four, handed over our money to the expatriate British owner, Beatrice Owen, and walked away, giving ourselves high-fives on what we thought was the deal of the century.
Heading up the stairs to W. W. Chan's became a morning ritual during our weeklong stay. Mr. Kiang said he needed to see me each day for fittings, and now Ruth, who became jealous watching me get so much attention, was in the adjoining room at Irene Fashions, Chan's women's division, having a jacket made. She had brought a favorite blazer to have copied, but Tommy Liu, the tailor at Irene's, placed the jacket on a chair, winked and quickly sketched a garment that put Ruth's Donna Karan blazer to shame. The sketched version was tapered and pleated in all the right places (as well it should be, for $560), and soon Ruth was being lassoed by Tommy's tape measure.
Over on the Chan side, I was having heart palpitations. Like most upscale shops, W. W. Chan's had not lowered its prices when we were there; and we did not try to negotiate. The dark cashmere-and-wool suit they had whipped up overnight, and which, at $875, would be the most expensive garment I'd ever purchased, still had chalk-marked lapels, no lining, no buttons, pins everywhere and only one sleeve. Mr. Tang, friendly as ever, poked and tapped me unceremoniously, while Mr. Kiang politely reminded me to return the following morning.
With my first bespoke suit under construction, I felt I needed a few great-fitting shirts to go with it. I walked two blocks to David's Shirts, a place my Uncle Sam visited years ago and had spoken about with reverence, and soon the measuring game was happening all over again. As with every custom-made garment, there were endless and perplexing questions: French paneled pleats or flat? Spread collar or point? And should the shirt be made of poplin or gingham, or maybe crepe de chine? I settled on Sea Island cotton -- one white, one blue, one checked. At $90 and up, I only hoped the shirts would absorb the sweat when I got the credit card bill.
A 10-minute walk away, nearer to Victoria Harbor, is Granville Road, Hong Kong's answer to Filene's Basement. It was Sale Week, a twice-annual buyer's bacchanal, and everywhere rabid shoppers, mostly locals, were scavenging through sidewalk bins for cut-rate Tommy Hilfiger overruns and imitation Prada bags. But since neither of us was particularly desperate for a "Rotex" watch, we thought we'd save our money for the more authentic goods.
In the late afternoon, we took a 15-minute double-decker bus ride inland to the madness that is the bazaar district. Promptly at 6 P.M. on Temple Street, a thousand dai pai dong -- market stands -- magically materialized. Hawkers with their rickety card tables gridlocked the street, selling everything imaginable: Little Mermaid bubble watches, ginseng tinctures, $800 abalone meat, whistling laser pointers, snake soup. While true bargains could be found on Temple Street (we saw chenille turtlenecks for $3), the more interesting, exotic part of the night market was on adjacent Market Street, where amateur opera singers, fortune tellers and sidewalk feng shui masters set up shop. I thought about getting a belt made there by an ancient-looking streetside cobbler, but the river of people wouldn't let me stand still long enough.
Wo On Lane is a perfect Hong Kong street. The dead-end alley in the Central district near trendy Lan Kwai Fong Street, off D'Aguilar Street, crams more into several hundred feet than most cities squeeze into an entire downtown. It is best to arrive, as we did the following day, around noon, when it's most active. On the corner, a sidewalk barber cut hair with a straight-edge under a makeshift sun canopy. Across the street, a Chinese herbalist offered his services next to a modern stationery store. At number 12 1/2, there was a yuppie (they're called chuppies here) jazz bar. At No. 14, a Vietnamese restaurant called Papillon was bookended between a Cuban cigar shop and an old-fashioned refrigerator repair place. The block ends at a Taoist Earth God shrine, and the whole lane smells faintly of incense.
One of the more intriguing shops in Hong Kong is also there. Mountain Folkcraft, at No. 12, specializes in handmade arts and crafts, new and old, from all over Asia: Tibetan chests, Mongolian horses, Silk Road batik, paddle-shaped Chinese wooden cake molds, intricately carved with deeply set images of cuttlefish, lotus flowers and Buddhas (we bought four for $40 each), tribal costumes, musical instruments, folk toys, jewelry and, much to our satisfaction, embroidered Chinese baby hats, slightly more expensive than our steals on Hollywood Road. The women who run the store are friendly and knowledgeable, and prices are fixed, a rarity in a city where prices are negotiable on everything -- especially now.
Leaving Wo On, we descended into the soul of old Hong Kong. Under the row of ragged tenements on Pottinger Street, a steep and crowded alleyway crammed with hawker's stalls, we saw live frogs for sale in mesh bags, and hair ribbons available for the equivalent of a penny. It was hard to fathom that some of the world's highest retail rents are just around the corner on Pedder Street. We plowed past the jackhammers and delivery scooters to Shanghai Tang at 12 Pedder Street, unquestionably the hippest store in town. If Hong Kong's economy is suffering, it wasn't evident here. Tourists and Hong Kongers alike were snatching up every Suzie Wong jacket and satin samfu shirt. The $35 dim sum watch we bought features a knife and fork pointing to pork buns and steamed dumplings. Our $45 Deng Xiaoping alarm clock shows the Communist leader smoking away the hours. After Shanghai Tang, I felt as if I'd done enough shopping for a lifetime, but Ruth forged on, tackling all nine floors of the adjoining Pedder Building, a bargain-hunter's nirvana where shops have names like Labels Plus and Sample Sale Warehouse. Miraculously, she emerged without any shopping bags, and aside from a few discoveries -- the Ann Klein II outlet and chic Blanc de Chine store among them -- she seemed more impressed by the stairway Buddhist shrines.
We felt a touch of sadness heading over to Chan's that final afternoon to pick up our suit and jacket. Even in our shopping stupor, it was impossible to ignore the depth of Hong Kong's distress. The week we were there, another major investment bank, Peregrine Investments Holdings, collapsed. The upcoming Chinese New Year was looking bleak without the prospect of fresh chicken for traditional feasts, as the territory's chickens had been slaughtered to impede the spread of a flu virus.
Mr. Kiang helped me into my wonderful new suit jacket, but even he couldn't contain his uncertainty this time. "Business is not so good," he said. "Next generation of tailors is not being trained, and I wonder if business can last much longer." Traditional tailoring houses like Chan's, where all the work is done on the premises, are rapidly being replaced by less exacting shops, which send out garments piecemeal to factories in mainland China. Of course, a proud man like Mr. Kiang would never permit such an arrangement.
He handed me his business card with two hands, as is the Chinese tradition, and promised he would visit the United States twice a year for new suit fittings and to make alterations on this one. Ruth joined me in her new chocolate brown outfit, and both of us, dizzy from a week on the streets, said goodbye to our tailors and to Hong Kong itself -- pondering, as we would a Zen riddle, how a "Super Saver" vacation could have cost so much money.

Getting There
Cathay Pacific's Super Saver deal is no longer available, but its new $999 30-day All-Asia Pass ($899 if you go through its Web site, www.cathay-usa.com), which is in effect through the end of the year, includes round-trip economy class service from New York or Los Angeles to Hong Kong with stops allowed in 17 additional Asian cities. For a brochure, call (800) 228-4297. Reservations: (800) 233-2742.
 
Lodging
The Regal Riverside, (852) 2649-7878, fax (852) 2637-4748, is on Tai Chung Kiu Road in Shatin. Doubles are $265, tax included.
 
Shopping
David's Shirts at 33 Kimberley Road, (852) 2367-9556, and W. W. Chan and Sons and Irene Fashions, at Burlington House, 94 Nathan Road, (852) 2367-5588, are in the heart of the Golden Mile tourist district in Tsim Sha Tsui on the Kowloon side of Hong Kong. (There is another branch of David's Shirts at the Mandarin Hotel, and another branch of Irene's at 86-90 Wellington Street in Central.) Shirts at David's range from $85 to $300. Men's suits at Chan's range from $650 to $2,000. Women's suits at Irene's start at $750. Luckily, the place with the best foreign exchange rate in town is there: City Foreign Exchange, near the back of Chungking Mansion arcade at 36-44 Nathan Road.
We received about 7.7 Hong Kong dollars to $1 (the rate is now $7.11 Hong Kong to the dollar). All the shops we visited took major credit cards, but payment in American dollars was not generally accepted.
Hollywood Road, in Central, is Hong Kong's antiques row. Arch Angel Antiques is at number 49-51, (852) 2851-6828; Wing Tei Curios is at No. 190F, (852) 2547-4755. Windsor House is at 10-18 Po Hing Fong, (852) 2850-7813. Mountain Folk Craft is at 12 Wo On Lane, (852) 2523-2817; Shanghai Tang is at 12 Pedder Street, (852) 2525-7333. DAVID HOCHMAN

LENGTH: 1355 words

HEADLINE: Q&A/Elena deMurias;
Banker to Museum Director With a Mission

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
WHEN the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport sought a new director in 1995, a startling 85 candidates applied. Only one did not have any prior museum experience. That was Elena deMurias, who landed the job.
Ms. deMurias, whose name reflects her Cuban roots, had worked overseas for many years as an international banker. She lived and traveled throughout Asia, Europe and Latin America. Three years ago the intrepid Ms. deMurias and four other women sailed a sloop from southern Maine to Connecticut during Hurricane Felix.
The trustees wanted someone energetic and creative to shake up the 36-year-old science and art museum. "What they wanted was a change agent who could move the museum into the next generation," Ms. deMurias explained. They got that, all right. 
 Dozens of programs fill the museum. A Challenger capsule attracts teachers and students captivated by space. Occasionally Girl Scouts can be heard whispering through the wee hours as they bed down in sleeping bags for a museum overnighter. Every Tuesday elderly men and women visit the museum to hear a Metropolitan Museum traveling lecture on art. And planning is underway for eight different summer camps.
Her most recent accomplishment was securing accreditation for Discovery Museum, only 1 of 18 in the State of Connecticut to achieve this distinction. In practical terms accreditation makes it easier to borrow colleagues' holdings, obtain grants and participate in professional programs.
The Discovery combines a children's museum with art and science. "The Discovery Museum is all three and we belong to all three professional associations," explained Ms. de Murias. "We try to do programs that incorporate all three, very much like the Leonardo DaVinci model."
Ms. deMurias has many dreams for the museum, some of which she shared in a recent interview. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Do you find suburbanites resistant to coming into the city to visit Discovery Museum?
A. The flip side of that is the reluctance that Bridgeport parents feel about sending their children to the white suburbs. Having the museum as a neutral zone makes it safe, easy and acceptable for both groups.
It is difficult when people look at our address and see Bridgeport. However, right off the Merritt Parkway, we find we have a positive geographic location. We get a lot of schoolchildren who go home and tell their parents about coming to the museum. The parents then feel it is safe to come back again.
A lot of parents also come as chaperones. Word of mouth is very important for us. We have a stable 93,000 visitors each year, about half schoolchildren and half general public.
We are the only space-oriented museum with a planetarium and a Challenger Learning Center.
Q. What is the Challenger Learning Center?
A. The Challenger Learning Center was founded by the seven families of the Challenger astronauts to continue the crew's education mission. What they wanted to do was "to prepare youth to live wisely and productively in a technological society." They felt that through a mock-up of the capsule and mission control, students would learn to understand the concept of space exploration and also the different scientific principles behind the experience and the communications that go into having a space mission.
There are only 25 in the United States and Canada. Students come from New York and all over New England to do the Challenger mission. One day recently we had a school from the Bronx and one from Rhode Island. This is a program for fifth grade and above.
We are working with NASA and the Connecticut Museum Collaborative for Science Education to start a teacher resource room for space science. Recently we received 1,700 pounds of CD-ROMs and other things to set up a new library. Teachers can use the resources. With Mir and the different space shuttles there is a tremendous amount of interest.
Q. Have you changed the art program?
A. We have upgraded the art programs I think a 1,000 percent, particularly, by bringing in an internationally renown curator, Ben Ortiz.
We have two main shows a year which are public shows. We have established the Partnership in Arts and Learning between the suburbs and inner city Bridgeport where we team up schools from each area to come to the museum and get to know each other.
We have 800 students coming in twice a year for this program from Bridgeport, Trumbull, Fairfield and New Haven.
We base the program on the public art show. We have art, dance and science components. Now they are using the Barnum Show.
Q. What outreach efforts does the museum have?
A. We have a whole team who go from Greenwich to Stratford two or three days a week. They usually fill up the whole back of a car. They may teach a course in physical sciences -- for example, electricity or bubbles. We also have a number of community centers like the McGiveny Center and Family Services Whitfield who bring their students here for after school programs.
Another piece of our outreach program is in the arts. We just finished an AIDS mural. We had child artists ages 9 through 12. Our teachers coordinated it. It's on the McGiveny Center wall. We worked with a group called Spanish Fly, a Hispanic group of young people in their early 20's who promote the arts in Bridgeport and the Hispanic community.
Q. Where does the museum's money come from?
A. Our money is mainly private. We get no money from the city or state except for program-oriented money. For example, the City of Fairfield has an escrow account of $25,000 for the use of their school children. Bridgeport has a $30,000 account for the schools.
Our school programs really drive what we do here. The admission and the fund-raising fall into place after that. We get some grants and private money. An enthusiastic group of volunteers called the Benefits Committee led by Martha Gesswein from Fairfield raises more than half.
We started a new program called Sunday Celebrations. It is funded partly by the Connecticut Commission on the Arts and Chase Manhattan Bank. It is a program to bring diversity to the museum on the weekends. Every three weeks we bring in an artists from different cultures to entertain and to provide a Sunday afternoon festival. Recently we had Senagalese drummers and Chinese instruments for 600 people.
We had blacks, Asians, whites, Hispanics; we had young, we had old. It was what I want to turn the museum into, a place where everybody in the community feels comfortable to be a part of what we do.
Q. Is the museum planning to move to the Harborplace redevelopment on the waterfront?
A. We think it is important for the Discovery Museum to be part of this cultural and economic development. We have begun to talk to the developers who won the project, Alex Conroy from Fairfield and ERE Yarmouth of Australia. They are very excited about having the Discovery Museum be part of the complex.
It is a huge commitment. In order to do this we would have to raise a great deal of money. We would go from 30,000 to 120,000 square feet. It is an opportunity to take all the pieces we do in a small way and be able to offer them in a much larger way.
We would have to raise between $30 million and $40 million. (Now we raise about $300,000 each year.) It is absolutely huge but the excitement is there. People love to give to a dream and to something they had a part in building. There is excitement in the suburbs as well. For Bridgeport it is exciting because it would be much more accessible. Kids would be able to walk to us after school.
What we are doing right now is talking to people to find out what dreams other places have had and been successful with. We've been to the Legislature and presented our plan to the Commerce Committee.
The designers who we are working with must think in a completely different way. They have to think of exhibits that cross our three areas -- the children's museum, art and science. If for some reason the move doesn't happen, we will be able to bring all this expertise and new excitement into the Discovery Museum right here.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Elena deMurias, director of the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport, in the Challenger Learning Center. (Gale Zucker for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 2; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1145 words

HEADLINE: The View From/Pleasantville;
U.N. Women Help 'Poorest of the Poor' of World's Children

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES; PLEASANTVILLE

 BODY:
A GROUP of articulate, intelligent women were gathered around a table decorated with ornaments from India, speaking in the accents of various countries: Ecuador, Austria, Japan, India and the United States. The wives of employees or consultants to the United Nations, they could simply have been enjoying themselves on a lovely spring afternoon at the home of Uma Banerjee.
But Mrs. Banerjee, who is from New Delhi and whose husband, Ajit, is a senior technical adviser to the United Nations, and the others were not just having fun at a pleasant social lunch. They are members of the United Nations Women's Guild, and they were planning a fund-raising, 50th anniversary gala, which will raise money for, as Mrs. Banerjee put it, "the poorest of the poor" of the world's children. The event, to be held May 1 at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, will feature a fashion show of native costumes by the wives of various ambassadors. It is open only to those members of the public -- private individuals or businesses and corporations -- who can pay several thousand dollars for a page in the fund-raising journal; otherwise, guild members will pay for their own tickets at $100 a person. 
 They pay -- or in more subtle terms -- contribute -- in other ways as well. Members of the guild raise about $160,000 a year; they not only put their own money into their projects but also put in time and effort. These women do not delegate jobs to staff members -- there are no staff members of the organization. They do virtually everything themselves, from contributing money to taking trips to far-flung places to visit people in need. Mrs. Banerjee, a sophisticated woman with high cheekbones and lively eyes, went, for example, to the Little Flower School in the foothills of the Himalayas. The main wall of the school had been swept away by a mud slide during the rainy season. The children there are disabled. They need prostheses and medicine and, often, simply a place to live. She presented them with a check and talked to them about what the guild does.
"It is very grass roots," she said. "No administrative costs. We go and we give."
Money comes from special events, fund-raising drives and the sale of T-shirts and souvenirs with the guild's logo at the United Nations gift shop. The organization supports 160 projects a year in 82 countries, said Ilsa Reynolds, an Austrian who lives in Scarsdale with her American husband, Philip, a senior officer with the United Nations Development Program.
The poverty in some developing countries, the women added, is mind boggling, even compared with the worst poverty in the United States. In these countries there is no running water, not enough vaccination medicine and many diseases that are virtually unheard of here. There is also a different mood: the violence one tends to associate with severe poverty in American cities is absent; children, despite their dire conditions, seem relatively content and will smile at the smallest things -- a wooden toy, a friendly visitor.
Connie Vegega, an American who lives in Dobbs Ferry with her Argentine husband, Carlos, vice chairman of the International Civil Service Commission for the United Nations, has visited Hugar de Nino Dre Zanocchi, an orphanage in a suburb of Buenos Aires. In this institution are children who are abandoned by parents who have no money to care for them. Some of the youngsters are dramatically disfigured by birth defects. "They're children born without legs or arms, children who are retarded and who were simply abandoned to the streets," Mrs. Vegega said. "Sometimes they are superstitious. Parents give them up because they feel they have done something wrong in life to produce a child with such handicaps.
"When I went there, it was so horrible, so sad, I could not even take photographs." Buenos Aires, she explained, is a city of great contrast between wealth and poverty. Next door to the orphanage is a private school for well-to-do girls. "Thank God, those girls go over each day and help care for these children."
LeNelle Suharto of Larchmont, whose Indonesian husband, Sam, is a senior statistical officer with the United Nations, has worked with children and girls just reaching puberty in Southeast Asia. In Thailand, she said, 9-year-olds are sold in the street as prostitutes. This practice was particularly prevalent during the Vietnam War. Unwanted by either Thai or American families, many of the offspring of young Southeast Asian women and American soldiers now need help breaking the cycle of prostitution and poverty.
Emperatriz Machuca, a native of Ecuador who lives in Eastchester with her husband, Clemente, a United Nations translator, said she frequently travels to her native country to help children in the poorest sections. She has also gone to Namibia in Africa. Some of the children there, she said, are "literally living in the bush" in child societies. Women's guild members do not try to change their basic culture, but they do take needed medical supplies and offer opportunities to read books and gain knowledge. Last year, the guild received a letter from one of the first young men in the area to go to college and graduate.
For Naoko Ishigami, who lives in Closter, N.J., with her husband, Yasunobu, who is in Technology Services at the United Nations, volunteering with the guild has meant helping people in her native Japan when a disastrous earthquake struck four years ago. It also meant designing this year's commemorative mug, which depicts children of various races and nationalities smiling as they make their way down a long slide. "Children play in universal ways, and I thought this would be appropriate," she said.
Nor does the guild benefit only the recipients of its charitable projects. Members say that the organization engenders in them a sense of camaraderie and belonging. "We United Nations wives must go wherever our husbands are transferred," Mrs. Banerjee said. "I've lived in 27 countries. This can take its toll. You are happy to find others who understand your unique situation."
Friendships are especially needed in America, Mrs. Reynolds added. "When you are stationed in a small developing country, there is usually a small community of foreign families living basically in one area. People reach out to each other and, because there are no movies or restaurants, your social life is just largely entertaining at home. But here in the United States it is different. Everyone is busy going out, going to work, going to the movies, to exercise classes, to school, or, if they're home, they're in front of their computers on the Internet. You can have neighbors and barely know or see them. The guild provides United Nations wives not only a chance to do some good for the children of the world but also to feel a part of a warm, rewarding circle of friends."

HEADLINE: Giving Schoolchildren Tools to Succeed

SERIES: MAKING A DIFFERENCE: Another in a series of articles about men and women who have changed life on Long Island.

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER 

 BODY:
GERARD LEEDS has always considered himself lucky. He escaped Nazi Germany in 1939, shortly after sweeping up the glass in his synagogue on Kristallnacht.
He was lucky in the electronics business and lucky at love. Mr. Leeds, now 75, met a mathematician, Lilo Schott, his wife and business partner of 47 years, at the only ski resort in the Adirondacks with snow on the slopes on New Year's Day 1950. 
 In 1971, Mr. Leeds started CMP Publications with The Electronic Buyer's News from his living room in Great Neck. The next year, the first issue of The Electronic Engineering Times was printed.
CMP Publications in Manhassset evolved into one of the largest high-technology media companies, CMP Media Inc. This year the company, whose publications include HomePC, Information Week and Windows Magazine, went public.
By 1988, Mr. and Mrs. Leeds, co-chairmen of the CMP board, retired from active management and appointed their oldest son, Michael, as president.
Another son, Dan, took over the printing plant and, eventually, international operations.
That could have been a time to relax, ski, hike and enjoy five children and 12 grandchildren. Instead the Leeds spent a year deciding how to use their resources. By last year CMP Media had revenues of $474 million. Its operating income was $39 million, including a $4.4 million gift of shares by the Leeds to the employees.
The couple donated $21 million from the stock sale through two foundations to the Institute for Community Development, which they founded in 1990 to improve the quality of education for children who might not complete school. The institute, which is changing its name to the Institute for Student Advancement, is headquartered in a wing of CMP headquarters on Community Drive.
Education, the Leedses say, is the key to breaking the cycle of poverty. "We started from the point that you have to do well and then you can do good," Mr. Leeds said. "I have a perfectly good pair of skis to ski on good snow and I have an old pair of skis to ski on rocks. A million dollars might buy 10,000 pairs of skis. But what do I do with the 9,998 others after the first two? It's really what you commit yourself to. There's so much to be done."
Mr. Leeds attended a high school in Hamburg that specialized in science and engineering. He attended 12 schools in the United States, studying mostly electrical engineering, before he received a B.S. at Adelphi in 1962.
Mrs. Leeds also escaped Nazi Germany, arriving here with her family at the age of 11. Together the Leedses received M.A.'s at the State University at Stony Brook and received honorary doctorates in 1996.
Before going into publishing, Mr. Leeds worked on a microwave relay link and started an electronic research business that made an electronic flash with a built-in autotransformer for photography. He was a sales engineer in the digital-computer business and made nuclear counters. In another venture, his Lumatron Electronics company developed the first commercial sampling scope. He started an operational amplifier business, the Data Device Company, which merged with Solid State Scientific, a semiconductor company in Philadelphia.
The Institute for Community Development involves businesses, other charities, schools, parents and governments. Started with 25 students at Roosevelt Junior-Senior High School who had low grades, attendance problems and poor attitudes, two programs, Comet and STAR, now work with 1,400 middle and high school students in six districts.
The institute runs programs in Roosevelt, Hempstead, as well as Brooklyn, Mount Vernon and Troy, N.Y.
"What we're doing now with the institute," Mr. Leeds said, "is more exciting than building a company. Our goal is to someday be at a point where a million children are in programs like this, and someday further than that, all children will get the education they need to succeed."
STAR, which stands for Success Through Academic Readiness, features four years of daily academic enrichment, counseling and support.
The Comet middle-school program for 12- to 14-year-olds, began in 1993 as Children of Many Educational Talents. It tries to help youngsters improve attitudes and academic performance. Students sign contracts to agree to attend school and enrichment classes before and after the usual school day.
For the first two years, Mr. Leeds said, the couple donated a few hundred thousand dollars a year to pay for the entire program. They wanted to do something about high dropout rates, low graduation rates and even lower rates of college-bound students.
"What's remarkable about it is here on Long Island there is a tradition of neighborhood schools and local school districts," said Patrick G. Halpin, the co-executive director of the institute and former Suffolk County Executive. "Very few people look beyond the boundaries of their own community, and they usually don't worry too much about kids who aren't making it in some other community, especially poor ones.
"What the institute did was to say that's unacceptable. We all have a responsibility and we all bear the costs when students aren't successful, even if they aren't from our neighborhood. Kids who graduate, have to function at a much higher skill level. The rise in standards and Regents requirements for graduation underscore that. The institute has developed these exceptional programs that helped schools have large numbers of underachieving students hit those benchmarks."
All the students in STAR have graduated from high school, with 96 percent going to college.
"Part of my job," Mr. Leeds said, "is to convince people to reorder their priorities. There are a lot of worthwhile causes to give money to, the church, the hospitals, the museums. We think education is primary. Education can change the world. We support all kinds of things in a responsible way. But we're reserving the substance of what we're able to do for education."
Mr. Leeds said he donated $2 million a year, or one-third the annual budget of the institute. One-third comes from 1,200 to 1,500 companies and foundations. The balance is from the state.
"We're in discussions with other school districts on Long Island," Mr. Leeds said. "It is purely a matter of funding. They would start tomorrow."
Earl Mitchell, a double major in business and history who is on the dean's list at Adelphi, was failing four subjects in the ninth grade at Roosevelt Junior-Senior High School when he joined STAR. "I was a little disruptive in class," Mr. Mitchell recalled. "I was a class clown. The environment could turn a child out. It will take you under if you're not strong."
By the end of the 10th grade, he had pulled up his average to 84. In the 11th grade he grew upset if he received less than a 90.
He is now a mentor at the STAR program in Hempstead.
"This is the best thing I did," he added. "It's a choice I made and never regretted. I got a lot of personal and undivided attention, a lot of support and people to help me function. The staff was very dedicated, and that's what the key was. I think they fill in a lot of the blanks. When I got to high school the path I was following was not going to lead me to college."
All the 24 students in his group went to college.
In the Comet classroom at Alverta B. Gray-Schultz Middle School in Hempstead several eighth graders gathered around a coordinator who was conducting a review before quarterly examinations.
A sign on the wall read, "When you believe in yourself, anything is possible."
The institute hires the four academic coordinators, two counselors and program director at Schultz to work with 100 seventh and eighth graders and add support for regular teachers.
The staff monitors attendance and attitude with daily telephone calls home. The students are sent to a three-week summer orientation program, including a three day retreat, with the staff members, who also eat lunch with the youngsters in the classroom and conduct an incentive program that includes trips to Broadway plays, restaurants, ice skating, skiing and bowling.
"That's our way of bridging the gap that might exist between school and home," the Comet program director in Hempstead, Debbie Morton, said. "We're that parent away from home. We're their eyes and ears. We provide a lot of love, a lot of nurturing, a lot of support. We deal not only with the cognitive domain, but the affective domain, as well."
The counselors work on social and personal development and hold forums with the students on topics like drugs, peer pressure and sex.
"We have a significant number of children who attend school who need additional support," said Diane Brown, principal of Hempstead Middle School, which is in an area with the largest number of people on Long Island who are infected with H.I.V., drug addicts and people in jail.
Ms. Brown said she believed that support from the Leedses enabled the school to pass preliminary competency tests in 1995 and last year and added:
"That's what the Leeds did. They provided additional support in an organized, systematic, well-thought-out process, so that the support could become institutionalized in the daily operation of the school. I can't imagine working without it. Every function that we have the Leedses are both here with their support. They sit down with the children. With all that they have, they sit down very comfortably and talk with the children and parents here. It's just so unique.
"The smile, the warmth when you meet them. They have these genuine smiles that permeate what they do, this gift. It's really incredible, the commitment that they have."
Lavinia Dickerson, a psychologist and an educator who developed the program, said: "Gerry and Lilo are people who wanted to contribute to the betterment of the world that they live in. We've learned from each other. I've learned how business people approach what they see as the bottom line. I understand their sense of how they hold for this whole issue of accountability, which is a very different view than schools and educators tend to take. It doesn't mean that they can't reach a balanced understanding of each other's approach. We've proven that, because we've been able to work together collectively over these many years. Add in the element of my co-partner, who comes from the political and public-policy arena.
"If anything, this partnership shows when you combine those three elements which are very different together, even though the words to articulate an issue may be different, we are all on the same page to improve the quality of education for low-performing students so they can become self-sufficient human beings."
The cost for four to six years for a young person in the programs is $20,000.
The institute also gives more than $100,000 a year to STAR graduates to help pay for transportation, books and similar expenses.
"When these children graduate from college," Mr. Leeds said, "they'll be making $30,000 to $40,000 a year. They'll average paying $10,000 a year in taxes. When they graduate from college, in two years they'll have paid society back in taxes. After that society gets its money back every two years for the working life of each person. That's a pretty remarkable payoff on an investment. You can't get that on municipal bonds.
"That does not say anything about the money saved in the costs from jail and the number of people on welfare. All the hospital costs and the other costs of violence. It's a tremendously powerful economic thing. The most exciting part of all this is, it works."
CMP has long had an active social role. At Mrs. Leeds's urging, the company was the first to offer day care on Long Island, now running a center for 85 preschoolers and 50 school-age children. CMP publishes 10 domestic print and on-line magazines, has wholly owned and joint ventures in Germany, France and Britain and networks, licenses and represents more than 100 publications worldwide.
"One of the values of the company." Michael Leeds said, "is that it doesn't just stand for driving profits for the owners or the shareholders. There's a lot of good that comes out of those profits, and it's very visible to the people in the company. It's a role model for Long Island.
"My parents' generosity is an example and will be something that other people will aspire to and match. They've been very fortunate. They've taken their fortune and shared it with others. It sets a standard. It's not only a good example, but it's a standard, too, that other people can match up to. They're doing it with their time. They're doing it with their energy and they're doing what they like. There are very few superstars that are willing to give up a business career and do things in the community.
"Money facilitates a lot of things. But it doesn't make anything happen by itself. You really need the people. You need the leadership. That's where the magic is. If you look at I.C.D. and how rapidly it's grown and how effective it is, that's not just because there's money. It was because it had the leadership of my parents and the people they brought in and led and developed that make it a successful program. One of the goals of I.C.D. is to not be personally funded, because then it's not enduring, either. It's what you do with your time and where you commit yourself that really makes a difference."
The Leedses have also become involved in "girls' equity," supporting organizations that help girls develop self-esteem and equal opportunity in the classroom. The couple also support arts organizations and other charities.
Mrs. Leeds works closely with the Child Care Council of Nassau County and the Great Neck-Manhasset Community Child Care Partnership, Inc. She is on the advisory boards of a child-care center at Hofstra and the Uniondale day-care center and is working with the Great Neck School District to set up a committee on caring for young children.
Through the Long Island Funders Group she is on a team that is trying to help home day-care providers with low-cost loans. Mrs. Leeds is also working on an initiative with a small-business group to teach day-care providers to run their centers as businesses.
Mrs. Leeds describes herself as a feminist, extremely concerned with women's rights to have careers and raise families. In 1949, as a mathematician at Bell Laboratories, she said, she realized that female mathematicians earned half as much as male colleagues. Pregnant at the time, she went to her manager and within a year all the female mathematicians' salaries were doubled.
Mrs. Leeds is analytical and methodical. Mr. Leeds is passionate and fiery, a salesman.
Michael Leeds said his parents were a strong team that operated independently but with the same set of values. In general, he said, his mother is much more attuned to people's personal feelings and his father is much more attuned to driving a business forward, but sometimes not recognizing where people's feelings are. "There are only a few people on Long Island who have made a lot of money here who give it back to Long Island," said Roger Tilles, senior vice chairman of Tilles Center and a longtime friend of the Leedses. "There are very very few people who put their time and efforts and energies, in addition to their money, into charity. The Leedses do that. They are a combination of intelligent and charitable at the same time. They infect other people with their own energy."
"Gerry and Lilo are exemplars,"Msgr. Tom Hartman, said. "They are a very good role model for businesses and corporations. I do believe it's a mentality more than a business strategy. It's a mindset of how to treat people. They believe every day is a gift and they're here to do good. They offer their time, their thoughts, their money unhesitatingly. They could speak to the most intelligent of entrepreneurs. They could speak to Wall Street and they could feel the heart of the poor, the abandoned and the downcast."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: A $2.3 Million Renovation for a Bridgeport Theater;
New Home for Polka Dot Playhouse

 BODY:
Bridgeport's venerable Polka Dot Playhouse will soon have an elegant new home that bears no resemblance to the purple polka-dotted building in which it opened as a community theater 44 years ago.
After a $2.3 million renovation, the new home will be in an 82-year-old, marble-clad former People's Bank building on State Street and an adjacent red brick office building developed by P.T. Barnum, the circus impresario and onetime Mayor of Bridgeport. The renovation begins this month with completion expected in early fall. 
 The project reflects a trend of converting stately old bank buildings that have been displaced by multiple small banking offices into other uses.
The Bridgeport architectural firm of Fletcher Thompson has redesigned about half of the bank into a theater seating 223 people. Three years ago the rest of the bank building became Roberto's Italian Restaurant, with an entrance on Main Street, and will remain so.
The first two floors of the five-floor Barnum's building will be converted into the theater entrance, a formal lobby and bar, box-office, "green room" and dressing rooms. In all, the project will encompass 12,581 square feet.
"The addition of a marquee and the removal of a coat of tan paint to expose the original bricks will be the only changes in the exterior appearance of these marvelous old buildings," said Bruce Heyl, vice president at Fletcher Thompson.
The interior marble walls of the bank will also be preserved, thanks to a series of strategically placed acoustic panels that will absorb marble-generated echos.
The renovation will end two stressful years for the Playhouse. In 1996 it was cut off from its customers when the bridge connecting its Pleasure Beach Island site to the mainland burned. But in a fortuitous bit of timing, the Connecticut General Assembly had set aside $25 million to help revive Bridgeport's economy, some say as compensation for rejecting the city's request for a gambling casino.
The theater received $2 million from the fund, $300,000 from the Connecticut Department of Economic Development and use of the People's Bank rent-free for 10 years.
