HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Talk About Multiplying Like Rabbits . . .

BYLINE: By NEIL GENZLINGER 

 BODY:
FIRST let me say that I have nothing against wildlife as a group. Wild animals perform many valuable services for our state, like harboring deer ticks and giving us an excuse to put eco-friendly license plates on our gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles. So I am in no way disparaging wildlife when I say this:
Will somebody please get these danged rabbits out of my yard? 
 Although the state has yet to waste any tax money conducting a rabbit census, we can safely conclude that there are approximately 71 million wild rabbits in New Jersey, using the following formula:

3R x 4,748,160 = approximately 71 million
 
where 4,748,160 is the total acreage of the state and R is the number of rabbits I am likely to see on a spring evening munching simultaneously on my third-of-an-acre property -- namely, five.
It's not just me, you understand. Every yard around seems to have an R value in the three-to-seven range. The beasts are Eastern cottontails, Dave Chanda of the state Wildlife Education Office told me, and the mild winter may have left more of them intact than usual.
It is virtually impossible to dislike rabbits, since they are, of course, adorable. Smart, too. I borrowed a Have-a-Heart trap. The rabbits, once they stopped laughing, actually dragged it to the curb on trash night.
Yet we should not let the cute smartness of rabbits blind us to the fact that they drain approximately $403 million a year from our state's economy, based on this formula:

T x 8,052,849 = approximately $403 million
 
where 8,052,849 is the state's population and T is the amount an average New Jerseyan, i.e. me, spent last fall on tulip bulbs that will never bloom because rabbits bit their heads off -- namely, $50.
I know various solutions to the rabbit problem are available. For instance, it appears rabbits don't like daffodils. Unfortunately, neither do I. Mr. Chanda pointed out that garden stores sell small-animal repellent. But it stinks, I said. "That's probably why it's working on the rabbits," he said.
There's fencing, of course, but that seems like an admission of defeat. A more sophisticated strategy is to get to know the enemy. So I looked at some Web sites. That's where I found Shelley Stack and the New Jersey Chapter of the House Rabbit Society.
Ms. Stack, who lives in Matawan and is the chapter manager, knows that sometime during Easter week a child -- presumably one you're related to, but maybe not -- will catch sight of rabbits in a pet store window and say, "Please, please, can I have one?" Ms. Stack hopes you resist.
That's because she hears from too many people whose goal in life is to get rid of pet rabbits they bought on a whim. The House Rabbit Society is a nonprofit group that tries to educate people about rabbit ownership, but a lot of folks don't want education; they just want to jettison their rabbits.
"They have all kinds of excuses: 'We're moving,' 'We have allergies,' " Ms. Stack said. She was getting 5 or 10 such calls a day; finally she changed the message on her answering machine to make clear that her group doesn't take in rabbits, but tries to find homes for those already abandoned.
There are plenty of those. Parks are a common dumping ground, Ms. Stack said; people either don't realize or don't care that pet rabbits generally can't survive in the wild. Supermarket parking lots, inexplicably, are another favorite of pet abandoners. The creativity award, though, goes to the person who recently smuggled a rabbit into a pet store in Eatontown and slipped it into an empty cage, a sort of reverse shoplifting.
Probably you've guessed that I'm preaching from experience: there's a pet rabbit in our garage. I actually like the little guy, kinda. But it's humiliating knowing that at the very moment I'm cleaning his hutch, his wild cousins are making my flower beds the laughingstock of the Garden State.
So don't be an idiot. Glance in the pet store window, then keep walking. You'll get your rabbit soon enough anyway. In four years, to be exact, as shown by the following formula:
 
 71,000,000 + (71,000,000/2 x 5 x 4) + (P/2 x 5 x 4) . . . x Y x 90 > 29.78 trillion
 
where five is the average number of rabbits in a litter, four is the number of litters the average rabbit has in a year, P is the previous year's rabbit population, 90 is the number of square inches an average rabbit takes up, 29.78 trillion is the number of square inches in New Jersey and Y is years.
That's right, in four years New Jersey will be completely covered in a carpet of rabbits. That last formula may not be quite right -- I was never very good at math -- but I don't have time to check it. I have to get to the hardware store. There's a sale on fencing.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 5; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1237 words

HEADLINE: Hunger Is an Issue Not Just at Holidays

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
NO snow? No problem. The Northwest Center for Family Service and Mental Health is offering "Not Ski" tags that look like lift tickets, and will have a fake ski party, as a way to raise money this month.
"You don't have to deal with the cold or the Spandex clothing, but you can still have the bragging rights if you hang the tag from your jacket," said Carol A. Mack, the development coordinator for the center, which has offices in Torrington, Lakeville and Winsted. "We try to make people laugh a little at this rather dull time of the year, and remind them that we're here." 
 A year ago, the center sent out an appeal printed on a brown paper bag and asked people to "brown bag" it to work and send them the money they save on lunch. The year before, they sent a tea bag and asked for donations for a tea party that they wouldn't have to attend. Each year about this time the center raises about $5,000 with Mrs. Mack's quirky ideas.
Increasingly, Connecticut nonprofit organizations are trying innovative ways to raise money this time of year, typically the slowest of times for donations.
"In December, we took in more than 19,000 pounds of food," said Mary S. Biggs, director of the Food Bank of Lower Fairfield County. "In February, it was a fraction of that. We get a huge outpouring of sharing over the holidays, but it drops off to nothing at the first of the year and by summer our shelves are empty."
Gloria J. McAdam, president of Foodshare in Windsor, which distributes almost 5 million pounds of food a year to 200 organizations in the greater Hartford area, said one of the largest events her organization sponsors each year is the Walk Against Hunger, the first Sunday in May.
"We do it in May for a variety of reasons, not the least of which is it's six months away from Thanksgiving," Ms. McAdam said. "It kind of balances out the year, makes people aware of the need at a time of the year when they might not otherwise be thinking about it."
"More than half of all our donations from individuals come in during November and December, and we certainly don't want to discourage that," Ms. McAdam said. "That's part of what our plan for the year is -- we know that's going to happen at the end of the year, and if we're spending more money than we're taking in it will hopefully balance out at end of the year."
The problem is, in the summer months the demand is just as high or higher, she said. If a family's finances are very tight, it might rely on the free meals children get at school to balance the food budget, and a problem exists in the summer when the children are not in school.
Lillian Maffia, manager of the St. Vincent DePaul Society of Waterbury Soup Kitchen, which serves about 25,000 meals a month, estimated that she collects 40 percent of her annual donations in the last two months of the year, versus 15 percent in the first three months. She has asked some schools and other organizations that volunteered to do food drives at Christmas to do them at Easter instead, when there is a greater need.
She said part of the problem is the misperception that there are fewer people in economic distress because business profits are up.
"One more person tells me the economy is great, and I'm going to scream," Ms. Maffia said. "There are jobs, but they're low-paying jobs, and even a single guy can't make it. We have a lot of men who work and don't make enough money so they have to come here and we help them take home meals for their family every day."
"It used to be we saw these people the last week of the month, then it went to last two weeks," Ms. Maffia said. "Now, after the 10th of the month we're starting to see a rise, because they're starting to save for their rent and their utilities and there isn't money for food."
Not everyone sees such a large percentage of their income arrive late in the year. Emily J. Gros, development director for the Ronald McDonald House of New Haven, which provides temporary quarters for the families of sick children when they are away from home for treatment, said two of the organization's major fund-raising events are timed to coincide with the holiday spirit of giving: its Trees of Hope, where businesses and service organizations donate a decorated tree that is sold to raise money, and Lights of Love, where people pay $5 to sponsor a light on the tree at the house.
But the organization's annual appeal starts in July, it receives bequests and memorial donations throughout the year, and its biggest fund-raising event, she said, is typically a golf tournament in September, which raises $60,000 to $70,000.
"For us, on a fund-raising calendar, September would be our best month," Ms. Gros said. "We're not quite as cyclical as some other nonprofits might be, but we still see fewer donations after you get past the holidays."
Still, Nancy L. Carrington, executive director of the Connecticut Food Bank, said most nonprofit organizations face the same situation as the Waterbury soup kitchen, with half or more of their annual budget raised in the last few weeks of the year, then donations dropping off to almost nothing for January through mid-year, at least. She said not only is it the holiday spirit of giving, but people are often reminded to take advantage of the tax benefits of charitable contributions. In the early part of the year it's not that people don't care, it's just that they don't think about it as much, she said.
The food bank distributed 3.5 million pounds of food in 1996, and 4.1 million pounds last year, often filling its larder with dented cans or crushed boxes, or other things that the supermarkets cannot easily sell.
"We have some holiday Rice Krispies in the warehouse right now," Ms. Carrington said. "Any time there's seasonal food, when the season is over, we generally get the food."
But Ms. Carrington said when a Providence, R.I., philanthropist made an offer to match all contributions to food banks during a 10-day period in February, up to $1 million, her organization put out a special appeal. She raised almost $70,000.
"Generally, people do want to help others. They just need to have the avenue opened for them, and be reminded," Ms. Carrington said. "If we hadn't had that special appeal, we might have collected $5,000 to $10,000 during the same period."
But even where matching grants are not available, organizations are finding that special appeals are effective -- with a greater emphasis being placed on "appeal."
Ms. Biggs of the Fairfield County food bank said her group has distributed bins in some neighborhoods of Greenwich, Cos Cob, Riverside and Stamford, similar to recycling bins in many communities, and asks people to put $2 to $4 of canned food a week in them out by their curb. Street captains pick them up and deliver them to a central location.
"We feel like this could be our best bet for keeping the shelves stocked all through the year, because it comes in every week," Ms. Biggs said. "That's what we need, people who give on a continuing basis." The program will soon be expanded to Darien, she said.
The food bank is also working with the local Council of Churches and Synagogues to establish a program under which each of its 86 members would have one food drive a year, staggered so that almost every week someone would be bringing in food. One member church has already had one and gathered 2,000 pounds of food.

HEADLINE: Neighbors Seek a Halt To Building Gas Pipeline

BYLINE: BY RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
OPPONENTS say that a high-pressure natural gas pipeline being constructed by Southern Connecticut Gas Company three feet underground along an 11-mile residential area through Stratford and Bridgeport presents a safety risk to homes, schools, churches parks and roadways.
They say the pipeline -- 16 inches in diameter and being built to fuel a new $260 million electric generating plant at Bridgeport Harbor for Duke Energy of North Carolina and the United Illuminating Company -- should be rerouted through Long Island Sound, where the Iroquois Gas line runs about six miles from the Milford shoreline, or to a more secluded pathway near Routes 8 and 25. But state and local officials, including the Department of Public Utility Control, as well as energy company engineers insist the pipeline is necessary to provide energy to customers this summer and to avoid power outages because of the rapidly growing need for additional sources of energy. While they concede that if the project is not completed by summer, it would have to be reconsidered and possibly even scrapped, they insist the chosen route is the best for long-term efficiency as well as economics. The proponents also say the pipeline will be safer and more durable than those already in existence, that the pressure will be considerably lower in the new pipeline. 
 The critics are unmoved. "If it's so safe, then let them build it through their own backyards," said State Representative Christopher Caruso, Democrat of Bridgeport, who is helping residents along the pipeline route in their battle to have it rerouted.
"This is a classic example of greedy and powerful corporations arrogantly forcing their will down the throats of ordinary citizens who probably don't have pockets deep enough to fight them," said Mr. Caruso. "But we're not giving up."
Stratford and Bridgeport residents who oppose the pipeline have organized a Coalition to Reroute the Pipeline; the coalition is preparing to go to court to seek a temporary injunction to stop the work that began several weeks ago.
Stratford residents are particularly outraged that the Town Council last month accepted a $1.5 million "host fee" from Bridgeport Energy, a subsidiary of Duke Energy, to drop its opposition to the pipeline. "They sold us out, plain and simple, they decided to take the bribe at the expense of residents' safety," said Paul Lovington, a 33-year town resident and a founder of the coalition. "This is the first time a pipeline of this type and size is being built under residential streets right next to all the other underground pipes including sewer lines, other gas lines and water lines," said Mr. Lovington, who does not live along the route but remembers "just recently there was a tragic explosion of a Massachusetts pipeline that led to a house being blown up that led to people's deaths and serious injuries."
Mr. Lovington said the energy companies have incorrectly classified the pipeline as a distribution line that delivers to residential customers and thus may be built under residential streets. It is, in fact, a one-terminus line, he said, "a major transmission line, but they don't want to call it that."
A Stratford Councilman-at-Large, Kent M. Miller, however, who voted to accept the host fee, said that as part of the agreement the town also gained additional safety measures, such as more safety valves and additional inspectors chosen by the town, but paid for by the Duke Energy.
"We realized that this is a fight we could not have won, so we decided to accept not only some money that will benefit all town residents, but to insist upon additional safety components that will make the pipeline safer than what engineers believe is even necessary," said Mr. Miller, who added that he would have voted against accepting the host fee if he believed there was any chance of stopping the pipeline through the courts.
The Council Chairwoman, Debbie Rose -- who before her election to the council last year began the grass roots opposition to the pipeline and voted against accepting the host fee -- said she would "never be convinced 100 percent that this will be safe." Ms. Rose also expressed the hope that residents would ultimately succeed in blocking the project.
At the Southern Connecticut Gas Company, however, Dave Silverstone, an incoming vice president, said the company is "either meeting and in most ways surpassing all of the safety standards at both the state and Federal level. After examining all possible routes, this was the one that posed the fewer problems and met all of the requirements we needed to get the project completed in a safe and efficient manner."
The general manager of Bridgeport Energy, Gianna Howard, said that her company's main concern was getting the pipeline constructed in time to provide energy to its customers by the summer -- and that the company left it up to Southern Connecticut Gas to find the best route to accomplish that.
"But safety is never, ever compromised," Ms. Howard said. "This project is crucial to our being able to generate efficient, low-cost energy for now and the future."
The state's Department of Public Utility Control approved the pipeline after conducting several public hearings, and argues that the pipeline presents no danger to residents in Stratford and Bridgeport.
"Not only do we believe the pipeline is safe, we believe that after exhaustive research we have an obligation, as a public service agency to approve this as a public service," said Beryl Lyons, a department spokeswoman.
The department's pipeline safety engineer, Philip Sher, said that under state regulations the gas company is allowed to generate several thousand pounds of gas pressure per square inch in this type of pipeline, but that it would only be generating 600 pounds.
Mr. Sher also said that the materials being used have mechanical abilities designed to make the pipeline particularly resistant to punctures by even the strongest and most powerful digging equipment, like backhoes.
"I believe that everything is being done that reasonably can be done to insure this pipeline is being constructed as safely as possible," said Mr. Sher. "This is a very special pipe that should be able to withstand just about anything that could possibly happen to it."
The department has also ruled that the pipeline does not "constitute a threat to the public health, welfare, and safety," as alleged by Stratford residents.
At a recent meeting in Bridgeport, the City Council voted unanimously to have Mayor Joseph P. Ganim refuse to sign permits to allow the project to continue, if, as some council members believe, the energy company continues to violate city ordinances by failing to have inspectors at work sites, and failing to post a $1 million bond to cover any construction problems.
Mayor Ganim was scheduled to meet with energy company officials by the end of last week. Chris Duby, a spokesman for Mr. Ganim, denied the Mayor was trying to make a host fee deal similar to Stratford's.
But there is apparently some support for such a fee. "Our first priority is of course safety, but I also think that if Stratford was offered $1.5 million, then the city of Bridgeport should have the same opportunity," said City Council president John Fabrizi. "The money is secondary, but it's something we have to think about."
But Carmen Franco, who has lived in Bridgeport his entire 74 years, said all he can think about is that his house will be less than 40 feet from the pipeline.
"When I go to sleep at night I don't want to have to worry about being blown up," said Mr. Franco. "It's just not fair that they can do this to us."
Armond Meroli, 85, of Stratford, agrees. For 52 years Mr. Meroli and his family have lived in his two-story, seven-room cape on Chicodee Lane in Stratford, a quiet residential street.
"My wife just died and I just want to live in my house peacefully for the time I have left," said Mr. Meroli. "Now, I worry about this every minute. I don't think after all these years I should have to."
Neither do Carol and Fred Haines, who moved into a sprawling converted barn last summer on Whippoorwill Lane in Stratford, across the road from the Mill River Country Club and golf course.
"We're horrified, just horrified that this would even be considered for such a densely populated area," said Mr. Haines. "All I can say is that if there is even one accident involving this pipeline, there are going to be a lot of angry people demanding to know why all the powers that be let this awful thing happen."

HEADLINE: County Rebounds With Rise In Jobs

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
WITH Westchester's latest unemployment figures at an all-time low and job growth robust, the county is finally flexing its economic muscle, continuing its recovery from a long-lasting downturn that -- like an illness that threatened to become chronic -- refused to go away.
"The recession here just didn't seem to end, and in many ways we're still on our way back," said Thomas J. Spitznas, a regional economist based in Mount Vernon. "But at least we're finally getting off the floor." 
 Appraising the economic indicators, economists reported that commercial vacancy rates were falling, residential sales were booming, house prices were on the way up and the county's tourism and hotel industries were gaining health.
In February, the most recent month for which figures are available, unemployment was 4.1 percent in Westchester, the lowest February figures for the county since 1990. The state's jobless rate was 6.8 percent for February, and for the nation, it was 5.0 percent -- the lowest figures for February on record.
Yet some disturbing symptoms of an economic malaise remained. While the economists had good news to report, their numbers offered little solace for those still looking for jobs. The gap between Westchester's rich and poor continued to widen, with some segments of the population taking home ever greater paychecks and others struggling to survive.
"People who are poor in this county have a more difficult time than poor people do elsewhere," said Christine Rohatynskyj, the executive director of Food-Patch, Westchester's food bank.
In one of the wealthiest counties in the state, according to the United States Census Bureau, being of modest means sometimes equates with poverty when factors like the cost of housing are considered.
"Sadly, there are folks who are playing by the rules and following the American dream and who still are not making ends meet," Ms. Rohatynskyj said. "At the same time that the economy is coming back, people of modest means are losing ground in Westchester."
Observing that New Yorkers had some of the highest average annual incomes in the United States, the Corporation for Enterprise Development, a Washington-based think tank, which rates states' economic performance, recently gave New York State a failing grade on one of its measurements because of the disparity between rich and poor statewide.
At the same time, the group also gave good grades to the state for finally ending its prolonged economic downslide and beginning to rebound.
In the Hudson Valley, the recovery in large part can be attributed to what seems to be the tapering off of corporate downsizings, which "cut into the bone as well as the fat" of the economy, Mr. Spitznas said.
But economists have been announcing for some time that the worst of the downsizing was past, and as Mr. Spitznas said last week, "People are still nervous -- they're still looking over their shoulders -- although they're not as nervous."
Indeed, worrisome news persists. Nine West, the White Plains shoe manufacturer, furloughed 85 of its 1,200 employees late last year and early this year. AT&T, too, planned to cut costs and eliminate jobs, mostly through attrition and retirement offers. About 270 of the company's 1,350 employees in Westchester were to be laid off, part of a national plan to streamline and revitalize the telecommunications company.
Texaco announced that it might reduce its work force of 1,200 at Harrison to 250; Prodigy Services laid off or redeployed 50 workers in White Plains; Tambrands' $1.85 billion merger with Procter & Gamble meant the dismantling of a 180-person work force in White Plains, and 22 bank branches in the county are candidates for consolidation, with 12 expected to close by midyear as the result of Chase Manhattan's $11 billion merger with Chemical Bank.
But there were many positive developments as well in the county's economic picture. For example, the White Plains Parker Corporation Center, a former International Business Machines site, is going to be renovated for multi-tenant use; SF Holdings in Valhalla completed an acquisition of the Fonda Group, a national producer of disposable food-service products; Foot Locker plans to move to the former Woolworth site in downtown White Plains, across the street from where Tishman Speyer Properties and Loews Theaters, a Sony Retail Entertainment company, recently announced that they would open a 24-screen, 5,200-seat movie theater.
Also, the Witco Organo Silicones Group announced plans last month to expand its Tarrytown laboratory, bringing 75 new jobs to the county; Pfizer, the world's sixth-largest drug maker, is hoping to link up with the Doral Arrowwood Conference Center to open a new training center with 130 employees in Rye Brook; PTI, a bicycle helmet manufacturer, expanded its Hastings-on-Hudson offices and added 40 new jobs; Philips Electronics is expanding its research staff by 150 employees in Briarcliff; Stew Leonard's, the Connecticut-based grocery store-tourist attraction, plans to open in Yonkers and hire 700 employees, and Sanford C. Bernstein and Company, a top Manhattan portfolio manager, announced plans to open offices in White plains and hire 300 people.
Overall, there was a net gain in 1997 of 4,800 private-sector jobs for Westchester, Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist with the State Department of Labor, reported.
Ross J. Pepe, president of the Construction Industry Council of Westchester and the Hudson Valley, said that new house construction, especially in the expensive home market, was proceeding apace to keep up with the new jobs being created in the county. Still, he said, jobs in the construction industry had not returned to the levels seen in the late 1980's before the recession took hold. "The signs are hopeful, but they could be better," Mr. Pepe said.
Residential sales reports for existing homes showed that there were 8,504 closings in 1997, the highest number since the Westchester County Board of Realtors and its subsidiary, the Westchester Putnam Multiple Listing Service, began keeping records in 1981. There was also a significant increase in the price of homes -- with the fourth quarter of 1997 showing a median sale price of $248,000, up by $14,000 from the fourth quarter the year before.
Home inventories, however, were limited, with Sylvia S. Ehrlich, director of relocation for Houlihan/Lawrence Real Estate Centers, reporting that transferees, being brought into the county by many Westchester concerns, are experiencing difficulty finding places to live. The dearth of available housing for mid- to upper-management transferees is driving up the cost of housing. The scarcity of existing homes for sale is in part due to the fact that empty-nesters and others who might ordinarily choose to move were staying put, taking advantage of lower interest rates to refinance and renovate, Ms. Ehrlich said.
Business properties were also doing well. Insignia/ESG, a commercial real estate company based in Stamford, reported that vacancy rates for commercial buildings fell to 15.49 percent in the first quarter of 1998 from 16.53 percent a year ago.
The company also said that the average asking price of rentals in the county rose to $21.54 a square foot in the first quarter of the year, compared with $20.94 in the first quarter of 1997.
As Harold E. Vogt, president and chief executive of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce, said, Westchester's economy has always been a function of what is happening in New York City -- and nowhere can that be seen more clearly than when it comes to vacancy rates and rental values for commercial properties. "As properties in New York City fill up, companies spread out to the suburbs," he said. "There's a spillover effect."
But he observed that small businesses -- rather than the Fortune 500 companies that were once the backbone of the county's economy -- were responsible for the new leasing activity. "More and more it's the smaller companies," he said, "but they fill up space, too."
With Westchester close to the largest city in the United States and still having its own airport, Mr. Vogt said the county would most likely emerge intact from the recession, which took such a harsh toll in the Hudson Valley. Meanwhile, the Westchester Partnership for Economic Development, a public-private coalition, has started the Westchester Cities Initiative to help formerly prosperous urban centers -- like Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, Peekskill, White Plains and Yonkers -- join in the upswing.
"In recent years, some of the focus of economic growth has shifted away from these established areas, which is not good for the cities themselves and which also hurts the county," William M. Mooney, the partnership's chairman, said.
Winston Ross, the executive director of Westchester Community Opportunity Program, said his organization had submitted a $4 million proposal to the Federal Labor Department to expand a welfare-to-work program and eliminate some of the pockets of poverty -- many in the cities -- that exist in the county.
Cities are also trying to attract some of the dollars being spent in the tourism industry. An example is Yonkers' $50 million effort to rebuild its waterfront. Last month, city leaders announced that a developer had been chosen to turn a run-down section of land along the Hudson River into an enclave of shops, offices and homes. The city also envisions a hotel on the waterfront.
Figures released by the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau show that there was an almost 21 percent increase in taxable hotel sales for Westchester from March to August last year, with hotels doing $84.3 million worth of business for the period -- up from $69.7 million for the same period in 1995. Hospitality-related businesses generated more than $28 million in county sales taxes and more than $3.5 million in hotel taxes last year.

HEADLINE: COMPOSERS;
Not Dead Yet

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In his article "Don't Blame Modernists for the Empty Seats" March 22 , Paul Griffiths defends contemporary composers in the ongoing dispute about the death of classical music. But Mr. Griffiths never asks the right question: If classical music is dead, then where's the body? 
 The accepted base line for the health of classical music runs from the 1920's to the early 1960's, with concert attendance in New York City as the primary monitor of vital signs.
In the early days, New York was aflame with an artistic fervor provided by first-generation Americans from Eastern and Central Europe who, though lacking education and wealth, revered the gifts of the mind and the soul. Mainline American families still measured part of their value by their support for the arts. This core audience was supplemented in the 1930's by refugees fleeing Nazism, and then by survivors who came to the United States after the war. Because it was concentrated in New York, this great confluence of artistic talent, interest and support was also highly visible.
It would not be surprising if there were now a diminished audience for classical music in New York. Although the city's population has grown, the generation that filled concert halls has either died or moved out of town. Their children, as they achieved economic success, may have moved on as well. The ethnic groups that replaced them are not as attracted to the European music tradition, although Asians are a dramatic exception.
However, we must be cautious about a pessimistic assessment. Since the 1950's there has been an extraordinary growth of performance space in New York. Even if the city's total classical music audience grew, attendance at any particular hall would have very likely declined.
We must also distinguish between what may be perceived as a diminished audience for classical music in New York and an increased growth in the rest of the country. Think, for example, of the symphony orchestras that have sprouted in Rochester, Buffalo, Cincinnati, Cleveland and the like. New Yorkers need look only as far as across their northern border to Anthony Aibel's Westchester Symphony Orchestra and Richard Kapp's Philharmonia Virtuosi Chamber Orchestra or across the Hudson River to the musical vitality of New Jersey to witness this growth.
 
NATHAN KOLODNEY
Hartsdale, N.Y.
 
The writer is a former director of the Kaufmann Concert Hall and Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y.

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

Works of Robert Kipniss
The River Gallery at 49 Main Street in Irvington has an exhibition of recent paintings by the American artist Robert Kipniss on display through the end of April. Mr. Kipniss is celebrated for his mastery of chiarascuro, transforming representational subjects into enigmas with light and shadow. 
 Examples of his work can be found in the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum in Manhattan, the Chicago Art Institute, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston and Yale University.
Visiting hours are Mondays through Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., and the number for more information is 591-6208.
 
'Indie' Band at Purchase
Yo La Tengo was reviewed in New York magazine as "part of a lineage stretching back past the Velvet Underground to a whole tradition of left-leaning, humanist-minded artists who have thrived in New York's margins."
The three members of the New Jersey-based "indie" band -- independently recorded on Matador Records rather than tied to a recording contract -- have been together since 1985. Ira Kaplan plays guitar and sings; Georgia Hubley plays drums and sings, and James McNew is the bass player. They will perform on Thursday at 8 P.M. in the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College.
Nils Bernstein, director of publicity for Matador, defines their music as "spacey pop, some soft and pretty, some loud, hypnotic, melodic, very theatrical," and he translated Yo La Tengo into "I've Got It."
Tickets are $12.50 and can be reserved by calling the box office at 251-6200 or Ticketmasters at 454-3388. The college is off Anderson Hill Road in Purchase.
 
Remembering Yom Hashoah
Dr. Susan S. Zuccotti, a New York-based historian and author of two major studies of the Holocaust in Italy and France, has concluded that "Italy's lack of a modern anti-Semitic tradition" was at the root of what she has determined was a higher survival rate of Italy's Jews. She will discuss her findings in a lecture titled "The Holocaust in Italy -- Destruction and Survival," to be given on Wednesday at 8 P.M. in Reid Hall at Manhattanville College in Purchase.
Her talk will be part of the program commemorating Yom Hashoah, Holocaust Remembrance Day. After her talk, a candle-lighting ceremony will honor Pepi Deutsch, 99, one of the oldest known Holocaust survivors in the United States, and her daughter, Clara Knopfler, also a survivor of Auschwitz.
A third segment will be the opening of an exhibition of photographs by Claire Yaffa, titled "Who Will Remember?" a documentary series on Holocaust survivors, their children and Christian rescuers. The pictures will remain on view Mondays through Fridays from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. for several months.
The event, organized by the Westchester Holocaust Commission in the lower level of Reid Hall, is open to the public free of charge but reservations are requested by calling 696-0738. Call the same number for directions or more information.
 
Short Films for Children
The Museum of Modern Art's Family Film Program has scheduled its first Westchester screening today at 3 P.M. in the Hastings High School Auditorium on Mount Hope Boulevard in Hastings-on-Hudson.
"Animal Safari" is the overall title of the series of short films, appropriate for children 4 through 10. MOMA's film consultant, Cheri Coffin, will introduce each film and generate discussion among the children between films. The program includes Maurice Sendak's "Alligators All Around" and "Jungle Juveniles," a 1937 live action short from the museum's Children's Film Resource collection.
Admission will be $5 for children or $3 for children whose families are members of the Rivertowns Arts Council of Hastings-on-Hudson, the sponsoring organization. Children must be accompanied by an adult, who will be admitted free. For reservations or more information, call 476-2321.
 
In Honor of Israel
Two Fordham University professors are to speak at Temple Israel in New Rochelle on intellect, ethics and ecumenism. On Wednesday at 8 P.M., Dr. John E. Healey's subject will be "Jews and Christians in Conversation: A New Relationship," and on April 15 at 8 P.M. "Jewish Intellectual Life in Pre-Revolutionary Russia" will be discussed by Prof. Bernice Rosenthal. The programs are open to the public at no charge.
Temple Israel's observance of the 50th anniversary of the founding of Israel includes an exhibition of sketches by David Rose, an artist and reporter who documented in his drawings the Israelis' almost dailyexperience of ricocheting between joy and despair over the years.
The exhibition, organized by the Yeshiva University Museum, will remain through June in Temple Israel's Cultural Center, at 1000 Pinebrook Boulevard. Visiting hours are Mondays through Fridays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., and Sundays from 9 A.M. to noon. The number to call for more information is 235-1800.
 
Nature Walks for Adults
Departing from its many nature programs for children, the Greenburgh Nature Center at 99 Dromore Road is offering monthly weekday nature walks for adults, particularly older adults. The first outing is on Thursday at 10 A.M., when a center staff member will meet a group at the center's Manor House and lead a walk through some of the 33 acres of woodland trails, lawns, gardens and fields.
A springtime crop of flora, fauna, birds and insects will be observed during the hourlong expedition.
Admission will be $4, including access to the Manor House exhibits, and reservations are not required. For more information or directions, call 723-3470.
 
Four Seminars at Bard
Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson has announced four intergenerational seminars to begin on April 13, each one meeting weekly at 7 P.M. for a total of three weeks. The programs are expected to generate educational and cultural benefits from the exchange of ideas between undergraduates and residents. A fee of $25 a seminar is suggested to defray costs.
The first subject will be "The Future of the Worker and Human Welfare in the Global High Technology Age," led by Dr. Kurt F. Flexner, professor emeritus of economics at the University of Memphis. "Unending Turmoil in West and Central Africa" begins on April 14, conducted by Dr. Justus Rosenberg, professor of languages and literature at Bard.
"Archeological Field Work in the Mid-Hudson Valley," led by Dr. Christopher Lindner, archeologist-in-residence at Bard, also begins on April 14, and "A Raconteur's History Through Time," with Luis Perez, adjunct professor at Bard, starts on April 16.
To register or obtain more information, call 758-7508. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
In Lot Prices, Too, It's Location, Location, Location

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

DATELINE: PORT JEFFERSON

 BODY:
THE three-bedroom semiattached two-story house that Don Lippencott selected at Harborview at Port Jefferson, under construction on a hill overlooking this village and its harbor, sells in other parts of the development for $269,000.
But Mr. Lippencott, an agent in a local insurance office, was glad to pay $25,000 more to get a premium location with an uninterrupted view of Long Island Sound. 
 "There are just not that many locations like this left in Port Jefferson," said Mr. Lippencott, who is also adding extras like a finished basement and a deck that will bring the total cost of his house up to $335,000.
"It works out just perfectly for me," he said, noting that he frequently takes the ferry from Port Jefferson to Bridgeport to go skiing in Vermont, where he has family. "When I want to go upstate, I will be able to look out my window and when I see the ferry coming, I can be on my way."
Although developers always offer a fairly wide selection of houses at the advertised price, buyers who want to be in a cul-de-sac, or next to the water or who want to enjoy a better view have to pay extra.
In a trend that has a lot to do with the positive economy and low interest rates, those better locations are the first to sell, said Ziggy Zborowski, who is a principal, with his father, Marvin, and brother, Mark, in Midland Partners of Manhattan, the Harborview developer.
Sales officially opened there yesterday, but 13 buyers had already put down binders, and all but one chose lots with premiums that ranged from $10,000 to $30,000.
Prices of more than 80 percent of the homes in the development carry lot premiums. Depending on their views, 9 of the 40 houses have lot premiums of $30,000, 2 cost an additional $25,000, 5 have $20,000 premiums, 8 have $15,000 premiums and 9 have a $10,000 premium. The 2,500-square-foot, three-bedroom houses range in price, exclusive of lot premiums, from $269,000 for all bedrooms on the second floor, to $279,000 for one with its master bedroom on the first floor. All have two-car garages and basements. Realty Group Marketing, of Smithtown, is in charge of sales.
The 18-acre parcel, through which a new road winds at a steep incline, had to be terraced with retaining walls, said Chris Keegan, the site consultant for Regional Builders of Smithtown, which is doing the construction. By stepping those walls all the way up the hillside, the developers are able to build the houses up to the summit, which is 240 feet above sea level.
A condominium association will own and maintain a tennis court, a clubhouse, a pool, and the road.
Rosalind Rossi and her husband, Roscoe, an anesthesiologist, are paying a $30,000 lot premium for the house they selected. The unit, priced at $269,000 without the premium, is already half- built. In addition to a water view it has a very private location at the lower edge of the development.
"It's my dream house because I've always wanted a beautiful view," said Mrs. Rossi, adding that she and her husband plan to install an extra large deck facing the water. "I can just imagine sitting out there with the lights twinkling in the distance."
Marc C. Eickelbeck, vice president of AVR Realty, a Yonkers developer with several projects under construction on Long Island, offered his view on marketing premium lots. "The general line of thinking is that you establish a base asking price for your typical lot in a project," he said. "And then there are always those lots that because of their size, or because they have a scenic view or other orientation will inherently be worth more."
He said that investing in a premium lot was no different from adding a fireplace or a deck, and was a much more important amenity since interior upgrades could be added later.
Geri Szymanski, who teaches elementary school in the Stony Brook schools, and her fiance, Jerry Aeck, a retired New York City fireman, signed a contract in October for a house in a development AVR is building in Setauket, paying $20,000 extra to be on a pond. With other extras the three-bedroom, 2,800-square-foot ranch will cost them a total of about $350,000.
The project, called Pond Field Estates, will have 89 houses on half-acre lots when it is completed. The three- to five-bedroom houses, which are part of a homeowners' association with a clubhouse and a pool, range in price from $290,000 to $370,000. Premiums on 64 of the lots add $10,000 to $25,000 to the cost.
"This is a second marriage for both of us, and we decided that with a new beginning we were going to treat ourselves to something special," Ms. Szymanski said. "I just look forward to seeing the sun rise and the sun go down over the pond and to sit on our deck watching the fountain and the ducks."
ALTHOUGH the waterfront is always prized, cul-de-sacs are also in great demand because they offer safety for children and privacy, said Charles B. Mancini, vice president of the Park Ridge Organization of Ronkonkoma, a large developer. He added that Park Ridge builds at least 20 to 30 percent of its houses without lot premiums "so people have a decent choice of houses at the advertised price."
In a 20-lot Dix Hills subdivision called the Estates at Half Hollow where Park Ridge just began sales, there will be several cul-de-sacs. Houses range in price from $619,000 for a four-bedroom, 4,000-square-foot colonial with a three-car garage up to $780,000 for one with five bedrooms and 5,000 square feet. Lots average one acre in size. In some cul-de-sac locations, premiums add $10,000 to $65,000 to the price, Mr. Mancini said, noting that he expects those choice locations to be the first to sell.
"Your home is your showpiece, and how it's presented is very important," said Marilyn Larsen of Lane Realty in Great Neck, which is handling sales at, among other developments, one in Glen Cove called Lattingtown Preserve and another in Melville called the Villages at Huntington.
At Lattingtown Preserve, where Peter C. Lewis of the Wharton Development Corporation of Manhattan and his partner, David E. Eisenberg, are building 19 houses, four one-acre lots overlooking a pond and a nature preserve have a $100,000 premium. One of the four is sold. The average lot is one-third of an acre. The three- to four-bedroom houses sell for $520,000 to $760,000 including lot premiums.
"When someone comes into this community and sees these acre lots they realize there has to be a difference in price from the others because they are so unique," Mr. Lewis said. "And for the more affluent buyer, spending $100,000 more is not a big concern if they get what they want."
At the Villages at Huntington, being developed by McGovern-Barbash Associates of Babylon, the 248 houses under construction are built on side streets away from the main through road. Houses, including some that are semiattached, sell for $155,000 to $415,000.
But premiums of $5,000 to as much as $40,000 are being charged for about half of the lots, specifically those that are slightly larger than the standard 70 by 110 feet and those that back up to parks maintained by the homeowners' association.
Buyers say they are happy to go the extra mile. "We didn't even think twice about paying $7,500 more," said Denise Berchtold. She and her husband, John, are buying a three-bedroom high ranch in a development in Coram called Windemere Oaks, where the 80 houses under construction by the Windemere Development Corporation of Hauppauge sell for $125,000 to $185,000. The Berchtolds selected a lot that backs up to a 55-acre preserve.
The greenbelt location increased the price of their house to $152,400 from $144,900, Mrs. Berchtold said, "but no one will ever be able to build in our back yard, so there is no way we wouldn't have done this."
THE Klar Organization of East Meadow, which is completing a 502-unit development in Moriches called Waterways at Moriches begun by another developer 10 years ago, will be charging $5,000 lot premiums for houses that will be clustered around one of eight ponds. Locations on the Forge River, on which the development fronts, had already been taken by the previous developer. The 214 units Klar is building, on which sales start in mid-April, include two-bedroom apartments and two-bedroom semiattached ranches, with prices to range from $169,990 to $249,990. Buyers must be 55 or older.
Among the original buyers at Waterways were Marcel and Lillian Haigy, who paid $50,000 extra for their waterfront two-bedroom semiattached ranch. The two retired schoolteachers have the house on the market for $280,000 because they are moving to South Carolina.
Have they ever regretted paying the extra $50,000 for the waterfront location?
"Never for a moment," Mr. Haigy said. "I've never gotten over being able to sit in my house watching the swans and the boats out there in Moriches Inlet. It's like being on vacation 360 days a year."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Houses under construction at Harborview overlooking Port Jefferson. (Photographs by Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: April 5, 1998

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2817 words

HEADLINE: In Suburbs, Housing Market Is Strong

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
RIDING the nation's record-setting residential real estate wave -- and a curl of demand out of New York City -- the metropolitan region's residential market enjoyed one of its healthiest years ever in 1997, with vital signs remaining strong.
Hot market or not, Tom and Jennifer Hopkins put their feet up last weekend -- a balmy precursor of summer that saw suburbanites painting fences and peeling back tarps from power boats hibernating in their driveways -- and just took a break from weekend after weekend of house-hunting. 
 "Working hard at hardly working," was the way Mr. Hopkins put it. "Lounged around a bit. Jen thumbed through a furniture catalogue."
The Hopkinses of Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, could afford to do nothing, slowly, at least for awhile. After trudging the Long Island house-viewing circuit -- "We saw more than 50" -- their $130,000-plus offer for a four-bedroom Cape in Bay Shore had been accepted.
And now, while the sellers tried to nail down where they might live next, the Hopkinses, though taking a breather, were still biting their nails a bit, waiting to go to contract. "Everything's on hold," Mr. Hopkins said. "We're a little apprehensive with this waiting period."
But at least they were well ahead of the exasperating game being played by thousands of hopeful buyers throughout the region, buyers competing in a stacked-against-them seller's market of tight inventory and correspondingly rising prices.
"No one has repealed the law of supply and demand," said Joseph Mottola, executive officer of the Long Island Board of Realtors.
"Prices and inventory were pretty stable for seven years," Mr. Mottola said. But last year, after a solid recovery in 1996, "inventory was down, probably off 20 percent, so prices had to go up."
They did.
According to a survey conducted by Case Shiller Weiss, a real estate statistics firm in Cambridge, Mass., house prices rose last year in 519 of 561 ZIP-code areas in 14 counties surrounding New York City.
By the reckoning of the National Association of Realtors, the median price last year for an existing single-family home in the region was $177,900, a 2 percent rise from $174,500 in 1996.
Sales volume also indicated a robust year, according to local realty boards. In Westchester County, sales were up 10.3 percent over 1996. In Fairfield County, they rose 9.7 percent. Nassau and Suffolk Counties also posted increased sales volume, of 7 and 5.9 percent, respectively, while in northern New Jersey, sales rose 8 percent.
"The first-time buyer is coming out in droves," said Michael Ford, president of the New Jersey Association of Realtors. "We're getting a lot of buyers from Staten Island right now in Union County. In Hoboken, you're getting Manhattan yuppies."
Sizzling though the Manhattan market may be, with its high-altitude prices and unrequited demand radiating through the region, there are other forces at work in the suburban ring's rising fortunes.
As always, the common concerns that drive consumer desire -- child-inspired upsizing for younger couples, downsizing by empty-nesters, the search for the right school, yearnings for open space, the job change and the quest for safety -- are all at play. But broader regional forces, like the rebounding Connecticut economy and the effects of immigration on expanding ethnic enclaves in New Jersey, are also powering the market. As is a very favorable set of national factors.
Last Wednesday, the nation entered its eighth straight year of economic expansion. "If it continues through December," said James W. Hughes, dean of the School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, "the expansion will be the second longest in the nation's history." (The longest lasted 106 months, from 1961 to 1969).
Last year, Dr. Hughes pointed out, the nation enjoyed: the fastest Gross Domestic Product growth rate in 10 years, 4.2 percent; the lowest level of inflation in 32 years, 2.2 percent, and the lowest unemployment rate in 25 years, 4.7 percent.
THE job picture also improved in the 31-county Greater New York-Northeastern New Jersey Region, said John L. Weiting, regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The region, by bureau designation, includes 14 counties in northern New Jersey, 12 in New York State, including the five boroughs of New York City, but not Nassau or Suffolk; all or parts of four counties in Connecticut, including Fairfield, and Pike County, Pa.
"The region added 158,000 jobs last year," Commissioner Weiting said. "That matched the number added in 1996, and brought total employment in the region to 9.3 million, a 1.7 percent increase over 1996."
Mortgage rates, of course, played a central role in the upswing. As of last week, said Keith Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage statistics company in Butler, N.J., the national average for a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage stood at 7.17 percent, "not much above the nation's 28-year low of 6.83 in October 1993."
All of that helped propel home buying to new heights. A national record for sales of existing homes was set in 1997, according to the National Association of Realtors, with the 4.2 million transactions representing a 3.1 percent increase over the 4.08 million in 1996 -- the previous record.
National sales of new homes hit 803,000 last year, according to Census Bureau data, 6 percent more than the 757,000 sold in 1996.
And the nation's home-ownership rate set a record in 1997, the Census Bureau reported, when 66 percent of all households owned their own homes.
"It doesn't get much better than that," said Dr. Hughes. "The home-buying stars are in full alignment. Some day we may be looking back and saying, 'Wow, what an extraordinary period '97-'98 was.' "
For Tom and Jennifer Hopkins, both 27, everything came into alignment 10 days ago. "Interest rates were attractive," said Mr. Hopkins, who works in his family's document duplicating business in Manhattan. "Jen is graduating with a master's in elementary education." Ms. Hopkins had been teaching part-time. But in September, she started a full-time second-grade position in Manhattan. "We could see what the future would bring," Mr. Hopkins said.
The Hopkinses both grew up in Suffolk, "so it was logical to go back," he said. The first house they bid on "turned out to be too much -- not the price, but with taxes, it went over our limit" -- $1,400 a month.
"What threw us off, at first," he said, "was a little mortgage broker in Brooklyn who told me we could get pre-approved for $185,000. They were willing to lend that much, but we weren't comfortable spending that much." The search took the Hopkinses to Bay Shore, Brightwaters, Lindenhurst, Babylon, West Babylon, Islip and, finally, back to Bay Shore, where the four-bedroom Cape "in the high $130's" fit the bill.
One of the bedrooms looks just like the darkroom Mr. Hopkins has long envisioned. "Kids?" he asked rhetorically. "Way, way in the back of the head; we'll start thinking about it when we're 30." Right now, there's that pending contract to worry about.
Lots of people on Long Island have faced that worrisome wait.
According to the Long Island Board of Realtors, there were 10,470 homes sold in Suffolk last year, a 5.9 percent increase over the 9,885 sold in 1996, and a very healthy 70 percent more than the 6,193 sold in 1990 at the depths of the real estate recession. The average price for a home sold in Suffolk last year was $164,662, 2.8 percent higher than the $160,091 in 1996.
In Nassau, the Long Island board reported 7,835 sales last year, a 7 percent increase over the 7,310 in 1996, and 51 percent over the 5,181 in 1990. The average price for a Nassau home last year was $209,466, 3.2 percent above the $202,466 in 1996.
Tracking real estate trends by the numbers cannot be done with absolute precision. Single-family sales are reported by local realty boards. But not all real estate agents are members of the boards, and not all sales in a given area are recorded. And then, one board may use median prices -- meaning half the sales are above that figure and half below -- while others calculate an average.
But the trends on Long Island were confirmed by another measure of the market, the Case Shiller Weiss repeat-sale survey.
THE survey is based on a table showing the average price of all single-family homes sold in most ZIP-code areas, year by year. To determine price fluctuations in 1997, for example, the survey took the purchase price of each home sold in each ZIP-code area during the year just ended, compared it to the price the house brought the last time it was sold, and then, using the annual index, adjusted the earlier purchase price to what it likely would have been had it sold in 1996. Some ZIP codes are omitted because of insufficient data.
Of the 133 ZIP-code areas for which there was sufficient data in Nassau and Suffolk, only one showed price depreciation last year. In Suffolk, 36 of 69 ZIP codes experienced price appreciation between 4 and 6 percent, and 31 appreciated by 6 percent or more. In Nassau, 36 of 64 areas experienced appreciation between 4 and 6 percent and 15 appreciated by 6 percent or more.
"Finally, after quite a few years," said Mr. Mottola of the Long Island board, "we're seeing prices rise."
Putting it in broader perspective, Mr. Mottola said stable prices during the early 1990's were "a market correction for the tremendous growth from '80 to '88, when prices tripled, from $50,000 to $150,000 for the average house. But over the past two years we've seen a return to increases, and last year more than the year before."
In Westchester last week, Robert Alter was emptying a rather large nest -- a 4,000-square-foot, four-bedroom glass-brick and stucco exemplar of the Bauhaus school of architecture, built in 1936, overlooking the river in Hastings-on-Hudson.
"I'm emptying out 35 years worth of files, papers and hidden possessions in the bottom of closets," said Mr. Alter, a retired president of a cable TV advertisers association.
As evidence of the hot Westchester market, consider that Mr. Alter and his wife, Lucille, sold their home for about $800,000 -- in less than a day.
"Our kids are married, so it's just the two of us in this large house," he said. "We decided it's easier to move into a condominium and not have responsibility for upkeep of the grounds, and also security."
In a vivid illustration of a seller's market, Mr. Alter said: "Our house was on the market for all of two hours. The broker brought our neighbors and they immediately decided this was their dream house." It took less than a week for the Alters to decide on paying "about $600,000" for a condominium on the grounds of a nearby golf club.
Not so expeditious was the mind shift. "There are emotional issues involved," Mr. Alter said, "ties to the community, the children, the grandchildren, memories. It's not just a real estate deal."
Still, quite a few people went through the process in Westchester last year. According to the county board of realtors, 5,750 existing homes were sold in 1997, 10.3 percent above the 5,211 sold in 1996. And the median sales price for the county as a whole was $293,400, up 1.2 percent over the previous year. That constituted the highest median price for any county in the state.
Of the 65 ZIP-code areas in Westchester surveyed by Case Shiller Weiss, only two showed depreciation last year, and 23 experienced appreciation of at least 4 percent.
Southern Westchester has long been desirable because of its relatively short ride into the city. "Traditionally, the family that was coming out of Manhattan looked for the 45-minute commute or less," said Robin Friedman, manager of the Irvington-Tarrytown offices of Houlihan/Lawrence. These days, "when people come up and want to find that new center-hall colonial for $400,000, it just doesn't exist. Now they go as far as an hour and a half north."
Ms. Friedman said that for "new construction on a third of an acre, a center-hall colonial, four-bedroom in Irvington -- I'm trying to keep it very generic -- that home would probably go for below $700,000. Fancier homes go for $850,000, $900,000.
"I believe you can go farther up, in Somers, on a larger piece of property, possibly an acre, and pay $500,000."
Hopeful buyers find themselves outward bound in New Jersey, too.
Since 1991, Ric Martel has been broker-manager in the Coldwell Banker office in the seaside community of Spring Lake, N.J., 55 miles south of Manhattan. "When I go by that train station, the parking lot is full," he said, "and it wasn't in '91." The newcomers, Mr. Martel said, "are young brokers, hungry guys making big bucks career-rolling in the city. And they say, 'I don't mind moving down here because I can still commute, be five blocks from the beach, not worry about my wife and kids.' "
The average price in Spring Lake is about $500,000, Mr. Martel said. "Some of them will buy these houses for a half-million dollars, level the place and start all over."
The New Jersey Association of Realtors divides the state into three sectors, with the northern sector, closest to New York City, including Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Hunterdon, Morris, Passaic, Somerset, Sussex, Warren and Union Counties. Sales volume in that sector, though not price, showed significant gains last year. There were 63,043 sales in 1997, up 8 percent from 58,400 in '96. The median price held steady at about $199,000.
And of the 318 ZIP-code areas surveyed by Case Shiller Weiss in northern New Jersey, only 39 experienced price depreciation.
"The mild winter started the spring market in February," said Mr. Ford of the New Jersey realtors association. "In the Bergen and Hudson County area you're getting the upper echelon Manhattan buyers who want proximity to New York. Young couples are coming over the Goethals Bridge and settling in Union County, which has a whole range -- pricewise and style -- from $100,000 and up."
Even some of New Jersey's decayed urban areas, Mr. Ford said, "are coming back block by block, inch by inch" -- fueled by the low interest rates and government subsidies. "You'll have a development of Portuguese in the Ferry Street area in Newark, and they expand with immigrants," Mr. Ford said. "Hispanics in Perth Amboy are claiming their turf, bringing properties back on line. Jersey City's West End has become very desirable, and it was a war zone not seven years ago."
THERE are signs of revival in Connecticut. "This state just decided: enough being a doormat," said Vincent Valvo, editor and publisher of The Commercial Record, a business weekly. "Three years ago, if you read that a company was hiring 300 people, it was greeted with a fatalistic attitude that someone else would lay off 500. But we've started believing the good news."
The good news includes, Mr. Valvo said: proposals for revitalizing the Hartford business district; construction of an Omni Hotel in New Haven; a $500-million plan to redevelop the wharf area in Bridgeport; opening of the Brass Mill Center, a mall, in Waterbury; large condominium projects in lower Fairfield. "When people think the economy's terrific and think it will continue, it will," he said. And they buy houses.
According to Commercial Record statistics, there were 61,205 house and condominium sales throughout Connecticut in 1997, a 12.9 percent increase over 54,212 in 1996.
In Fairfield County, there were 17,743 sales last year, a 9.7 percent increase. The median price for all sales in the county was $203,500, 3.3 percent higher than the $197,000 price in 1996. And of the 45 ZIP-code areas in Fairfield, none showed price depreciation.
Randi Hutton, a broker with Weichert Realtors in Westport, attributed higher prices to lower interest rates. "Attorneys seem to be very busy with refinancings because the rates are low and it's a good time to remodel instead of move," she said. "That's causing very low inventory. So we can't find enough homes for the buyers, and that pushes up prices."
The impact was felt by Karen and Gary Steinfield, who moved to Connecticut from Philadelphia with their sons, Jacob, 4, and Evan, 1. "Certainly, leaving the Philadelphia market, we experienced sticker shock," Ms. Steinfield said.
The Steinfields sold their home in a Philadelphia suburb for $210,000. "Coming up here, you have to spend more than double for the same kind of house," Ms. Steinfield said. After renting in Wilton while looking at "easily, 50, 75 homes," the couple finally bought a four-bedroom "country house -- it has one of those farm porches," Ms. Steinfield said, on five acres in Redding, Conn. The price: $500,000.
"This is more rural than we've ever lived," Mr. Steinfield said. "In our minds, the question is how we will adapt. We've got snakes and frogs and deer out back. The kids are thrilled."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
401(k)'s Can Be a Great Place to Trade Your Company's Stock

BYLINE: By ABBY SCHULTZ 

 BODY:
LET'S face it: Buying and selling your company's stock may be the one area where you have a leg up on Wall Street. After all, you probably know a lot about your employer. You hang on every stock price rally and retreat, week after week. You know the competition, the market and whether your division is likely to hit its internal performance goals.
You have an edge for another reason, too: there's a good chance that you can trade that stock without paying brokerage commissions and without paying a big tax bill on any capital gains. That is because 401(k) plans are increasingly allowing such trading, often on a daily basis. 
 In 1997, some 52 percent of 460 companies surveyed by Hewitt Associates, a consulting firm in Lincolnshire, Ill., included company stock as an option in their 401(k) plans. That is up from 36 percent in 1995. Meanwhile, 64 percent of these companies gave their employees the ability to transfer assets daily among their 401(k) investment options in 1997, up from 41 percent in 1995.
The big question, of course, is whether you ought to use your 401(k) this way. Many experts discourage doing so, figuring that a retirement account is no place for such a risky tack. Remember, they note, that if you lose money in a 401(k), you cannot use the loss to offset gains the way you can in a taxable account.
Some companies limit how much you can trade. Undoubtedly, they do not want to see employees spending their hours timing the market instead of working. And over all, employees aren't that active as investors anyhow: on average, they trade less than 1 percent of their 401(k) assets monthly, Hewitt data show.
But this much seems clear: if you are going to trade your company's stock, the place to do it is your 401(k).
A growing number of professional services are available to employees who want to do so. David Evans, chief executive at Scarborough Retirement Services, a 401(k) advisory firm in Annapolis, Md., offers employees of General Motors, AT&T and Lucent Technologies, among others, advice on how to trade their company stock -- and when it's wiser not to.
Cyclical stocks are often good fodder for 401(k) trading strategies because of the way they rise and fall in relation to the economy, he said. Aggressive growth stocks do not, because they are far less predictable.
WHO is trading their company stock? Everyone from chief financial officers to line workers to people like Ron Shannon, a 30-year veteran of General Motors who retired as regional truck manager in Atlanta two years ago. Over several years he would move all of his 401(k) into and out of G.M. stock as the price fluctuated. "I was hanging out there pretty risky," Mr. Shannon said.
Today, on the advice of Scarborough, he moves money in and out of G.M. stock about twice a year. But the stock is a relatively small portion of his total 401(k) savings -- a maximum of 30 percent.
Newsletters offer advice, too. David Paul, an investment adviser in Cincinnati, began a newsletter for employees of the Ford Motor Company in 1994 and another for G.M. employees in 1995 to offer advice on the Fidelity funds in their 401(k) plans. He did not plan to write much about the companies' stocks, but readers asked for it.
Today, each of the quarterly newsletters, the Ford 401(k) Investor and the GM 401(k) Investor, features its company's stock and gives recommendations to buy, sell or hold.
"They love that; they want that," Mr. Paul said of his advice. "I think money can be made doing it."
He does not advocate daily or even weekly trading. But he argues that buying and selling company stock at periodic lows and highs, as often as two or three times a year, can beat a strict buy-and-hold strategy, particularly for employees like those at G.M. and Ford who do not have to pay transaction fees.
The results of Mr. Paul's recommendations are not audited, but here is an example of how they could work: Say an employee followed his advice and bought G.M. stock at $56 a share and sold at its recent peak of about $74, for a return of 32 percent. If the stock accounted for 10 percent of the employee's portfolio, the maximum that Mr. Paul advises, the trade would have added about 3 percent to the employee's total 401(k) holdings. (G.M. stock has since retreated to well below $70.)
Certainly, there are risks to any such trading strategy, however tempting the potential gains. "I personally think it's a rare individual that's going to be able to capture incremental value from day trading or constant shifting into and out of their company stock," said Stephen L. Deschenes, president of 401(k) Forum, an Internet-based advisory service in San Francisco.
WHEN there is the risk that you will find yourself on the wrong side of insider trading regulations. Regardless of whether you think of yourself as doing something illegal, if you have "material, nonpublic" information that could be of value to an investor about your company, then you are subject to insider trading rules under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
Company officers and directors are most clearly at risk, said David E. Morse, a partner at Whitman, Breed, Abbott & Morgan, a law firm in New York. Most companies advise top officials only to buy and sell during specific "windows," like after the release of an earnings report, said David F. Kroenlein, who heads the corporate practice at Whitman, Breed.
What kind of nonpublic information can get you in trouble?
Suppose you worked at a big fashion company that catered to teen-agers and 20-somethings and attracted trendy types of all ages. The company has just appointed a new head for the shoe division, which contributes 50 percent to the company's annual bottom line. Well, you know that the new boss's style runs to standard pumps in decidedly unflashy colors and that she would shun the hot leopard print platforms that the division has been designing and that you know will be the rage. Under the circumstances, you may be inclined to transfer your stock to a bond fund. Go ahead, Mr. Kroenlein said. The boss's appointment was disclosed to the public; the fact that you know she does not know what she is doing is a nice insight, but it is not insider information.
But what if you are a secretary typing a memo that says the whole company is about to be bought by the Gap? Could you dial the toll-free number of your 401(k) with a buy order? No, Mr. Morse said. The secretary, although not in on the negotiations, would have seen enough information to be considered an insider.
What if you just went to get a drink at the water cooler and overheard two top officials talking about the pending sale in sufficient detail to reasonably believe that a deal was about to go through? Could you call the "800" number then? Well, maybe, Mr. Kroenlein said. The law is written with enough leeway to give judges wide discretion. So proceed at your own risk.

HEADLINE: THE ARTS;
In New Arts Plan, an Appreciation for the Bottom Line

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Arts in service to the economy, not arts for arts' sake, is the theme of the state's new plan for the arts in public life, recently released by Governor Whitman.
The plan, drawn up after two years of focus groups, public hearings and research, and directed by the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, lays out six goals that are intended to expand the role of public arts in the state and to increase citizens' access to the arts. If there was a theme to the underlying argument, it was that public art should serve public goals, whether in reviving urban areas or in attracting sightseers. 
 "We at the council can already see what can be accomplished when the arts are integral components of urban revitalization program like those that are reshaping New Brunswick and Newark," said Barbara Russo, executive director of the Arts Council, in a statement. "Every bit as important is the way that the arts, particularly folk arts, can bring together diverse communities like Perth Amboy, Jersey City and Vineland."
Still, a 10-page synopsis of the plan does not entirely ignore art as a private esthetic experience. In the introduction, titled "Why an Arts Plan?," the document offers a less pragmatic vision: "It is in the realm of the non-profit arts industry, composed of a wide array of arts institutions, companies, facilities and enterprises, woven into the fabric of our communities that artists and creative energies emerge."
That paragraph concludes, "In this realm, one with no personal profit motive, the great majority of everyday people experience the joy, fulfillment and reward of the arts."
On March 24, when the plan was released, the Council on the Arts also announced the allocation of $270,000 for arts programs in South Jersey, $6,000 to pay for the New Jersey component of a program about Delmarva Peninsula folk life and $4,000 for the NJN Hispanic Youth Showcase, a program that is part of the Images/Imagenes series on New Jersey Network.
"Arts Plan New Jersey: Toward a Thriving New Jersey" offers six goals for the arts and five strategies for supporters of the arts to consider. The goals emphasize access, education, and public and private support for the arts, while the strategies urge supporters to coalesce and cooperate.
Goal No. 1, for example, urges the state and arts supporters to involve people through volunteerism and community participation. Goal No. 3 argues for greater public participation in arts projects by using technology to enlarge the audience, and to recycle available spaces into arts centers. Goal No. 4 calls for improving arts education. Goal No. 6 urges increased spending for the arts. And among the strategies, the plan urges hope: "Think 'Arts First,' " it tells members of the arts community. "Be amazed at the possibilities."
In its "Vision Statement," the report said: "We envision a New Jersey that celebrates the arts and extends their benefits to all residents; promotes excellence, education, and diversity in the arts; encourages artists and arts organizations to excel, grow and be welcome partners and participants in the state's advancement; abounds with vibrant, livable and attractive communities made so in part through the arts; regards the arts as a vital resource and an indispensable part of the everyday life."
Penelope Lattimer, an assistant superintendent in the New Brunswick public school district and chairwoman of the Arts Council, noted in releasing the plan that Governor Whitman had talked about it at the Governor's Conference on Tourism, held the same day the arts plan was released.
"Involvement by professionals who run hotels, resorts, tourist attractions and restaurants was an important dimension of the planning process," Dr. Lattimer said. "They understand that the arts contribute much to efforts to create a reputation that appeals to visitors and tourists. For them as well as for many others, the arts are part of the mix that creates a highly prized quality of life for those who live in and visit this state."
The arts plan had its start at a three-day meeting in 1995 attended by 450 people including artists, representatives of philanthropic and non-profit groups, educators and government officials. It was followed by eight focus groups convened by the Arts Council. Nine thousand surveys were mailed out, and 1,300 people responded. Other ideas came from several meetings involving arts groups and three public hearings, which attracted 150 witnesses.
A copy of a summary of the plan may be ordered from the Council on the Arts, P.O. Box 306, Trenton, N.J. 08625; (609) 292-6130.
