PUB-DATE: April 5, 1998

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2646 words

HEADLINE: The Bases Are Definitely Loaded

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

 BODY:
THE Trenton Thunder's opening day is Wednesday, and the box office has a nice problem: not enough tickets. In Sussex County, the New Jersey Cardinals expect to sell more tickets for the season than there are seats. Standing-room-only has become routine.
But these won't be the only baseball tickets around this season. A state that had no professional baseball five years ago will now have half a dozen teams in the lineup. 
 Down in Atlantic City, Ken Shepard is trying to answer the question: How much baseball, how much romance and family fun, does one state want? A lot, says Mr. Shepard, president and general manager of the brand-new Atlantic City Surf of the brand-new Atlantic League of Professional Baseball Clubs.
As he gazes at the $14.5 million stadium rising like a field-of-dreams apparition on the plains, he promises: "We'll do fresh-cut flowers in the women's restroom. We'll have a locksmith service so if you lock your keys in the car you can get it taken care of without leaving your seat."
He points to a gentle slope just off left field. "And say you've got a 2-year-old and a 4-year-old and they're going to be mayhem. You can plunk a blanket down on a grass berm just off the field. You tell me, how can the Phillies compete with that?"
This season will tell. The two traditional farm teams -- the Thunder, a Class AA affiliate of the Boston Red Sox, and the Cardinals, a Class A affiliate of the St. Louis Cardinals -- have easily wedged themselves into the territory of the Phillies, Yankees and Mets in the last few years. Not too far away the Reading Phillies and the Wilmington Blue Rocks in Delaware have drawn nicely, too.
This year the Surf will be playing in their own stadium; two other Atlantic League teams, the Somerset Patriots and the Newark Bears, will spend the season on the road while their home ballparks are under construction. In Montclair, the New Jersey Jackals will make their debut in the Northeast League, which like the Atlantic is composed exclusively of independent teams -- those with no major-league parent club.
And when the Cardinals are out of town, a women's pro team, the New Jersey Diamonds, will be playing in their park in Augusta in Sussex County.
The dreams don't stop there. The Atlantic League plans a team in Camden, to start in a new waterfront stadium in the spring of 2000. And North Wildwood is chasing a team of its own.
Opinion is divided on whether this proliferation of teams is an obvious response to an obvious consumer demand for baseball or whether, when the last dizzy-bat race of the season is over, it will all amount to too much of a good thing.
There is the cool perspective of those who study the economics of baseball.
"I start off with considerable skepticism that New Jersey needs another baseball league," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College and the author of "Baseball and Billions." "People in New Jersey have a lot of options for entertaining themselves, for their leisure time, including other baseball options."
There is the sunnier view of the local guys who are bringing on the independent teams.
"This area is so densely populated that we can draw and it's not really going to hurt or hinder Trenton," said Dave Gasaway, general manager of the Somerset Patriots, who will be playing all their games on the road this season. "I have just under 500 seats committed for 1999. I had three people trying to give me their credit cards yesterday, and I'm not set up to take them."
And around Camden, "you've got literally millions of people within a 25-minute ring," said David Brandt, attorney for the investors who are planning a waterfront stadium there. "With a clean, modern facility, we see success in places that don't have anything near the density of Camden County. And we know Trenton, Wilmington and Reading are not filling the need."
Finally, there is the not-disinterested assessment of the New Jersey baseball establishment, which now consists of the Thunder and the Cardinals.
"I always think, the more baseball the better," said Joe Finley, an owner of the Thunder. "Even though Somerset is maybe 25 miles away, we have not seen any adverse effect at all."
But of the new independents, Mr. Finley said: "Quite frankly, it's a different level of baseball."
Tony Torre, general manager of the Cardinals, is a bit harsher.
"Long-term I'm very skeptical," he said. "My real concern is what's going to happen to municipalities that might be left with $15 million white elephants."
These new stadiums are what makes the Atlantic League unusual among independent leagues, which have cropped up around the country over the last five years but have struggled and teetered and only rarely managed to build permanent stadiums.
 
Yearning for a Team To Call Their Very Own
The leagues arose largely in response to soaring demand for small-city franchises. Minor-league teams that have a major-league affiliation drew 34.7 million fans last year, the best season since 1949. Since 1985 they have built 86 new stadiums.
And franchise prices have risen accordingly. The larger franchises are now bringing around $10 million. The Thunder, brought from Ontario five years ago, cost $3.5 million.
Franchises from the leagues that don't have a major-league affiliation cost a fraction of that, though their prices, too, are rising. The Northeast League is now charging $400,000 for a new franchise. (Atlantic League officials will not disclose the prices paid for their clubs.)
Of course, it's probably worth millions to have the problems that the Trenton Thunder has. When season ticket sales closed on Tuesday, the club had sold 1,950, and had to add two rows of seats to the season-ticket section.
Susan Glimcher of Princeton was worried last week on behalf of her nine-year-old son, Nicholas, who received a certificate for two tickets last summer but was told it would have to be used this season because there were no seats left for 1997. Having waited to redeem them, she is now afraid she will find many of this year's games sold out.
"They're in trouble here," said Mark Thorne, who came down to Waterfront Stadium from Ringoes to pick up tickets for his usual 10 Friday nights and was able to get only eight. "They don't have enough seats. You can't get good seats on an individual basis."
Mr. Thorne converted to minor-league ball with the Thunder's arrival in 1994 after a long estrangement from baseball; born and raised a Yankees fan, he never forgave George Steinbrenner for trading Chris Chambliss in 1979. "Once he did that," Mr. Thorne said, "I said, 'It's not a team. It's just a franchise.' "
Jim Kenney of Newtown, Pa., after gesturing toward the Trenton stadium stands and announcing, "It's fantastic here," explained that he is indifferent to baseball but comes for the park.
"My wife's a fanatic Phillies fan, but she likes it over here," Mr. Kenney said. "It's better over here. You feel like you're on the field."
The Thunder, like the Cardinals, are apparently defying a trend that has become clear at the dozens of new stadiums that have been built around the country in the last 10 or 15 years.
"Generally, there's a honeymoon period where you're sold out for the first few years and then it tails off," said Steven P. Boyd, director of minor-league stadium facilities for Heery International, an architecture and construction management firm based in Atlanta. "The honeymoon period lasts three to five years. You just put on the games and people come and they love it. After that time, attendance drops."
If New Jersey loves minor-league baseball, it's a good thing, because except for its southeast corner, the state is closed off by the Phillies, Mets and Yankees to new major-league franchises. The territorial rights of the Thunder, a Red Sox affiliate, and the Cardinals, a St. Louis team, foreclose any more minor-league affiliates, too, except in Cape May County at the southern tip of New Jersey.
Independent teams, of course, can locate anywhere. And their owners emphasize that they are not trying to compete with major-league teams like the Yankees and Phillies but with local movie theaters and miniature golf courses. (Most ticket prices for the new teams are $3 to $8, with a peak price of $12 in Atlantic City. A ticket to Yankee Stadium, by comparison, costs $12 to $25.)
The Atlantic League is not especially worried about having teams as close together as Newark and Camden. League officials were careful, however, to locate where Thunder and Cardinals fans are not. The Thunder's most recent fan survey shows that 29 percent live in Mercer County, 19 percent in Bucks County, Pa., and 13 percent in Monmouth County; fewer than 3 percent are from Somerset County, where the Patriots will play. The Cardinals draw 32 percent of their fans from Sussex County, 22 percent from Morris and 17 percent from Bergen and Passaic.
Even the independents' smaller markets can be subdivided, said Leo Kirk, general manager of the New Jersey Jackals. His franchise, the newest member of the Northeast League, which has teams in New York State and New England, would seem perilously close to the Atlantic League's Newark Bears.
"In terms of distance, Newark is not too far away," Mr. Kirk said. "But people in this immediate area have really embraced us as their own. This is also a very densely populated area, and I feel there's plenty of room to have more than one baseball team in the vicinity. There's more than one movie theater, more than one ice arena."
Mr. Kirk said that about 1,300 season tickets had been sold, though the opener is not until June 5, and that season ticket sales would be cut off after 1,600.
Even more teams may soon be competing for fans' loyalty -- and money.
Mike McGuire, executive director of the Northeast League, said investor groups had approached the league with serious plans for sites in Camden County and in Hammonton in Atlantic County.
The fear of market saturation has dampened hopes somewhat in North Wildwood, which is in Cape May County, the only county in New Jersey where it would still be possible to put a minor-league affiliate. Now, North Wildwood, which has courted a Cleveland Indians Class A franchise for several years, is looking for public financing, and looking up the road at Atlantic City stadium with a case of baseball envy.
"We have a site," Mayor Aldo Palombo said, "18 acres on Hereford Inlet that would be beautiful. If it weren't for Atlantic City we'd have a stadium. But we're a small town. Let's face it. In the state of New Jersey, there's a lot more money thrown at Atlantic City than anyplace else."
Indeed, the new team in Atlantic City is thinking large. Its stadium, which is to be finished before the season opener May 20, received $11.5 million from the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, the state agency that allocates gambling taxes for redevelopment projects, and $3 million from the city. Mr. Shepard, the general manager, projects attendance this year at 350,000 to 400,000.
For an independent team, that would be astonishing. Among the eight or nine independent leagues now playing around the country, the highest-drawing team by far is the St. Paul Saints in Minnesota, which had attendance of 260,701 last year; the majority of independent teams get 20,000 to 50,000 a year.
The Thunder, by contrast, drew 446,527 last season. The Cardinals, who as a short-season team played just 38 games, drew 171,244.
Ken Shepard, who joined the Atlantic League and became a co-owner of the Surf after five years as vice president of the Wilmington Blue Rocks, acknowledges the competition. "Wilmington and Trenton are two of the top 10 minor-league operations in the country," he said. And as for the crowded New Jersey market, he said, "You can sugar-coat it all you want, but we're going to be in competition with each other.'
"But this is America," he added. "Competition is good."
 
Chocolate-Chip Cookies And Other Enticements
 And in drawing the families that every small-time franchise covets, Mr. Shepard said, the game is not really the point. "It's all about entertainment," he said. "When you go to a minor-league game, do you really know any players? No. It's our job to think of ideas that will make people say, 'Wow!' "
In Wilmington, Mr. Shepard's ideas included having the kitchen bake chocolate-chip cookies, which he sold himself, two for a dollar, behind home plate. Before that, in Geneva, N.Y., where he worked for the completely miserable Geneva Cubs, he announced after the team lost five of its first six games of the 1988 season that he would sleep in the press box until they won. He did, for 17 more games, and attendance rose 36 percent that year.
The Surf plans a number of unprofessional events this season at its park, called the Sandcastle. A nine-year-old girl from Brigantine is to sing the national anthem on opening night, and a four-year-old Atlantic City boy will do "Take Me Out to the Ball Game." ("He's good," Mr. Shepard said, "really good.")
Still, Mr. Shepard insists that the players are to be taken seriously.
Last weekend, the league held tryouts in Plant City, Fla. Each of the member teams signed several players. Others were signed by the league, which will allocate them in a draft next month.
The Surf is setting player salaries at $850 a month for raw recruits, rising to $3,000 to $5,000 a month for its bigger names, who are expected to come from the ranks of former major-leaguers.
That is more than competitive with salaries paid by affiliated minor-league teams. The Thunder and Cardinals players average less than $1,500 a month -- though as an apprenticeship for the majors the Thunder has seen some players arrive with huge signing bonuses. Tony Clark, a first baseman who now plays for the Detroit Tigers, and Nomar Garciaparra, the Boston Red Sox shortstop who was the 1997 American League rookie of the year, each showed up with signing bonuses of more than $800,000.
For now, most of the former major-leaguers in the Atlantic League are owners, managers and coaches: Bud Harrelson, the league president, spent 34 years in the Mets organization, most famously as the shortstop for the 1969 Miracle team. The Newark Bears are owned by Rick Cerone, the former Yankee catcher. The Somerset Patriots have hired Sparky Lyle, the former Yankee pitcher, as manager, and Jim Frey, who managed the Chicago Cubs and Kansas City Royals, as vice chairman of baseball operations. Doc Edwards, a former Mets coach, will manage the Surf.
And the players have no choice but to give their all.
The first player signed by the Surf, the former Phillies pitcher Jose de Jesus, showed not a trace of major-league cockiness when he was presented at a news conference on March 25, the beginning of a small promotional blitz.
"I'm trying to come back," Mr. de Jesus said. At 33, he is returning from two seasons of play in Taiwan, where he went after a serious shoulder reconstruction derailed his major-league career.
And the next day, in an interview at the Surfs offices, he offered: "I want to live close to the ball park. I'll be the first to get there and the last to leave. I'm very excited that the Atlantic City area is having baseball. I'm happy for them, too."
Later, in a car headed for his hotel, he complained about Taiwan.
"I don't know how I did it," he said, twice, and on passing a restaurant with a facade styled like a pagoda, he said, dyspeptically, "Oh, Chinese."
But he was, after all, very tired. The evening before he spent with Mr. Shepard addressing the Galloway Township Athletic Association, which runs sports programs for children. And he had to catch a few hours of rest at the Comfort Inn before heading onward, to a Latino focus group.
The Surf, he agreed, is sparing no effort.

PUB-DATE: April 5, 1998

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 4; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1784 words

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
'Is Ralph Here Yet?'

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: MILLBURN

 BODY:
"NINETY percent of life is showing up," as Woody Allen once said. But how many clock-watchers said it, or thought it, before him?
Just showing up reflects not only the cool, blase attitude of a celebrity but also the insignificance of thousands of faces in the crowd, from the downward-bound (the Willy Lomans, the Wozzecks of the world) to anyone who bides time on the job, waiting for something to happen. 
 Carl N. Wallnau knows the feeling. This spring, he has spent six weeks in theatrical no man's land as standby for three roles in "Death of a Salesman" at the Paper Mill Playhouse here. The job included two weeks of rehearsals "without getting up and moving," he said. Tonight it's over. And he did go on -- once.
In the Arthur Miller classic, which closes today, Mr. Wallnau has been standby for Uncle Ben (Willy Loman's brother, played by Michael Balcanoff), Charley (Willy's next-door neighbor, played by Joseph Hindy) and Stanley (the bartender, played by Ford Austin). Last Tuesday, at a noontime student matinee, Mr. Wallnau took over for Mr. Hindy as Charley, while Mr. Hindy -- the understudy to the star, Ralph Waite -- played Willy Loman.
Through it all, he continued holding auditions and callbacks in Manhattan for "The Killing of Sister George," the next production of the Centenary Stage Company, where he is producing director. Then back to Hackettstown to teach three courses a week, two classes a day, as associate professor of theater arts at Centenary College. "Most of my time was really spent in my car," he said.
The standby is the necessary phantom of the theater, the second-class citizen among thespians, not necessarily an Eve Harrington type. Unlike the understudy, who has a part in a play or is a member of the chorus in a musical and simply steps up when the star or a supporting player is indisposed, the standby is relegated to just showing up, being there, waiting.
For some actors, the standby's role seems to be a run-of-your-life contract, a commitment not to the glamorous life but to the vicarious one, of perpetual anticipation with no guaranteed entrances. The show will go on, as it must, but the standby may not.
What made Mr. Wallnau's job more nerve-wracking than tedious was Mr. Waite's much-publicized travels while he has been running for the seat in Congress that Sonny Bono held until his death in January; the election is to be held on Tuesday in Palm Springs, Calif. After each Sunday night performances, Mr. Waite, "a well of endless energy, would fly out to Sonny Bono-land," Mr. Wallnau said. "And he'd fly back on Tuesday. So every Tuesday, we'd all be lingering. And I'm standing around like a hyena or a jackal waiting for the kill. Then the cry would go out: 'Is Ralph here yet?' Then I'd hear, 'He's on the highway.'
"Sometimes he would arrive at 7:45, and the curtain would be delayed a few minutes. I'd spend a lot of time asking Joseph and Ford and Michael, 'How are you feeling today?' You wait for a cough so you can say, 'Rest a bit.' It was always worse for Joseph, who had to anticipate the audience groan."
Tuesday's matinee was a no-groaner. "We banked on the high school groups not knowing who Ralph Waite is," Mr. Wallnau said after the performance. "And that they'd just be glad to be out of school. And we were right."
Groups from 24 high schools and middle schools in New Jersey, and one from Staten Island, filled the 1,192-seat. Among those represented were Nutley High School, Hopatcong Middle School and Kushner Yeshiva High School in Livingston.
"There were more school buses than I've ever seen in one place," Mr. Wallnau said. "And it was a different kind of audience," he added, even though he is accustomed to young audiences in Hackettstown, where each semester his Young Performers Workshop trains 60 to 75 students, ages 6 to 18, and stages 12 full productions a year. Once there was an all-white version of "The Wiz." This year's shows include "The King and I," "Life With Father" and "Schoolhouse Rock."
To Mr. Wallnau, "the audience is always a character in the play; it just isn't introduced until the performance starts."
"When the lights went down at Paper Mill, a roar went up," he said of Tuesday's performance. "It sounded like the final death throes of the Titanic, and our hearts sank." The exhausted Willy Loman, lugging his suitcases, should make his entrance to the sound of silence.
"But once the play was cooking, they were really hooked into it -- except in the predictable place with Willy and the woman in the hotel room in Boston. Then they hooted. Luckily, with the size and distance at Paper Mill, distractions don't come across the footlights. And they cheered like crazy at the end."
During a discussion after the performance, -- "it was so reassuring that so many remained to talk about the play," said Mr. Wallnau, who participated -- students asked questions ranging from the stock ("How do you become an actor?") to the psychologically sophisticated ("Why does Linda put up with Willy's emotional abuse?"). "They were very interested in the relationship between father and son," he said. "And all the girls were in love with Happy, that sleazy womanizer. Why? Because he's a take-charge guy, not a wimp."
Biding his time in the green room during a performance two weeks ago, Mr. Wallnau mused on his latest theatrical credit. "I have to keep ready as if I'm going on -- for someone," he said. Usually an understudy must appear "at half-hour" -- 30 minutes before curtain time.
"But I don't have to get here before 8 o'clock," he said. "Ben and Charley's first entrances are in the middle of the first act. That would be about 8:30. When I arrive, I look at the sign-in sheet. That gives you a clue. But usually the name that wasn't on it was just mine.
"The theater is not obligated to let me know, but I am -- contractually -- to be there every performance. Then I come up here -- and sit there, right by the coffee machine, reading papers, grading papers, filling out State Arts Council grant applications. And I wait. Everyone knows about waiting." Mr. Austin's entrance in the second act is the cue for Mr. Wallnau's exit: "Once Stanley goes on in the second act, I go home."
"But I always watch the scenes," Mr. Wallnau said. "I want to see the process. I would stand backstage and try to get the attention of the stage manager, Betsey Berther, so that maybe I could do lines with her, and she'd be too busy with light cues to bother with my yammering."
Clearly, Mr. Wallnau took the term standby too literally. "I grew accustomed to hearing, 'Go away, Carl; you're muttering in my ear.' She was getting the same words three ways -- from the stage, from the monitor, from me next to her, standing by."
N OW that the six-week grind of "teach the class, drive to Paper Mill, park the car, wait" is over -- not to mention the understudy rehearsals on Fridays at 2 P.M. -- he will begin directing "The Killing of Sister George," a four-character English comedy from 1966. His wife, Colleen Smith Wallnau, is to play Miss Mercy, an emissary from the BBC who arrives to tell the actress playing Sister George, a nurse on a television soap opera, that her character is to be killed off and then takes off with the actress's girlfriend.
As the artistic head of Centenary Stage -- where, he says, he is also "janitor, usher and concessionaire at times" -- his mission is "to challenge audiences with neglected works." For next season, Mr. Wallnau is thinking of directing a play by Terence Rattigan, and "Below the Belt," by Richard Dresser.
But esoterica does not fill the 174-seat house. Mr. Wallnau does not deny his practical side, although he says he despises it. So he once did what theater managers everywhere do: when the bills pile up, call in "Nunsense."
It would be a canard to believe that the crowds who flock to "Nunsense" will come back for Mamet or Rattigan. "There were people living in Hackettstown for 15 years who'd never been to Centenary," he said. "But they came to 'Nunsense,' and they travel all over to see the same show. This was their fifth 'Nunsense,' and they haven't been back to our theater since. But nothing else we do pays the bills."
The standby's lot may not be a happy one, but "if I weren't here, I'd be on my way to the Forum," Mr. Wallnau said, referring to the Forum Theater Group in Metuchen. "My vocation is also my avocation." Summing up his Paper Mill experience, he said: "I'm glad I did it and I'm glad it's over, and I don't think I'd do it again. It's frustrating. You never bring your experience to completion, just your version of someone else's version, so that it doesn't mess anyone up. You just show up. And get ready to wait."
 
RESUME
Carl N. Wallnau
 
BORN Jackson Heights, Queens, July 8, 1953.
EDUCATION Bachelor of arts in drama and economics from Dickinson College, 1975. Master of fine arts in theater and acting, 1982, Mason Gross School of the Arts, Rutgers University.
CURRENT JOBS Associate professor of theater arts at Centenary College since 1984, teaching theater appreciation, public speaking and a communications seminar this semester. Producing director of Centenary Stage Company, in residence at the college in Hackettstown, since 1990. Producing director of the Young Performers Workshop since 1994. Mr. Wallnau founded the stage company and the workshop under the banner of the Centenary Performing Arts Guild, which presents music and ballet.
DIRECTING More than 30 productions at Centenary Stage, including "The Innocents" last season and "The Killing of Sister George," running May 1 to 16.
ACTING Credits include "Speed-the-Plow," "Billy Bishop Goes to War," "Private Lives," "Talley's Folly" and "Absent Friends" at Centenary Stage. At other New Jersey professional theaters: "Laughter on the 23d Floor" at the Forum Theater Group in Metuchen, "A Thousand Clowns" at American Stage in Teaneck, "To Be Young, Gifted and Black" at Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick. Currently understudy and standby for the roles of Uncle Ben, Charley and Stanley in "Death of a Salesman" at Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn. Acted at other regional theaters including Pennsylvania Shakespeare Festival, where he plans to return this summer for "All's Well That Ends Well."
FAMILY Married for 18 years to Colleen Smith Wallnau, an actress. The Wallnaus live in Hoboken with two 12-year-old Siamese cats, Hessie (named for Hesione in "Heartbreak House") and Snuggles (named for the fabric softener).
INTERESTS Theater. "That's it," he says.
HOBBIES Reading plays, seeing plays, watching his wife act in plays and musicals, directing plays, and acting in plays.

PUB-DATE: April 5, 1998

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 26; Column 1; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 4102 words

HEADLINE: The Changing Face Of America's Teachers

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
The lights went off inside the windowless, cinder-block room, and the television screen began to glow, filled with the grainy images of a Department of Defense video. As the 11 viewers took furious notes, the camera focused on a communications tower outside of Baghdad. Seconds later, the tower exploded, blown up by a bomb from the belly of an American plane.
As if leading a Pentagon briefing, the man at the front of the room noted the angle and speed at which the bomb had hit, his voice matter-of-fact, his cadence clipped from two decades in the Air Force. When the lights came up, the viewers began a series of calculations of their own. 
 But those being briefed were not in the military; they were 12th-grade physics students at Richmond Senior High School, in a small town 80 miles southeast of Charlotte, N.C. And although the speaker was an Air Force colonel who commanded 500 men and women in Operation Desert Storm in 1991, his career ended a lifetime ago. At least that's how it seems to him.
For four years now, Jay Gaskin has been a teacher.
While a 26-year military odyssey that stretched from the Nevada desert to the Far East is hardly the most direct path to the front of a classroom, experts say it will take tens of thousands of teachers like Mr. Gaskin -- people who were well established in other careers, and who probably didn't take an education course in their undergraduate years -- to help fill all the vacancies projected in the nation's public schools over the next decade.
The Department of Education predicted last fall that two million elementary and secondary teachers will have to be hired and trained by 2007, a figure that is nearly three-quarters as large as the current workforce of 2.7 million public-school teachers. (And that doesn't include the 100,000 elementary-school jobs that would be created over the next seven years, under President Clinton's recently proposed effort to reduce class size.)
Most of the vacancies will come as a result of teacher attrition or enrollment growth. But the current cast of teachers is a driving factor as well: today's teaching ranks are generally considered too white and too female, given the diversity among students in the nation's schools. And a third of all teachers are not trained in the subjects they teach.
As they have in the past, the nation's teaching schools, whether undergraduate or graduate, will produce most of the teachers who will fill these available slots. But they won't be able to do it alone -- especially in districts like Los Angeles and Houston, which are already short thousands of qualified teachers.
And so districts must get creative, looking in unusual places for candidates who can relieve shortages but who also bring to the classroom skills and a point of view that might not be taught in an education school.
There are currently more than 300 alternative teacher-recruitment and training programs in the country -- half begun since 1990, many catering to physicists, engineers and business people, among others, who are looking for a career change. At a time when education schools are striving to give prospective teachers better grounding in subjects like math and science, the alternative programs produce teachers who have used such skills in everyday life.
One program is Troops to Teachers, a four-year-old clearinghouse that has moved Mr. Gaskin and more than 2,000 other retiring military personnel out of their labs and barracks and into second careers in schoolhouses in impoverished communities that more experienced teachers have shunned.
Another venture, Teach for America, has strived over the last nine years to counter teaching's bad rap as a career choice. The organization's pitch -- that teaching in the inner city is cool and rewarding -- has been so persuasive that it has rerouted, or at least delayed, the career plans of 4,000 prospective bankers, doctors and software writers on the nation's most elite college campuses.
Janice Gordon, for instance, a Dartmouth College student who was planning to apply to law school until she was buttonholed by Teach for America in 1991, is finishing her sixth year at an elementary school in one of New York City's least affluent communities.
Looking closer to home, the DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund has given nearly 2,000 classroom aides who were already working in urban districts the financial means to reach the major leagues: to be trained and promoted to full-time teachers. One recent graduate of the program, which began in 1989, is Kathy Moran, a teacher's aide in Pittsburgh who dreamed for two decades of presiding over her own classroom.
"It's not healthy -- and it's not sufficient or realistic -- to just replace the next generation of teachers with only 23- and 24-year-olds from the suburbs who don't have much life experience," said David Haselkorn, the president of Recruiting New Teachers, a nonprofit resource center in Belmont, Mass. "These alternative-route programs draw from different talent pools and they connect, in many cases, much more directly to the needs of urban and low-income classrooms."
Most of the new hires will be replacing an unusually high number of retirees: about one of every two teachers is 45 or older and is expected to leave the classroom by 2007, at or around age 55. The bulk of these teachers were hired to teach the baby-boom generation in the late 1960's and early 70's.
But other departing teachers have far less experience. Nearly a third of the nation's newly minted teachers, by some estimates, have been quitting in their first, second or third years, discouraged, they say, by the low pay and monumental task of prodding student achievement. Indeed, if everyone who received a teaching degree in recent years were in the classroom today, there would be a surplus.
A major new movement has been creating a safety net for the most vulnerable educators by strengthening their teaching skills and pairing them with mentors. In Goose Creek, S.C., just outside Charleston, a new state-mandated mentoring program may have already saved one fledgling teacher -- Tammy Reynolds, 22 -- who got rattled like a rookie starting pitcher in the early weeks of the school year.
New hires like Mrs. Reynolds are charged with relieving the effects of burgeoning enrollments, as the children of baby boomers advance through the nation's schools, joined, especially in California and New York City, by a continuing flood of immigrants. Over the next decade, the rolls of public schools are expected to grow by 4 percent, from 46.4 million to 48.3 million.
Some parts of the country have greater needs than others: In Texas, for example, the state's universities graduated 457 certified math teachers in 1996 -- but the Texas public schools needed 2,500, according to Houston school officials.
And although other states, particularly Minnesota, Indiana and Wisconsin, are graduating tens of thousands more teachers each year than they can place in jobs, those rookies have been reluctant to relocate to areas where the needs are most great, like urban schools in Los Angeles, or depressed communities like Richmond County, N.C.
 
Desert Storm? Piece of Cake
Forgive Jay Gaskin if standing in front of a classroom in rural North Carolina did not sound like hardship duty.
After all, he spent four years in the 1980's testing and redesigning the F-117 Stealth fighter. And for the first year of that classified project, he left his home outside Las Vegas, Nev., every Monday morning and did not return until Friday night -- never at liberty to tell his wife, Sandra, where he had been. (He was working from a hangar in the Nevada desert that only a few people knew existed.)
But nothing, he says, prepared him for what he encountered four autumns ago, on his first day as a science teacher at Richmond Senior High. Unfazed by the colonel's eagle once worn on his shoulder, his students never hesitated to tell him, "You stink!" or worse.
"There was a desperate feeling of helplessness," Mr. Gaskin, now 52, recalled, his face reddening. "I went from a situation where I could tell a person to go into certain death, and they'd do it, to a case where it was just the opposite. Nothing was obeyed blindly.
"I couldn't take their paycheck," he added. "I couldn't throw 'em in the brig. What could I do?"
Fighting the temptation to ball his hand into a fist, Mr. Gaskin says he learned, slowly, to use charm instead of pulling rank.
"If they would walk up to me and say, 'You stink!' I'd say, 'That's funny, I thought I put on my deodorant today."'
Coming from a stern-looking man with a brushy mustache and a midsection as trim as when he enlisted, the humor was disarming.
Ralph Robertson, the principal of Richmond Senior High, said it was nothing short of a godsend to get a science teacher with the qualifications of Mr. Gaskin, who had hands-on experience with the most sophisticated engines in the world.
Although the school's football team is a perennial state champion, Mr. Robertson has had difficulty attracting teachers to this depressed, pine-studded county near the South Carolina border. Its most productive textile-manufacturing days came and went long ago. When the school's lone, longtime physics teacher announced his retirement in 1993, Mr. Robertson did not have an applicant for the job.
Then he heard about the Defense Department's Troops to Teachers program. Seeing Mr. Gaskin's resume on a Troops to Teachers circular, Mr. Robertson invited him for an interview.
The principal learned that four years earlier, Mr. Gaskin had begun to contemplate retiring after a quarter-century in the military and was wondering what he should do next. He thought about joining an aerospace company, but he also thought of the words of his high school chemistry teacher, who had predicted that Mr. Gaskin would make a wonderful teacher himself.
Although he had a bachelor's degree in geology and a master's degree in psychology, Mr. Gaskin knew he needed some education courses to satisfy the requirements in most states. So, during his last command, at Langley Air Force Base in Virginia, Mr. Gaskin enrolled in night school at Old Dominion University in Norfolk. He graduated two years later with a master's in education.
For Mr. Gaskin, who grew up in a South Carolina town not far from Richmond County, the chance to return to the region -- and a student population he felt he could help -- seemed perfect.
Now a veteran of four years in the educational trenches, Mr. Gaskin has looked to his military career for a trove of real-life examples to help his students grasp the concepts of chemistry and physics.
"Think if you were shooting artillery at Saddam Hussein," he said in class the other day, attempting to guide a student through a lab he had designed on the concept of ballistics.
At another point, he cautioned his students against trying the demonstration portion of the lab before calculating their anticipated results.
"You got to do the paperwork first," he said, his voice a bark. "When I was in the Air Force, I hated paperwork. But you got to do it."
The principal says his prized teacher is getting
results: the school's scores on standarized state physics tests have increased 25 percentage points over the last four years. The students have noticed a difference, too.
"He did this all his life," said Brandon Thrower, 17, a member of Mr. Gaskin's second-period, college-level physics class. "He used physics to plan bomber runs."
A classmate, Jaime Bolton, 17, added: "He makes it fun. When he talks about his military background, it's weird to think he was above all these people, and now he's just teaching us.
"But he's not scary at all," he said. "He's just Mr. Gaskin."
 
Ivy League Tweed
A quarter-century ago, one of the few career options open to Janice Gordon would have been teaching. But this is a different time, of course, and by the summer of 1991, before her senior year at Dartmouth College, Ms. Gordon had decided on a far different course: she would be an international lawyer.
Then she saw a Teach for America flier, and figured she might as well hear what the recruiter had to say.
Since 1989, Teach for America, a nonprofit venture, has been trolling for inner-city teachers on Ivy League and other elite campuses. Its pitch to economics, science and other majors has combined the hard sell of a visiting investment bank ("We're looking only for the best and the brightest") with the higher calling of the Peace Corps (the desperate need for qualified teachers in under-served neighborhoods). And hey, those accepted to the program need only commit to two years.
More than 4,100 graduating seniors have signed on.
Ms. Gordon, who grew up in one of New York City's hardscrabble neighborhoods, East Flatbush in Brooklyn, says she has always been grateful to the teachers who guided her through the city's public schools, though she never imagined following in their footsteps. Nonetheless, as she listened to the Teach for America presentation, she suddenly found herself reflecting on her sixth-grade teacher, Joan Diehl, at Public School 219, who taught her "probably all the vocabulary I needed to survive in life in that one year.
"I thought about what a good teacher can do for a student," she added. "I thought, 'Maybe I could teach for two years, and then go to law school."'
Since she had never taken an education course, she spent two months that summer at a Teach for America boot camp at the California State University, at North Ridge, which taught her the basics of managing a classroom and assessing children's needs.
While there, she met Miriam Acosta-Sing, the principal of the Mott Hall School, a magnet school populated almost entirely by first- and second-generation Dominican immigrants in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan. Impressed that Ms. Gordon had majored in Spanish -- a language in short supply among New York City teachers -- the principal offered her a job as a fourth-grade teacher.
That first year she was continually exhausted and anxious. Commuting 80 minutes each way on the subway from her mother's house in Brooklyn, she sometimes fell asleep on the ride home and missed her stop. In class, she peppered herself with questions: "How am I going to make sure I cover all these things? What is a fair test?"
By that spring, she was pulling out her law school applications again, she says. But on the last day of school, something happened. "I had 25 students," she said. "And each one sat in the lunchroom that day and cried that the school year was over.
"I said, 'I think I'm hooked."'
Ms. Gordon, now 27 and in her sixth year, has since completed most of the coursework for a master's in education. She was also selected to be the pilot teacher in a program, partly sponsored by Microsoft, in which laptop computers are leased to students. In early March, the Microsoft chairman, William H. Gates, visited her class. "He seemed like the person from down the block, who just happens to be the richest man in the world," she said.
And how has Ms. Gordon coped with a salary that, this year, is about $31,000? She's still living at home. And sometimes she wonders about all the money she could make on Wall Street. But then she pulls out a stack of valentines from her students. "I don't think $100,000 would make me feel as good as these do," she said.
Though her posture is ramrod straight and her clothes are Ivy League tweed, Ms. Gordon has encouraged her students to loosen up a bit as they learn. On a recent morning, she asked them to report on the status of their forthcoming presentations on the ancient kingdoms of Africa.
"We're still getting a rhythm for the rap we're going to do," said one boy from the group researching Nubia.
"Nubian rappers?" Ms. Gordon responded, her smile quizzical. "I wonder if they were around at that time?"
Her students say they appreciate that she speaks often of growing up in a poor neighborhood, not unlike theirs, the daughter of a single mother from Jamaica.
"She can relate to us," said Evelyn Perez, 11. "She's very determined to succeed. She has accomplished a lot. It's very encouraging."
 
A Dream Realized
If Teach for America has shown school districts the rich rewards of aggressive recruiting, then the DeWitt Wallace-Readers Digest program has taught them that their most qualified candidates may have been under their noses all along.
That was true of Kathy Moran, who for 20 years labored virtually unnoticed as a teacher's aide in a succession of special education classrooms in inner-city Pittsburgh.
About a half-million aides, or paraprofessionals, hold such jobs nationally, and their role is to ease the burden of the classroom teacher by, say, reading with a slower student or escorting the class to the playground.
Often, the heart of a classroom teacher beats within the teacher's aide. But more often than not, that ambition is squelched by the challenge of attending college -- and, in many cases, returning to high school first -- to collect the requisite degrees and education courses to be promoted.
Ms. Moran, now 41, was mired in just such a rut. The daughter of a mechanic and a school secretary who graduated to teaching herself, Ms. Moran grew up in Pittsburgh and dropped out of Indiana University in Indiana, Pa., in 1976. She had been there less than two years and had no idea what to do with her life.
Two years later, she found part-time work as an aide in a special education classroom in a Pittsburgh elementary school, and a light went on.
"Just seeing what they did," she said of the teachers and the pupils, who overcame any number of physical and emotional barriers, "enlightened me."
Although she then knew she wanted to lead her own classroom, she saw no easy way to get there. Married to a bank maintenance worker who, like her, was earning little more than minimum wage, she had no resources to pay for the 90 additional credits (or 30 courses) that she needed. And so Ms. Moran enrolled in a community college at night, taking one or two courses a year, as well as working full-time as a classroom aide and often part-time as a department store cashier.
"I was real frustrated," Ms. Moran said. "It was always not too far away. I could almost put my hand on it. But I couldn't.
"Still," she added, "I was determined to finish."
Fifteen years later, in 1993, she had 60 credits -- 30 more than she had left college with, but still 60 shy of a degree.
Then, she said, fate finally smiled: she learned that Readers Digest was doling out millions of dollars to education schools to turn teachers' aides into teachers. All tuition was covered. And one such program was at Indiana University, the same school Ms. Moran had left. Ms. Moran was one of 85 paraprofessionals in the Pittsburgh schools who applied for 36 available spots. To her delight, she was accepted.
Edwina Vold, who oversees the program at Indiana, said Ms. Moran and her classmates bring enormous gifts, because they are "unafraid of the inner city" and "have very few stereotypes about the children they are working with."
One night last August, only three months after graduating with her degree in elementary education, Ms. Moran endured a sleepless night. She knew that the following morning, she would stride into a classroom that was her very own -- for the first time in her career.
"I was bouncing off ideas and writing notes," she said. "It was excitement."
The months since have been a challenge. Ms. Moran has sole responsibility for a classroom of 21 second graders at the Weil Technology Institute, a red brick fortress in the middle of the struggling Hill District. Only 4 of every 100 pupils at the school has two parents at home. From the window of Ms. Moran's classroom, she can see an overgrown, vacant lot filled with tall weeds.
Inside her class, behind its bright yellow door, the learning is often bumpy. Standing 5 feet 10 inches, but seeming far taller, Ms. Moran uses her booming voice as she patrols the rows of tan, open-top desks.
"Shawn, sit down!" she intoned the other day. "Turn your paper over and do it the right way!"
But a moment later, she had another boy clutched in a bear hug. "Tie your shoe," she told him softly. "Don't break your neck."
So far, the combination of good cop and bad cop seems to be working.
"If we're bad, she makes us stay after school and gives us a lot of work," Darren Scott, 8, related over a lunch of ham and cheese and fruit cocktail. "And every time we win a game, she gives us a treat."
Though imploring her students to improve has often been frustrating, Ms. Moran says she wouldn't ever want to return to her former, subordinate role.
"How can I put it?" she said the other day, the stern expression she shows her class finally dissolving into a smile. "This is a blessing for me."
 
A Guardian Angel
If Kathy Moran's path to the classroom seemed as long as a marathon, then Tammy Reynolds's was a sprint.
Mrs. Reynolds decided in her sophomore year at Ohio University that she wanted to be a teacher. Over the next two years, she took more than a dozen traditional education courses, with titles like "Classroom Management" and "Multimedia in the Classroom," and even logged several months as a student teacher in a first- grade class.
Last spring, she and her professors believed she was ready, and she graduated with a bachelor's degree in elementary education.
But in August, after her first day as a seventh-grade mathematics teacher at Westview Middle School, in a middle-class suburb of Charleston, S.C., Mrs. Reynolds went home and wept. Lucky for her, her school district had assigned her a guardian angel.
Mindful that many teachers drop out of teaching early in their careers -- many of them midway through the first year -- the South Carolina Legislature last year required districts to establish intensive mentoring programs for new teachers. While recruiting has been a high priority in many states for some years, it's only recently that states have begun to focus on the next steps: retention and staff development.
So many things had unnerved the 22-year-old rookie on her first day. At 5 feet 3 inches, she was shorter than most of her students, including several who played junior varsity football at the local high school. ("It was very threatening," she said.) When she gave out her first homework assignment, she said she was met with "rolled eyes.
I missed the hugs of my first graders," she said. "I got a lot of sarcasm." Within weeks, Mrs. Reynolds was wondering whether she had made the right career choice.
To help her over such patches, Westview Middle School had made her well-being the responsibility of Lee Ann Coleman, 33, a nine-year veteran who had known since the age of 13, when she all but received a vision in an evangelical church service, that her life's work was to teach.
Meeting before and after school, Mrs. Coleman tutored her pupil in any number of areas. She helped Mrs. Reynolds establish classroom rules, as basic as when her students would be permitted bathroom breaks. She guided her through the writing of a yearlong lesson plan. And
she staged a mock evaluation interview, playing the role of the principal.
"There were little things she doesn't even know she did," Mrs. Reynolds said. "For example, I was always really tired all the time. My husband was like, 'You must be sick.' But Lee Ann said, 'That's normal. It's O.K. You're tired because of the stress and the workload and because your immune system is not used to being around all these kids.' "
Slowly, Mrs. Reynolds's confidence has grown. Last November, she was confronted with her most challenging behavioral problem: a student who insisted on banging his head against a cabinet as a way to get attention.
"I asked the rest of the class, 'Raise your hand if you want this student to be in the class,' " she recalled. "No one did."
"He felt bad," she said. "He asked if he could participate. So I said to him, 'Go and ask if anyone wants you in their group.' Finally, one person took him in."
There are still ups and downs, she says, but with the encouragement of her mentor, Mrs. Reynolds no longer thinks much about truncating her career.
"Whenever I start to get so bogged down with paperwork and I'm fed up with that one problem student," she said, "another student seems to come along and let you know how much you mean to him.
"There's more of those times than the bad times," she said. "I will hang in there."

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD: LANGUAGE OF COMMERCE;
In Vietnam, A New Approach To English

BYLINE: By David W. Chen 

 BODY:
Vietnam's English-language curriculum, hampered for decades by a lack of materials and trained teachers, is being revised for the first time in 17 years.
In a program run by Business Alliance for Vietnamese Education, a nonprofit organization based in Manhattan, all of Vietnam's 450,000 sixth graders in 1,560 public schools will receive a new textbook this year. Titled "English for Vietnam," it was developed by American and Vietnamese educators. Books for 7th and 10th graders are in the works, and by the year 2000, all of Vietnam's middle and high school students are to have textbooks. 
 Expected to be in schools in September, the new curriculum emphasizes participatory exercises involving audiotapes and role-playing, said Daniel W. Reese, director of the alliance.
The program, which will cost an estimated $1.2 million for the first year, is sponsored by corporations that have been active in Vietnam's rapidly growing economy, including Chase Manhattan, Citibank, McDonnell Douglas, Microsoft and Coca-Cola.
"This is a very important project for Vietnam," said Tran Khanh, a counselor with the Vietnamese Embassy in Washington, noting that English, not French, is now the country's official second language. "It will have very long-lasting impact on the younger generation of Vietnamese."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
Can't Get Subsidies, Can't Buy, Can't Move

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
They live in a solidly middle-class area, opposite First Avenue from Peter Cooper Village and just a few blocks from Gramercy Park. And that is precisely the problem for tenants of 346 East 21st Street, nearly all of whom are low-income families who have lived in the rundown tenement for many years.
The 30-unit, six-story building is like thousands of others that fell to the city when previous owners abandoned them. But because of its location, city officials are refusing to offer tenants subsidies that might allow them to buy it, even though similar buildings in poorer neighborhoods generally qualify. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which appraised the building at $1.5 million, has given tenants until June 30 to come up with the money. If they can't, it will go on the open market, where a developer may be willing to pay far more than the appraisal figure. 
 "It's impossible," said Ed Delgado, president of No. 346's tenant association. He said 98 percent of residents had family incomes of less than $7,400 annually. "Who is going to give us a mortgage?"
Since 1994, building residents have tried to join the city's Tenant Interim Lease program, which would permit them to organize as a low-income cooperative and buy their units at low cost after a leasing period.
But the city has turned them down. A department spokeswoman, Cassandra Vernon, explained that the program "is a subsidy, not an entitlement," to be used only "when there is little chance for a private sale."
"But this building is located in a good area," where a private sale is likely, she added.
Mr. Delgado said that he had met with department officials several times but that the city had consistently turned down his requests for low-income tax credits and low-interest loans often offered to low-income apartment buyers in abandoned buildings elsewhere in the city.
Mr. Delgado declined to say how much apartments in the building rented for, but he acknowledged that rents were "very low." Tenants will continue to have rent protection if a private owner buys the building, but the cost of much-needed major capital improvements could be passed on to them. That, Mr. Delgado said, would probably force most tenants out.
"Many people are disabled or retired," he said, adding that the building is "racially mixed."
"It's not fair," he said. "If we were south of 14th Street, we would have gotten into a program."
Councilwoman Margarita Lopez agrees. Her district includes East 21st Street and the Lower East Side, the site of many subsidized buildings.
"I'm looking into the question of discrimination against poor people in a middle-class area," she said. "This building is the only one I know of between 14th and 35th Streets asking to join the Tenant Interim Lease program, and it's not getting it." BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
Right Time for an Inflation Hedge?

BYLINE: By ABBY SCHULTZ 

 BODY:
YAWN.
That is how investors have greeted the small crop of new mutual funds investing in inflation-indexed Government securities. 
 Since the securities were first offered, a little more than a year ago, only three retail funds specializing in them have been introduced. Together, the funds have just $26.6 million in assets, some of which is in inflation-indexed securities issued by other countries.
But now, precisely because inflation is so low, the cost of buying protection against its rise is about the cheapest it has been since the Government began issuing the securities in 1997. And that could make this the right choice at the right time for people seeking a conservative fixed-income investment.
"I can't say what inflation will be in 10 years, but inflation protection costs less now than it did," said David W. Schroeder, manager of one of the funds, the $5.2 million American Century-Benham Inflation-Adjusted Treasury fund.
According to Daniel S. Bernstein, director of research at Bridgewater Associates in Wilton, Conn., when the inflation-indexed securities were issued last year, inflation would have had to be 3.3 percent or more a year for the notes to earn a higher total return than traditional Treasury notes. Today, he said, inflation would have to be just 2 percent or more a year for them to do so.
"From a year ago to today, it just makes inflation-indexed bonds more attractive," he said.
If inflation does strike harder, these securities will offer better protection than traditional inflation hedges like commodities, precious metals, collectibles or real estate, said John B. Brynjolfsson, manager of the $7.7 million Pimco Real Return Bond fund, another of the funds specializing in inflation-indexed securities. That is because inflation-indexed notes not only guarantee that the principal of the securities will maintain today's purchasing power, by rising with inflation, but they also offer interest income, now about 3.7 percent for 10-year issues.
"That essentially means until the year 2008 you can lock in a 3.7 percent real return above inflation," Mr. Brynjolfsson said.
INSTITUTIONAL investors worldwide have bought most of the $39 billion in these securities that the United States Treasury has issued so far. Retail investors have been more reticent, and for several reasons.
The first, of course, is low inflation -- it is about 1.4 percent a year now, down from 3 percent at the time of the first, $7 billion offering of 10-year notes last year, and it shows no signs of picking up. Selling inflation-indexed bonds now is like "selling ice in the winter," said Michael Shamosh, chief fixed-income strategist at Gabriele Hueglin & Cashman, a New York brokerage firm.
Investors have also avoided the securities because of a tax on the so-called phantom income that accrues in the notes but is not passed on to investors until the security matures. Unlike regular Treasury notes and bonds, which have a fixed principal and a fixed coupon, the principal in an inflation-indexed bond is adjusted continually for inflation, as determined by monthly changes in the Consumer Price Index. If inflation were to rise 10 percent in a year, the principal of a $1,000 bond would adjust to $1,100 and holders would be taxed on the $100 gain as ordinary income, even though they had not pocketed the increase.
But it is most likely that individual investors have shied from inflation-linked funds because their returns have paled in comparison with those of other fixed-income funds, let alone the soaring returns of stock funds.
The average total return of the three retail funds -- the third is Brown Brothers Harriman's 59 Wall Street Inflation-Indexed Securities -- was 3.7 percent for the 12 months ended March 31, according to Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago. That is less than the 3.9 percent return of a Lehman Brothers index of the Treasury's inflation-indexed securities for the same period, and well below the 10.5 percent return of intermediate-term Government bond funds or the 7.4 percent return of short-term Government bond funds, Morningstar said.
The meager results reflect the fact that "real yields," or interest rates minus inflation, have risen and prices have fallen in the last 12 months. At the same time, yields on traditional bonds have fallen and prices have risen because inflation has continued to drop. The first 10-year inflation-indexed Treasury note, for instance, was priced at 101.05 percent of par value when American Century opened its fund on Feb. 10 last year; on April 1 this year, the note's price had fallen to 97 percent of par value -- although the loss was not quite as great as it seems because the par value had grown in line with inflation. The fund, meanwhile, returned 3.4 percent for the year ended March 31.
While this short-term record is lackluster, long-term investors should not be discouraged, said Mr. Schroeder, the fund's manager. "Folks should know that, over the short term, performance will be impacted by changes in real yields, while long-term performance will be impacted more by changes in inflation," he said.
That is a strong reason to take a look at these securities now, when the inflation protection is relatively cheap. The traditional 10-year Treasury note yields about 5.5 percent, while 10-year inflation-linked notes yield about 3.7 percent -- a difference of just under two percentage points. If inflation were 2 percent a year or higher for the next 10 years, the return on the inflation-indexed security would be higher than the return on the traditional 10-year note, Mr. Schroeder said.
Mr. Brynjolfsson's fund, Pimco Real Return Bond, is the best-performing of the three retail offerings. It had a total return of just over 4 percent for the 12 months ended March 31, according to Morningstar.
The manager uses several strategies to outperform the Lehman Brothers index of inflation-linked securities, including the buying of foreign inflation-indexed bonds -- other big issuers include Canada, New Zealand and Australia -- and securities issued by corporations and agencies in the United States.
The $13.7 million 59 Wall Street Inflation-Indexed Securities fund also invests overseas and in corporate issues. Only American Century sticks solely with United States Government issues.
All these funds will have the opportunity to lock in inflation protection over a longer period on Wednesday, when the Treasury Department auctions $8 billion in 30-year inflation-indexed securities.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
How a Few Leapfrogged the Rest

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
WHAT a way to start the year. United States stock fund managers seized hold of the red-hot equity market and the best delivered returns as high as 24 percent, with only five diversified funds losing money in the first quarter.
The average return of 11.2 percent, however, still trailed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which returned 13.9 percent for the quarter. 
 It was a trio of takeovers that landed Mark A. Coffelt, manager of Texas Capital Value's Value and Growth fund, at the top of the group in the first quarter, with a return of 24.3 percent. Other managers in the quarter's top 10 for United States diversified stock funds with $30 million or more in assets were Thomas F. Marsico, formerly of Janus Capital, who started Marsico Focus on Jan. 1; Mark G. Seferovich, manager of Waddell & Reed Growth, and Arden C. Armstrong, who manages MAS Institutional Mid-Cap Growth.
The three oldest of these funds also made the top 20 list for the last 12 months.
How did these winning managers achieve their gains? Three of the four have concentrated their investments in so few stocks that their winning picks had a particularly big impact in the quarter. The fourth scurried to avoid earnings disasters. Here, the managers discuss their good fortune and look forward to the rest of the year.
 
Where Takeovers Rule
Mr. Coffelt uses a quantitative approach to figure companies' worth if they were taken over, depending on their profitability, growth in business, leverage and current interest rates.
He hit the bull's-eye in the first quarter when 3 of the 35 companies in the Value and Growth portfolio of Texas Capital Value Funds rose on takeover news, helping to propel the fund into first place for that period and into second for the 12 months, with a return of 77.16 percent.
"It's unusual to get that many takeovers in one quarter, although typically we get many throughout the year," said Mr. Coffelt, who has run the fund, with $60 million in assets, since its inception in 1995. Acquisitions of Medusa, a cement company, and the Money Store were announced in the quarter, and the acquisition of Oregon Metallurgical was completed at the end of March.
Mr. Coffelt screens the 1,700 stocks tracked by the Value Line Investment Survey, rating them on such criteria as earnings growth, cash flow and book value. He then estimates each stock's intrinsic value and tries to buy at a discount.
He sells shares when he thinks the companies are fully valued, as he did with Tommy Hilfiger last quarter when its shares reached $60. He also dumps companies that add debt to their balance sheet or whose earnings shift direction, or when he finds a better bargain elsewhere.
Mr. Coffelt is a believer in beneficence. He donates part of his management fee to charities designated by his shareholders. And the fund will waive its usual initial sales charge for investors who transfer money from another fund.
 
Powered by Ford
Mr. Marsico says pure and simple stock selection was the key to his fund's 23.1 percent return and fourth-place finish in its own first quarter.
"It came from a broad base of industries because, in managing a focused fund, you need that to diversify risk," he said. The young fund holds just 24 stocks; the top 10 make up 60 percent of the portfolio.
"We're looking for companies that are improving their return on assets and equity and building a stable growth platform for the future, usually including a global growth opportunity," he said.
His biggest holding is the Ford Motor Company, which makes up 11.2 percent of the fund. Ford has been increasing its cash position to weather a downturn in its core car business, as well as liquidating some peripheral assets, Mr. Marsico said.
Another winner was Dell Computer, the fund's second-largest holding, at 8.5 percent. The company is profiting from its direct distribution model, Mr. Marsico said, and he expects earnings to grow annually over the next three years as Dell moves into the less competitive markets for servers and work stations.
Looking ahead, Mr. Marsico is bullish on the stock market.
"I'm seeing earnings growth of about 10 to 12 percent for United States companies over the next 12 to 18 months and interest rates falling below 5 percent," he said, "which would mean the market is undervalued at these levels."
 
Three Stocks With Punch
"What drove the quarter was telecommunications stocks," said Mr. Seferovich, who has managed the $350 million Waddell & Reed Growth fund since its inception in 1992. He owns just 56 stocks, with the top 10 making up one-third of the fund. Annual turnover is a low 35 percent.
Mr. Seferovich devoted 10 percent of his portfolio to three telecommunications stocks, each of which turned in a stellar quarter that helped the fund return 22.2 percent, for a sixth-place finish in the three months, and 65.4 percent in the 12 months, for 18th place.
Colt Telecommunications, a British company traded as an American depository receipt, doubled in price. Colt offers bundled fiber optic cable for combined voice-data-video transmission in big European cities and, because it invests in advanced equipment, it can provide services much more cheaply than local telephone companies, Mr. Seferovich said. Its customer growth is increasing, but Colt has yet to report a profit.
"They spend like crazy on infrastructure; the revenues will come later," he said.
He also made a lot of money in Intermedia Communications, a similar company operating in the southeastern United States.
His third telecommunications holding is America Online, whose stock rose 50 percent in the quarter. "They successfully diversified revenues from subscriptions to E-commerce and advertising," he said.
Among his other winners were Williams-Sonoma, the catalogue retailer. The company brought in outside managers to fix its distribution system, and that paid off in unexpectedly strong earnings, he said.
As for the year's strong start, Mr. Seferovich is doubtful it can be maintained. Instead, he figures that 1998 will have up-and-down quarters.
"I don't see a continuous stair-step pattern," he said. "We haven't had one in two years and I don't expect to see one now."
 
The Earnings Test
Keeping a keen eye on earnings helped Ms. Armstrong and her $450 million MAS Institutional Mid-Cap Growth fund grab the top spot for the 12 months, on a return of 77.18 percent, and ninth place for the quarter, at 20.7 percent.
"When the Asian crisis hit late last year, our strategy for 1998 was to avoid earnings misses, which would be more pervasive because of Asia," she said. "So we were brutal about going through the portfolio and tossing out anything we thought had earnings risk." She moved out of export, personal computer, economically sensitive and aggressive companies and into more stable domestic businesses.
Ms. Armstrong did especially well with media, broadcasting and cable companies, she said, including Panamsat, a private satellite company, and Outdoor Systems, a billboard company. Her fund owns 90 stocks, and the top 10 represent 21 percent of the portfolio.
"We spend a lot of time thinking about profitability and cash flow," Ms. Armstrong said, adding that she likes a company with excess cash because it can reinvest in the business and thereby sustain growth. "If Microsoft were small-cap," she said, "I'd buy it."
Instead, she owns BMC Software, a data base management software company, and Network Associates, a specialist in anti-virus software.
Ms. Armstrong is confident the market for smaller stocks will move ahead, even if it slips occasionally, given forecasts of slower economic growth and lower interest rates. "As long as cyclical stocks have earnings risk, people will go for growth stocks," she said. "The real risk to the stock market is a sustained rise in interest rates."
The fund ordinarily has a retail minimum of $5 million, which tags it an "institutional" fund, but it is available for a $2,500 initial purchase through fund supermarkets.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
Fickle and Faithful Formulas

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
MUTUAL fund portfolios are as different as the investors who create them. Some are positioned to reflect the market outlook three years from now; others take a closer view. Some use contrarian strategies, and some work hard to reduce the portfolio's risk levels. Some play market momentum; still others bet on unusual opportunities or historical patterns.
Such differences in the hypothetical retirement portfolios created by five professional money managers for The New York Times go a long way to explain the range in their returns for the first quarter this year. All the managers came in winners, gaining 7.23 percent to 11 percent. But none outpaced the market proxy, the Vanguard Index 500 fund, or even the average of all stock funds, because they held small or emerging markets stocks along with the large United States stocks that dominated the list of leaders in the first three months of the year. 
 Holding a diversified portfolio for the long term as market favorites come and go can be hard to live with day to day. "Long-term investing is my mantra and my faith, but I will admit that, about now, 'long-term' seems interminable," said Harold R. Evensky, a financial adviser in Coral Gables, Fla.
(Rather than publishing this retirement portfolio horse race once a year, as readers and managers were told last quarter, The Times has decided to continue presenting it each quarter.)
Looking long term, Mr. Evensky had carefully created a diverse portfolio that was held back by its big stake in small overseas companies and emerging-market stocks as well as by its holdings in domestic small stocks. The portfolio placed third among the five, returning 8.94 percent in the quarter.
He was also hurt by an 11 percent stake in Barr Rosenberg Market Neutral, which started in mid-December and was flat for the quarter. "I can't say we're happy," Mr. Evensky said, although he noted that the return was not out of line with the performance of similar investment portfolios run by Barr Rosenberg.
"My job is to plan for a lifetime, and my concerns include risk as well as returns," he said. "The portfolio is well-diversified and run by world-class managers, so damn the torpedoes and full steam ahead!"
His only change is to replace the Yacktman Fund with Wilshire Large Cap Growth, an index fund. "Don Yacktman is too often in cash and his investment style is tending too much toward value," Mr. Evensky said.
IN first place for the quarter was Jack A. Brill, a San Diego money manager who steers a "socially responsible" course. Mr. Brill's portfolio rose 11 percent, mostly because of its bias toward large-cap stocks, he said. He plans no changes.
"My portfolio contains a good mix of growth styles and defensive funds for the high market volatility I expect this year," he said.
Sheldon Jacobs, who edits the No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y., retains the overall lead among the five managers, with a gain of 128.4 percent since the contest began on July 7, 1993. The five portfolios have risen an average of 107.6 percent since then, compared with a 176.5 percent return for the Vanguard Index 500, which mimics the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
The performance of the hypothetical portfolios is tracked each quarter by Lipper Analytical Services of Summit, N.J. It excludes sales charges, transaction costs and taxes because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts. The five managers can choose any fund open to new investors. From the outset, they were asked to pick portfolios that would grow for 20 years.
While Mr. Jacobs leads long term, he trailed the other four managers for the quarter, with a return of 7.23 percent -- in large part, he said, because he had made the portfolio more conservative when The Times told him he would be making only annual changes. Now that he is back to quarterly reporting, he is bolstering his large-cap stock allocation and generally taking a more bullish stance.
To that end, he has dropped Heartland Value Plus and USAA Tax-Exempt Intermediate, which together had totaled one-quarter of the portfolio, and added a 20 percent chunk of Vanguard Total Stock Market, an index fund. "I've been gradually trying to switch over to index funds, which I think are superior in the long run because of their lower expenses," Mr. Jacobs said.
He chose this fund over Vanguard's S.& P. 500 fund because Total Stock Market holds small- and midcap stocks in addition to bigger ones, more closely mimicking the overall market. "To me, the whole concept of an index fund is not to make any judgments on the market," he said.
Mr. Jacobs also added a 10 percent position in Marsico Focus, one of the quarter's top performers. Thomas F. Marsico, formerly of Janus Capital, was doing a great job with a similar fund there, Mr. Jacobs said: "Now he can take the same strategy and start all over."
Eric M. Kobren, president of Kobren Insight Group in Wellesley, Mass., runs a portfolio of all-Fidelity funds that gained 8.87 percent in the quarter, taking fourth place among the five money managers.
Mr. Kobren is selling his 20 percent stakes in the Low-Priced Stock and Mid-Cap Stock funds, replacing them with two new Fidelity funds: Small-Cap Stock (20 percent) and Contrafund II (10 percent).
"While we would not recommend buying new funds simply because they are new, our research does show that new Fidelity stock funds tend to outperform their mature counterparts during their first and second years of operation," Mr. Kobren said. "Though larger Fidelity funds are forced to take a more sector-oriented approach to investing, these new funds can focus on the type of bottom-up stock-picking that has helped other Fidelity funds to outperform their competitors in years past."
He also doubled the position in Fidelity International Value, to 20 percent, on the theory that most international markets are attractive relative to United States valuations.
Susan Dziubinski, editor of Morningstar Investor in Chicago, took second place among the managers, with a gain of 9.82 percent. She is making no changes to her portfolio, which includes a big chunk of international stocks to help counteract a possible slowdown in the United States. Those holdings fared well largely because of a heavy investment in European companies. Her portfolio also includes small-cap issues that did well in the quarter.
Her only loser was Oppenheimer Real Asset, which fell 9.6 percent, in large part because of falling oil prices. But she's sticking with it. "The fund acts as a hedge against inflation and the stock market because it's more like a commodity play," Ms. Dziubinski said.
