HEADLINE: Nations Endorse Moves to Eradicate the Plague of Small Arms

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: OSLO, April 2

 BODY:
With words like path-breaking, courageous and visionary, representatives from African and Western nations, including the United States, have resoundingly endorsed measures to control the spread of light weapons, the major cause of death in today's wars.
The action came at a two-day assembly here called to advance a proposed moratorium on the export, import and manufacture of light weapons in West Africa, and to consider how that moratorium could be a model for other regions of the world, like Central America. 
 Reflecting a rapidly growing movement to stanch the flow of light weapons into areas of conflict, the conference was attended by 18 African nations, more than a dozen European countries, and Japan, Canada and Argentina.
"It is a dream come true," said Jan Egeland, director of the Norwegian Initiative on Small Arms Transfers, which convened the meeting, along with the United Nations Development Program. "Africa has seen too many wars, too many civilians killed, too much human rights abuse," said Mr. Egeland, a former Norwegian diplomat, who two weeks ago was the key speaker at a conference at Columbia University on controlling the light weapons trade.
It was therefore imperative, he said, for governments to support the "visionary idea" of a moratorium.
In a distinct break from weapons control measures in the past, delegates noted, this one is not the work of major outside powers. Rather, the project came from the President of Mali, Alpha Oumar Konare, who has been commended for the symbolic burning two years ago of a pile of 3,000 weapons surrendered by rebel groups in his country.
"The political, economic and social consequences of the anarchic proliferation of light weapons are well known," Mr. Konare said in his opening address. "They are the millions of victims, most of them civilians, the displaced populations with their tears and suffering, the phenomena of child soldiers, terrorism and wide-scale banditry in urban areas."
Mr. Konare said his Government would soon declare a moratorium, and other countries at the meeting here said they expected the 15-member Economic Community of West African States to call for a moratorium at its next meeting, in July.
The fledgling movement to curtail the trade in small arms and light weapons, like automatic rifles, machine guns, hand grenades, mortars and shoulder-fired missiles, has been propelled by the successful campaign to ban antipersonnel land mines.
And this time the United States is determined not to be left out, as in the land mines campaign, which produced a treaty that the Clinton Administration has refused to sign.
"We not only want to play in this, but exercise a little control to keep it in the right direction," said Herbert Calhoun, an official in the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and the leader of the United States delegation to the conference.
The Clinton Administration is fully mobilized to support measures to control the trade in light weapons, and is preparing some proposals of its own, he said.
The focus of Washington is on the illicit trade in pistols, which it wants to keep out of the hands of street criminals and drug gangs. But the participants here were part of a much broader movement, one aiming at all small arms, and the legal as well as illegal trade. It is primarily concerned about the political and social mayhem magnified by the spread of small arms.

HEADLINE: Strides in Pet Care Come at Price Owners Will Pay

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER 

 BODY:
When young Trina's adult teeth started coming in crowded, Dee Hanna did what so many other Americans have done -- she collared her little one and headed for a dentist who could straighten teeth.
Now, hundreds of dollars later, Trina's smile is as lovely as any other 12-pound Norwich Terrier's. 
 Veterinary medicine has moved way beyond rabies shots and heartworm pills, and now provides orthodontics for dogs, kidney dialysis for cats, Prozac and Valium for pets.
The money goes for pet pacemakers, chemotherapy, artificial hips, even open heart surgery.
"A lot of the things that are available to humans are available for pets," said Sharon Granskog, spokeswoman for the American Veterinary Medical Association. "I think the pet is being more and more recognized as a member of the family and is being treated as one."
Before World War II, when more Americans lived on farms or in rural areas, barnyard animals were kept for practical purpose and such fancy treatments were unheard of, said Bernard Rollin, a professor at the Colorado State University School of Veterinary Medicine and a trailblazer in the field of veterinary ethics. Now, with Fifi sharing the urban apartment and providing what may be the closest link to nature -- as well as being the closest thing to a child living at home -- the idea of spending thousands to save her life no longer seems far-fetched. This attitudinal shift started after World War II and has accelerated in the last 20 to 25 years, Mr. Rollin said.
A 1995 report by the American Animal Hospital Association found that 70 percent of former and current pet owners surveyed thought of their pets as children. Asked what one companion they would want on a deserted island, 53 percent listed a dog or cat.
Such feelings have translated into a huge change in the way veterinarians do business, and the amount of business. While $6.9 billion was spent on dogs, cats and birds in 1991, according to the American Veterinary Medical Association, pet owners spent $11.1 billion on health care in 1996, an increase of 61 percent.
Until 1951, the American Veterinary Medical Association did not recognize practice specialties. Now, there are 20 board-certified vet specialties -- from anesthesiology to toxicology -- and the number of vets who have taken the additional schooling and examinations to become certified has grown to more than 5,600, up from 2,700 in 1984.
Not surprisingly, the cost of a typical visit to the vet has also ballooned. The average cost for a dog went from $49.96 in 1991 to $73.60 in 1996, increasing at an 8.1 percent compound annual rate, according to the veterinary association. For cats, the price rose from $44.81 to $66.58, an 8.2 percent compound annual increase. Inflation grew just 2.9 percent.
Pet owners like Sally Prewett, a registered nurse in Sacramento, Calif., are fueling this economy. Bandit, a male Maine coon kitten she bought for $12, suffered kidney damage in 1992 after tasting antifreeze picked up off the garage floor. Five years later, Bandit was referred to the Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital at the University of California at Davis, a pioneer in feline kidney transplants. The operation was a success.
Ms. Prewett, 34, had to borrow part of the almost $3,000 it cost to get a new kidney for her large, black, gray and camel-colored cat. And since his surgery last spring, Bandit has also needed about $80 worth of anti-rejection drugs each month.
"A couple of people said, 'You're crazy for doing this,' " said Ms. Prewett. "I said, 'It's my cat and it's my money.'
"I don't have children. I'm single. These cats are like my kids," she said of Bandit and his three playmates. "I just can't imagine not doing it."
While the University of California at Davis is known for kidneys, Michigan State University's Veterinary Teaching Hospital is recognized for open-heart surgery, and Colorado State University's Veterinary Teaching Hospital is the place to go for bone cancer treatment. In fact, that hospital perfected a procedure for treating osteosarcoma later adapted for humans.
In the footsteps of "E.R." and "Chicago Hope" comes "Emergency Vets," a program broadcast five days a week over a cable station starring veterinarians at Alameda East Veterinary Hospital in Denver.
Even the emotional problems of dogs, cats and parrots merit treatment by specialists.
Veterinary behaviorists use drugs like Valium or Prozac for anxiety-ridden kitties that mark the kitchen with urine and dogs that howl from separation anxiety, said Dr. Benjamin Hart, professor of behavior at the University of California at Davis's School of Veterinary Medicine. Dr. Hart brings pet and people into his office for $120 consultations lasting an hour to an hour and a half to determine what is causing the behavior. Follow-up visits cost $80 but are less common than in human therapy. "People aren't going to string along for an hour-a-week for a year," Dr. Hart said.
Americans' increased care for pets may one day affect stark agricultural practices. "As people identify more with their pets they become more and more concerned with the treatment of all animals," said Mr. Rollins, the ethicist.

HEADLINE: Business Groups Press For $18 Billion for I.M.F.

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
Every Friday afternoon, 100 of the country's top business advocates meet in the majestic courtyard of the United States of Chamber of Commerce headquarters here to map out strategy in their struggle to influence one of Congress's biggest foreign policy decisions this year.
Still smarting from its role in last fall's defeat of the fast-track trade negotiating authority, American business has regrouped and enlisted new allies, and is furiously lobbying Congress to approve $18 billion in new financing for the cash-strapped International Monetary Fund, which has been instrumental in the Asian financial bailout. 
 It is an unusual coalition with about 300 members -- Fortune 500 companies and small businesses, ranging from Boeing to the San Francisco Pasta Company, as well as trade associations, farm groups and local chambers of commerce. Their effort began in February out of concern over losing exports or letting a financial crisis abroad upset national security goals at home.
The campaign has scored one major victory. Late last month, the Senate overwhelmingly approved the financing and attached it to a must-pass disaster-relief bill. But the House is balking, setting up a showdown when Congressional negotiators return later this month from their spring recess to hammer out a compromise on the disaster-relief legislation.
"We are going to ratchet up the temperature on this," said Edmund B. Rice, executive director of the Coalition for Employment through Exports Inc., one of the main trade groups setting sights on lawmakers here and mobilizing business advocates in the field to buttonhole their legislators.
In the ill-fated fast-track trade campaign, business and many liberal Democrats were in opposite camps.
In this fight, however, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, was an early and influential ally of the business lobby.
Another big difference this time around is the business community's close coordination with the Clinton Administration's point man on the I.M.F. financing, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, has also influenced many lawmakers, especially some skeptical Republicans.
Despite the advantages, I.M.F. supporters still face huge hurdles. "Of all the trade issues, I.M.F. is still pretty esoteric," said Willard A. Workman, the Chamber's international vice president. "Most members of Congress don't really understand how the I.M.F. works."
In addition, Big Business can no longer count on the lock-step support of Congressional Republicans, longtime allies of corporate America and Wall Street.
A new breed of populist Republicans has emerged, particularly in the House, who are not responding to business's appeals.
"Many of these new Republicans are skeptical of many positions of U.S. business, particularly in the international arena," said Mr. Rice. "It is clearly more difficult for business interests to make their case."
Moreover, senior House Republicans, including Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, and Representative Christopher Cox of California, chairman of the House Republican Policy Committee, oppose additional financing to the I.M.F., arguing that the fund is more the problem than the solution to the economic crises overseas.
Business groups are waging a counteroffensive to educate lawmakers on the importance of the new financing. The Chamber of Commerce's web site, for example, features I.M.F. facts and figures.
Peter G. Peterson, a former Commerce Secretary who is chairman of the Council on Foreign Relations, and Maurice R. Greenberg, an insurance executive who is chairman of the Asia Society, mobilized a $400,000 newspaper ad campaign in several major daily newspapers, and recently sent an appeal to all 535 members of Congress signed by dozens of corporate chiefs and a bipartisan group of former Cabinet Secretaries.
Using Government data, the Chamber of Commerce and other groups, including the Business Roundtable, are alerting lawmakers on the amount of international business in their state or district at risk if another crisis hits and the I.M.F. is unable to respond.
In a letter sent last month, the Chamber reminded Representative Robert L. Livingston, a Louisiana Republican who heads the House Appropriations Committee, that his home state exported $2 billion in merchandise to Asia last year, a 66 percent increase over 1993.
Three dozen agriculture groups, from the American Soybean Association to the National Cattleman's Beef Association, have urged Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, to support the $18 billion financing package. He did.
"If the economic situation deteriorates and the I.M.F. is unable to respond, the loss in agricultural exports could be devastating to the domestic farm economy," the letter said.
The Chamber of Commerce is gathering anecdotal evidence of the domestic fallout from the Asian financial crisis:
Boeing expects 60 fewer aircraft deliveries to Asia. Wheat sales from Washington State to South Korea have plummeted. Sales in Southeast Asia for Amerex International Inc. of Trussville, Ala., one of the nation's largest fire-extinguishers makers, are down $610,000.
Senators credit the business lobby, along with efforts by the Administration and I.M.F. supporters like Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, for the large victory in the Senate.
"The business community is on the front lines, and I'm sure they did sway some votes," said Senator Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican who helped guide the financing to an 84-to-16 victory in the Senate.

HEADLINE: Deep Plowing Is Halted By Many to Protect Soil

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ill., April 4

 BODY:
Jim Kinsella turns a spadeful of black soil on his 640-acre corn and soybean farm, exposing a pack of wriggling earthworms that signal an abundance of organic material.
The soil breaks apart easily in his hands, and the land suffers far less than it used to from erosion. Pheasants and other wildlife flit about in the crackling corn stalks left scattered after harvest. 
 Mr. Kinsella's land is twice as rich in nutrients as it was when he first abandoned deep plowing 21 years ago. "Farmers are still infatuated with tilling, but they are kind of living in the past," Mr. Kinsella said. "The soil plays out. You can only do that for so long."
Across America, an increasing number of farmers are turning to no-till methods to stop the loss of topsoil and improve its organic content, conserve ground moisture and reduce runoff of pesticides and fertilizer into lakes, streams and rivers.
"Tillage is a disaster for the soil; it's like a hurricane coming through," said Steve Groff, who runs a no-till 135-acre vegetable farm in Lancaster County, Pa. "I'm going to leave this soil in better condition than when I found it."
In simple terms, no-till means just what it says: not plowing the ground -- or at least only minimally disturbing the topsoil -- to plant seeds. Crop residue is left on the field over the winter to improve soil quality and stop erosion, and crops are rotated annually to cut down on diseases and insect infestations that take root if the same crop is planted each year.
To be sure, thousands of farmers are still cranking up their tractors and plowing the land just as their fathers and grandfathers did.
Those traditional methods are somewhat easier and do promote faster early growth in crops, Mr. Kinsella said, because the soil warms up faster and the nutrients are exposed. And, he said, many farmers view no-till as a fad with unproven economic consequences.
"Farmers are very traditional and they're very slow to change," he said. "There is a stigma to no-till."
Yet there are some economic benefits to no-till methods.
Because farmers do not repeatedly go into the fields to plow, they can save up to 3.5 gallons of fuel an acre on a 500-acre farm, $5 an acre on machinery wear and maintenance costs, and four 60-hour weeks in labor time, according to the Conservation Technology Information Center. The center, based in West Lafayette, Ind., is a government-agribusiness partnership that promotes no-till methods.
Its latest statistics show that three common conservation tillage systems accounted for almost 110 million acres of farmland in 1997 -- or about 37 percent of the total acres planted. Conventional deep plowing with metal disks and blades was practiced on about 107 million acres, while reduced-till farming accounted for an additional 77 million acres.
Although the methods have been in use since the 1960's, there is more interest than ever now that the 1996 Freedom to Farm Act is phasing out subsidies and ending restrictions on what farmers can plant.
This is especially true in the Great Plains, where many farmers once planted only wheat and let the land lie fallow the next season. Now, they need more income from the land and are looking for new crops to put into rotation.
There are new challenges with no-till methods. There is more variability within a single field, meaning farmers must use precise amounts of fertilizer and improved seeds to have desirable yields.
New equipment must be bought and techniques learned, like leaving mounded strips of soil on fields over the winter to warm the soil when planting time comes.
"When you first start doing this, you might suffer a yield hit," Mr. Groff said. "The soil has been addicted to tillage."
But this season, Mr. Kinsella said his yields in this north-central Illinois county were above average.
"It takes better management to make it work," he said. "It takes patience."
Mr. Kinsella said reduced deep plowing could cut release of carbon dioxide from the soil to the air, helping ease global warming. And the increased carbon dioxide in the soil, he said, will help farmers grow enough food to feed the expanding world population without using more and more chemicals and fertilizers.

HEADLINE: Hunger Rising, Study Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, April 4

 BODY:
A study by Second Harvest, a national network of food banks, indicates that even as the economy booms, more people are seeking relief from hunger.
The study, based on interviews with 28,000 people visiting soup kitchens, shelters and food pantries across the country, found that 26 million Americans made onetime visits to charitable food programs during 1997 -- an increase of 15 percent on average to charitable food programs. 
 The report, "Hunger -- The Faces and Facts," was released on Friday at Senior Gleaners, a volunteer organization that distributes food to charities throughout Northern California and Nevada.
Christine Vladimiroff, the president of Second Harvest, said the healthy economy is bypassing about 20 percent of the population, many of them children and the elderly.

HEADLINE: D. C. McClelland, 80, Pioneer In Work on Human Motivation

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Dr. David C. McClelland, a psychologist who studied human motivation, job competency and the entrepreneurial spirit, died on March 27 at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 80.
For most of his 57-year teaching and research career, he enthralled Harvard University students with his unconventional, even radical, approaches to studying human personality. He was among the first scholars to offer scientific evidence that successful entrepreneurs were driven by an inordinate need to achieve. 
 Dr. McClelland's studies on motivating achievement raised many eyebrows. Instead of relying on clinical intuition to interpret fantasies and imaginative thoughts, he and his students developed scoring systems to map those thoughts. The researchers used various experiments to measure psychological characteristics, in effect quantifying those drives.
"He was one of the most creative psychologists that I have ever known," said David G. Winter, a psychology professor at the University of Michigan who had studied with Dr. McClelland at Harvard. "He was always interested in measuring things that you might call ineffable or subtle. He tried to be both B. F. Skinner and Sigmund Freud."
Dr. McClelland advanced his argument that the desire to achieve was a factor in entrepreneurship and economic growth in the 1960's. Under State Department sponsorship, he trained entrepreneurs in India, Ethiopia and other countries. In 1963, he was a co-founder of McBer, a consulting company in Boston that helps employers assess and train people to improve effectiveness.
Ten years later, Dr. McClelland wrote an influential article in The American Psychologist in which he said that commonly used I.Q. and personality hiring tests were poor predictors of applicants' performance. Companies, he argued, should hire based on competency in relevant fields, meaning that a company should hire, say, a mechanic based not on Scholastic Assessment Tests but on spatial reasoning.
His idea, competency assessment, was considered radical at the time but has become a standard tool in many corporations.
Toward the end of his career, Dr. McClelland focused more on the relationships among motivation, the quest for power and physical and emotional stress. He wrote or was co-author of several books, including "Personality" (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, 1951), "The Achieving Society" (Van Nostrand, 1961) and "Human Motivation" (Cambridge University Press, 1985).
Dr. McClelland instructed students at institutions other than Harvard, including Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., his alma mater, and Boston University, where he was a research professor of psychology from 1986 until his death.
He was born in Mount Vernon, N.Y. Dr. McClelland grew up in Illinois and lived the rest of his life in New England. He graduated from Wesleyan in 1941, and received his Ph.D. from Yale University in 1941.
Surviving are his second wife, Marian Adams McClelland, and their children, Mira, 14, and Usha, 12, as well as five children and nine grandchildren from his first marriage. The five are Catherine Dole of Morristown, N.J.; Duncan McClelland of Winchester, Mass.; Nicholas McClelland of Marblehead, Mass.; Sarah McMullen of Downey, Calif., and Jabez McClelland of Bethesda, Md.
Dr. McClelland's first wife, Mary Sharpless McClelland, died in 1980.

HEADLINE: Droves of Rich Foreigners Hit the Slopes of Colorado

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: VAIL, Colo., March 30

 BODY:
The high chiseled peaks are American Rockies, the resort architecture is neo-Tyrolean, but in a few days the language of the lift lines will be Mexican Spanish.
"During Semana Santa you will hear so much Spanish in the streets, you will think you are in Mexico City," Elena Campa said today, forecasting a large Easter invasion of wealthy skiers from Mexico and points south. 
 A pioneer in this emerging Latin skiing market, Ms. Campa publishes Andando por Vail, a brochure that advertises in Spanish everything from furs to ski boots. The number of pages of her Vail guide quickly tripled, and she recently started Andando brochures for other Colorado resorts, including one brochure in Portuguese for Brazilians who flock to Aspen.
Colorado, long the nation's most popular skiing state, is rapidly becoming a sort of Cancun with snow. In three winters, the number of foreign skiers at Colorado resorts has increased to 9 percent of the total last year from 6 percent.
This season at Aspen, the Rockies' most cosmopolitan resort, nearly one quarter of all lift tickets have been sold to foreigners. More British skiers are expected to ski in North America, largely in Colorado, than in Switzerland.
"Someone who lives in the U.K. has to fly to a resort anyhow," said Kristen Kopplin, marketing director for Copper Mountain Resort. "And, unlike the Alps, we have guaranteed snow."
At nearby Breckenridge, newsstands stock London tabloids and magazines in the winter. Every Dec. 31, the Breckenridge Hilton has a New Year's party at 5 P.M. -- timed to coincide with festivities in Britain.
The British attachment to Colorado has grown so strong that in June, British Airways will begin direct daily service between London and Denver. Next year, Lufthansa is expected to begin direct flights between Frankfurt and Denver.
The desire to integrate Colorado into the world skiing economy is driven by the search for profitable growth. "Where the domestic market is flat, or growing slightly, our international market is growing every year," said Jean Alexander-Gitchell, international sales director for Vail, the nation's largest skiing area.
"Eighty percent of the world's skiers live outside of the United States," said John Frew, president of Colorado Ski Country USA, an industry group. "International destination skiers represent the most important and promising target market for our resorts."
His group's research indicates that the foreign skier visiting Colorado spends $300 a day, the out-of-state American skier spends $150 a day, and the day tripper from Denver spends $49 a day.
Foreigners not only spend more, they generally stay for at least a week, while the average out-of-state visitor skis here for four days, down from a week a decade ago.
The international influence can be felt across the Colorado Rockies.
"You close your eyes, and you think you are in Brazil -- 95 percent of the conversations are in Portuguese," Alexandra Lichtenberg, a businesswoman from Rio de Janeiro, said on a recent snowy afternoon at the Club Med in Copper Mountain.
"I was renting my skis and I ran into someone I knew from Rio, then I ran into a girl I knew from Sao Paulo 25 years ago," said Ms. Lichtenberg, who came to Vail and Copper Mountain with her sister, Wendy, and their four sons.
A Latin American tradition of turning overseas trips into shopping sprees is heightened by the radical change in climate.
"We live at sea level, we don't have snow, people don't know what to wear -- so we buy it here," said Esther Loewenstein, a visitor from Sao Paulo, who was wearing a new skiing outfit.
Last winter, Marise Cipriani, a Brazilian who owns Silver Creek Resort, began including trips to Denver's largest malls -- Cherry Creek and Park Meadows -- in her package tours for Brazilian guests.
"The Brazilians kept asking to go shopping," said Ms. Cipriani, whose family owns Transbrasil, one of Brazil's largest airlines.
Foreign fortunes are heating up an already overheated vacation home market in the Colorado Rockies.
In early March, a planned complex of 108 condominiums at Copper Mountain sold out in eight hours at an average price of $308,000 a unit. "We had several big spenders who flew in from Mexico for a couple of hours to buy places," Ms. Kopplin of Copper Mountain said.
In the United States, where an estimated 70 percent of skiers use the Internet, American skiing marketers increasingly favor Web sites over printed brochures, the traditional marketing tool. Vail Resorts maintains a Web site, www.snow.com, with pages in English and six other languages.
But Internet usage in other countries trails far behind that of the United States, and skiing marketers are using traditional tools: free trips for travel writers and agents. The four areas of Vail Resorts -- Vail, Beaver Creek, Breckenridge and Keystone -- are represented by travel agencies in 39 countries, ranging from Argentina to Venezuela. Vail Resorts publishes its brochures in English, Dutch, French, German, Japanese, Portuguese and Spanish.
Determined to attract more foreign visitors, Copper Mountain maintains international toll-free reservation numbers.
"They ring directly through to us here in Colorado," Ms. Kopplin said of people making reservations from Australia, Britain, Germany, Holland, Mexico and New Zealand. "There are people on this end of the phone that speak their language."

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
Cane? Fiberglass? It's Still Fishing

BYLINE: By Nelson Bryant 

 BODY:
Norman Rockwell's 1948 calendar illustration of a barefoot lad and his eager beagle loping across a field beside an older man at the start of a fishing adventure dramatizes the changes that have taken place in recreational fishing in the United States during the past half century.
The boy is carrying a cane pole with line and bobber attached, and a worm can dangles from his waist. Rockwell, who was best known for his nostalgic Saturday Evening Post covers -- hundreds of them from 1916 to 1963 -- equipped the man with a split bamboo rod, a rudimentary bait casting reel and a wicker creel. 
 Today, the boy's cane pole would be replaced by ultralight spinning gear, his worm can would be a box of lures, and the man's rod and reel would be hanging in a collector's den, as would his creel.
It wouldn't be too far-fetched for an illustrator of a 1998 version of that scene to give both of them waders, a fly rod and a fly-fishing vest. There should be no creel. Creels are used to bring home fish for the table, a ritual that has fallen into disrepute because many species -- wild trout among them -- are in short supply. Today's youthful anglers are likely to eschew the messy business of killing and cleaning their catch and to settle for a Big Mac.
If they are trout fishermen, they know that portions of some streams are limited to catch and release, and even if there is no legal restriction against the act, growing numbers of anglers are morally opposed to killing their quarry, hence the scarcity of creels in trout country.
There are variations on this theme. The daily limit for trout or some other species might be one fish of a certain size. At present, for example, sport fishermen in my home state, Massachusetts, are limited to one striped bass a day, 28 or more inches long. This hampers food gathering. When fly-fishing for stripers, I find that, on the average, I catch and release more than 100 sub-legal bass for every one that I can keep and eat.
Despite legal or ethical restrictions against keeping one's catch, sport fishing is big business, and is the nation's third most popular participant sport, topped only by swimming and bicycling. In 1996, according to the American Sportfishing Association, the total economic impact of recreational fishing in the United States reached $108 billion, which is, says the association, a 36 percent increase over the 1991 figure.
The association's economic estimate derives from a 1996 nationwide survey, conducted by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, which included expenditures by anglers in pursuit of their sport. In New York State alone in 1996, sport fishing's total economic impact was over $3.1 billion. California led with $7.1 billion, followed by Texas with $6.3 billion.
Although the ranks of anglers remained virtually stable from 1991 to 1996 -- some 50 million, if children under 16 are included -- by 1996 they were fishing more often and spending more money. Money shelled out for fishing trips was the largest single expenditure, over 40 percent, followed closely by the cost of boats, motors and vehicles. Equipment, including rods and reels, accounted for about 14 percent.
Freshwater fishing accounts for the majority of angler expenditures in the United States. This is true even in New York State with its extensive fish-rich coastline.
The nationwide, big-money professional tournaments for freshwater black bass, sponsored by the Bass Anglers Sportsman Society, have contributed mightily to angling's popularity. Founded in 1968, B.A.S.S., which advocates catch and release, now has half a million members, and bass have become the favorite quarry of this country's anglers.
Bruce Shupp, the organization's conservation director, said more than 75 percent of its members release all the bass they catch. In the organization's tournaments, the fish are kept in live wells, weighed, and returned to the water alive.
New fishing magazines and a spate of new books -- or reprints of old ones -- have also sparked interest in sport fishing. Fly-fishing got a substantial boost from Robert Redford's film version of Norman Maclean's book, "A River Runs Through It" and from the fly-fishing schools put on by Lee and Joan Wulff, Lefty Kreh, Mel Krieger and by fly-fishing houses, including Orvis and L. L. Bean.
Although both Orvis and L. L. Bean favor catch and release, both still offer wicker creels for sale, a nod to tradition that pleases some anglers who are long in the tooth.
Americans delight in competition. The prestigious International Game Fish Association, which is the official keeper of records for freshwater and saltwater species caught on rod and reel the world over, launched a junior angler record program last year. This year it set up separate records for women who fly-fish in saltwater. The association favors catch-and-release angling, but notes that it is not possible to weigh certain fish without killing them.
Both Trout Unlimited and the Atlantic Salmon Federation espouse catch and release, but Pete Rafle, a T.U. official, noted that to some anglers catch and release "has become a religion unto itself." He added that his organization regarded the practice as one of the tools used to protect trout, with the guarding and enhancing of trout habitat being another.
It is possible to catch certain species -- in fresh water, yellow perch and bullheads would be among them -- and bring them home for supper without feeling guilty. But booted or barefooted, someone beginning his angling career today would do well to focus on the total experience, minus -- sadly, to one who was a lad in the 1930's -- the closure symbolized by the endangered creel.

A Hobbled Japan Copes With an Economic Crisis
Japan is facing an economic crisis, but seems unable to do much about it, because the Government is weak and the system is dictated by consensus. "There is no leadership," one banker said. Also, the country is paying the price of disastrous austerity measures. News analysis. 1

But it is not clear whether the old balance of power can be restored. 1
 
Fewer People Pay Nanny Tax
Four years ago, Congress simplified the requirements for reporting wages paid to nannies, maids and other servants and for paying the employer's share of Social Security, Medicare and Federal unemployment taxes. The new law also requires that people who employ household help declare the taxes due on their income tax forms -- leading to a 40 percent drop in the number of people who pay those taxes. 1
 
Suicide's Toll in South Dakota
In the last three years, Pierre, S.D., the capital of South Dakota, with a population of 13,000, has been wrenched by a series of suicides at 13 times the national rate. Of 11 people from 13 to 23 years old who died there, 8 were teen-agers. 1
 
Environmentalist Debate
The Sierra Club is in the final throes of a bitter debate over whether to call for restrictions on immigration as a way of controlling growth in the nation's population. The issue has raised sensitive questions about social justice, racial equity and political strategy for the group's generally liberal constituency. 14

The New Times Square
In less than five years, Times Square has been transformed from a lifeless area to arguably the most sought-after 13 acres of commercial property in the world. How the pieces came together with such speed after languishing for more than 15 years has as much to do with chance and perception as it does with careful urban planning and corporate muscle. 1

In New York City, where real estate is gold, the demand for playing space dwarfs the supply, making it agonizing for soccer leagues, Little League teams, cricketers and other recreational organizations to find places to play and often quite troublesome for the lucky ones who do. 31

HEADLINE: The Mayor's Reach

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
For a Mayor who takes pride in the tight control he has asserted over an economically buoyant city, they are both a political asset and a pesky distraction: New York City's 39 business improvement districts, which for more than a decade have performed a variety of municipal good works beyond the reach of City Hall.
But last week Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani informed the districts that, however commendable their work in cleaning streets, fighting crime and generally improving life, they would now have to submit to far greater city control. 
 "All activities and initiatives must be discussed with the Department of Business Services at the first opportunity and prior to their development," the city said in letters the districts began receiving on Thursday, provoking anger and confusion among business people.
Before the letters arrived, the Mayor had said on Thursday, "The fact is that most of the BID's were formed at a different time, when the city wasn't functioning as well, and when we allowed unaccountable activity all over the place."
From their inception in the 1980's, the districts have been charting unfamiliar territory at the intersection of private and public sectors. Formed by property owners who agree to pay for a variety of services and projects, the districts have been described by some urban planners as front line troops in a period of economic and social renewal.
The districts have helped make sidewalks, streets and neighborhoods cleaner, safer and more civil. And businesses admit that they have been rewarded with higher property values. Some of the larger districts have amassed hundreds of private security and sanitation workers, and invested millions of dollars in landscaping, signs and tourist services.
Would this be happening under tight government control?
"If you layer them over with bureaucracy it defeats the purpose," Emanuel Tobier, an economist and urban planner at New York University, said. "The point is that the BID's can do things better than the government, and if they weren't doing them, the city would still be a mess."
Executives involved with the districts said they were mystified by the Mayor's motives. Although all insisted on anonymity, the chairman of one large Manhattan district said the new rules might reflect the Mayor's fear that the districts' power will continue to grow. He said the Mayor might have begun to think that the districts are becoming too influential in municipal affairs, much as has happened with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which Mr. Giuliani has repeatedly criticized as unaccountable to the city.
Other officials speculated that the Mayor might simply be imposing his own mark, in a effort to claim control and credit, as they say he has done with the Police Department and the Board of Education.
Even within city government, critics of the districts said the new rules would be difficult to enforce without interfering with their affairs.
"We do have to avoid trying to micromanage their affairs," said Herbert E. Berman, the chairman of the City Council Finance Committee. But he added, "The BID's can't work in a closed environment in which they are the only ones that know what is going on."
The districts are formed when a majority of commercial property owners in a neighborhood agree to participate and pay annual assessments. Then, all property owners -- even those who are opposed -- become members and are assessed.
Although the system generates the income to support its projects, it relies on the city to collect the money and return the proceeds to the districts' directors.
Each district is required to sign a five-year contract with the city that spells out what projects and services it plans, and four city representatives are appointed to each district's board. They include designees of the Department of Business Services, the Comptroller, the Borough President and the City Council. The city's representatives are far outnumbered by others on the districts' boards, which in some cases include more than 40 people.
"Obviously, since we are under contract with the city, they are entitled to a lot of oversight," said Michael A. Weiss, director of the Metrotech Business Improvement District in downtown Brooklyn and president of a managers' association representing all of the city's 39 districts.
Mr. Weiss said there appeared to be little legal recourse to fight the new policy. "The city probably has a lot of leeway in this," he said.
Still, the Mayor's motives for his edict remained unclear, particularly because he has repeatedly cited the districts as symbols of the city's renaissance. Instead of taking issue with the broad precepts of governance, several officials said privately, he may have been prompted by a series of irritants arising from some of the districts.
There was the City Council study, released in November by Mr. Berman's committee, that found that property owners in several of the districts felt they were being left out of their board's decisions on expenditures.
There was a Federal Court ruling in March that the Grand Central Partnership and the 34th Street Partnership, two of the largest districts, had illegally used homeless people as sanitation and security workers at below the minimum wage.
Advisers to the Mayor said his anger has also been provoked by a plan by the Times Square Business Improvement District to spend $1 million to restore the interior of a closed theater as a tourist information center on Seventh Avenue between 46th Street and 47th Street. After a series of missteps and disjointed negotiations, the district's plan, when it was announced in early February, did not include space for a booth that would be controlled by the city.
In an interview, Randy Levine, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, said the Mayor had been annoyed because the Times Square district had at first asked the city to pay rent to use such a booth. (All others who are to be represented in the tourist center, including the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and a theater owners' group, will pay rent.)
Meanwhile, since the plan for the center was announced, officials of the Times Square district said permits that they had expected to receive swiftly from the city's Landmarks Commission have been delayed, without explanation. (Officials of the Landmarks Commission did not respond to repeated requests last week for information on the status of the permits.)
Now, with their project delayed, and left to reflect on the potential effect of the city's new oversight rules, executives in the Times Square district said they were eager to appease the mayor.
Robert M. Kaufman, the district's chairman, said the city's initial request for free space had been denied "because, legally, we are not supposed to be subsidizing the city." But in recent weeks, he said, the district has written to the Mayor, offering free space, but has received no response.
Now, Mr. Kaufman said, the district has been granted a meeting with the Mayor on Tuesday and plans to present its offer in person. "It still stands," he said. "The city can have our best booth at no charge."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
The D.H. Is 25 Years Old, but Now the Question Is Whether It Will Get to 30

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
With the elimination of the designated hitter from his team, Milwaukee's Cal Eldred faced Greg Maddux on opening day last week and lined a single to right-center field.
"I think it was a fastball," Eldred, the Brewers' starting pitcher, said of the pitch from Maddux. "That tells you how much I know about what I'm doing up there." 
 The way Bobby Bonilla tells it, he did not know a whole lot more about what he was doing at bat when he was the Baltimore Orioles' designated hitter two years ago, a circumstance that was overcome with controversy.
"The trouble is, I told the truth," Bonilla said. "I was asked about being the d.h. I said I didn't like it. I didn't say I wouldn't do it. But I figured after hitting .190 for two months, it wasn't for me."
The designated hitter, now 25 years old, has always been a source of debate, and now it threatens to engender ever-nastier controversy. The owners' labor representatives, following a procedure provided for in the collective bargaining agreement, have sent the union a notice they feel would allow them to change the designated hitter rule unilaterally next year (the union disputes that position) if the owners want to eliminate the position and the players balk.
Donald Fehr, the head of the union, has reacted harshly to what he perceives as a threat and a signal that the owners are willing to shatter the labor peace that has existed since the end of the 1994-95 strike. But the owners, management people say, have made no decision among themselves about the future of the d.h.
"We have nothing in particular in mind right now," said Bud Selig, the acting commissioner. "There is no reason to force any decision on the d.h."
Last summer the owners proposed that the designated hitter be phased out over three to five years. As a quid pro quo, they offered to add a 26th spot to team rosters. The players rejected the proposal.
"At that point we were talking about a rather significant amount of realignment," Selig said. "I guess I would call that the event in history, the force that would say we need to have one set of playing rules. At least for the time being, we don't need to do that."
Selig said he believed at the time there would have been enough votes in the American League to kill the designated hitter. But he added: "That was based on a lot of contingencies, and now all of those contingencies are gone. There is no specific proposal right now to force the American League to consider elimination of the d.h. We'll see what happens in the next two, three years."
Renewed discussion about realignment could trigger renewed consideration, but Selig, speaking vaguely, said, "I think you'll find any future debate on the d.h. will be tied to something else, and what that something else is isn't clear right now."
What will not happen, Selig said confidently, is the acceptance of the designated hitter by the National League. "It became clear in the realignment discussion," he said, "that the National League clubs were unalterably opposed to the designated hitter. They are inflexible. If anybody thinks ultimately the National League will go to the d.h., they're living in a fairy land. That's not going to happen."
Bonilla, for one, is delighted that the N.L. does not have the designated hitter. "You have to learn how to do it," the Florida Marlins' third baseman said. Then he praised such designated hitters as Harold Baines of Baltimore, Paul Molitor of Minnesota, Edgar Martinez of Seattle and Chili Davis of the Yankees.
"Bainesy said it took him two, three years," Bonilla said. "Molitor said he pretty much had to do it because of his arm. Edgar Martinez, if he picked up his glove he got hurt. They wouldn't let him pick up a glove anymore. Chili in New York -- a tremendous pickup."
The designated hitter, Bonilla added, is "a very sensitive subject with me because I like to see the guys playing, but I enjoy playing the whole game."
 
Great Power, Great Hitter
 Mark McGwire's sizzling start for St. Louis has figure fanatics agog. Based on his pace in the Cardinals' first four games, they can say, McGwire will hit 162 home runs. Sound silly? Of course. But it is just as silly to project what a player will do for an entire season based on 20 or 40 or 60 games.
Phil Garner, on the other hand, offered a meaningful assessment of McGwire's development as a hitter.
"Four or five years ago, he was a good power hitter but without a good swing," the Milwaukee manager said. "He had a big loop in his swing, and you could pitch to him. But in the last couple years, he has developed a good swing. He doesn't have that loop anymore. He's a .300 hitter. Add to that the power, and he's a devastating hitter."
 
Nothing but the Truth
 After Hideki Irabu had defeated the Detroit Tigers in his major league debut last July, the Detroit players were generally complimentary about his performance. Brian Hunter, however, presented a contrary assessment. Irabu was nothing special, Hunter said of the Yankees' heralded rookie; wait until he pitches against a more veteran team whose hitters would be smarter than the Tigers.
Sure enough, five days later, the wily Indians roughed up Irabu and deflated the balloon of hype and hope that the Yankees had created for Irabu. The development came as no surprise to Hunter.
"I just tell the truth," Hunter said eight months later when asked about his candid remarks. "Everybody was kind of comparing him to Roger Clemens and all these great pitchers, and it's unfair to do that to him."
Hunter said everyone else on his team thought as he did, but nobody wanted to say it. "They were saying the same thing I was," the center fielder said. "It just came out different. They know big words. I don't know a lot of big words. I wasn't trying to hurt anyone's feelings. The media there had some fun with it. They said I called him a bust. I didn't call him a bust. I said in time he may be one of the great pitchers, but it's not fair to compare him to great pitchers now."
 
Turn Two? Not Against Biggio
 Last year, Craig Biggio, the Houston Astros' outstanding second baseman, became only the third player in major league history to go through an entire season playing a minimum of 150 games without grounding into a double play. Playing in all 162 games, he joined Dick McAuliffe of Detroit (1968) and Augie Galan of the Chicago Cubs (1935).
Biggio recalled one instance in particular in which he thought he would be out at first. "I had to thank Tim Bogar," he said. "He went in real hard to second and wiped the guy out, and he airmailed the ball to first."
Reflecting on his rare feat, Biggio added: "You don't really think about it, but when the season is over, you do and say, 'Wow.' You're going to hit into one or two or three no matter who you are, no matter how fast you are. You have to have luck on your side to go through a season without hitting into one."
Luck evidently abandoned Biggio this year. He grounded into a double play in his second time at bat in the Astros' opener against San Francisco.
If luck had been by his side again, the wicked one-hopper that Biggio hit to third base would have gone a few inches to Bill Mueller's right. But the ball sped directly at Mueller, who fielded it on his knees, then got up and threw to second to force Brad Ausmus.
Unlike Bogar last year, Ausmus did not have a chance to take out second baseman Jeff Kent, whose throw to J.T. Snow easily got Biggio.
 
Crowns and Crowds
 Before their game with Milwaukee today, the Florida Marlins will present World Series championship rings to their players. The ceremony will take half the time it normally might take because half of the players are gone.
In shredding their World Series team, the Marlins forfeited the economic boost that baseball history shows comes from a championship. The economic benefits for a team come not necessarily in the championship season, but in the following year. Of the 10 previous World Series champions, eight experienced an increase in attendance the next season.
Of those eight, four set team attendance records the season after: the Toronto Blue Jays in 1993, the Oakland Athletics in 1990, the Minnesota Twins in 1988 and the Mets in 1987. The Blue Jays drew more than four million fans, the Twins and the Mets exceeded three million, and the A's reached what was for them an astronomical total, 2.9 million.
The two teams that did not have higher attendances, the 1991 Cincinnati Reds and the 1989 Los Angeles Dodgers, dropped off by mere thousands, the Reds by 28,000 and the Dodgers by 36,000. The Marlins are expected to draw closer to their 1996 attendance of 1,746,767 than the 1997 total of 2,364,387.

HEADLINE: U.S. Auditing Five Hospitals In New York

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Five teaching hospitals in New York City and Long Island are being investigated by the Federal Government to determine whether they submitted fraudulent Medicare bills for tens of millions of dollars.
The audits are part of a nationwide effort to determine whether hospitals overbill the Government for treatment by highly paid senior doctors when the care is actually given by doctors in training. The Government is also looking into whether doctors and hospitals charge Medicare for more complex -- and expensive -- treatment than they actually provide. 
 The Government first put the nation's 1,200 teaching hospitals on notice that it planned to vigorously pursue such overpayments three years ago, when it announced that the University of Pennsylvania's health system, while admitting no wrongdoing, had agreed to pay $30 million to settle complaints that it had improperly billed Medicare for doctors' services. Since then, three other hospitals have paid a total of $37.6 million to settle similar charges.
But this latest round of audits is the first to involve hospitals in New York State, which has the greatest concentration of medical schools and teaching hospitals in the nation and trains about 15 percent of the nation's medical residents. Of the 105 teaching hospitals in the state, 77 are in the New York City metropolitan area.
If the Government examines the records of all of them and seeks reimbursements and penalties in line with those announced in other states, hospitals in New York might have to pay collective penalties of several hundred million dollars, health care economists said .
Hospitals and trade organizations around the country have denounced the audits, asserting that hospitals submitted bills in good faith and that the Government is retroactively applying standards that were only recently clarified by the Health Care Financing Administration, which is the Department of Health and Human Services agency that administers the multibillion-dollar Medicare program for the elderly and disabled.
The audits cover the period from July 1, 1995, to June 30, 1996. Guidelines that made the existing regulations more understandable were announced in December 1995 and took effect on July 1, 1996.
But Federal officials and several health care economists said most hospitals were well aware of the standards and merely took advantage of lax enforcement.
"People get comfortable with what they are doing and forget to follow the regulations," said Michael Mangano, principal deputy inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services. "The first line of defense of anyone who gets confronted by an audit is to say the rules were vague. And then when we show them the rules were spelled out clearly, they turn and say, 'But you never enforced them.' Well, we're calling people on it now. Taxpayers have a right not to pay for what they don't get."
Mr. Mangano did not have an estimate of the costs related to this type of Medicare fraud.
Mr. Mangano would not confirm that any New York hospitals are being audited, and would say only that 40 audits are under way across the country. But hospital officials in New York said the state hospitals facing audits are Mount Sinai Medical Center and Beth Israel Medical Center, both in Manhattan; Long Island Jewish Medical Center in Queens; University Hospital of Brooklyn of the State University of New York Health Science Center (commonly known as Downstate), and University Hospital of SUNY at Stony Brook, on Long Island. Officials at the hospitals under review declined to comment on the record for fear of antagonizing the auditors.
Investigators and hospital industry analysts said the inquiries conducted so far have not only revealed abusive financial practices in some of the nation's teaching hospitals, but have also highlighted how often novice doctors treat patients without proper guidance and supervision.
Time and again, investigators said, the records at teaching hospitals have shown that senior doctors responsible for training new physicians leave diagnosis and treatment in their inexperienced hands -- then review the decisions by reading patients' charts and cosigning the entries. Those senior doctors then charge the Government as if they had played a bigger role, Government officials said.
In doing so, officials say, they are billing the Government twice for the same service. The officials explained that under what is known as Part A, Medicare already pays a share of the residents' salaries and many of the indirect costs connected with graduate medical education.
Senior doctors may charge for patient care, under what is known as Medicare Part B, when they deliver it themselves or provide direct supervision of a resident's work beyond the tutorials that go on during rounds. In both cases their participation must be properly documented.
But before July 1996, hospital officials say, regulations spelling out how much oversight and hands-on participation a senior physician needed to give before billing the Government, and how to document that involvement properly, were vaguely worded. Moreover, the officials say, the rules were inconsistently publicized and applied by the dozens of intermediary carriers across the country that handle Medicare billing.
In preparing hospitals for their audits, the health department's Inspector General provides copies of documents that the Government says show whether the local carrier gave clear billing directives.
In the current audits, the Government has decided not to investigate hospitals whose carriers gave unclear directions or guidelines that conflicted with Federal policy.
The main carrier for the New York metropolitan region is Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. New York hospital officials contend that much of the material the Inspector General provided to them was isolated paragraphs and pages from a newsletter dealing with Empire's main line of insurance business, a publication they say providers were never told to regard as the official source for Medicare billing information. They point out that the newsletters were filled with seasonal pictures of Santa Claus and pumpkins and tidbits about Empire employees.
They contrasted the directives from Empire with more formal and explicit ones distributed by carriers in other states.
"We have hospitals that underwent periodic audits, had their charts reviewed and their billings approved, and they don't conform to the new standards," said Susan Waltman, senior vice president and general counsel of the Greater New York Hospital Association, an industry group. "How can the Government now turn around and say we should have known that our practices were wrong? Our practices were cleared by the carrier."
The biggest concern for hospitals is whether a senior doctor's cosignature alongside a chart entry written by a resident for work basically carried out by the resident is sufficient proof that a senior doctor supervised the work and is entitled to payment.
The clarified regulations clearly state that the underlying note must mention the senior doctor's involvement or the senior doctor must write a detailed addendum. Hospitals say that in the past, Empire and other carriers routinely accepted a cosignature alone as sufficient. But Government officials say many of their audits have shown that doctors were out of the hospital, even out of the state, when the treatment was rendered, then cosigned the charts at a later date and billed for the work.
Hospital officials also complained that the audit process itself is coercive. The Inspector General offers hospitals two audit options: Have the Government pay for auditors or be viewed as cooperative and hire an outside auditor acceptable to the Inspector General. If hospitals pick the first option and the auditors find false claims, the hospitals are liable for costs up to triple the loss to Medicare plus up to $10,000 per billing, because the investigations come under the Civil False Claims Act. If they pick the second option, they risk only double penalties.
"It's a classic Hobson's choice," said a senior-level employee at Mount Sinai who would speak only on the condition of anonymity. "And it's distressing that the Government goes into this viewing every error in billing as fraud."
The Greater New York Hospital Association, along with Beth Israel, Mount Sinai and New York University Medical Center, plan to file a lawsuit challenging the audit process in New York, contending that there was no clear guidance from Empire regarding the level of senior physician presence and the type of documents required before billing.
A similar suit challenging the overall fairness of the audit process was filed last fall in a Federal District Court in California, with arguments to be heard this month.
Government officials discounted the hospitals' arguments. They said their best proof that the rules were clear is that two hospitals -- Yale-New Haven and Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, N.H. -- went through audits, were found to have acceptable error rates and did not have to pay either reimbursements or penalties.
Uwe Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University, said audits like these are an efficient way for the Government to hold down fraud. "For every one place they hit, 10 other places are trembling in their boots and cleaning up their act," Dr. Reinhardt said. "It's like cops on a highway. They can't go after every speeder, but knowing that the one they go after could be you keeps people more honest."

HEADLINE: Peril of Politics in Japan

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 4

 BODY:
As the world's second-largest economy lurches to a standstill, possibly threatening to cause a global slowdown, paradoxically the fundamental reasons are not economic.
Instead, they are political. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is a weak leader governing with a fragile coalition of parties and factions that seldom agree with each other, so the Government finds it difficult to shift economic directions even as it becomes clear that the Japanese ship of state is heading toward an iceberg. And the Japanese system is based on consensus, which has always made decision-making here difficult in a crisis. 
 "The Hashimoto administration is in a terrible situation," said Makoto Sataka, a writer on economic issues. It is flying a plane, he said, and the "destination of such a plane is a crash."
On Friday President Clinton renewed his pressure on Mr. Hashimoto, calling on Japan to "take a bold course" and stimulate its economy. But the problem in a sense is that there is no counterpart to Mr. Clinton here. Tokyo is a hydra, with each head looking the other way and blaming the next.
"There is wealth here in Japan, there are diligent people here in Japan, there is obedient labor in Japan," said Ryuji Konishi, former managing director at the Long-Term Credit Bank, one of Japan's largest financial institutions. "However, there is no leadership."
Yet, equally paradoxically, the problem is not simply a lack of decisiveness. A year ago, the leaders in Mr. Hashimoto's Government were unusually decisive -- in pushing through a tax increase, cutting public spending and suspending tax breaks. But all that helped steer Japan toward its present economic disaster.
Having established that policy direction a year ago, Mr. Hashimoto's Government is finding it extremely difficult to be decisive once again and to switch course. So now Japan is paying the price for those fiscal austerity measures, and for seven years of delays in confronting the country's economic troubles. A result is that consumers' willingness to spend has fallen to its lowest level in nearly three decades, unemployment has soared to a 45-year high, unsold products are piling up in warehouses and wages and industrial production and corporate profits are all sliding.
Many economists say Japan is now headed for its first major recession in a quarter-century. Such a downturn, they say, could prompt Japanese companies to cut back or abandon operations in the United States and elsewhere, or to sell some of the country's $800 billion in net assets abroad. It would also threaten prospects for a recovery in the Asian financial crisis.
Asian countries dependent on exports desperately need buyers for their goods, and so far the United States has filled that role. But Japan, the world's largest creditor nation, with an economy twice as big as the rest of Asia combined, has so far been unable to absorb many additional products from countries like Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and South Korea. Because its own economy is so weak, it cannot be Asia's buyer of last resort.
The United States -- along with many private Japanese economists -- is urging two strategies to revive the Japanese economy and avert a dangerous downturn. The first is a huge fiscal stimulus, some combination of deficit spending and tax cuts. The second is far-reaching economic deregulation.
The Government has made some headway in both, but not much.
Prime Minister Hashimoto has been reluctant to pursue the fiscal stimulus, because until a few months ago he was hailing as a major triumph his opposite strategy: fiscal austerity measures intended to put the Government on a sounder financial footing. During the last few months, under strong American pressure, he has agreed to take some degree of stimulus measures, but it is not clear how much.
"We will boldly do what we have to do," Mr. Hashimoto told Japanese reporters on Friday.
In fact, some Western economists say the Government has a reasonable position in its concern for fiscal deficits. The aging of the Japanese population is projected to lead to huge spending in the coming decades, and that makes it all the more important to cut deficit spending now -- and Japan has a huge budget deficit already.
Yet the general verdict is that while the Government has a legitimate concern, it has been obsessed with the issue. These days, many say, the risk of a recession is so severe that some greater fiscal stimulus is essential, even at the risk of worsening the Government's accounts.
"The Government should borrow," said Shijuro Ogata, a former deputy governor at the Bank of Japan. "We have enormous savings. The Government should not worry about borrowing, for the sake of the country, for the sake of Asia and for the sake of the world."
Yet the Government has another practical reason for delay. The fiscal stimulus will come in a supplemental budget that can only be drawn up after the regular budget is approved later this month. So under the rules of the political game here, Mr. Hashimoto cannot really begin talking about the details of a fiscal stimulus for a few more weeks.
The other approach to stimulating the economy -- deregulation -- will be difficult because most of the proposed efforts at deregulation are opposed by key interest groups and cannot simply be pushed through Parliament by a weak leader like Mr. Hashimoto.
On Wednesday Japan did introduce a wide-ranging financial deregulation package called the Big Bang, for which many have high hopes. But just a day earlier, the Government reverted to a traditional tactic of propping up stock prices with public money to help support banks that rely on stocks to boost their capital base at the end of each fiscal quarter.
A broader problem is that Japan has been so used to the idea of Government direction of the economy that few leaders seem to have a vision of the direction that most of the industrialized world is headed.
"I don't think they fully understand what the market means," said Shigenori Okazaki, a political analyst at SBC Warburg Dillon Read in Tokyo. "They lack a fundamental understanding of a market economy. They are more worried about farmers losing jobs in construction work. To me, it's a simple mismatch of the system."
To be sure, Japanese leaders have taken some important measures in recent months: a $15 billion tax cut, a $222 billion bank bailout, a $120 billion package of economic stimulants. "Japan is starting to take correct action," said Richard Koo, chief economist at the Nomura Research Institute. "Public spending always works."
But some economists say the problem is that Japan's leaders waited too long. The tax cut put $15 billion into the pockets of Japanese consumers in February, but the effects were negligible. So economists worry that a bigger tax cut may not give as big a boost to the economy as is hoped.
The $222 billion in public funds for the banks has helped increase the capital base of the banks and thereby brought some stability, but there is still a credit squeeze because banks remain reluctant to lend in a time of rising corporate bankruptcies.
The $120 billion package is currently being drafted, but economists say they fear that much of the package will be in the form of Government loans that will replace bank lending, rather than actual money that will stimulate the economy.
Japan's economic troubles began when the speculative bubble burst in the early 1990's. Since then, Japan has been battling a banking crisis caused by a plunge in the property market that led to bad and doubtful debt of more than $600 billion, an amount larger than the size of the entire Chinese economy.
Then last fall, four financial institutions collapsed, leading to a sharp financial crisis, and corporate bankruptcies are now soaring. With economies in Asia shrinking, and therefore the appetite for Japanese exports declining, Japan's economy is suffering its worse crisis in decades.
"The real fact is that there is no magic bullet, and they have a very complex economic adjustment going on," said Jesper Koll, economist at J. P. Morgan Securities Asia Ltd. about the Japanese leaders. "We are in a period of crazy ad hoc-ism."

HEADLINE: DISMISSAL OF SUIT PUTS CLINTON BACK ON CENTER STAGE

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
For two years, President Clinton and the Republicans were locked in an uneasy embrace that allowed them to enact a number of major initiatives like the balanced budget agreement while containing their mutual hostility.
But the eruption 10 weeks ago of accusations regarding Mr. Clinton and a former White House intern upset that delicate balance, as the White House devoted much of its private and public energies to dealing with the potentially fatal accusations and as the Republicans awaited, mostly in silence, the outcome of the investigation. 
 This week, a Federal judge's surprising dismissal of Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit against the President promised to change the political calculus once again. But it was not clear at week's end that the old Clinton-Congress relationship could be restored to anything resembling the balance of power that existed in the age of relative innocence before anyone had heard of Monica S. Lewinsky.
With Congress gone for a two-week Easter recess and the Paula Jones debacle quieted, at least for now, the President is preparing to change the subject and reclaim the public stage. Mr. Clinton will try to appeal to a scandal-sated electorate with a new series of policy proposals built on the foundation laid in January in his State of the Union address, which has been largely drowned out in recent months by the Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones matters.
Less than 12 hours after returning from a 12-day trip to Africa, Mr. Clinton was before the cameras in the White House Rose Garden on Friday to criticize Republicans for their $1.73 trillion budget plan that ignores many of his priorities, to press for a tobacco bill and to raise questions about Tokyo's management of the Japanese economy.
The President is planning a full week of domestic policy pronouncements: Monday on crime, Tuesday on Social Security, Wednesday on education standards, Thursday on tobacco, Friday on school safety. He is using the breathing room that a Federal district judge, Susan Webber Wright, gave him by dismissing Ms. Jones's lawsuit to bring pressure on Congress to begin to deal with his priorities for this year.
At the White House, aides see an opening for the President to recover some lost ground.
"We're going to try to show a picture of the President busy at work on important issues and try to pull the media into covering the President busy at work," said a senior White House aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
This official said the Jones decision should be taken by Republicans in Congress as a sign that it is time to resume cooperating with the White House on issues -- like tobacco -- where compromise is possible and the political benefits are substantial and bipartisan.
But this aide said: "There has always been a wing of their party that believed that pushing scandals as an issue was a political strategy for them. There's not much evidence that it's right; and now there is a lot of evidence that it's wrong."
Frank Luntz, a Republican consultant, agreed. He said Republicans should focus on the handful of items they agreed on internally -- tax overhaul, restructuring of the Internal Revenue Service and an emphasis on private savings accounts as a solution to the looming Social Security shortfall -- and use them to draw distinctions with the President's agenda. Beating up on the President on the issue of morality will only anger the public and cost Republicans votes in the midterm elections in November, Mr. Luntz said.
"Some Republicans keep waiting for the other shoe to drop on Clinton," Mr. Luntz added. "It never happened. Bill Clinton is a survivor. In a tornado, he'll be in the eye; it's a way of life for him. Some Republicans still just don't accept that."
White House aides insisted that Mr. Clinton never stopped attending to what he calls "the job the American people hired me to do," even as the newspapers and airwaves were soaked in humiliating accounts of his encounters with various women over the past 20 years and political coverage was devoted to examining a "Presidency in crisis."
"We've done a good job of continuing to do our stuff in the wake of this barrage," the senior White House aide said. "What has changed is that maybe now we'll be able to be better heard."
Until Mr. Clinton's well-received trip to Africa, the President's substantive exploits were relegated to small corners of inside newspaper pages and short items in the evening news broadcasts.
The White House policy shop has continued to produce briefing papers and policy proposals, under strict orders from Erskine B. Bowles, the chief of staff, to stick to business as usual. But the White House political apparatus, which in ordinary times would be pushing policy and public relations initiatives, has been consumed with monitoring the scandal and trying to contain its fallout.
As public attention focused on Mr. Clinton and his legal difficulties, the President and Speaker Newt Gingrich quietly carried on discussions aimed at finding common ground, particularly on Social Security and tobacco legislation.
Mr. Gingrich, in an interview late this week, said the President had not been personally engaged in recent debates on Capitol Hill on campaign finance, transportation issues and the budget. Nor does he expect Mr. Clinton to become visibly involved with Republicans on the Congressional agenda in the coming months.
"I don't think there's much up here to engage him," Mr. Gingrich said. "Remember, last year we only engaged on a handful of very big things. I think this year we'll eventually engage on a handful of very big things."
He singled out Social Security, on which both he and Mr. Clinton are committed to fundamental change, although their approaches are at odds. Mr. Clinton advocates reserving any budget surplus until the retirement system is put on firm financial footing while Republicans propose partial privatization.
"We both believe we should deal with Social Security," Mr. Gingrich said. "We both believe that our generation should solve it now before we're older because it gets a lot more painful if you wait very long. So that's huge."
For now, the issues related to Mr. Clinton's private life have moved from the critical list to the chronic care ward as the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, continues his investigation of the President's personal and public conduct over the past two decades. But that investigation still poses a substantial threat to the President -- and a challenge to Republicans.
"Starr and his report still hang over all of Washington's political players," said Stuart Rothenberg, publisher of a political newsletter here. "The President because he doesn't know what's in it, the Republicans in Congress because they don't know how to deal with it."
But in this climate, Mr. Clinton has at least a momentary advantage, Mr. Rothenberg said, because he has a clear agenda for the year while the Republicans are united on only one proposition -- that he is a cad.
"He comes back from Africa more focused, while the Republicans are merely trying to stagger through to November," Mr. Rothenberg said. "The Republicans are on the defensive, trying to explain why they brushed off campaign finance reform, trying to figure out what to do about tobacco. Their whole focus is to avoid screwing up and to avoid a debilitating internal battle."
Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, essentially dismissed the possibility of impeachment arising from Mr. Starr's various investigations. Mr. Specter, a former district attorney in Philadelphia, said this week that Congress would probably not even consider an impeachment inquiry unless it was presented with "an open-and-shut case" that would lead to the President's resignation, as in the case of President Richard M. Nixon.
Mr. Specter said Judge Wright's decision to dismiss the Jones lawsuit had changed the political climate in Washington, even though the judge did not rule on whether Mr. Clinton had made a "boorish" sexual overture to Ms. Jones.
"It changes the political atmospherics because Judge Wright's opinion will be widely read as to say that Ms. Jones should not have bothered the President to start with or should not have brought the lawsuit," Mr. Specter said. "The political atmospherics have changed in the President's favor."
