HEADLINE: In Little City Safe From Violence, Rash of Suicides Leaves Scars

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK

DATELINE: PIERRE, S.D.

 BODY:
Sometime on the afternoon of Dec. 2, after he grabbed lunch with a school buddy, rode around town in a pickup truck and bought Christmas presents with his pocket money, 15-year-old Kenny White shredded the secrets of his short life when he gripped his father's pistol and shot himself in the head.
"I really don't know what to say in these dam things, but I want you to know that I love you mom and dad," Kenny had scribbled on notebook paper found in the bedroom next to his slumped frame. "I'm not in English class so my spelling doesn't have to be perfict." 
 He asked his mother to quit smoking and his parents, separated for 10 years, to remarry. "Take good care of my cat, Smokey Jr.," he wrote. "Also, I'm putting my will in this letter." He said his baseball cards should go to Steve, "my bee-bee gun collection" to Ricky, "my Minnesota Twins jersey" to Steven, adding: "It also needs to be washed. It's in my back pack."
It was the cipher of a child, giving no real inkling of what could drive someone so young to suicide. But to the people of Pierre, the most frightening thing was that they had seen it too often before.
In the last three years, Pierre -- the capital of South Dakota, though a city of only 13,000 people -- has been wrenched by a series of suicides, most of them young people. Eleven people from 13 to 23 years old, including 8 teen-agers, have killed themselves, about 13 times the national rate of 13 per 100,000 population per year.
The suicides have begun to haunt Pierre (pronounced PEER), which sits on a skinny elbow of the Missouri River and has one high school, one hospital and one shopping mall.
In the treeless center of this corn-stubbled state, in the gullet of the Great Plains, Pierre is such a safe place that the police captain rarely locks his house, and he cannot remember the last time someone so much as stole a car.
In January, when a 21-year-old man killed his 19-year-old former girlfriend and then himself, it was the city's first murder in nine years.
"People just don't kill each other around here," said Velda Bartel, whose son John, 19, committed suicide the summer before last. "They kill themselves instead."
Now, after the death of Kenny White, who had shown few signs of severe distress, and a State Health Department report on the extraordinary suicide rate, people in Pierre have begun an impassioned effort to stop the suicides. For many, this meant swallowing their ambivalence, hurt and pride to seek advice from around the country, as they realized how ill-equipped the city had been to cope with such trauma.
"We're the capital city, but we've been just brutalized with all of this," said Ellen Lee, executive director of St. Mary's Foundation, a health education organization, and head of Pierre's new Suicide Prevention Committee of parents, students, teachers, clergy members, health professionals and law-enforcement officers. "We have to do something."
Strings of suicides have struck other areas, including Westchester County in New York, Bergenfield, N.J., Plano, Tex., and last year, South Boston. In some places, including on some Indian reservations, the suicides seem to have root causes or common threads, like socio-economic despair or heavy alcohol use. But in many places, like Pierre, the causes have less clarity.
"Why do you have a suicide in one community and nothing else happens, and why do you have another community where one suicide follows another?" said Dr. Madelyn S. Gould, an epidemiologist and associate professor of public health at Columbia University, who is studying 49 suicide clusters around the country from 1988 to 1995. "We haven't found any striking pattern. We've seen it in affluent areas and poor areas, in rural communities and urban communities."
Pierre's suicide rate is "clearly exorbitant," said Dr. Gould, who was recently contacted by the South Dakota Health Department. "In such a small population that's a very significant increase."
More critically, Pierre had little in the way of professional services to handle such a situation.
 
Emotional Strain In an Isolated City
Although government jobs and politics draw people to its regal black Capitol dome, Pierre remains remarkably isolated, ringed by a vast, grassy moonscape and bracketed by the Bad River and whistles of water with names like No Heart Creek, Whisky Gulch and Tall Prairie Chicken Creek. The Interstate is 35 miles of two-lane hardtop away, the closest big city (Rapid City, population about 55,000) is three hours away and only small planes fly here.
There is no psychiatrist, only periodic visits from those in Rapid City or Sioux Falls, 225 miles east, which also have the nearest centers for treating youths under emotional stress. And until recently, when suicidal people called 911 for help, they were not taken to a hospital, but sent to a jail cell, until they could be evaluated by a mental health expert.
"It's a really terrible deal to take someone who's depressed and put them in jail," said Sheriff Mike Leidholt, who has pressed for a hospital "safe room" where suicidal people can be treated. The city is working to create such a room. At least one depressed teen-ager who was put in jail subsequently hung himself, and the prospect of jail makes teen-agers reluctant to seek help for themselves or troubled friends.
For families, navigating each suicide's aftermath has been especially difficult. When Michelle Cox, 18, stayed home from church one Sunday and killed herself with her father's shotgun, her parents, Kenneth and Katherine, both 58, appreciated the sympathy of friends but still felt emotionally stranded.
"A lot of people in town knew Michelle had problems," said Mrs. Cox, a nurse, "but a lot of people, you know, don't like to ask, and you don't stand on the corner on your soap box all day either." She and her husband, an engineer for the state transportation department, found no support group in Pierre, and waited 18 months for a spot in a suicide survivors' group in Rapid City.
"You get to a point where you want to stay in bed and cover up your head and not want to deal with anything and not have any feelings," Mrs. Cox said, her eyes wet, as she sat in her living room. "It's a terrible way for a child to leave you."
After John Bartel locked the door of his basement bedroom, cranked up the music and shot himself in the chest, "for about six months I prayed that I would die," said his mother, Velda, 42, who works for a guardianship agency. She and her husband, John, sent their two daughters, Kelsey, 15, and Katie, 12, to a therapist, but did not seek treatment themselves until last fall, when Kelsey overdosed on Tylenol P.M. trying to end her own life.
Kenny White's sister, Lori, a year younger but in the same grade, was so upset over her brother's suicide that her grades plummeted and her behavior suffered. Kenny's friend, Ted Voigt, makes pilgrimages to Kenny's grave, even taking his date there before the high school's King of Hearts Dance.
"I sit and talk to him, get things off my chest," said Ted, a gangly 16-year-old.
 
Risk Factors Unclear in Pierre
"You get to this point, you want to try to figure out what you can blame," said the Rev. Charlie Wharton, the police chaplain. "Believe me, I've looked."
No one seems to know why this is happening in Pierre, where many "risk factors" that experts tie to suicide are not apparent. Middle class, with no great pockets of wealth or poverty, it has good graduation rates from solid schools and large numbers of educated, working parents. It is quiet, but residents say there are things to do, like fishing, water skiing and going to movies. Teen-age drug and alcohol use seems no greater, and high school cliques no crueler, than in similar cities.
The teen-agers who killed themselves came from diverse family, economic and academic circumstances and the suicides, each a few months apart, appeared to be unrelated. Michelle Cox had been in therapy, but most others had not. Two boys, a handsome 16-year-old football star and a 13-year-old with artistic talent, had alcohol habits, teachers and friends said. John Bartel had a learning disability that led to feelings of failure, his parents said.
Dr. Gould said research elsewhere had shown later suicides often had only peripheral relationships to earlier ones and seemed to involve less severe psychological problems.
Strikingly, John Bartel, Michelle Cox and Kenny White each told family members or friends after the early suicides that they could never kill themselves because it would hurt those left behind.
There are strands of stress in the city's fabric. With nearly half the work force employed by the state, some families have been unsettled by government layoffs. Since state employees often transfer here from other areas, many residents have shallow roots in Pierre and few relatives close by. And in the middle of a half-plains, half-mountain state, Pierre seems unsure if it is more "Mayberry" or "Old West," Mr. Wharton said.
"It's a very transient town," Mrs. Bartel said. "It's a political town. It's got all the makings for things that can be disruptive."
Guns, the most common suicide weapon, are rife in its hunting culture, where children, allowed to drive at 14, often handle firearms earlier. Police scanners are as popular as television sets.
"Stuff doesn't happen here that people don't know about," Mr. Wharton said.
Suicide, jarringly, is in the vernacular here now. Students in school readily told a visitor about their own suicidal feelings and pointed out siblings of students who killed themselves. A pet-sitter in town spoke of her helplessness and guilt when a client's son committed suicide two weeks after the sitter noticed he seemed unhappy.
Still, for a long time, Pierre has been torn over how to handle the suicides. Newspaper obituaries of the suicides used the euphemism "died at home."
At Riggs High School, some parents believed open discussion would romanticize suicide or plant the option in students' heads. Others "wanted us to do all these assemblies," said Gary Schneider, a guidance counselor.
Then, after assemblies about suicide, said the principal, LeRoy Fugitt, "we get bombarded with people saying enough is enough."
 
Coming Together In School and City
By January, Allyson Friez, 18, became so concerned that she successfully ran for student vice president promising not "let's have parties, let's have dances," but "let's get help."
Others in Pierre felt the same. The Suicide Prevention Committee began meeting at Pierre's Chamber of Commerce. It has already hooked Pierre to a suicide telephone line at a Sioux Falls hospital, pasting its number on posters and a billboard and distributing "yellow ribbon cards" containing a message the bearer can use to ask for help.
Suicide intervention classes are available for all residents, adults are volunteering to be mentors to teen-agers, student drama groups are taping public service announcements for radio and television, and Ms. Friez, who recently became Miss Teen South Dakota, brought a speaker to the city to talk about self-esteem.
The school is monitoring students closely for "even a casual reference about not being able to go on," said the superintendent, Ken Rasmussen.
All this is heartening, if painful, parents say.
"It's just awesome how the community just pulled together," said Terri White, Kenny's mother, whose family inadvertently galvanized the town when, to dispel any "gasping behind your back" about "what's wrong in that home," they began talking about Kenny's death and wearing sweatshirts with his photograph.
"You never think it will happen to you," said Rick White, who moved from the apartment where his son died, but is in an identical one a few doors down, blaming himself for not taking the pistol he uses as a private investigator with him that one awful day. "So many whys and ifs."

HEADLINE: DESPITE AN EASING OF RULES, MILLIONS EVADE 'NANNY TAX'

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Four years ago, after President Clinton withdrew Zoe Baird's nomination to become Attorney General because she had not paid taxes on her children's nanny, Congress simplified the requirements for reporting wages paid to nannies, maids and other servants and for paying the employer's share of Social Security, Medicare and Federal unemployment taxes.
The new law also added a line to the 1040 individual income-tax form -- line 52 -- asking for the amount of Social Security and Medicare taxes owed on wages paid to household help. Because the form is signed under penalty of perjury, people who employ household help must choose between declaring the taxes due and lying to the Government. 
 The response was immediate, if not exactly what Congress had in mind: The number of people paying the tax on household help fell 40 percent, from nearly 500,000 in 1994 to just below 300,000 in 1995, the year the new law took effect, and 314,000 in 1996, and the Internal Revenue Service expects little change for 1997.
Based on I.R.S. estimates that as many as four million people owe nanny taxes each year, that means that fewer than 1 in 13 are obeying the law, compared with 1 in 8 under the old, more cumbersome reporting system. And some people have even figured out how to combine a legal tax break for child care with tax evasion, in essence double-dipping the system.
Of course, the main reason for the cheating is probably that it is so easy to get away with: Of the millions who have flouted the new law, only two have been charged with wrongdoing.
"My accountant told me I have to stop this and issue paycheck stubs and report what I pay to the I.R.S.," said Elaine, a divorced 42-year-old mother of two who covers Hollywood for a magazine and asked that her last name not be used. "But since no President is ever going to nominate me for the Cabinet, what do I care about paying this stupid nanny tax? And if I get caught, I'll just pay the fine and go on doing what I am doing."
The spread of noncompliance among such people raises troubling questions for some about whether the foundation of the tax-collection system in the United States -- the assumption of honesty by filers -- is crumbling.
"A culture is being created that this is fair game to do," said Jay A. Soled, a Rutgers University tax expert who has studied tax cheating by people who consider themselves honest. Political attacks on the current tax system as unfair only encourage people to cheat on the ground that "this is our way of evening the playing field," he said, adding, "This is a dangerous game."
Dangerous or not, Elaine is probably right not to fear the wrath of the tax collector. There is no national nanny-tax enforcement effort because of a lack of staff, said Tom Burger, the I.R.S. official in charge of employment taxes. Indeed, the service has never pressed a civil case in court and has filed criminal charges only twice, both times as part of a more serious criminal prosecution.
The law requires anyone who pays a nanny or other servant more than $1,100 this year to report those wages to the I.R.S. Assuming that only one in 13 is doing so -- and that the tax evaders spend as much on household help as the upright citizens do -- the Federal Government is losing $1.2 billion a year in Social Security and Medicare taxes.
To be sure, some people question whether the problem is as serious as the I.R.S. contends. Michael Graetz, a Yale Law School professor and former Bush Administration tax official, said he thought the agency's estimate was inflated. And he says fewer people may be reporting because their accountants advised them that they were exempt from nanny taxes because their maid or gardener was arguably an independent contractor, not an employee.
For those who know they are cheating, the motive is often not only to save money but also to avoid paperwork and the inevitable exasperation that comes with dealing with the tax bureaucracy.
"The truth is that Government has not made it easier to comply," said Roger L. Conner, executive director of the American Alliance for Rights and Responsibilities, a Washington nonprofit group that urges people to become more involved in their local communities. "Congress made it easier on the Federal level, but you also have to pay state taxes and pay state unemployment taxes, and if you live in one state and your nanny in another, then you are forced to master the arcana of Social Security and Federal unemployment taxes plus two state unemployment and tax systems."
James Neff, a journalism professor at Ohio State University who writes books on crime, said he discovered how frustrating complying with state requirements could be after he used three nannies last summer. Together they made slightly more than $1,500, the threshold for paying quarterly state unemployment taxes, and Mr. Neff discovered that he had to cope with complex state tax forms designed for corporations, not individuals.
Worse, even though Mr. Neff only used nannies in the summer, the state required him to file every quarter and report zero as the amount due for the other three seasons.
In interviews, parents in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, California, Virginia and the District of Columbia reported similar difficulties dealing with state tax forms designed for corporations rather than individuals. One of their greatest frustrations was navigating through bureaucracies that they said were unresponsive or, worse, behaved as if their efforts to comply were a nuisance.
Mr. Neff and others who pay the taxes say they do so not only out of moral duty but also because they or their spouses hold jobs that require scrupulous compliance with all laws. Mr. Neff's wife is a Federal prosecutor; Mr. Conner's organization preaches self-reliance and individual responsibility for the welfare of communities.
Many Americans legally avoid the nanny tax by sending children to day-care centers or by hiring maid services or lawn-care companies rather than paying individuals directly. Also, maids who bring their own tools and cleaning solutions are arguably independent contractors, not employees, and thus might be exempt from the nanny tax.
Even if an employer wants to go by the book, household servants -- many of whom are immigrants or welfare recipients, or juggling more than one job -- often accept money only under the table.
In Central Park in New York, a nanny who was taking her charge to a playground and who identified herself only as Elena said her weekly pay included a $100 check and $260 in cash. The check allows her employers to take advantage of a tax break known as a flexible spending account in which $5,000 is deducted from their paychecks and then reimbursed when they produce canceled checks and a Social Security number for their nanny. The I.R.S. does not routinely match these payments with tax returns, however.
Thus, they benefit twice, saving as much as $1,980 through a legal deduction and almost $1,400 more by evading their share of the nanny's Social Security and Medicare taxes.
Michael Josephson, founder of Character Counts in Marina del Rey, Calif., which promotes ethical behavior by youngsters, said he did not even know the nanny tax existed until the Zoe Baird hearings. He said he then felt compelled to pay five years of back nanny taxes, penalties and interest.
Mr. Josephson said he thought the Government should either enforce the nanny tax or repeal it. "Congress needs to be thinking about this law that makes honest people feel like fools," he said.
There is no move in Congress to overhaul the system at the moment, and tax specialists say they see no easy solution. But, they say, some of the more promising ideas being kicked around include making all household servants independent contractors, responsible for their own taxes; raising the threshold to $5,000 or higher from $1,100, then making a greater effort at enforcement and imposing a surtax somewhere else, perhaps a fraction of a penny on each gallon of gasoline, to cover the lost Social Security and Medicare taxes.
Failure to pay the nanny tax can boomerang in the long run, for both parties involved. Social Security benefits are now based solely on reported wages, so household servants who never report their income can face poverty in old age unless they plan to return to countries where their needs will be met in other ways.
They might also make life difficult for their former employers by reporting the income years later in an effort to get more Social Security money.
Mr. Josephson recommended making nanny-tax compliance an issue in audits of all higher-income people because "almost everyone over a certain income, especially when both of the couple work, has a maid, a nanny or both."
Turning a blind eye to the problem, he added, is the worst possible way to deal with it. "When the Government encourages systematic lying, it undermines the whole notion of voluntary compliance" on which the tax system rests, he said. "It has an incredibly corrosive effect on people voluntarily complying with all tax laws."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Cone Keeps Insisting He Knows His Limits

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif.

 BODY:
THE meter was running on David Cone. Tick. Tick. Tick. He has been hearing the voices -- including his manager and pitching coach -- telling him he now has 100 pitches, 110 tops, in any given game.
Fast approaching that agreed-upon limit, Cone was struggling in the sixth inning yesterday. His 99th pitch became a grand slam by Scott Spiezio that put the Yankees, if not Cone himself, in a certifiable slump. 
 The Yankees lost this one, 7-3, to Oakland, which means they have lost all three games this season and that the molten ash from Mount St. Steinbrenner will soon be settling on the Yankees if they don't do something quick.
After suffering from an aneurysm in 1996 and shoulder surgery last fall, Cone has decided that trying to strike out every batter may have been dangerous to his health.
"The days of 150 pitches and nine innings are over," he said Friday night. "I'm going to have to squeeze as much as I can out of 100 pitches. If I want to pitch nine innings, I'm going to have to economize."
"We'll just tap him on the shoulder," Joe Torre, the manager, was saying.
Cone started off economically yesterday, giving up no hits for two innings, and single hits in the third and fourth innings. Then the pitch total started to rise as old Rickey Henderson slapped a two-run single in the fifth. The the A's loaded the bases in the sixth with Spiezio, a .247 hitter with a bit of power, coming up.
Mel Stottlemyre, the pitching coach, visited the mound and talked to Cone. Managers and coaches praise a star pitcher who tells the truth about what he has left. The only thing they value more is the starter who absolutely loathes coming out.
"We'll ask him and he'll say, 'I can get this guy out,' " Torre said. "He'll never say, 'I'm done.' "
Stottlemyre's presence was already a tipoff that Cone did not even have to argue. He was pitching to Spiezio. The 99th pitch hit a concrete abutment above the 362-foot sign in right-center.
"Sidearm slider to Rickey, cutter to Spiezio right over the plate, two awful pitches," Cone said afterward. "I felt good but I let the game get away."
Torre insisted that Cone had not looked tired as his pitch count ticked upwards through the 90's.
"Bad location but good stuff," the manager said. "Mel was checking him out, just giving our bullpen a chance to get going, but you want to give a David Cone a chance to lose his own game. You don't want somebody else to lose it for you."
The words don't sound positive, but the thinking behind it makes sense. Cone has earned the right to decide his own games, although it conflicted with the pitch-total conversations of previous days. Cone does not want to put pressure on himself by pitching until his arm falls off. That may be how he hurt the shoulder originally.
Cone wrecked his shoulder in 1995 by willing himself deep into the fifth playoff game in that classic series with Seattle before ultimately walking Doug Strange for the tying run. After the Yankees lost, he went home with a dead arm and an empty feeling of having let his team down. The physical problems that he and the Mariners' Randy Johnson had in 1996 can certainly be traced directly to their extra heroics in 1995.
Even in these highly technical days, with computer printouts on everything, managers and pitching coaches of Cone and Johnson were willing to ignore the pitch quotas set for just about everybody else.
"He's always been a gamer, a team player, who's not going to let his team down," said Torre, who wasn't there in 1995. "That's his mind set."
It was also the Yankees' mind set. Torre cited the 1996 World Series, after Cone had suffered an aneurysm during the season but somehow came back. The Yankees lost the first two games at home but were still encouraged when they went to Atlanta, "just knowing he's going to pitch," Torre said.
Last year Torre and Stottlemyre kept Cone under 120 pitches in every start but one. Cone finished third in the league in strikeouts with 222, but he also missed a month after feeling twinges in the shoulder in early August.
"If I had managed it better, I wouldn't have missed six weeks," he said the other night. "I probably pushed too hard. I've always been stubborn."
This year, he said, "I'm trying to put a little margin between pain and injury." He was out with tendinitis from Aug. 18 to Sept. 20, and when he came back, he was not right. In his first playoff game against Cleveland, he lasted only three and a third innings and two weeks later had arthroscopic surgery.
Torre said Cone reported "in better shape this spring than in the first two years I had him," because Cone worked out in the off season, rather than resting his arm.
The manager had hoped Cone could lead the Yanks out of this early miasma. Cone undoubtedly has more heroics in his future, but for the moment, the little voices are telling him, "Don't be a hero."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "He's always been a gamer," Joe Torre says of David Cone. (Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Tugboat Pilots Strike, Seeking Increase in Pay

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, April 4

 BODY:
Angry tugboat pilots pushing cargo-carrying barges pulled off to the side of the Mississippi River today and walked off the job in a dispute over pay.
The United States Coast Guard said an estimated 600 barges were stopped along the river, which is the nation's primary inland waterway. 
 "They're pulling off to the side and they're telling the barge companies to send a relief pilot if they want the barge moved," said Petty Officer Paul Painter of the Coast Guard.
The strike began after a loosely organized group called Pilots Agree tried unsuccessfully to meet with transport companies for salary talks. When the companies failed to send representatives, the pilots, meeting in Memphis, voted to walk off the job.
The group is thought to include about one-third of the nation's 3,000 tugboat pilots.
A Pilots Agree leader, Dicky Mathes, said he had begun organizing the group several months ago. He said the pay for tugboat pilots, who make an average of $50,000 annually, should be doubled.
The Coast Guard said in a statement that it would not interfere as river traffic was not obstructed.
The river barges, which are also used in the Intracoastal Waterway that spans most of the Gulf Coast, haul grain, petroleum products, chemicals and steel.
An extensive and long-lasting strike could have widespread effects on the nation's economy, officials at the Port of New Orleans said.
"Give it a day or two, this might fade," said Al Warriner, owner of the Pearl River Navigation Company. "If it does take hold it could be devastating."

HEADLINE: '97 Middle-Class Tax Relief Benefits Wealthy First

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Last August, with Speaker Newt Gingrich at his side, President Clinton signed the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997, praising it as a milestone that focused most of its benefits on the middle class through a $500 child tax credit, education tax breaks and the new Roth individual retirement accounts.
But as 174 million Americans struggle to file their 1997 income tax returns before April 15, only 1 in 17 poor and middle-class taxpayers will enjoy any tax relief because the benefits aimed at the middle class did not begin to take effect until this year. 
 Only one tax break became effective last year, a reduction of capital gains rates on the sale of stocks, art and other assets that have increased in value and are owned primarily by the affluent.
The cut in the capital gains rate means that the wealthiest 1 percent of taxpayers will enjoy $1,189 of tax benefits in 1997 for each dollar of tax relief enjoyed by the bottom 80 percent of Americans -- the 97.6 million tax-paying households that earned less than $59,000 last year, according to a new analysis of Government data by Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal nonprofit organization in Washington that believes that the tax system favors the affluent.
The Treasury Department did not dispute these figures. "Our numbers are similar," said Dan Israel, a Treasury Department spokesman.
And Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas and the chief tax writer in Congress, said that the group's "raw data is generally accurate."
However, Mr. Fleischer called the organization "a liberal group funded by unions" that had made "a tortured analysis" of tax benefits. He said that to realize the tax benefits, the rich would have to pay more in total tax dollars. And both Mr. Fleischer and Ginny Flynn, the spokeswoman for Senator William V. Roth, the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, emphasized that beginning this year the middle class would receive the bulk of the 1997 law's tax cuts.
The different views of the law's effects stem from how each side wants taxes examined. To the Republicans, a cut in the tax rate is an increase in taxes because they expect the affluent to cash in so many assets that their total tax bills will actually rise.
But Citizens for Tax Justice wants to focus on effective tax rates -- that is, on the share of income that goes to the Government. For 1997 such rates are virtually unchanged for everyone making less than $200,000, according to the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation. In the case of people making $50,000 to $75,000 a year, the effective rate is 20.3 percent, the same as a year earlier. But the top income group, those making $200,000 or more, will have their effective Federal income-tax rate cut from 30.2 percent to 28.3 percent.
The analysis by Citizens for Tax Justice found that the top 1 percent, who averaged $666,000 of income last year, saved an average of $7,315 in 1997 because the rates were cut. The bottom 80 percent, those making $59,000 or less, saved an average of $6.
This is not the way the Republicans want to focus the debate. They want to concentrate on how many tax dollars are paid. By that measure, those making $10,000 to $30,000 in 1997 are expected to pay a smidgen more than in 1996, about $23 million extra, because of minor changes in the tax code.
Those making more than $200,000 are expected to pay $5.6 billion more because the joint committee assumes that these people will cash in more of their assets to take advantage in the reduction of the top rate on capital gains to 20 percent from 28 percent.
So both sides may be correct: The wealthy get bigger tax benefits because capital gains rates were cut, and if they sell more assets to increase their incomes they will pay more in taxes.
For 1998 the distribution of tax benefits changes as the child credit, expanded retirement savings and cuts in the Earned Income Credit for the working poor start to take effect. The joint committee estimates total tax relief in the new law at $22 billion for this year, saying all of the benefit will go to those making less than $200,000 this year. The joint committee treats the lower capital gains tax rates as a tax increase and estimates that the rich will pay $1 billion in additional taxes this year because of the changes in the law.
Margot Thorning of the American Council for Capital Formation, an advocate of lower capital gains rates who maintains that they spur investment and economic growth, said the proper focus on the effect of the 1997 law was on the child credit and other tax relief aimed at the middle class.
But Representative Bob Matsui, Democrat of California who was one of only 43 members of Congress to oppose the bill even though he favors capital gains cuts aimed at job creation, said, "This bill was cleverly sold as being a middle-class tax cut, but as the real numbers come out it is clear that the benefits will go disproportionately to the wealthy."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 6, 1998, Monday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: Disney Wished Upon Times Sq. And Rescued a Stalled Dream

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI and RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
On a breezy summer day in 1993, a top Disney executive picked his way along 42d Street with a video camera, the viewfinder filling with images of the crumbling theaters and shuttered storefronts slung between Eighth Avenue and Broadway. It was not a vision he wanted to take back to California, where his bosses were weighing a radical idea: lending Disney's wholesome name to a street that had become a byword for urban decay and failed renewal plans.
"It wasn't so much that it was scary," recalled the executive, David L. Malmuth, then vice president of Disney's development company. "It was dead. It was this odd street in the center of the city where there was almost no life." 
 Only five years later, a relative blink of the eye in the world of New York City development, that 42d Street is a dim memory. Times Square is a swirl of theaters, theme restaurants, tourist buses and construction cranes. It has become arguably the most sought-after 13 acres of commercial property in the world. And the sale this week of rights to the last two office tower sites along Seventh Avenue means that the final pieces of a grandiose four-tower plan -- long at the heart of the renewal and long presumed unworkable -- are in place.
How the pieces came together with such speed after languishing for more than 15 years -- spanning two economic downturns and the administrations of three governors and three mayors -- is a story that has as much to do with chance and perception as it does with careful urban planning and corporate muscle.
Almost in spite of the mountains of blueprints and contracts, the emerging Times Square is a mix of the pure confection of the earliest plans (one discarded plan included a 15-story indoor Ferris wheel) and the button-down vision of the 1980's, when developers wanted to make the area into an office park resembling Rockefeller Center.
And the hundreds of millions of corporate and entertainment dollars flowing into Times Square have come in large part, many developers say, because of a comparatively trifling amount pledged by a single company, Walt Disney. In late 1993, the company agreed to put up just $8 million of its own money -- less than the bonus earned last year by its chairman, Michael D. Eisner -- toward the renovation of the New Amsterdam Theater.
But that commitment, which city and state officials jumped through hoops to secure, was a catalyst more powerful than anyone expected. It opened the floodgates just as a confluence of other forces -- the reviving economy, the return of retailers to inner cities and the rise of entertainment and communications giants -- readily supplied the flood.
"What made it possible," said Richard A. Kahan, the former president of the state's Urban Development Corporation, "was Disney and the basic change none of us could have anticipated in American urban retailing, technology and the communications industry."
"It's what people dreamed of: very high energy, people-oriented entertainment," he added. "It reverts back to what it once was in New York City history."
Seven years earlier, at what was perhaps the project's lowest point, few people believed that it could happen. The dream of reclaiming Times Square had already been around for more than a decade and had produced little more than sweeping announcements, false starts and 47 lawsuits.
The list of potential developers whose plans had been shelved was a Who's Who of real estate: Trammell Crow, the swaggering Dallas builder; Cadillac Fairview and Olympia & York, the now-bankrupt Canadian giants; Tishman Speyer, an owner of Rockefeller Center, and Helmsley Properties.
By 1991 the project was at a dead stop. The state had used its power to condemn and acquire property along 42d Street, but the developers who had been selected by city and state officials as the best hope -- George Klein, an heir to the Barton's kosher chocolates fortune, and the Prudential Insurance Company of America -- said they did not want to build. There were layoffs at most major companies in the city. Office vacancy rates were soaring.
By the next year, the project had fallen so far off the screen that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo failed even to mention Times Square in his State of the State Message among the projects intended to jump-start the economy.
But while the recession was responsible for stalling the renewal, another problem preceded it and would continue to plague the project: deeply conflicting visions of the future shape of Times Square.
Under the master plan approved in the early 1980's that had framed thinking for a decade, Mr. Klein and Prudential were to build four granite office towers at the intersection of 42d Street, Broadway and Seventh Avenue that would give Times Square a toned-down image far removed from the neon and pop culture that had made the area famous.
In exchange for enormous tax breaks, Mr. Klein and Prudential were also to pay for a $127 million renovation of the subway station and the restoration of nine theaters.
"There was a common theme for these four regal towers," said Brian J. Strum, the former chief executive of the Prudential real estate group. "The buildings made Times Square respectable."
But in 1991, Prudential surveyed the weakness of the economy and demanded a 10-year hiatus from the commitment to build the towers, hinting that it would pull out of the project if it was forced to build in the middle of a recession.
Vincent Tese, then the State Commissioner of Economic Development, and Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Corporation, saw an opportunity in the impasse: redefine the project by emphasizing Times Square's historic connection to entertainment and retailing. It was a decision that could have mired the project further. It turned out to be almost prophetic.
"Times Square had been about entertainment since 1893, when the first theater was built on 42d Street," said Ms. Robertson, now the director of real estate for the Shubert theater organization. "The office market had died in the 1990's, but retail was doing great. We had the Broadway theaters. There were 16 million people a year -- the same number of people that went to Disney World -- going through Times Square. All the elements of what became known as urban entertainment were here."
They were certainly hard to find among the cracked sidewalks, vacant buildings and flashy neon peep shows that lined 42d Street. But after a series of tense meetings between developers and officials in 1991 and 1992, the state agreed to delay the towers for up to a decade, so long as the developers agreed to attract bright, dazzling stores to the vacant buildings on 42d Street and provide $20 million to restore the theaters. As a concession to the developer, the state dropped the demand for an important public benefit: the subway renovation.
Mr. Klein and Prudential fiercely but unsuccessfully opposed parts of what became known as the interim plan for Times Square, which required them to concentrate on retail and entertainment businesses and to install spectacular neon signs. Mr. Klein feared that the return of a honky-tonk atmosphere would repel the kind of corporate interests he wanted to attract.
"There were some heated moments," Mr. Strum said. "We were still convinced that this was an office market for financial corporations. If you had this glitzy retail, with all the signage, the tenant would say, 'What do I need this for?' "
But even as the city wallowed in the recession, there were signs that this kind of retailing, which had fled the cities for suburbs and malls in the 1960's and 70's, was returning, and with it, the idea of urban theme parks.
Andrew Tansley, executive director of the Tussauds Group, had been scouring Times Square for much of the early 1990's for a site for a New York outpost of Madame Tussaud's wax museum in London.
"The saddest thing was to see all the tourists going to Times Square because of its international reputation," Mr. Tansley recalled. "But there was nothing there except for sex shops."
But it was the emergence of Disney that would serve as what one city official described as the "bell cow" to lead other reluctant companies into Times Square.
Despite its friendly image, Disney was a relentless negotiator, unwilling to lend its imprimatur to such a risky venture without numerous assurances and steep public subsidies. City and state officials resisted weakly. "The policy was simple," Mr. Cuomo said. "The policy was: get Disney's name." Disney eventually agreed to put up the $8 million to renovate the New Amsterdam Theater, while city and state officials agreed to provide more than $30 million in low-interest loans.
"By Disney standards, it was a small deal," Mr. Malmuth conceded. But he added that the company was putting something greater than money on the line. "It was the brand risk," he said. "We were terrified that we would go forward and there would be some unspeakably horrible act on 42d Street."
Ultimately, they decided that the potential profit from a theater in a tourist-rich Times Square was worth the risk.
Even as the project seemed to be coming back together, there were many moments when it threatened to fall apart. Both Governor Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins, whose term expired at the end of 1993, were desperate to conclude a deal with Disney before a new administration at City Hall created uncertainty in the company's mind.
They were so desperate that on Dec. 30, 1991, Barry Sullivan, the city's Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, signed a memorandum of understanding with Disney atop the metal detector near the doors of City Hall as he left the building for the last time. The papers were rushed the next day to Mr. Malmuth in Burbank, Calif., for his signature.
City and state officials deftly seized on the momentum generated by Disney to generate even more. The 42d Street Development Corporation hired a public relations firm and began leaking to the media details of negotiations with Warner Brothers, MTV and dozens of other companies that came hunting for space.
Meanwhile, the Giuliani administration, and later Gov. George E. Pataki, wrestled over the final terms of a deal with Disney, which was not interested in being the only pioneer on 42d Street. In a move that served to intensify the cleanup and development, Disney demanded that the state evict the remaining peep shows from 42d Street and sign deals with Madame Tussaud's and the AMC Theaters chain before it made a final commitment.
Officials negotiated those agreements only hours before a news conference announcing the final deal with Disney.
With Disney signed, the city and the state rapidly struck an agreement with the developer Bruce Ratner to build an entertainment complex on the south side of 42d Street that would include Madame Tussaud's museum and a 25-screen theater. On the north side of 42d Street near Eighth Avenue, Tishman Speyer was selected to build a luxury hotel and entertainment complex.
Even with the momentum generated by the Disney deal, city officials have continued to dole out tax breaks. Last November, Reuters, the British information services company, got a $26 million tax break to build a headquarters on a parcel at 42d Street and Seventh Avenue that already had tens of millions of dollars of tax breaks. And the city is negotiating with Mr. Ratner for subsidies for a hotel that was never part of the redevelopment project, even as Planet Hollywood is building a 50-story hotel five blocks away without any tax breaks.
Rather than leading the revival of Times Square, the plan to anchor the square with four massive office towers resurfaced only after many of the other pieces were in place. Douglas Durst, the developer whose family once opposed the state's redevelopment of Times Square because it would compete with their nearby office towers, was the first to move in. Mr. Durst bought control of a site from Prudential for a 48-story tower that will be home to Conde Nast Publications.
It was an especially bitter moment for Prudential's partner, Mr. Klein, who privately blamed Mr. Durst for 45 of the 47 lawsuits that had delayed the project in the 1980's.
In short order, Prudential sold a second site to a joint venture of the Rudin real estate family and Reuters.
And finally, last week, Prudential reached a tentative agreement to sell control of the remaining two tower sites along Seventh Avenue to a joint venture that includes Mr. Klein.
When the deal was announced, Mr. Klein -- whose long struggle to redevelop Times Square had become a potent symbol of its difficulties -- said his vision for the area had been "vindicated." But the neon-infused retailers and the brash entertainment executives who will soon roam the streets and office corridors of Times Square bear little resemblance to what he originally planned.
Eighteen years ago, Edward I. Koch, the Mayor who originally selected Mr. Klein to clean up Times Square, warned: "New York cannot and should not become Disneyland -- that's for Florida. We've got to make sure we have seltzer instead of orange juice."
In the end, Times Square got both.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 70; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3299 words

HEADLINE: An Uneasy Alliance

BYLINE: By Lucinda Franks; Lucinda Franks, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, writes frequently about children. Her last article for The Times Magazine, "Little Big People," about parents and children, appeared in October 1993.

 BODY:
There were so many layers of satin to the white christening dress that Rose could hardly find the baby inside. If only this little burden would always stay so light, she thought as she found herself standing at the baptismal bowl, the only white woman in an evangelical church in Brooklyn, about to become the godmother of her nanny's illegitimate child.
It was a bit more than she had bargained for six years ago when she hired Jacqueline to care for her children, organize their schedules, buy and cook the meals, keep her house clean and generally make the life of her family possible. Jacqueline -- who is identified by her middle name to protect her privacy, as are all the other characters in this story -- had broken the news of her pregnancy seven months before. She had dragged the vacuum cleaner halfway up the stairs, sat down and begun to cry. Rose, a psychotherapist, had never seen her like that. Normally stalwart, Jacqueline had brought structure, discipline and neatness to the household. As she consoled her nanny, Rose saw her own tightly woven existence unraveling. She could not have been more undone had her husband announced he was leaving. Without Jacqueline, she could not manage. 
 As water was dripped onto the baby's head, the congregation murmured, Oh yes, Lord, and Rose's daughter, Tecla, age 6 at the time, gazed wide-eyed at a woman swaying and bowing behind her. Rose worried that Tecla would ask loudly what was wrong with the woman, a worry that reflected her deeper fear of what the future might hold for a white woman with a black godchild. Yet as she beheld the chocolate-colored face, and the faces of her own family -- Tecla, her husband, Ira, and son, Louis -- sitting in the pew, she also felt the exhilaration of having ascended a mountain.
Across the economic spectrum, child care in America is generally inadequate. Even if mothers have finally started to win acceptance in the workplace, their children often still pay a heavy price. The poorest mothers rely on friends or relatives, sometimes barely out of childhood themselves. In urban areas, some middle-class women hire immigrant labor, often illegal and inexperienced. These nannies work 10 to 16 hours a day, 5 or 6 days a week, living with their employers in cramped apartments as closely as roommates.
Green cards, which enable aliens to work legally, can take years to obtain. Until they get theirs, immigrant women remain trapped in legal limbo without health insurance, social benefits or job security. Parents, for their part, turn over the most precious part of their lives to a stranger whom they have known for little more than the hour it takes for a job interview. For Rose and Jacqueline, as for thousands of others, it is an intimate and unlikely cross-cultural alliance, often just the other side of the law, textured with deception and affection, mistrust and trust.
Jacqueline, 34, grew up in the flat farmlands of a Caribbean island. She set up house in a one-room apartment with her common-law husband, a fireman, and had two children. But when her daughter was 7 and her son was 2, she became restless. Her aunt, who had emigrated, told her that in America you could live in a real house and still send home enough goods and money to lift your kids out of poverty.
I kept saying, should I do it, or should I not, Jacqueline says. It was so hard to leave. My son was very attached; he slept with us, he breast-fed until he was 18 months. Finally, I just closed my eyes and said this is the only chance my kids will have, and I left them with their father.
She went to New Jersey and worked for two years for an elderly invalid. Meanwhile, in Manhattan, Rose was coping with the newborn, Tecla, Louis had attention-deficit disorder and the family had begun renovating their Upper East Side town house. Rose stopped working and looked for more stable help than the au pairs she had been using. I needed someone to be me when I wasn't there, Rose says. My walls were half down and I was a wreck. Jacqueline had a quiet confidence; she came in and she knew just what to do.
Jacqueline had never lived with a white family before, and it felt strange. They made big meals with so many different kinds of food, and the children, not the adults, were like the high point of everything.
About half the nannies she knew were unhappy, stuck in situations they likened to a 1990's form of slavery: white parents who delegate all responsibility for rearing their children to an overworked, often illegal immigrant. They treat their help like she's not human, Jacqueline says. They make her come at 7 A.M. to get the kids up and ready for school so they can sleep late, and then they work all day and go out at night. One woman out in the Hamptons, you always see her carrying two separate bags of groceries. She had to buy her own food, even though she cooked for the family. They even had a lock on the icebox."
Jacqueline quickly found that she was one of the lucky ones. Rose and Ira treated me with respect. We did things together. They had nice friends, not the type that are way up there and you're down here and they pass you by like you're furniture. She was able to send home $100 a month and still afford to telephone her kids regularly. She tacked up pictures of them in the smart new American clothes she had sent. She grew attached to Tecla and Louis, and particularly liked shooting baskets with Louis.
Rose opened up the world of America to Jacqueline. She sent her to driver's education, taught her to stand up for her rights against the bureaucracy in the torturous process of getting a green card and set up bank accounts for her, giving her two checks a week, one to put in savings. She paid her doctor's bills, went to her aunt's wedding, got her cousin a nanny's job two doors away and ended up going over to help whenever the cousin, who was inexperienced with children, called in tears. When the father of Jacqueline's two children came to visit, Rose let him stay at their house in the Hamptons. Jacqueline gave in kind to Rose. She was better at some aspects of mothering than I am, Rose says. I'm a pushover. She would make them sit down at mealtime and take a bath every night. Instead of letting them sit in front of the television, she played board games with them for hours. I would tear my hair out after five minutes of those games. I watched the kids become more and more attached.
Jacqueline tried to nudge the kids toward Rose when she wanted them, for she knew how it felt to be afraid you were losing your kids. But Rose faced her own jealous feelings head on. When the kids would start to run to Jacqueline instead of me, I would just run and put myself between them. Rose's children are adopted, so their devotion to Jacqueline had particular resonance. You fret sometimes -- do they really have any special attachment to you? One day, when we were preparing to leave for my dad's birthday, Tecla whined, 'How come Jacqueline isn't coming?' and I said: 'Because you and Louis and Dad and me, we are a family and this is a family gathering. Jacqueline lives with us but she is not family.
Jacqueline's own children remained out of her reach. She was unable to travel home -- her green card application was still pending, so she could not have gotten back into the country. Nor could her children visit, because the American authorities in Caribbean countries routinely reject such visa applications.
 After a year or so, jacqueline's children stopped asking when she was coming home. Her son learned to talk, her daughter learned to read and they seemed to grow out of one set of clothes before Jacqueline could send them another. When she picked up the phone to call them, her heart would race. You know who this is? she would ask, and then heave a sigh of relief when her boy or girl said, Of course, it's you, Mommy. Small things, especially ironing Tecla's and Louis's clothes, could set her off. A pair of jeans, a little velour dress, sometimes I just held them up and thought about my kids. I kept saying, one day they'll be with me, we'll be back together."
Rose was as skillful as Jacqueline in denying the troubling aspects of her separation from her children. My fantasy about Jacqueline is that she is very much like me. She did what she was supposed to do. She had her kids and then she dared to go after something different. I just did it in reverse order. If I was stuck in some backwater and there was a world out there I wanted to be part of, I think I would leave my kids with my sister. It's not as though you lose them forever.
Rose, 51, who grew up in an extended Italian family, and Ira, 55, who is proud of his working-class roots, came to depend on Jacqueline's solid values to counteract the consumerism that saturated their children's world. "She had this folk wisdom," Rose says. "Like one time Louis came home complaining that his new shoes were not Gucci's like his friends'. She told him, 'Listen here, Louis, they are nice shoes, and it doesn't matter whether they are Gucci or Pucci or any other label."'
Ira says: "We gave Jacqueline complete authority. We told our kids, when we are not here, you listen to Jacqueline. She is the mommy."
Jacqueline plays her daughter's life like a movie in her head, picturing her traveling to and from one of the island's best high schools, which is far from her home. Jacqueline had paid for a tutor to prepare her for the school's rigorous entrance exams, and had sent her a couple hundred dollars for books and the $5 daily taxi fare. Still, she worries that none of this will make up for what her daughter, now 16, is missing. "I want her to have that mother-daughter thing. I keep saying it will happen one day, but then one day, they are almost grown up and you still haven't got them here."
Jacqueline panicked when she realized she was pregnant with her third child. "What was I going to do? Send another child away? But how could I raise it in this country? And then I remembered it wasn't my decision alone."
Jacqueline, Rose and Ira had a meeting after the children were asleep. Ira cleared his throat. Jacqueline was the caretaker of his family, and that in itself meant he must ultimately take care of her. She was his third adopted child. Now must he acquire a fourth? This could not have come at a worse time. He was changing jobs, Louis was changing schools -- the family was in flux.
Ira, a financial consultant, was a conservative who often held forth on the evils of big government and the welfare state, which he believes encourage poor single women to have children. He tried to fall back on these abstractions. Jacqueline, do you expect us to be responsible for your mistake?" he asked. "What is the father going to do?" Jacqueline shook her head: nothing. Such a question was seldom asked in her culture.
"What kind of a message is that going to send to Tecla and Louis? Being pregnant and not married. Bringing up a child without a father."
"I can take care of it," she replied.
"You can't. And I'm not going to. If I did, it would violate all my beliefs about the obligations of people to face the consequences of their own actions." Rose looked daggers at him; he did not notice that Jacqueline was quietly crying.
Such is the nature of the relationship that while the employer regularly unfurls his feelings, the nanny, by dint of culture and necessity, sits mute. "I could have said something, but I chose not to," Jacqueline says. Instead, she resolved, then and there, to have the baby and keep it, whatever the consequences. "I was very, very hurt. I'd been working there six years and felt so comfortable with them and I understood what Ira was saying about not being married and all, but nobody was thinking about me. Don't I get to have a little taste of life, even if it isn't supposed to be like this?"
Jacquelne proceeded to take chunks of time off for prenatal appointments, turning over to Rose the job of toting her children around to sports and ballet lessons. Rose went around looking stunned, saying to her friends: I can't believe it. I just can't believe this is happening. What am I going to do?
Rose worried about her children's reaction to the advancing pregnancy and the issues it would raise about their unmarried birth mothers not having kept them. But Louis, then 9, appeared to care not at all about Jacqueline's condition and Tecla acted delighted, touching and even kissing her stomach. Ira felt easier about appearing to condone unmarried motherhood by implying that the father of her other children was also the father of this one. To his surprise, friends and neighbors said not a word about her swelling size.
Rose and Tecla got into the spirit, buying baby clothes, collecting hand-me-down equipment from cousins, calling Jacqueline's nanny friends and organizing a baby shower. Jacqueline worked until three weeks before she was due. Rose and Ira gave her paid maternity leave for the summer, and on July 18, 1996, she gave birth to a healthy eight-and-a-half-pound girl. She named her Shemel. "I was so happy," Jacqueline says. She filled that big empty spot inside. It was like having my other children here. In September, she returned to work, paying her landlady to look after the baby. At night and on weekends, she returned home to Shemel. It is an uneasy alliance at times. Shemel and Rose compete for Jacqueline's attention. "With Tecla and Louis in school all day," Rose says, "I really need a sitter in the early morning and evenings."
Says Jacqueline firmly: "That's when my baby needs to know I'm there -- that I make her breakfast and come back home at night to put her to bed." That winter, the baby came with Jacqueline for a week in the Hamptons, and Tecla and Louis diapered and played with her constantly. But when Rose packed up to spend the summer in the Hamptons, Jacqueline reluctantly sent Shemel to stay with relatives in the Caribbean. "I needed to work to make money, and I knew I couldn't bring her along. She was too little. When I put her on the plane with my sister, we both wept." At the time, Jacqueline hadn't any idea how she was going to get Shemel home. It wasn't until the end of August that a tourist was found who agreed to shepherd her home.
Shemel has given Jacqueline a little more of the aura of equality. More than ever, Rose feels self-conscious about the tremendous financial gap. She and all the other nannies have to pass all these pricey children's clothes shops near the schools. I have taken to cutting the price tags off things I bring home. You feel guilty and you try to hide the difference, but of course, you cannot.
Sometimes the two of them have a silent battle of wills. Rose gets sharp-tongued and Jacqueline narrows her eyes and sulks. The two are capable of spoiling each other's day. "In an office, grumpiness is dispersed among the sheer numbers," Rose says. "You give a report to a secretary to do and boom, it gets done. I can give Jacqueline all the prioritized lists in the world and she will do things in exactly the order she wants. For instance, she loves to do laundry, but only all at once. She will iron every single undershirt, and heaven help the streaks and fingerprints on the mirrors. On the green marble kitchen table is a plant whose parched leaves slowly lift as Rose waters it. She gives a little smile. "This particular plant is our Gettysburg. It's a contest to see who will be the one to let it die."
Jacqueline says: "Well, you have to work how you work best. I have my own rhythm -- and my pride. Also, you know white people have attitude, too, and, boy, do they let it hang out." Late one recent Friday, Jacqueline was preparing to leave for the weekend while Rose was taking an important phone call. Louis burst in, declaring he was hungry. Without bothering Rose, Jacqueline ducked out to the deli and came back with some cheese, which is all Louis will eat these days.
"Mmm, what a great-looking sandwich," Ira says, coming into the kitchen as Jacqueline butters fresh pita bread and piles on the cheese. "You know, Jacqueline claims she can't cook." Rose laughs. "She can cook, but she won't," she says, looking at Jacqueline. "I even tried therapy on you to get to the root of this cooking phobia, right?"
Jacqueline puts the cheese back in the fridge. "I have to be in the mood," she says coyly, then rolls down the extra-long sleeves of the special shirts Rose buys her and puts on her coat. Rose looks longingly at the highly piled sandwich. "Gosh, that does look good!" Jacqueline asks her if she wants one and turns to take out the cheese, but Rose waves her on.
I drive Jacqueline to her apartment in Brooklyn, and when I park in front of her small brick row house, she disconnects the car phone and hides it under the seat. "We will keep an eye on the car from the living room," she says.
The stairway is battered, but inside, the apartment is cozy and the few pieces of furniture--two white sofas, blond dining-room set, single decorative fern, antique mirror--are immaculate. There are three tiny bedrooms, one each for her cousin, her sister and herself. Out toddles Shemel, then 18 months old, in a lovely pink sweater set, with her fine hair arranged in seven tiny braids around her head. She brings out her toys, a black doll, a white clown and a toy telephone to show me, a stranger, while ignoring her mother. "I phone her during the day so we can hear each other's voices," Jacqueline says. "But she still punishes me for leaving her all day."
Shemel is a beautiful and engaging child with delicate, impish features. She holds the receiver to her ear and cries, "Dadadada, yayaya, uh-huh, uh-huh," and then hangs up, grins at me and turns to throws her arms around her mother. The toddler leads me to her bedroom, where she gives me a pair of smart patent leather hiking boots to put on her so she can do a little dance. Her snowsuit and four outfits hang on a wall bar. Beneath it is her crib, and flush with that is her mother's double bed. Squeezed nearby is a long bureau, half devoted to Jacqueline's toiletries and half to Shemel's Pampers and baby paraphernalia. In between are two pictures in identical frames: one of Jacqueline's son and older daughter, who have her heart-shaped face, and the other of Jacqueline surrounded by Louis and Tecla.
Although it is usually past 8:30 when Jacqueline gets home at night, the first thing she does is pack Shemel's bag with clothes and toys and Pampers for the next day at the landlady's apartment downstairs. Then she will eat a little something, drink a cup of tea and lie with her baby until she sleeps. She has cut back her monthly checks home to $50. "I'm saving up so that whatever it takes, I'll get my other two over here so we can, for a while, be a family. It's been too hard to explain to them why I left, but I have to now or it will be too late for them to forgive me."
Before I go, Shemel puckers her little lips to kiss me and points to a picture taped to the wall -- a glittery scribble of yellow that Tecla helped her draw during a recent weekend when Tecla stayed with them. Rose worried the whole time, even though I knew Jacqueline would guard her with her life. Tecla has begged to go back, but Rose wants to keep her from getting any more attached to the baby. "I need to wean Tecla away from Jacqueline because if she leaves. . .I mean, she does have her own family now. How is it going to affect my kids?"
Rose wants to ask Jacqueline what she sees in her future. "Does she see herself going back to the Caribbean? Or staying with us for the rest of her life? I'd like to ask her where she feels her real home is, but the truth is, either way, I'm afraid of what the answer will be."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22; Column 4; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 680 words

HEADLINE: A Crucible Cracks

BYLINE: By Robert Weisbrot; Robert Weisbrot, who teaches at Colby College in Maine, is the author of "Freedom Bound: A History of America's Civil Rights Movement."

 BODY:

RACE PRIDE AND THE AMERICAN IDENTITY
 By Joseph Tilden Rhea.
 163 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $25. 
 SINCE the late 1960's, blacks, Indians, Latinos and Asian-Americans have increasingly reclaimed their heritage from public notoriety or neglect. In documenting their campaigns to influence repositories of the past, ranging from museums to battlefields, Joseph Tilden Rhea shows how assertions of "race pride" have transformed our cultural landscape as surely as civil rights campaigns have reshaped our politics.
Rhea argues that the jockeying over cultural symbols itself shapes collective memory. This has certainly been evident in the well-publicized controversies over the Vietnam Memorial, the Smithsonian's Enola Gay exhibition and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial. But Rhea's focus is on ethnic campaigns, which, he contends, have reinforced a larger movement for race pride. This is a movement that lacks organizations and common leaders, but cumulatively its struggles have infused historical presentations with an awakened sensitivity to minorities on the part of the white majority.
Rhea, an assistant professor of sociology at Arizona State University, cites Indian protests as an example of how changes in American culture owe as much to activists as to academicians. Using militant tactics that included defacing a mass grave of slain white soldiers, the American Indian Movement insisted that George Armstrong Custer was no martyr to Western progress but a brutal Indian killer. Prodding the Federal Government in 1991 to drop Custer's name from the site of his famous last stand and instead to highlight Indian language, artifacts and perspectives, the American Indian Movement, in Rhea's words, achieved "as complete a victory" as Sitting Bull's against Custer over a century ago. "The victors of the Battle of the Little Bighorn," he observes, "had at last won the power to write its history."
The outcomes of such ethnic battles have been uneven, Rhea says. African-Americans have done the most to enrich the national memory, building not only on civil rights triumphs but also on a tradition of cultural protest going back to Frederick Doug-lass, who warned whites against too much "generous forgetfulness" of the wrongs done to blacks. And Japanese-Americans have induced Congress to approve a memorial (and, later, financial compensation) to those interned for their Japanese ancestry during World War II. But Chicano activists have fared less well in pressing to have the Alamo in San Antonio reflect Mexican culture, in part because their myth of a glorious "bronze race" failed to inspire or even to interest other Hispanic Americans.
While most of "Race Pride and American Identity" is soundly argued, the book occasionally labors with unresolved tensions. Rhea notes the limited power of cultural memory to solve such problems as poverty, yet he repeatedly criticizes the Martin Luther King Jr. Museum for slighting King's late economic radicalism. And while stressing the crucial bond between political and cultural protest, he claims that civil rights laws "could do nothing to redress" the "persistent culture of racism." In fact these laws helped curb racist rhetoric as newly respectful Southern white politicians seeking black votes began celebrating diversity.
Rhea also overburdens his subject by asserting without argument that "memories which become embedded in physical space are somehow more powerful than those which find no material manifestation." This is a questionable claim, given the central role of the news media in stirring awareness of white racism and sympathy for minority aspirations. During the 1960's, news photographs and film of police dogs attacking peaceful civil rights marchers galvanized crucial white support for racial justice, while the 1977 television drama "Roots" riveted 140 million viewers with tales of black freedom struggles. Surely Rhea does not have to exaggerate the impact of museums and other physical memorials to justify his otherwise searching study.

HEADLINE: Venture Capital Is Alive, and Plentiful

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Late last year, Timothy C. Draper, a West Coast venture capitalist, found himself listening to a pitch from two 20-something entrepreneurs who were insisting that their computer networking "company" -- basically a good idea in search of early-stage financing -- was worth a whopping $15 million.
"It was outrageous," Mr. Draper, the managing director of Draper Fischer Associates in Redwood City, Calif., recalled recently. "They were just starting out." 
 But not long afterward, the two young men, whom Mr. Draper declined to identify, did find other investors who agreed to buy a big share of the company based on a valuation of $20 million. The punch line: The entrepreneurs and investors then together sold the company to a large corporation for $30 million.
Longtime venture capitalists say such stories are not unique.
In the world of computers and information technology, investors are laying out record levels of venture capital -- the seed money from professional fund managers on which many a high-technology start-up is nurtured. The accounting and consulting firm Coopers & Lybrand estimates that venture investments totaled $12.2 billion in 1997 -- nearly half of it going to software, communications and electronics -- up from a total of $10.1 billion the previous year.
The surge, driven by investors seeking the annual returns of 30 percent or even higher that some venture funds have realized in recent years, is causing the cost of investing in young companies to skyrocket. In some cases, bidding wars are erupting over unproven technologies.
As a result, some established venture capitalists are growing leery of the inflated bets they see eager novices willing to place in a game with notoriously high rates of failure.
"I'm walking away from a significantly higher number of deals than ever before," said Lucio Lanza, a managing partner of U.S. Venture Partners, situated on the famed Sand Hill Road venture-capital power corridor in Palo Alto.
Venture firms say that the stimulus is a combination of so-called weekend venture capitalists -- wealthy individuals enamored of the idea of high-risk, ground-floor investing -- and more risk taking by many traditionally conservative institutional investors like pension funds, endowments, universities and major corporations.
Indeed, a growing number of corporations have developed discreet venture-capital arms intended to nurture companies that fit into the strategic direction of the corporation. Neil Weintraut, of 21st Century Internet Venture Partners, based in San Francisco, said that 21st Century gets at least a call a week from a corporation looking for advice on how to start a venture fund.
Also, industry executives say that corporations with existing venture capital arms are increasingly active. The Intel Corporation, for example, said it made 100 venture capital investments last year, twice as many as in 1996.
Generally speaking, the phenomenon is parallel to what is taking place in the stock market, particularly in the high-technology sector, where investors have been willing to take chances on nascent technologies in hopes of getting in on the ground floor of the next high-rise stocks like Yahoo or Netscape.
A handful of top-tier venture firms boast annual returns higher than 40 percent on some of their funds. Hummer Winblad of San Francisco, for example, returned $260 million in four years on a $35 million investment made in 1990. Historically, the annual returns have hovered around 20 percent for the industry, according to Venture One Corporation, a San Francisco-based venture capital research group.
But many experienced venture capitalists insist that these high returns are becoming harder to get, as more money chases more deals. Last year, there were 2,706 new companies financed by venture capitalists, compared with 2,163 in 1996, according to Coopers & Lybrand.
Ann Winblad, a founding partner of Hummer Winblad, said that venture capitalists were having to go after the best prospects more aggressively, hoping to get to them before a competitor does. And her own company, she said, is now doing what was once unthinkable: looking outside Silicon Valley, where many other venture capitalists have yet to wander. Hummer Winblad's last two deals were in Atlanta and Seattle.
One company that has benefited from the venture frenzy is Snickelways Interactive, a New York start-up company that provides corporations with the technical wherewithal for electronic commerce. In October, the company raised $600,000 from so-called angels -- individual investors. Now that it is seeking to raise $5 million from venture funds, it has no shortage of suitors, said Snickelways' chief executive, Paul Cimino.
"We have people contacting us every week -- not necessarily with term sheets, but with offers," Mr. Cimino said.
The phenomenon has wrung a defensive tone from some traditional venture capitalists. They insist it is not nearly so easy to succeed in the early-financing game as some of their returns might imply. They say their success lies not just in their knack for picking the right companies but with the ability to then steer the companies, hire the right managers and help fit the technology squarely into the proper market. They refer to themselves as professional investors to distinguish their ilk from the "newbies" of venture capital.
As for the traditional venture capitalists, there is at least one upside to all this new money: they seem to have as much of it as they want.
Bill Davidow, a general partner in the Sand Hill-based Mohr, Davidow Partners, said he recently raised $120 million for a new venture fund but could easily have raised $250 million. He had to turn down investors, he said, because the company did not think it could judiciously oversee that much investment.
