HEADLINE: The Truth About Switzerland

BYLINE: By Hans Schaffner; Hans Schaffner was head of the Swiss Federal Office of War Economy from 1939 to 1946. He served as an elected member of the Swiss Federal Council from 1961 to 1970 and as President of Switzerland in 1965.

DATELINE: BERN, Switzerland

 BODY:
Once again debate has arisen concerning the measures that should be taken by Switzerland to settle the claims of Holocaust victims whose stolen property made its way into Swiss banks. The compensations provided by my country to date have been widely portrayed not as an honorable act of compassion but as evidence of a guilty national conscience.
This confusion comes after two years of accusations that Switzerland collaborated with Nazi Germany in World War II by stealing Jewish property and mistreating refugees. These charges were not based on any new information. All the relevant details have been available since 1946. But what is new is the surge of resentment against Switzerland, and the ignorance that underlies it. 
 Since I directed the Swiss war economy during the menacing years of World War II, when we had to prepare against Nazi aggression, I'm appalled to see Swiss wartime actions misrepresented so consistently. It is time to set the record straight.
To begin with, Swiss neutrality during the war was not an opportunistic subterfuge. It was a continuation of our policy, maintained over centuries, of achieving permanent armed neutrality. That neutrality is based on explicit provisions of international law recognized by the Allies, and it includes the obligation not to take sides with any belligerent nation.
It has never implied moral indifference. During World War II, the vast majority of Swiss sympathized with the Allies and our shared democratic traditions. That is why Hitler continually expressed contempt for us. Many who now criticize Switzerland's neutrality overlook the contributions it enabled us to make. Our International Red Cross was permitted into Germany and Japan, where it saved the lives of many Allied prisoners of war.
Neutrality also enabled Max Waibel, a Swiss intelligence official, to assist in arranging a conference at which Allen Dulles, then an official with the American Office of Strategic Services, met with the German commanders in Italy to negotiate an early German surrender, thereby reducing bloodshed and destruction in the final days of the war.
This same spirit animated the efforts of Walter Stucki, a Swiss diplomat who prevailed upon the Germans to hand over the city of Vichy to the Allies peacefully. These are just two examples of many acts of mercy and courage shown by the Swiss people.
Switzerland wasn't fully free, however, to act as it wished during the war, as President Franklin Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill both understood. We were blockaded by the German Army on one side and by the Allies on the other.
To avoid economic strangulation we had to negotiate constantly with both sides. Swiss industries developed armaments for our own defense and supplied them to Germany at its demand and to the Allies at theirs.
Despite these constraints, we defied Germany by sending the Allies precision instruments from our watch industry. We also smuggled plans and know-how to the Allies so they could start up their own production of these items.
And while the Germans forced us to expand our credit lines so they could import more Swiss goods, we used German coal, oil, steel, cement and food to build our mountain fortifications and the guns that held off the threat of Nazi invasion.
Some have argued that we should have been tougher with the Germans after the fall of Stalingrad in 1943, which reduced Nazi power in Europe and slightly eased our long-term military concerns.
But that turn of events also made Hitler desperate and multiplied the risk of his making unpredictable moves against Switzerland.
The issue of Jewish property has also been misunderstood. First, Switzerland was not the preferred destination for those trying to get their holdings out of Europe. The United States was. Even Switzerland kept the bulk of its gold reserves in Fort Knox. As far as I know, aside from a few isolated instances, Swiss banks did not pocket unclaimed deposits. These accounts continue to exist and are still available to legitimate claimants and their heirs.
I'm confident that current investigations will show that only a tiny fraction of those accounts are associated directly with the Holocaust. In any case, those records are available for inspection. Other countries, including the United States, simply took the money after a period of time and destroyed the records.
There is also a good deal of confusion about Switzerland's handling of gold transactions with Nazi Germany. Some of the gold the Germans sold us had apparently been looted from Jews. But we had no way of investigating this.
Furthermore, international law required the Swiss National Bank to deal equally with every country, including Germany, that wanted to buy our currency with gold. We lacked a legal basis, not to mention the military might, to cut the Germans off.
In 1946, the Allies and Switzerland signed the Washington Agreement, which settled the postwar claims of various European banks. Initially, the United States still held six billion francs in frozen Swiss assets as well as gold payments owed to the Swiss National Bank. Because international law supported the Swiss position, the United States released the assets.
Switzerland, like the United States, made a contribution to the recovery of Europe at that time because she had suffered less than most. The attempt to reopen this settlement a half-century later is scandalous.
Of all the allegations that have been made against Switzerland, nothing disturbs me more than the charge that my country was insensitive to the plight of wartime refugees. In 1938, when it became clear that substantial numbers of people would soon be fleeing German control, an international conference was held in Evian, France.
The Swiss offered to take an unlimited number of refugees on a temporary basis. Despite our tiny population (about half that of New York City), we accepted more than 300,000 people. It is true that we turned away 30,000 Jews. But we sheltered 25,000 other Jews at a time when other countries, including the United States, shut their doors firmly against Jewish refugees. Some have pointed out that many refugees were housed in temporary camps, along with the thousands of Allied soldiers and pilots who sought internment in Switzerland rather than be sent to Nazi prisons or face death. Yet how else could a small mountainous country deal with a sudden population increase of nearly 10 percent -- in wartime?
Today a generation that knows nothing about World War II is being misled about my country. To compare a diplomat like Walter Stucki with an SS executioner, as some have done, is untrue and shows bad faith. The same holds for those who have referred to the defensive strategy of Gen. Henri Guisan as a "submissive gesture," when in fact the Germans hated Guisan because of his visceral distaste for Nazism.
It is time for these falsehoods and half-truths to stop. All my life I have done my best to foster good relations with America, Switzerland's great sister republic. But good relations must rest on truth.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Laura Ljungkvist)

HEADLINE: MEDIA: ENTERTAINMENT;
The threat of a strike by actors remains despite a tentative labor agreement.

BYLINE: By Bernard Weinraub 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
SHERRY LANSING, chairwoman of the Paramount Motion Pictures Group, said simply, "You have to prepare for the worst, but hope for the best." Across town, Bill Mechanic, chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, said: "You do what you can. You plan for contingencies."
The two executives are hardly talking about a new deal with James Cameron -- the studios financed "Titanic" -- or a blockbuster gone awry. What's on the minds of Ms. Lansing and Mr. Mechanic is the possibility of a strike by actors that would not only damage the entertainment industry but also Southern California's economy. About 262,000 people work in the television and movie business in the Los Angeles area. 
 Although the three-year contract between the producers and actors -- represented by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Radio and Television Artists -- does not expire until June 30, negotiations grew intense last week. Both sides bargained all weekend and reached a tentative agreement early yesterday morning.
But the situation remains delicate and volatile. The agreement is subject to approval by a board representing both groups. And then the joint membership of 130,000 must vote on it, too. So must members of the management side, the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers.
Richard Masur, head of the Screen Actors' Guild, said yesterday that he expected the membership to vote on the proposal in the next few weeks. "I feel very secure that when we have a chance to present what's in the package that there won't be any disappointments," he said.
The last actors' strike came in July 1980, stirring turmoil mostly with that year's fall television schedule until the actors returned to work three months later. But the most serious Hollywood strike in recent years took place in 1988, when the Writers Guild of America went on strike for 22 weeks. The walkout cost the industry and writers an estimated $500 million. (The writers, whose East and West Coast branches have engaged in a high-profile squabble in recent months, are now in negotiations on a new contract with producers and the networks. The deadline is May 2, but, for the moment, studios seem to think that an actors' strike may be a more immediate threat than a writers' walkout.)
At issue in the talks between the actors and management is the subject of foreign and cable television "residuals" -- the share of revenues that actors earn when their films are shown abroad or on cable. The unions insist that it is time for studios and companies to share the wealth they are reaping from such sales. They argue that the residual formulas -- set up in the 1980's, when the lucrative foreign marketplace was less developed and cable channels less numerous -- are outdated.
Producers, on the other hand, insist that expenses have exploded: the average cost of making and marketing a movie has reached $75.6 million. Producers say that keeping costs down, and companies profitable, can create more jobs for actors.
Under the tentative contract, both sides agreed to undertake a joint study to define the structure for a deal on the residual issues. The study is expected to be completed in two years.
A strike would hardly affect the fortunes of Leonardo DiCaprio or Jerry Seinfeld. But 8 of 10 members of the Screen Actors Guild earn less than $10,000 a year from acting, and most hold down other part-time jobs to pay the rent.
Mr. Masur of the Screen Actors Guild has said that a strike is just about the last thing his members want but that the union will call one if the members see no progress in their key demands.
Film studios are reacting nervously to the threat of a strike. What especially concerns studios is the possibility of a strike in the midst of making a film.
"We're taking precautions," Ms. Lansing said. "We are not shooting any pictures that don't finish before a strike." Ms. Lansing said that she was hopeful, in fact, that films currently in production would be completed three weeks before the June 30 deadline. "We want to have a three-week cushion," she said.
Like many other studios, Fox is to start filming several new projects in July -- not May or June. So if a strike takes place, the studios would simply delay new productions.
Mr. Mechanic, the Fox executive, said, "Everything should either be wrapped or ready to start. We won't get caught in the middle."
Mr. Mechanic said that the last thing the movie business needed was a strike. "A strike is obviously bad -- and the only positive that could come out of it will be to perhaps slow down production," he said. "Maybe all the studios will decide that less may be better and that the costs of movies are out of control. Maybe we'll get sane at the same time."
Not every studio is alarmed about a potential strike. Dreamworks, for example, is moving ahead with film production that could be interrupted by a strike. And producers said that if a top star became available, other studios would take the risk, too. "Believe me, if Tom Cruise said he wanted to start a movie before that deadline date, they'd start it," said Scott Rudin, one of Hollywood's most prolific producers. Mr. Rudin has three new movies about to start production -- a remake of "Shaft," the adaptation of the book "Angela's Ashes," and the film version of the television show "South Park." None of them are starting before June 30.

HEADLINE: Shareholders Push for Tighter Rules Abroad

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Once seen as the exclusive concern of a handful of shareholder groups in the United States, corporate governance issues are going global.
That reality was driven home last week, when an international panel submitted recommendations to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development intended to improve the accountability of foreign companies to their shareholders. 
 And it will be underscored today with the release of a new international survey of more than 350 institutional investors.
Commissioned by Russell Reynolds Associates, an executive search firm, and conducted by Wirthlin Worldwide, an opinion research organization in McLean, Va., the survey, "Furthering the Global Dialogue on Corporate Governance," polled fund managers and institutional shareholders in Australia, France, Britain and the United States.
Russell Reynolds commissioned two previous governance surveys, which were limited to the views of American fund managers and institutions. But changes in the global economy drove the firm to seek a broader frame of reference.
"This survey is mirroring the flow of capital and the internationalization of capital markets," said John T. W. Hawkins, managing director of the global board practice at Russell Reynolds.
Further, "the whole information revolution and the Internet have eased communication to the point that it has facilitated cross-border discussions on these issues," he said. "And the introduction of the euro is making European investors expect greater transparency and the unification of principles and codes of conduct on the Continent."
Indeed, because three-quarters of the investors surveyed have holdings in companies outside their organization's home country, it is perhaps not surprising that a significant percentage endorsed the development of a global set of corporate governance standards.
More than 25 percent of American institutions said realization of that goal was either extremely important or very important to them; the figure was more than 60 percent in France, 52 percent in Australia and 27 percent in Britain.
And there seems little doubt that interest in corporate governance issues is increasing.
Sixteen percent of the American organizations surveyed said that in the last year they had participated in four or more investor activities like voting for a shareholder resolution or writing a letter to the company's board relaying the institution's point of view. In 1996, only 6 percent of those who responded to the poll reflected that level of activity.
Last year, just 25 percent of the American institutions surveyed said that the quality of a company's board was an extremely or very important factor in making an investment decision. In this year's survey, the figure is 35 percent. The numbers are even higher in Australia (83 percent) and Britain (58 percent), but lower in France (16 percent).
A majority of investors in all countries said one of the most critical responsibilities of a board was to determine whether an underperforming chief executive should be forced to resign.
Half of the American institutions surveyed said boards should play a critical role in determining the compensation of senior management and the chief executive. And 55 percent of the United States institutions said the board, and not the chief executive, should play a critical role in developing management succession plans.
The survey results are considered accurate to within plus or minus five percentage points.
 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: SIC7361 EMPLOYMENT AGENCIES (57%);

HEADLINE: 8 Countries Agree to Fight Environmental Crime

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LEEDS CASTLE, England, April 5

 BODY:
Ministers from Russia and the Group of Seven leading economies agreed today to step up their cooperation against environmental crime, a market estimated at $20 billion a year.
"We want to declare war on the smugglers who trade illegally in banned products such as endangered species, the ozone-depleting substances and hazardous wastes," Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott of Britain said.
The meeting of environmental ministers from Britain, the United States, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Canada and Russia was held in advance of a gathering of national leaders in England in May.
Mr. Prescott said he wanted to see the equivalent of an Interpol for environmental crime.
He said the illegal trade in endangered species was estimated at $5 billion a year; the figure rises to $20 billion when illegal fishing, logging and trade in bootleg chlorofluorocarbons are included. Those gases, which deplete the ozone layer, are still produced in Russia, China and some other countries. Environmental crimes can be as profitable as drug crimes, Mr. Prescott said.
The meeting highlighted continuing differences between the European Union and the United States about how governments should carry out the Kyoto conference agreement to cut emissions of greenhouse gases.
The pact, which Mr. Prescott helped negotiate in December, agreed that industrialized nations should cut emissions of six greenhouse gases by an average 5.2 percent between 2008 and 2012, with a 7 percent cut for the United States and 8 percent for the European Union.

HEADLINE: Privatizing Social Security Gains Backers in Congress

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Just a few years ago, Cynthia de Lorenzi, a stay-at-home mother in Dallas, knew little about investing and found the topic intimidating.
"It was like knocking on the doors of a world I'd never been invited into," said Ms. de Lorenzi, who was forced to confront the subject after a divorce left her in charge of her own finances for the first time. 
 These days she spouts investment jargon, debates the merits of technology stocks and rattles off names of mutual funds.
With the stock market having gone up and up since her first tentative investments three years ago -- the Dow Jones industrial average topped 9,000 briefly for the first time on Friday, up from 4,000 in 1995 -- Ms. de Lorenzi now feels confident turning her modest savings over to Wall Street. So much so, in fact, that she enthusiastically supports what would be one of the most fundamental changes to the Government's compact with its citizens in decades: the proposal to remake Social Security by giving individuals the right to invest some of the money they normally pay in taxes to finance the retirement system, granting them a shot at a pot of gold but also exposing them to new risks.
"Be afraid not to do it," she said, "because you'd be missing the opportunity of a lifetime to get control of your life."
Not everyone shares her outlook. Among those who believe that stock markets go down as well as up, and others to whom Wall Street might as well be on another planet, the notion of turning Social Security into an investment program is often seen as irresponsible or at least unnecessary.
"There are tens of millions of people who have no familiarity with financial affairs," said Henry J. Aaron, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, the research group. "Even among those who are sophisticated, we tend to be lulled into a false sense of power and competence by what has happened recently in the U.S. with this perfectly marvelous period of rising share prices."
But as Congress and the White House debate how to insure that Social Security will be able to weather the retirement of the baby boom generation in coming decades, members of both parties are taking seriously the idea that this has become a nation of money managers, knowledgeable and secure enough, like Ms. de Lorenzi, to take on at least partial responsibility for what has long been a Government guarantee against poverty in old age.
The issue is sure to be central to a public discussion about Social Security's future that President Clinton will lead on Tuesday at a bipartisan forum in Kansas City, Mo., the first in a series of events he will hold this year on how to prepare for the aging of the 76 million Americans born in the 18 years after the end of World War II.
When the baby boomers start retiring in droves in about a decade, they will drain Social Security's reserves rapidly, and by 2029, if no changes are made, the system will be able to pay only 75 percent of promised benefits. Defenders of the current system say the problem can be taken care of through relatively modest steps like accelerating the planned increase in the retirement age to 67, raising payroll taxes slightly and trimming cost-of-living increases.
It remains unclear which way the debate will tilt, or whether the solution might be found on some middle ground like having the Government invest the Social Security system's money directly in the markets in search of higher returns rather than turning that job over to individuals.
That such a national discussion is taking place at all reflects the changes to the nation's psyche wrought by the stock market's unprecedented surge and the proliferation of investment vehicles like 401(k) programs, mutual funds and Individual Retirement Accounts.
Just to touch Social Security was long considered political suicide in Washington, an attack on what is arguably the most popular and successful of Federal social programs.
But privatization proposals that even a year or two ago were heard only at conservative think tanks are now being bandied casually about Congress with no apparent political backlash. With little fanfare, the Senate last week passed a nonbinding resolution calling for private investment accounts to be part of any Social Security reform package. Even Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, a Democrat who is a staunch defender of Social Security, set out an approach last month that includes private accounts.
Most of the privatization proposals call for a portion of the payroll taxes levied on workers and employers to finance Social Security to be diverted into individually managed accounts that could be tapped only in retirement. The Government, under these proposals, would continue to pay a reduced but guaranteed benefit as a safety net for the elderly. Under the current system, known as pay as you go, each generation of workers pays for the benefits of people then in retirement.
"Stock ownership is now wide but not terribly deep, and clearly that fact along with the extraordinary upsurge in the market has changed the way people think about savings and retirement," said Robert B. Reich, who was Secretary of Labor in Mr. Clinton's first term.
"This debate was ostensibly triggered by fears about the solvency of the Social Security trust fund. The real source of this debate is the increase in stock market participation."
The percentage of Americans owning stocks doubled, to 21 percent, in the 25 years up to 1990, said a report done last year for the Nasdaq stock market by Peter D. Hart Research Associates. In the next 7 years, it doubled again, to 43 percent.
The same study reported that ownership of mutual funds jumped to 40 percent of adults in 1997 from 13 percent in 1990. The number of people in 401(k) programs jumped to 27 million last year from 7.5 million in 1984, the Labor Department said.
Yet, if there is clearly a constituency for a more investment-oriented approach to Social Security, the data also show a sharp divide between people who invest and those who do not.
The 1995 Survey of Consumer Finances conducted by the Federal Reserve, the most recent detailed nationwide look at household finances, found that among respondents who identified themselves as professional and managerial, 70.3 percent had some form of retirement account, 26.1 percent owned individual stocks and 21.3 percent owned mutual funds. Among respondents who identified themselves as machine operators and laborers, 47.3 percent had retirement accounts, 9.0 percent owned individual stocks and 6.9 percent owned mutual funds.
Moreover, for 16 percent of the nation's elderly, Social Security's old-age benefits are their only source of income; and for two-thirds of the elderly, Social Security is the major source of income.
Defenders of the current system and proponents of a major change have been arguing heatedly in the last several months about the relative rates of return available from the stock market over the long run versus the payback workers can expect from their contributions to Social Security.
From 1926 through 1996, the stock market generated an annual average return of 7.56 percent after factoring out inflation, far higher than almost anyone working today can expect to get back in retirement benefits from their Social Security contributions. But critics of the investment-oriented approach said the overall figures mask long periods in which returns have been weak or even negative.
None of the counterarguments shake the faith of Ms. de Lorenzi in the power of investing. She has started appearing on a radio program in Dallas to urge people, especially women, to save and invest more, and she has joined a grass-roots group, Economic Security 2000, that advocates individual investment accounts as one element of a plan to fix Social Security.
"When we first started talking about this, it was a taboo subject, as if you had showed up in your underwear," she said. "Now people are constantly talking about the stock market, and becoming very comfortable with the language. And as they become more comfortable, they're more accepting of the idea."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cynthia de Lorenzi, a divorced mother forced to face the world of personal finances. (Mark Graham for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Bad Law Breeds New Trouble

 BODY:
For a decade now, through administrations Democratic and Republican, the New York State Legislature has persistently struggled to subvert the Constitution on behalf of the small but politically influential enclave of Kiryas Joel. That Hasidic village in Orange County has been waging a long battle to establish its own school district so its disabled students can get publicly financed remedial education without being exposed to the secular world. Whatever the good intentions of parents and politicians alike, this is a demand for government-subsidized segregated schools that the courts have rightly and repeatedly struck down.
The Legislature's contorted efforts to accommodate the Hasidic parents will eventually encourage other communities that would like to keep their schools homogeneous. There are some signs that this is happening already, and it is time for Gov. George Pataki to declare that he will sign no further laws on behalf of Kiryas Joel. 
 After passing three laws, losing two battles before the state's highest court and one in the Supreme Court, the state was rebuffed again last week when the State Supreme Court in Albany struck down the latest law that would permit Kiryas Joel to keep its own special public school district. The ruling, by Judge Joseph Teresi, indicated that the state's judicial system is losing patience with the Legislature's repeated attempts to find a constitutional way to accomplish an unconstitutional end.
Allowing very small communities to establish their own school districts is contrary to state policy because it is economically inefficient. The Legislature keeps trying to draw up a law that would set standards for secession narrow enough to include the 12,000-resident Kiryas Joel without opening the doors to a statewide balkanization of education. The most recent attempt would be applicable to only one other community, Stony Point in Rockland County. The reaction by Stony Point shows the danger of continuing any further down this road. Residents of that largely white district are circulating petitions to set up a school system separate from the more heavily minority neighborhoods around them.

HEADLINE: Farewell to Rust and Ripped Upholstery;
The Commuter's Frugal 'Station Car' Is Replaced by Luxury and Leasing

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 5

 BODY:
A generation ago, every commuter railroad station had a parking lot full of rusty Nash Ramblers or dented Ford woodies, cars with a hundred thousand miles on the odometer, stuffing oozing from the upholstery and at least one door that could be opened only from the inside.
Known as station cars, these beat-up vehicles, with just enough life to get from the house to the railroad, were proud badges of frugality, even in well-to-do suburbs, for men raised during the Depression. But 30 years later, these cars are all but invisible in these parts, as rare as unlocked doors, clotheslines and aluminum siding. In their place are leased Jeep Cherokees and BMW's, shiny and fully loaded. 
 Jon Epstein, a real estate executive, says that nobody he knows buys cars anymore and thus there's nothing in the garage long enough to qualify as a station car. As he climbed into his new Grand Cherokee Laredo at the train station here the other night, he said he could imagine only one situation suitable for a jalopy. "For my sons, for their first car, I might go out and buy a clunker," he said.
Automotive experts cite three intersecting reasons for the decline of the station car: the acquisitive nature of baby boomers and their younger siblings who want the latest status symbol, the enormous increase of wealth in already prosperous suburbs like this one and the advent of leasing, which allows people to drive high-end models and move on before the cars lose the new-car smell.
Chris Cedergren, the managing director of Next Trend Company, which takes the pulse of the auto industry, said the primary explanation is the image consciousness of today's consumers, whose "desire to make a certain statement about themselves" is facilitated by new wealth and the economics of leasing. He puts himself squarely in this category. He loves fancy cars, keeps his money in the stock market and leases a new BMW every two years.
The surge in wealth this decade, fueled in the New York metropolitan region by the buoyant stock market, is paying for the luxurious vehicles left out in the rain at railroad stations in Westchester and Fairfield County, two of the richest areas in the nation. Similar cars are found at stations in Summit, N.J., and Great Neck on Long Island, pockets of comparable plenty.
George Pipas, the sales analysis manager for the Ford Motor Company, pointed to eight years of business expansion, the huge sums of money people are making on Wall Street and the lowest interest rates in years. "Tons of people have done extremely well for themselves," he said. 'It's gotten so bloody bad the word millionaire doesn't mean anything anymore."
At the same time, leasing automobiles, once the province of corporations with fleets of cars, has become a popular alternative. "Leasing has just gone into orbit," said David Cole, the director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan.
In 1984, just 2.5 percent of the new cars and light trucks acquired by individuals were leased. By 1990, the percentage was 7.3 and headed sharply upward -- to 13.5 percent in 1992, 23 percent in 1994 and 30.5 percent in 1997. According to projections by CNW Marketing/Research, by 2001 more than one in three personal cars on the road will be leased.
Because the cost of leasing depends on the residual value of the car when it is returned, high-end brands, like BMW's, and fashionable models, like sport utility vehicles, are especially well priced. And although the price of leasing a luxury car is higher than that for other cars, that price is a smaller percentage of the car's purchase price. This economic anomaly allows people to lease fancier cars than they could afford to buy, said Bob Casey, the curator of the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., and to switch readily to the car of the moment. It also means less worry about leaving a car in a lot all day, subject to the harsh sun and the dings left by strangers.
Then there is image, what a car tells the rest of the world about its owner. "Nowadays anybody who has a beater has got to be a loser," said David Lewis, a professor of business history at the University of Michigan, using a synonym for jalopy. "When you see a car belching black smoke and rattling along, you feel sorry for the person driving it."
The few beaters found during a random survey of a half-dozen railroad parking lots in Westchester and Fairfield Counties seem to be owned by people who take a stubborn pride in not keeping up with the Joneses. In Westport, Conn., 75-year-old Charles Temko, a patent attorney, said his neighbors all drive Mercedes-Benzes, BMW's and sport utility vehicles while he gets along nicely in a 1985 Ford Crown Victoria. "At my age I don't need status," he said.
"The way America lives today, people drive expensive cars they have no business owning," Mr. Temko said. "There are loads of people up here making 70 or 80 thousand and trying desperately to live like they make 125."
In neighboring Fairfield, Mike Esposito, who builds the sets for the soap opera "The Guiding Light," said no car has soul unless it has chrome bumpers, like his 1973 Chevy Impala. "It runs nice and clean," he said. "Mechanically it's 100 percent. It's safe. So what if nobody looks at me and gives a thumbs up?"
Irwin Schildkraut, an engineer who commutes from Fairfield, also thinks it is the mark of good judgment to drive a station car, in his case a battered 1988 Subaru. "Who's going to steal it?" he asked. "And if they do, who cares?"
But Mr. Schildkraut's wife and children don't see it his way. His wife, who drives a 1996 Taurus, "has this thing about my car -- she doesn't want to be seen in it." And his children, 13 and 9, argue for family outings in Mom's wagon because it has a compact disk player and boom-box quality speakers.
The small number of station cars in communities like Scarsdale is one way to measure the new trend. Perhaps more telling is what passes for a beater these days. A leased Jeep Cherokee is the family car in his household, said Rick Knief, car keys in hand as he loped into the parking garage here the other night. But he wanted something modest for trips to the station or the golf course.
His choice? A 1990 Mercedes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a commuter train station in Fairfield, Conn., Mike Esposito explained that his 1973 Chevy Impala had soul. The vintage car is a rarity in parking lots filled with luxury vehicles like leased Jeep Cherokees and BMW's. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1703 words

HEADLINE: EMPLOYERS HUSTLE TO FILL JOB ROLLS, WITHOUT PAY RISES

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Unable to recruit enough workers, Otto Engineering Inc. near Chicago lowered its standards. Assemblers of its electronic switches no longer need to score at a sixth-grade level on a math test. Fifth grade is now enough. The Walt Disney Company, trying to hire for its theme parks in Florida, is recruiting for the first time in Puerto Rico, where unemployment is three times that in the United States. And Rubbermaid Inc., chronically short staffed at a toy factory in Ohio, hired a temporary help agency to run a recruiting center at the plant.
Not since the early 1970's, when the unemployment rate was last below 5 percent, have America's employers scrambled as much as they have in recent months to find workers. A quarter-century ago, they relied chiefly on higher wages. Wages are beginning to rise now, even for people with only high school educations, but not by so much as in the past. Far more than in the 1970's, companies are using other recruiting tactics to dilute wage pressures. 
 In previous periods of economic growth, the wages of most workers rose early in the upturn. This time the opposite happened; the median weekly wage, adjusted for inflation, fell in each of the first five years of the recovery, rising modestly for the first time in 1997, according to Labor Department figures. All the while, the unemployment rate has been falling, getting as low as 4.6 percent last November. Since then, it has ticked back and forth between 4.6 percent and 4.7 percent, edging up last month to 4.7 percent.
"New and aggressive hiring tactics postponed wage growth, and they continue to suppress it," said Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute. Corporations say they have no choice -- they cannot raise prices as easily as in the past, and they must sustain profits. But Mr. Bernstein, echoing a view widely held among labor economists, said, "A lot of employers have grown accustomed to a culture in which they don't need to give real wage increases to hire and hold workers."
What no economist or policy maker can know is how long companies can fill hundreds of thousands of new jobs and also resist bigger wage increases, which could squeeze profits. Perhaps a slowing economy will bail them out, easing the demand for workers and raising the unemployment rate from its remarkably low level. That does not seem likely to happen soon, despite the occasional months, like March, when the work force shrinks instead of expanding.
Still, there are big pockets of potential workers that have yet to be reached. Despite the low unemployment rate nationally, joblessness is just beginning to decline significantly for those without high school diplomas and for black and Hispanic people. And there are regions where unemployment is still relatively high, prompting companies to go where the people are.
Many companies enlist their own workers as recruiters, awarding bonuses or prizes for each new employee they bring in. Some, like XL Connect near Philadelphia, which employs 1,500 people skilled in computer networks, pay as much as $1,000 to an employee who recruits someone who stays six months. "Even then we hired and trained 900 people last year to retain 500," Tim Wallace, XL's president, said. "But we can't pay more than our billing rate, and when others offer higher salaries, we have to let them go."
The General Electric Company finds itself moving more quickly than in the past to hire experienced candidates, often offering a job within two weeks of meeting a promising applicant. "These are valuable mid-career people seeking new jobs," said Robert Corcoran, a human resources manager, "and if we delay a decision, others have time to grab them, perhaps at a higher wage."
The Maytag Corporation, adopting a growing corporate practice, now lists job openings on the Internet -- appealing nationwide for applicants. It is also recruiting, for the first time, among minority organizations, including an association of black men and women who have master's degrees in business. "We would probably have done this anyway," said Kim Miller, Maytag's manager of employment, "but we are certainly doing it in a tight labor market."
Like numerous companies forced to choose between raising wages and lowering standards, Otto Engineering decided to accept less math proficiency but hold to a $6 hourly wage for assemblers. Maytag has also lowered standards. Community college graduates with two-year degrees now get jobs in sales and marketing that once went only to those with four-year degrees. And Maytag for the first time is beginning to train computer programmers instead of hiring fully trained ones.
"It could be production folks, nurses, clerical staff," Ms. Miller said, "anyone already on staff who shows an aptitude for programming might come into the training program we are now setting up."
Rubbermaid, which makes plastic kitchenware and toys, gave ground on wages, but only as part of a broader recruiting tactic. Unable to hire enough people for its Little Tykes toy factory in Hudson, a suburb of Cleveland, it raised the starting wage last August by $1, to $8.07 an hour, roughly the going rate for entry-level factory workers in northern Ohio.
"We had been drawing applicants who were unemployed or on welfare, and when the wage went up, we started getting people who had jobs and wore clean shirts and ties," said Scott Silver, vice president for human resources.
But with the factory's employment rising to 1,000 from 700 in 1996, the higher wage was not enough, and like many companies across America, Rubbermaid turned to the temporary help industry, which acts increasingly as a clearing house, bringing workers and companies together. Rubbermaid asked the Olsten Corporation to open a recruiting office inside the factory. And Olsten for the first time sent recruiters deep into the surrounding communities, tapping church groups, bowling leagues and immigrant organizations for people willing to work for $8 an hour -- initially as Olsten employees but shifting in two or three months to Rubbermaid's payroll.
"People often see us as a vehicle to gain access to first-line companies that they don't think they can get into on their own," Dan Brunell, Olsten's regional director in the Cleveland area, said.
Other companies are going even further. With a fourth theme park opening next month in Florida, Disney has set up recruiting offices in five Puerto Rican cities, mostly to recruit low-wage workers. And Burrelle's Information Services, a newspaper and television clipping service based in Livingston, N.J., is hiring and expanding in Presque Isle in northern Maine.
Burrelle's employs 1,000 people at its main sites in Livingston and in Provo, Utah, but has trouble finding workers in these cities for $7 an hour. Rather than raise the wage, it is expanding employment at a newer office in Presque Isle, where the unemployment rate is still above 6 percent. The office now has 700 workers earning $7 an hour, including some with college degrees.
"You have to be flexible this way, and move where you can get the people," Robert Waggonner, the chief executive of Burrelle's, said. He rents quarters in Presque Isle, reluctant to build and then face rising wages as other companies tap into northern Maine's labor pool, just as they once did in Provo.
Ohio is demonstrating a newfound flexibility as well. The Department of Economic Development, like other state agencies everywhere, has spent years trying to persuade companies to come to Ohio and hire its residents. But workers are suddenly in short supply. Last month, the department started placing television ads, even on the "Larry King Live" show, to encourage people to move to Ohio and take jobs.
"You cannot bring a company in, even with tax breaks, unless you can show you have an available work force," John Damschroder, the department's director of special projects, said. Ohio's unemployment rate is less than 5 percent.
In pursuit of that work force, the ads offer a toll-free number. The operators direct callers to a new site on the World Wide Web that lists hundreds of unfilled jobs in the state, or they mail out a promotional booklet. "We have gotten 500 calls, mostly from people who hold jobs elsewhere but have family here or once lived here and want to come back," Mr. Damschroder said.
Kenneth Vaughn of Torrance, Calif., an aircraft inspector for American Airlines, saw the commercial and dialed the number. He grew up near Cincinnati and is trying to persuade his wife -- also an Ohio native -- that northern winters are not so bad after all. He may return in July, when he can take an early retirement agreement that will give him $31,000 a year.
The tight job market in states like Ohio, Mr. Vaughn said, convinces him that at age 52, he will not have trouble landing another job that pays enough to bring his income up to $75,000 a year. That would match his current earnings at American, including overtime. "My children say, 'We will be poor,' " he said, "but I don't think so. I'm ready to try something new."
Oklahoma also worries about having enough workers for the industrial companies already there or thinking about coming. The state Commerce Department plans to circulate a directory of M.B.A. graduates of Oklahoma State University and the University of Oklahoma -- each with a photo and biographical sketch -- to local businesses.
"It will look like a football program," said Ronald Rosenfeld, the Secretary of Commerce. "Many of our companies don't recruit on our college campuses, so we will bring the candidates to them."
The Boeing Company, which employs 1,600 people at two aircraft operations in Oklahoma, is also concerned. At a recent dinner at the governor's mansion, Boeing executives said they wanted to bring in more bright young engineers and technicians, Mr. Rosenfeld said.
"They were saying that in order to get people to leave places like Seattle to settle in places like Tulsa," Mr. Rosenfeld said, "they would probably have to provide the additional inducement of subsidized vacations" to ski in Colorado, go sailing off Seattle, where Boeing is based, or attend the theater in New York.

HEADLINE: Report Says Quality of Life Rises Slightly In Connecticut

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
An annual report that traces a wide array of social indicators in Connecticut found that the state's overall quality of life rose slightly in 1995, researchers said yesterday. But they cautioned that social conditions were not improving as rapidly as the economy and that reports of child abuse were rising at an alarming rate.
The report, by the Institute for Innovation in Social Policy at Fordham University, is commissioned annually by the state government and the Graustein Memorial Fund in New Haven. It tracks conditions in a variety of categories, like unemployment, health care and teen-age birth rates. 
 "One of the things that really bothered us this year was the child abuse rate," said Marc L. Miringoff, a Fordham professor and the principal author of the study, whose findings were released in January. "The preliminary data for 1996 showed the same jump. That's why we're concerned."
From 1994 to 1995, the number of children reported to be at risk or suffering from neglect or physical or sexual abuse rose by 9,000, bringing the total to 37,043, Professor Miringoff said. No changes were made in the state's reporting system during that period, he said. Since 1990, the report found, reports of child abuse in the state more than doubled.
While indicators of the strength of the state's economy improved, a handful of indicators of social conditions worsened sharply. "What we're seeing is that the social health is not improving as quickly as the economy of the state," Professor Miringoff said.
The report said that unemployment declined for the third consecutive year, violent crime declined for the fifth consecutive year and the cost of a single-family home declined for the sixth consecutive year. But income disparity in the state widened from 1994 to 1995. Health care costs fell during that period, but so did average weekly wages.
The study found that while child abuse rates rose, infant mortality rates fell from 1994 to 1995. Youth suicide and teen-age birth rates also dropped, and high school graduation rates rose.
The report gave the state an overall score of 44.5 for 1995 out of a possible 100, a slight increase from 42.7 in 1994. In 8 of the last 10 years, the state's score dropped, with a decline of roughly 20 points since 1984. Connecticut's 1995 score roughly matched the standard of social well-being for the nation in a similar study by Professor Miringoff. The state's highest score was 74 in 1973, and its lowest was 42 in 1992.
High school completion rates were among the report's bright spots, with 81.5 percent of enrolling freshmen graduating in 1995, an increase from 1994 and the highest rate since 1973.
But a public opinion poll of 1,000 state residents in December 1997 and released with the study found mixed views. Connecticut residents who were polled thought that economic conditions had improved since 1995, when the last poll was taken.
The poll, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points, found that perceptions of job opportunities improved, with 47 percent saying that job opportunities were good in the current poll, compared with 24 percent in 1995.
Although most of those who were polled responded that conditions had improved in the state over the short-term, many said conditions were worse than they were five years ago. Fifty-one percent of those polled said the standard of living in the state had decreased in the last five years, and 41 percent said safety had decreased during the same period.
There was also little optimism for the future. Forty-two percent of those polled said they believed that the overall standard of living in the state would decline, and 36 percent said conditions will stay the same in the next five years. The area of highest optimism was education: 39 percent expected the quality of education to improve, and 35 percent expected it to stay the same.
Finally, the poll found that residents still have a stubbornly persistent perception of two Connecticuts -- an issue that has long vexed the state. In a /2 percent increase/ from the 1995 poll, 80 percent of those polled said they agreed strongly or agreed somewhat with the statement, "There are two Connecticuts, one prosperous, one poor."

HEADLINE: The Middle Class Can Live Here

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As a recent Brooklyn home buyer, I could appreciate "For Middle Class, New York Shrinks as Home Prices Soar" (front page, April 1). You do not mention, however, that while the middle class has been priced out of neighborhoods like Yorkville, the West Village and Brooklyn Heights, this is an excellent time to explore more racially and economically integrated areas of the city. 
 Neighborhoods like Prospect Heights, Williamsburg and Fort Greene in Brooklyn, for example, offer beautiful old homes, tree-lined streets and the opportunity to raise a family in an ethnically diverse setting. Perhaps the city, instead of investing in cheaply constructed new high-rises, should provide incentives for middle-class buyers to renovate old homes in these historic neighborhoods.
 
DAPHNE EVIATAR
Brooklyn, April 1, 1998

HEADLINE: Time and Technology Threaten Digital Archives . . .

BYLINE: By STEPHEN MANES 

 BODY:
JEFF ROTHENBERG, a senior computer scientist at the Rand Corporation, is fond of quoting Shakespeare's 18th sonnet, the one that begins "Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?" But in keeping with his interest in the preservation of digital data, he prefers the final couplet: "So long as men can breathe or eyes can see/So long lives this and this gives life to thee." Referring to the poem itself, the lines attest to the poet's faith in the staying power of ink on paper.
Today's digitally processed words and images may not be nearly as stable or long-lived. In a recently revised paper, "Ensuring the Longevity of Digital Documents," Mr. Rothenberg noted that a modern-day Shakespeare bent on accuracy might be forced to write, "So long as the magnetic flux on this disk has not been disturbed, and so long as humans retain the appropriate size and speed disk drives, and so long as they have hardware controllers and software device drivers capable of reading the bits from this disk, and so long as they have access to the software that encoded the file structure and character codes employed in the bit stream of this document, and so long as they can still find or recreate the computing environment necessary to run that software, and so long as they can still breathe or see/So long lives this . . ." 
 As that suggests (and as anyone who has lost the only copy of precious computer data can confirm), preserving information in digital form is far more daunting than filing sheets of paper or shelving rolls of microfilm. The problems have been studied in library, archive and academic circles, but their implications are now becoming clear to the wider world.
Donald Waters, director of the Digital Library Federation, a consortium of large research libraries and archives, said the issue was not merely a matter of technology. "It's also legal, organizational and financial," Mr. Waters said. The simple question of how much information has already been lost is difficult to answer. "There are lots of examples, but people are very unwilling to talk about them," he said. "This is a very sensitive topic."
The instances most often cited date to an era that in computer terms is ancient history. From 1976 through 1979, the National Archives worked on recovering certain 1960 census data from tapes designed to run on long-obsolete machines. By the mid-1980's, computerized land-use maps of New York State produced in the 1960's became unavailable; the State Archives found that the software required to analyze the data had not been stored with it and that the hardware and operating system no longer existed, so the original data remain available only in printed form. In another instance, satellite observations of Brazil in the 1970's were lost irretrievably.
Newer material, particularly complex multimedia software, is hardly immune. Last year, when a museum asked Jaron Lanier, a pioneer in virtual reality research, to display a video game called Moondust, which he had written in 1982 for the popular Commodore 64 computer, he had to track down a machine of precisely that vintage (but no newer), along with a joystick and video interface that could work with it. To play a CD-ROM called "How Computers Work" in a traveling exhibit recently, Carl Goodman, a curator of digital media at the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, had to borrow a vintage Macintosh; current models could not read the disk.
The archival problems begin with the furtive nature of digital data storage itself. Paper may crumble, but its condition is usually obvious based on its appearance. But for a typical disk or tape, short of running it in the proper computer, there is no easy way to determine whether it holds data or whether the information is deteriorating. For a variety of reasons, including the life of coatings and physical materials and the deterioration of magnetic impulses, magnetic media like tape and disks do not last nearly as long as acid-free paper even when they are merely sitting on a shelf. Not even optical media like CD-ROM are permanent.
Data from the National Media Laboratory suggest that the longevity of tapes and optical media depends not only on their quality, which can vary widely, but also on storage conditions, cold and dry being better than warm and humid. Without special storage, lower-quality media should typically survive two to five years, but only certain high-quality optical media are likely to last 100.
That is why Bill Gates's privately held image-bank company, Corbis, "refreshes" its data tapes by copying them every few years onto more advanced ones that typically hold more data in the same space and last longer. Still, Tony Rojas, the company's president, said that of the company's 1.3 million digital images, 50 had been lost because of media failures. The National Archives keeps two copies of its tapes and refreshes them every 10 years.
But physically maintaining data does not begin to guarantee their survival because the devices that create the data quickly disappear. "The media become obsolete even faster than they become unreadable," Mr. Rothenberg said.
A standard cassette tape holding information created on a now-vanished early personal computer is likely to be unreadable even if it still retains its data. Eight-inch floppy disks and drives, popular as recently as a dozen years ago, are now virtually extinct, and their 5 1/4-inch successors are rapidly disappearing. Optical and magnetic disks recorded under nonstandard storage schemes will be increasingly useless because of the lack of working equipment to read them.
"People are also talking about the notion of migration," Mr. Rothenberg said, "which means you not only have to copy the bits, you have to worry about the fact that the software that you used to create and read the document has become entirely obsolete." Documents created with obsolete word processors or old versions of current processors can often be converted to newer formats, but formatting and even footnotes may be lost in the process, which may have to be repeated again and again over the years. Mr. Rothenberg likened it to the parlor game of telephone, where a whispered message is often garbled beyond recognition by the time it is repeated five or six times.
Storing the information in standard formats can minimize the readability problem, which is why repositories like the National Archives insist on receiving documents only in the most plain-vanilla forms, like ASCII text. But standard formats typically do not retain information about such things as fonts and formatting, and they are hopelessly inadequate for representing files with hypertext, sound or video. Moreover, formats that seem standard today may change; today's ASCII scheme, for example, may one day give way to a standard known as Unicode, which is better able to represent the characters of languages other than English.
Mr. Rothenberg prefers the idea of storing documents in their original forms and formats, with the software that created them and is typically required to view them. But 100 years hence, what machines could possibly run that software or understand those documents? Instead of the actual hardware, which is likely to deteriorate anyway, Mr. Rothenberg favors storing detailed, complete descriptions of it. Then one day software could be created that would let the hardware of the future mimic the hardware of today.
The idea of using one computer to emulate another is not new; the technique is used to let Windows programs run on current Macintosh computers. More than 20 years ago, Bill Gates, Paul Allen and Monte Davidoff developed the original Microsoft BASIC by using a big computer at Harvard University to emulate the dinky Altair 8800, one of the first personal computers, without ever having seen one. An Internet cult has been developing emulators to run code from creaky video arcade games on fast modern computers. Given the speed improvements in computers, said Mr. Rothenberg, "the thing I worry about most is that if I emulate current software 100 years from now, it will work too fast."
But emulating today's complex systems is not easy. In a posting to the Web site for the Time and Bits conference in Los Angeles in February at the Getty Museum, Mr. Lanier was skeptical of this approach. In attempting to move his virtual worlds from their original software platform to others, he found that "the transfer process turns out to be impossible," and came to believe it "unlikely that complex, deeply interactive systems will ever be documented to the point of perfect completion." He added that "unlikely" does not mean "impossible" and called the problem "the Everest of computer science."
It is also just the beginning of a mountain of legal, cultural and financial issues that archiving will inevitably entail. For example, the Internet Archive (www.archive.org) stores "snapshots" of the Net for posterity and keeps "dead" content publicly available after it has officially disappeared. The practice raises knotty questions not only about whether storing someone else's data and making them available to the public violates copyright laws, but also about how best to prevent institutions from unmaking history by removing information from public view and how best to maintain archives without compromising creators' intellectual property rights.
Digital archives have the potential to avoid pitfalls that have beset their traditional forebears since the days of the Library of Alexandria. Because perfect digital copies can be made with ease and maintained in a small space, storing precious information at multiple sites can minimize damage from the fire, flood and fungus that threaten traditional media.
Handling can be virtually eliminated; fingers that can damage paper are kept well away from digital media. And digital archives can be much more accessible then their current counterparts. But just because an archive is maintained in digital form does not exempt it from the disastrous consequences of the kinds of decision-making that caused television producers to erase and reuse archival videotapes and film studios to reclaim the silver from one-of-a-kind negatives.
Don Whiting, assistant secretary of state for Washington State, oversees an office charged with maintaining the government archives and grappling with these problems on a daily basis. "One of the things that may make it hard to answer the kinds of questions people face is that the technology moves so fast," Mr. Whiting said.
He knows that problem all too well. In his spare time at home, he is refreshing and upgrading his personal archives. Many of his old files are stored on 5 1/4-inch floppy disks, which his newest machine cannot read. They were created and stored in the format of a program called Framework, which disappeared from the market about a decade ago. In the computer world, those bygone times seem positively Elizabethan.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Ink on paper, as Shakespeare pointed out, can endure for years; witness the shelves of the Library of Congress, right (United Press International). HEADLINE: Broadway's Impact On Economy Grows

 BODY:
The Broadway theater generated $2.7 billion in the city's economy in the 1996-97 season, much of it in restaurants, hotels and other services used by tourists who said they came to New York primarily for a show, a study by the League of American Theaters and Producers says.
That is a 37 percent increase from the economic impact figures in a similar study five years ago, said Jed Bernstein, executive director of the league. 
 The study, produced in partnership with the Alliance for the Arts, found that there was $485 million in direct spending on Broadway. The largest contribution came from indirect tourist spending, which had an economic impact of $1.7 billion, the study concluded.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Sorry, Game Over

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
At this time each year world leaders prepare for the annual June G-7 summit meeting by asking themselves: What should we talk about this year? Every year they come up with some phony theme. Well, I've got an idea. Let's have them talk about something really important. Let's make this year's G-7 about Japan. Even though this year's summit will be in Birmingham, England, I say serve those G-7 leaders sushi and rice for every meal, make them attend origami classes and tea ceremonies, and list every item on the agenda as: "Discussion about Japan." That's right, let's really spotlight Japan. Who knows, maybe that will help trigger the only thing that will really stimulate Japan's economy: a revolution.
Why should you care? Because Asia today is sinking into recession. In an effort to climb out, all the Asians are trying to use their cheap currencies to increase exports and stoke up growth. But someone has to buy all those exports. And if Japan, the world's second-largest economy after the U.S., won't take its share, everyone is going to try to export to America. That, in turn, could send the U.S. trade deficit soaring, shrink the earnings of U.S. multinationals, spark a strong protectionist backlash in America and end the long boom in the U.S. economy. 
 I'd say that's worth talking about at a G-7 meeting, especially since Japan, despite seven lean years of virtually no growth, still can't stimulate its economy, because it has political and economic arteriosclerosis. Politically speaking, Japan today is like Japan near the end of World War II: Tokyo was burned to the ground, Nagasaki and Hiroshima had been flattened, the Japanese fleet was at the bottom of the ocean. But the Japanese political leadership would meet each day in the Emperor's bunker and none of them could bring themselves to tell him: "Game over." Finally, the Emperor had to do it himself, telling the Japanese people they had to swallow their tears and surrender.
Well, today unfortunately there is no all-powerful Japanese Emperor. So Japan's politicians are home alone in their bunker, still dithering over who will tell the people that they have to surrender to the global economy. The old Japanese system -- top-down capitalism, protected by high trade barriers -- cannot be sustained in today's new, fast-paced, integrated information age.
"Japan can't stimulate effectively unless the system is changed," argues Clyde Prestowitz, head of the Economic Strategy Institute and a longtime analyst of the Japanese economy. "You cannot have a macroeconomic solution in Japan without a micro solution."
That's because Japanese consumers won't spend and Japanese banks won't lend -- without radical reforms. Japan's banks are in feeble shape, notes Mr. Prestowitz, so when the Government tries to inject money into the banking system (usually by propping up the stock market), the Japanese banks keep the money to shore up their balance sheets, and don't make any new loans. Until the Japanese Government does an American-style S.&L. bailout, and takes the bad loans off the books of the Japanese banks, it will be hard for them to contribute to a stimulus.
Meanwhile Japanese consumers, who in the best of times save too much and in uncertain times do so even more, tend to take tax cuts and stuff a lot of it in their mattresses. One reason Japanese consumers don't spend is because everything in Japan is so expensive, because the economy is so regulated and full of hidden monopolies and tariffs. Without some real move to open the Japanese economy, Japanese consumers, who have trillions of dollars in savings stashed away, are never going to buy enough from the rest of the world.
But Japan's macroeconomic policies have also been wanting. The Japanese Government keeps offering what the U.S. Deputy Treasury Secretary, Lawrence Summers, rightly calls "virtual fiscal policy" -- phantom spending programs and voodoo tax cuts that not only haven't stimulated the Japanese economy but have actually left it contracting at a time of already slow growth, a la Herbert Hoover.
Japan needs an economic revolution. For now, though, there is no ruling or opposition figure there to articulate and lead that revolution. So either America and its G-7 partners will do it, by hammering Japan, or a major economic catastrophe will do it, by hammering us all.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.N. Report Criticizes U.S. for 'Racist' Use of Death Penalty

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, April 6

 BODY:
The United States has been accused of unfair, arbitrary and racist use of the death penalty by a United Nations special investigator in a report here at a meeting of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.
Overriding American objections, the commission voted last week for the second year in a row to call for a worldwide moratorium on executions. 
 The author of the United Nations report, Bacre Waly Ndiaye, a lawyer from Senegal, wrote that "race, ethnic origin and economic status appear to be key determinants of who will, and who will not, receive a sentence of death" in the United States. The report was presented to the commission last week.
Mr. Ndiaye is an independent expert appointed by the commission to investigate extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions worldwide.
He traveled in the United States from Sept. 21 to Oct. 8 last year and based his findings on meetings with Federal officials and officials in New York, Florida, Texas and California, and on visits to death rows.
In the 65-page report, Mr. Ndiaye said he found "a significant degree of unfairness and arbitrariness" in the death penalty's use. Considerations aside from the crime itself often influence whether the death sentence is imposed, he said, contending that such considerations include the race and economic level of both the victim and the accused. Mr. Ndiaye urged that the United States stop executions at least until it can assure fair and impartial application.
He rejected the argument that there is broad public support for capital punishment in the United States. "In many countries, mob killings and lynchings enjoy public support as a way to deal with violent crime and are often portrayed as 'popular justice,' " he wrote. "Yet they are not acceptable in any civilized society."
He said that "allegations of racial discrimination in the imposition of death sentences are particularly serious in southern states such as Alabama, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, Georgia and Texas, known as the 'death penalty belt.' "
Some Federal and state officials refused to see him during his visit. Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, called the mission an "absurd U.N. charade," and urged the State Department not to cooperate. He made his comments in an angry letter to the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Bill Richardson, who later commented that the report would only "collect a lot of dust."
Mr. Ndiaye's report was issued late Friday, just before the Commission voted 26 to 13, with others abstaining, to continue its call for a general moratorium on executions, with the goal of eventually abolishing them globally.
The Commission has 53 delegate nations at any one time, with a system of rotating three-year terms.
In addition to the United States, the opponents included China, Congo and the Sudan. George Moose, the American delegate to the United Nations in Geneva, defended each country's right "to decide this issue through its own democratic process."
"We believe that in a democratic society, the criminal justice system, including the punishments prescribed for the most serious crimes, should reflect the will of the people freely expressed and appropriately implemented," Mr. Moose said at the commission meeting.
Despite the commission's vote, many countries retain the penalty. A recent report by the United Nations Secretary General says that 90 countries have capital punishment, while 61 have formally abolished it.
But while the number of countries doing away with the death sentence has been increasing, the United States has greatly extended its use, since it was reinstated in 1976, particularly to punish Federal crimes, Mr. Ndiaye said.
The United States, Iran, Nigeria, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and Yemen are the only countries where offenders under age 18 can be executed, the report said, adding that this violates international law.
Executing mentally handicapped defendants, a practice allowed in 28 of the 38 American states that have capital punishment, is a breach of international standards, the report said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Networks Turn to Affiliates To Defray Program Costs

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
Since the earliest days of radio in the 1920's, one principle has governed the relationship between networks and the hundreds of stations around the country affiliated with them: The networks put on the programs and they paid the stations a fee to broadcast them.
Now, in what would be a fundamental restructuring of the economics of broadcasting, executives at several of the networks are trying to redefine that relationship. In interviews over the last week, several senior network executives, including Robert A. Iger, the president of ABC Inc., and Neal Braun, the president of the NBC television network, argued that the system was anachronistic and increasingly unrealistic at a time when program costs have escalated and network profits have eroded drastically. 
 In recent months, networks have asked stations to help defray the costs of specific programs like National Football League games. But the executives latest proposals would go further. Among the changes being contemplated: selling affiliated stations commercial time now owned by the networks during the prime-time hours and ending program exclusivity arrangements with affiliated stations so that networks can sell more of their programs to secondary buyers like cable channels.
Any such moves will likely bring the networks into conflict with the affiliates, whose executives have resisted any actions the networks have suggested that would reverse the policy of paying fees, called compensation, for carrying network programs. They have also pointed out that the networks are now owned by huge conglomerates, such as Walt Disney, which owns ABC, and General Electric, which owns NBC, that can easily absorb the extra cost of programs.
The three major networks -- Fox pays no compensation -- now pay between $175 million and $200 million each annually to hundreds of affiliated stations. The new moves are designed to raise money from affiliates without taking them on directly over the issue of compensation. The $175 million paid out by ABC last year was almost equal to the network's total profit on more than $3 billion in sales.
"The economic model that exists between networks and stations has to be re-examined," Mr. Iger said. "Competition has increased for viewers and advertisers and program content. We are going to need help and we are going to have to get it. I'm not embarrassed about having asked for it and I'd be very disappointed not to get it."
Mr. Braun said: "The world has changed. The historic relationship between affiliates and networks no longer works on an economic basis."
Mr. Iger said that stations would have to begin helping pay their networks for the cost of such high-priced programming as N.F.L. football, the Academy Awards, and the drama "E.R."
Mr. Iger, who addressed the need for change in the network-station relationship in a keynote speech at the National Association of Broadcasters convention in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday, said last week that ABC had a plan that would allow local stations to buy commercial time from ABC that is actually more valuable when sold locally.
"If we have a spot that sells for, say $100,000, the local stations might be able to sell it collectively for $150,000," he said. Without specifying figures, Mr. Iger said the amount of money ABC could recoup in this way was significant. "It will help us with the N.F.L. deal," he added.
Mr. Iger said ABC was challenging affiliated stations by beginning to replay programs on cable channels that compete with the the network's affiliates. That policy is bitterly opposed by many station managers, who insist that they have exclusive rights to network programs for at least one year.
At NBC, Mr. Braun said the network had put together a large-scale proposal to restructure the network-affiliates relationship, which he said he intended to send to affiliates in the next month. Mr. Braun said the affiliates continued to resist the notion of helping networks because "they don't want to cross that line -- it's ideological."
The networks, in recent months, have made several expensive programming deals. ABC committed to spend $550 million a year for "Monday Night Football" this coming season, up from $230 million. (It also committed to paying $600 million for Sunday night football on its all-sports cable channel, ESPN, up from $124 million.)
Similarly, NBC agreed to pay $13 million an episode for "E.R.," a total of of $286 million a year, up from about $40 million. The deal, along with higher rights fees for National Basketball Association basketball, is expected to cut deeply into NBC's substantial profits this year, estimated at more than $500 million.
CBS also spent so lavishly on football -- $500 million a year -- that it is widely expected that the network will not make any profit next year.
CBS had asked stations to help defray the costs of football programming, but CBS executves last week declined to comment on whether they would see further changes.
The affiliates are made up of small, individually owned stations and large groups owned by such companies as the Gannett Company and the A. H. Belo Corporation. Station profit margins can reach as high as 50 percent and the value of stations has increased markedly in the last decade as more and more stations have become affiliated with networks.
David Barrett, the chairman of the ABC affiliate board, has already informed ABC that affiliates "would be strongly opposed to contributing cash" to help pay for the football deal. Mr. Barrett, the executive vice president of Hearst-Argyle Broadcasting, which owns 10 ABC affiliates, sounded a note cited by many affiliates managers when he categorized the football deals as a "strategic corporate decision" by Disney, which "will derive benefits far beyond the price they are paying." Disney, for example, could make N.F.L. games the centerpiece of many other ESPN programs.
In 1994, the networks were forced into long-term deals with local stations -- some as long as 10 years -- after the upstart Fox network stole a large number of affiliated stations away from the other three networks.
Had the raids not occurred, Mr. Iger said, "I think you would have seen at least a leveling off and probably a continuing decrease in compensation." Instead, he said, "compensation went up hundreds of millions of dollars."
Mr. Braun said he had hopes that station managers would respond to NBC's proposals. Otherwise, he said, the conversations might get a lot tougher as affiliate deals begin to run out. "If these network-station issues are not addressed, there is going to be some sort of adversarial escalation," Mr. Braun said. "I'm desperately trying to avoid an adversarial escalation."
