HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Closes Above 9,000 For First Time

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Propelled by news of the biggest corporate merger in history, the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 9,000 for the first time yesterday.
The blue-chip barometer, which crossed 8,000 less than nine months ago, has ridden a swell of money into stock mutual funds and a conviction that the current benign economic conditions can continue indefinitely. 
 But the last 1,000-point move has been one of the rockier ones in recent memory, including a period of worldwide unease when Asian economies were in turmoil.
The Dow crossed the 9,000 level on Friday, only to back off, but climbed 49.82 points yesterday, to 9,033.23. The biggest gainer in the index was Travelers Group, which announced in the morning that it would merge with Citicorp to form the world's largest financial services company in a stock swap valued at more than $70 billion. The news buoyed shares of other financial services companies, including J. P. Morgan and Merrill Lynch, as investors placed bets on further combinations.
Despite the Dow's historic climb, broader market gauges faltered. Citicorp's gain of 37 5/8 was not enough to bolster the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which slipped 1.32 points, to 1,121.38. And the Nasdaq composite index, a key technology barometer, fell 26.26 points, to 1,829.14, led by losses in Microsoft, Intel and Dell Computer.
On the New York Stock Exchange, declining issues outnumbered advancers by 1,727 to 1,318.
The lackluster performance of other market gauges reflected some analysts' concerns that stocks might be overvalued and some uneasiness about first-quarter earnings reports, scheduled to begin in earnest next week.
"I'm not sure it would have gotten there without the merger," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company. "This market is probably a little ahead of itself."
In fact, mergers have played a big role in the market's gains this year. As of yesterday, more than 2,500 deals valued at more than $316.5 billion had been announced, according to the Securities Data Company. That represents an increase of more than 50 percent from the $200 billion worth of deals announced in the comparable period of 1997. So far this year, there have been fewer deals over all, but an increasing number of very large deals, with many being done for stock. To many investors that indicates that corporations do not believe that market values are too high.
While earlier concerns about Asian economies seem to be lessening, economists still expect the slowdown in that region to thwart strong worldwide growth of American companies.
South Korea expects this week to borrow $3 billion from bond investors, paying interest rates far less than would have seemed possible only a few months ago. At the same time, Robotic Vision Systems, a maker of vision systems that examine semiconductors for flaws, became the latest company to point to Asia as a source of trouble, saying it expected to post a loss for its second quarter because of a slowdown in the semiconductor industry, which it attributed in part to Asia's economic crisis.
Yesterday, Asian markets were mostly lower, although Japan's benchmark Nikkei rose 1.21 percent, posting its first gain in four days.
The Dow's move has come despite evidence that the United States economy is slowing. Last week, the Government reported that the number of people with jobs declined in March, and so many companies have posted disappointing profits that I.B.E.S. International now says Wall Street analysts expect first-quarter profits for the companies in the S.& P. 500 to decline from a year earlier. As 1998 began, those analysts expected a 9.7 percent gain.
Nonetheless, investors appear to be generally optimistic that Asia's woes, which have hurt some corporate profits, will not cause a serious problem for the American economy.
And despite the notes of caution, most analysts and investors are betting that the bull market will continue once first-quarter earnings have been digested.
"Investors are willing to buy stocks because they think the profit growth will continue," said Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. While corporate earnings growth may not be as robust as it has been, "what matters is the durability and the longevity" of the trend, she added.
There was no such confidence in October, when the Dow completed its first-ever 1,000-point decline, having fallen to 7,161.15 on Oct. 27, from 8,259.31 on Aug. 6. Then there was worldwide concern that the Asian crisis would have dire effects. But markets rallied after that, and rising prices reassured investors.
The run of the Dow also marked another milestone. On March 2, the index passed 8,546, meaning it was up 1,000 percent from the 1982 low of 776.92. That 1,000 percent move took less than 16 years. By contrast, the previous record for a 1,000 percent rise, coming off the Depression low in July 1932, took 23 years.
Earlier this year, the flow of money into stock mutual funds seemed to be slowing, perhaps because of Asian concerns. But it has picked up dramatically in recent weeks, in part as investors put money into individual retirement accounts.
The run from 8,000 to 9,000 has nonetheless been a shaky one. Of the 30 Dow stocks, nine are lower than they were when the average hit 8,000. Those are, by and large, industrial and commodity companies, including Boeing, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, Alcoa and International Paper, which need a strong world economy. The leaders are much more reliant on a healthy American economy, where the current low-interest rate environment has facilitated some of the merger moves. The eight Dow stocks up more than 30 percent are AT&T, Travelers, Wal-Mart, Walt Disney, Merck, American Express, General Motors and J. P. Morgan.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Group Strikes Blow at U.S. Environmental Law

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
In a decision that could undercut the use of trade sanctions to promote global environmental goals, the World Trade Organization ruled today that the United States was wrong to prohibit shrimp imports from countries that fail to protect sea turtles from deadly entrapment in the trawls of shrimping boats.
The decision by a three-member panel in Geneva was the latest sign that when free trade conflicts with environmental protection, the international trade body is unlikely to swerve from its central mission of promoting trade. 
 The Clinton Administration responded defiantly, but officials did not detail how they would pursue a policy required by United States law.
"We believe the W.T.O. panel reached the wrong conclusion," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative. She said it "does not affect our efforts to protect endangered sea turtles."
The large reptiles, at risk of extinction, are especially threatened by the shrimping boat nets that entangle and drown them.
The United States requires shrimpers in its waters to equip nets with metal grills that exclude turtles and other large animals, and in 1989 Congress passed a law prohibiting shrimp imports from countries not requiring these devices in their fleets.
Shiv Mukherjee, the minister for press at the Indian Embassy in Washington, called his nation's petition to the W.T.O., which was joined by Thailand, Pakistan and Malaysia, "a matter of principle" in opposing trade barriers.
"Our shrimp exports are one of our significant items on our export list," he said, adding that shrimping is a labor-intensive industry that employs hundreds of thousands of people. "That was a demand of the United States that would have had a significant impact if allowed to stand."
The panel found that even under the provisions of the W.T.O. agreement that allow environmental exceptions, the United States would not be permitted to force other nations to adopt policies to protect an endangered species like the turtle.
"There isn't a strong basis for arguing a pro-environment position within the W.T.O.," said Robert F. Lawrence, an international trade lawyer with Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. "The environment is going to take a back seat whenever there is a direct and open conflict with open and free trade."
The trade body has ruled before against the United States on issues involving protection for dolphins and requirements for cleaner-burning gasoline, but conservation groups reacted especially strongly to this case, citing its broad implications as well as the plight of the turtles.
In affirming an earlier, preliminary decision that the American embargo violated trade rules, the trade organization said that while environmental considerations were important, the primary aim of international agreements on trade remained the promotion of economic development through unfettered trade.
Clinton Administration officials, who had expected the ruling, said they would likely appeal. But they said several other options were also under consideration -- including simply disregarding the report, which could lead to fines or countervailing trade barriers against the offenders of the turtle protection law.
The trade organization has no power to overturn a United States law. If the Administration does not win on appeal, it may try to change the shrimp import rules to accommodate today's ruling, although officials said they were unsure how they would accomplish that.
Conservation groups called on the Administration to defy the W.T.O. decision and seek international talks aimed at reshaping how the trade group addresses environmental issues.
"It is unthinkable that we should not be allowed to mitigate the impacts of our own shrimp markets on endangered sea turtles," said Deborah Crouse, senior conservation scientist at the Center for Marine Conservation, a Washington-based advocacy group.
"This entire life form is threatened with extinction," she said.
The United States imports most of the shrimp that Americans consume, some caught in the wild but most raised in coastal farms.
After prohibiting imports of shrimp caught by boats that might kill turtles, the United States negotiated agreements with several countries, especially in the Caribbean region, to protect turtles from shrimping boats. The United States provided foreign aid to help pay for the expense of installing turtle excluders. More than three dozen countries have been certified by the United States as safe shrimpers, either for having adopted the devices or as fishing only in waters where turtles are not usually found.
Daniel Seligman, director of the responsible trade campaign at the Sierra Club, said the trade organization's decision was much broader and made it difficult to envision how trade sanctions could be used to promote environmental causes.
"This is the clearest slap at environmental protection to come out of the W.T.O. to date," he said.

HEADLINE: A Good Time to End Tobacco Quotas

BYLINE: By Richard G. Lugar; Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican, is chairman of the Senate Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Several anti-smoking groups, including the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, the American Cancer Society and the American Heart Association, have recently taken a position that is at odds with their goals. They want the comprehensive tobacco legislation, currently being debated in Congress, to preserve a Federal program that regulates the amount of tobacco that can be grown and the price at which it is sold.
Currently only farmers with Government-granted quotas may grow tobacco, and they profit heavily from this control. Anti-smoking groups believe that this system keeps the price of cigarettes higher than it would be otherwise. 
 But maintaining the Federal Government's sponsorship of tobacco production, marketing and warehousing is wrong -- both morally and economically.
Ending the program would have a negligible impact on the price of cigarettes. True, cutting quotas would cause the price of leaf tobacco to fall. But only six cents of the approximately $2.00 cost of a pack of cigarettes is attributable to the tobacco itself.
Economists testifying in Senate hearings estimated that ending quotas would cause the price of domestic leaf tobacco to drop by about 25 percent, as more and more farmers entered the market, increasing supply.
This would translate into only about a 1.5-cent difference in the price of cigarettes. Nobody can reasonably argue that a penny and a half would have any effect on teen-age behavior or consumer demand. Moreover, if Congress passes the comprehensive tobacco bill it is considering, the price of cigarettes might rise as high as $3.50 per pack. In that event, the one-and-a-half-cent difference would amount to less than one-half of 1 percent of the price of a pack of cigarettes.
Health groups are also concerned that the drop in the price of tobacco will raise the profits of cigarette companies. But with Congress about to pass legislation that would raise cigarette prices by as much as $1.50 per pack, why would we use a byzantine Federal program to protect 1.5 cents of the current price? Would it not make far more sense to offset the drop in tobacco prices in whatever legislation Congress may pass?
As everyone involved in the debate over smoking recognizes, we cannot end the price supports for tobacco unless the tobacco bill not only raises the cost of cigarettes and limits advertising to children, but also forces cigarette companies to pay hundreds of billions of dollars in smoking-related health care costs. Otherwise, there would be no money to buy out the tobacco farmers.
As chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, I have introduced a bill that would be part of the comprehensive tobacco legislation. It would buy out the tobacco quotas of farmers at $8 per pound. This one-time cost of $15 billion would end Federal price supports, while fairly compensating farmers who have depended on these quotas.
Many farmers want out of tobacco farming, but cannot afford to abandon it without help. Continuing the current program would not only trap the Federal Government into aiding the production of tobacco, it would trap many individual farmers as well.
The tobacco price supports probably cannot be sustained in any case. Domestic demand for tobacco is falling, and the quality of foreign tobacco continues to improve. The tobacco legislation may be our last chance to do right by these farmers.
Comprehensive legislation would not have been possible without the work of anti-smoking groups. But if the Federal Government's anti-smoking efforts are to succeed, its policies must be consistent. The Government should not support the production of tobacco, while it spends billions of dollars on tobacco-related health care costs and anti-smoking campaigns.
This dual course is simply contradictory and wrong, and it weakens the Government's message to the public about the dangers of smoking.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS: THE MARKETS -- Market Place;
Motorola issues some relatively good news, then some bad.

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
MOTOROLA Inc. reported late yesterday that it had managed to match Wall Street's diminished expectations for its first-quarter earnings, but any likelihood that investors in technology companies would take that as good news was dashed when the company warned that its second quarter was shaping up much more poorly than projected.
"This doesn't look good," said John Lazlo, who follows technology stocks for Paine Webber in San Francisco. "Most people felt that the first quarter would be the trough." 
 Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., said that it earned $180 million, or 30 cents a share on a diluted basis, in the first quarter, down 45 percent from $325 million, or 53 cents a share a year earlier. Revenues were $6.9 billion, up 4 percent from a year earlier.
Excluding $54 million from asset sales and other one-time gains, the telecommunications and semiconductor giant had operating earnings of $142 million, or 23 cents a share, right in line with what analysts had projected after being warned a month ago to reduce their estimates.
Last month's warning had focused attention on the problems Motorola and other major technology companies were facing as a result of Asian currency declines and the resulting economic woes in several key Asian countries. Motorola had issued its bad news on the heels of a warning from the Intel Corporation, another technology bellwether, that its earnings would be below projections. But at the time Motorola had also injected a note of hope when it said that it had seen signs that Asia's economic problems were abating.
Yesterday, though, Christopher Galvin, Motorola's chief executive, said that problems in Asia might continue for "several more quarters." The company also said that it was being hurt by weakening demand for pagers and analog cellular telephones in the United States.
"Second-quarter sales are expected to be below those of a year ago," Mr. Galvin said. "Second-quarter earnings are expected to be well below current investment community expectations and could be equal to or less than 1998 first-quarter earnings."
The earnings and disappointing forecast were released after trading had ended on the New York Stock Exchange, where Motorola's share price fell 31.25 cents, to $59.875. Analysts were awaiting the chance to question the company in a conference call scheduled for early today.
Motorola has long been among the most widely held of technology stocks, but its usefulness as a barometer for the sector has been questionable for some time. Analysts say that many of its problems, especially in the wireless communications business, result from poor execution rather than industrywide pressures.
Motorola's largest business, the cellular phone group, increased sales to $2.81 billion in the first quarter as demand grew for the company's new digital products, but overall orders were flat and operating profits dropped as sales of its older, analog products fell sharply. The semiconductor business, which sells many of its products to the cellular group and other Motorola operations as well as externally, had a 4 percent decline in orders, although sales edged up 1 percent, to $1.83 billion.
Motorola's radio sector had a 27 percent increase in sales, to $1.24 billion; increased profits, and a 2 percent growth in new orders. But that was partly offset by the messaging sector, which includes paging products, where sales tumbled 25 percent, to $693 million, orders fell 21 percent and Motorola lost money. Motorola said that the paging decline reflected efforts by retailers to reduce inventory and that sales to consumers in the key North American and Chinese markets appeared to still be growing.

HEADLINE: Union Organizer's Warm and Chilly Reinstatement

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: SOLVAY, N.Y., April 6

 BODY:
More than a year after being dismissed from her job, Kathy Saumier went back to work at a plastics factory here today with a little band of union supporters outside to applaud her, and her dogged effort to unionize workers still ahead.
It was the first time Ms. Saumier had stepped inside Landis Plastics since February, 1997, when the company charged her with sexually harassing male workers and dismissed her. Over the months of her appeals, Ms. Saumier has become something of a local hero in this factory town just northwest of Syracuse, especially since March, when a Federal District Court judge issued a preliminary injunction ordering the company to take Ms. Saumier back. The judge said the dismissal was in reprisal for Ms. Saumier's pro-union activities, rather than for sexual harassment. 
 If anything, the time off has re-energized Ms. Saumier, a product of the city's working-class West Side.
"I'm going to go back and do the job I get paid for, and I'm going to go in and organize this place and get a union in there," Ms. Saumier said in an interview Sunday night. "I'm going to do what I have always done."
About a dozen supporters, including two prominent religious leaders in Syracuse, gathered in the chill of the early morning to see Ms. Saumier back to work.
"In this Holy Week we think of Moses going to the Pharoah to let his people go," the Rev. William L. Coop, a Presbyterian minister who heads the Labor and Religion Coalition of Central New York, said to the little band. Turning to Ms. Saumier, he continued, "Maybe you're going to be not only Norma Rae but Moses as you go back in there and help your people get fair representation in a safe workplace."
Bishop Tom Costello of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Syracuse also came to show his support. He said he first began following her case when she raised concerns about the plant's poor safety record, and became a supporter when she was dismissed.
"Some of us feel that Kathy was done an injustice," Bishop Costello said, "and we did not want her to think she didn't have any friends."
Inside the plant, which is appealing the injunction, Ms. Saumier did not face as welcoming a reception. Most workers on the floor who could take time to answer questions were noncommittal about her return. And Kimberly Holden, a vocal union opponent and a critic of Ms. Saumier, strongly objected to the religious leaders' accompanying Ms. Saumier. "They're not reading the same Bible I read," Ms. Holden, a stacker at the print machines, said.
At first, it might seem odd that there would be any doubts about organizing a plant here in central New York, where big industry and big unions have long worked together at places like the Crucible Steel Company, the Anheuser-Busch brewery and the Carrier Corporation air-conditioning equipment plant.
Yet the idea of voting in a union still seems to scare some of the workers at Landis, most of whom are women, and many of those single mothers. Several said they were a job or two away from fast-food work, which pays much less than the $7 to $9 an hour that is a typical wage in this plant.
Random and unsupervised interviews inside and outside the plant today revealed some distinct support for a union, some adamant hatred of the very idea, and a lot of wariness in between. "This is a particularly vulnerable group of people, or at least, they feel vulnerable," said Robert J. Rabin, a law professor who follows labor law issues at Syracuse University. "They feel terribly uncertain about their place in the economy, and Landis is a newcomer -- they have facilities in other states -- and I think people are afraid that if Landis is unhappy with the outcome, it could pick up and move."
Tenille Terranova, 21, who makes $9.70 an hour stacking and inspecting yogurt cups that tumble from a machine, could be one of the women Mr. Rabin had in mind. "If there was an election right now? I think I'd vote no, personally," she said. "I don't really see where we need a union, and there seems to be a lot of trouble around them."
Trouble is what Ms. Saumier got in buckets when the optical shop she was working for closed and she got a job at the Landis plant in April 1995, six months after it opened.
A 36-year old single mother of two, she began attending organizing meetings held by the United Steelworkers of America so she could raise her complaints about unsafe working conditions around the big, chugging machines, and about undependable worker compensation payments.
With the union's help, Ms. Saumier obtained Landis's workplace injury reports and discovered that the company was one of the most accident-prone in the region, with four workers losing their fingers or parts of fingers in one 13-month period. She also found that the family-owned company, based in Chicago Ridge, Ill., was underreporting its injury rate to the New York State Workers' Compensation Board and to the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration.
In late 1996, the Workers Compensation Board fined Landis $48,000, which it paid, for failure to report on-the-job injuries, and in January 1997, OSHA imposed one of its heaviest fines ever, $720,700, on the plant for deliberately underreporting the number and severity of injuries there. Landis is contesting the Federal fine.
Although they disputed the severity of their safety record at the time, Steve Ellis, the plant's manager, conceded today that accidents had gone unreported, and that a large investment in safety equipment made last year was badly needed. And in a speech to company employees on Friday, Greg Landis, the company's chief operating officer, told the plant's 250 workers to accept Ms. Saumier's return.
"Everybody is to be treated equally, with dignity and respect," Mr. Landis said, according to an abbreviated version of his talk released by the company. "Whatever your feelings may be about Kathy, leave 'em outside."
Whatever the workers think of Ms. Saumier and her return, their ideas about forming a union at Landis seems to have more to do with their own experiences and struggles in life.
Evelyn Davis, for example, said she did not mind Landis's practice of imposing penalty points for tardiness that, if accumulated, can lead to dismissal. "I think it's good that they just give you points," Ms. Davis said, "because you have a chance to work them off if you're not late for a while."
Ms. Davis, 28 and with a young son to care for, said she had worked at a linen service that docked her pay 15 minutes in wages for every 5 minutes she was late.
Besides Ms. Saumier, a second worker, Clara Sullivan, who was dismissed on charges of racial and sexual harassment, was also returned to work today under the order. Judge Rosemary S. Pooler ordered the reinstatement of the two workers after the National Labor Relations Board filed 77 charges against Landis, accusing it of unfair labor practices involving the two workers and several others.
But Judge Pooler's ruling is only a preliminary one. An administrative law judge is expected to rule over the next few months on all 77 charges, including the charges involving the two women.
The Steelworkers have refused to hold a union vote at Landis until all 77 charges have been resolved. To do less, Jim Valenti, a senior union official, said, would be like letting the workers vote "while Greg Landis has a gun to their head."
As for being a symbol of labor, Ms. Saumier just shakes her head.
"I don't know how I got that," she said at last, smiling. "I never asked for it. I just got ticked off."

HEADLINE: Some Black Americans Find Only a Chill in South Africa

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, April 6

 BODY:
Charles T. Moses, raised in New York City and once Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's adviser for black affairs, lives these days in the northern suburbs of Johannesburg, eager to make a contribution to the new South Africa.
With a master's degree in business administration, Mr. Moses says, he has skills to offer a country that has too few educated blacks and which -- since voting in its first black government in 1994 -- has suffered a huge brain drain caused by fleeing whites. 
 But like many African-Americans who come here, some with an almost missionary zeal, he has not always been received with open arms by black South Africans. For Mr. Moses, a recent Op-Ed article in an influential Johannesburg newspaper suggesting that black Americans were taking jobs that would otherwise go to black South Africans was the last straw.
"While black South Africans say African-Americans leave something to be desired, some African-Americans can offer similar comments," Mr. Moses wrote in The Sunday Independent, which published the article to which he was responding. "Many of us have been lied to, misled and abused by our South African brothers and sisters, usually out of jealously and ignorance."
While President Clinton's recent trip to Africa was aimed at focusing the world's attention on this continent, many black Americans turned their attention here long ago and in recent years have come to South Africa in the hope of helping to build a prosperous black nation.
After Mr. Moses' article, South Africa's Oprah Winfrey, Felicia Mabuza-Suttle, devoted two one-hour programs to the subject of tensions between black South Africans and black Americans, putting a spotlight on difficulties that have largely, until recently, just been whispered about.
The South Africans on her show, an academic and two business executives, pulled no punches. The Americans, they said, were patronizing, socialized among themselves and believed they were owed something because of their efforts to support anti-apartheid boycotts.
One of the panelists was Makaziwe Mandela, President Nelson Mandela's daughter and an executive with the state-owned rail company.
Despite the public airing of tensions, the topic remains sensitive and South Africans and Americans are reluctant to be quoted on the subject. But one South African executive involved in helping American companies settle here said that at least one company she knows of has decided not to send African-Americans here anymore.
"A lot of the black Americans come here expecting to find their brothers and sisters," the executive said. "But they don't share a common language or culture or background. All they share is their black skin."
Moreover, she said, "a lot of South Africans see the black Americans as false affirmative action and there is some resentment for companies that do it."
The tension is particularly heartbreaking for Americans like Mr. Moses, who say they came here with the best of intentions.
"We are here to help if we can," he said. "We want them to succeed. It's a vicarious pleasure thing."
Though there are no accurate statistics, most experts estimate that about 1,000 black Americans are working here. Many have come as representatives of the 300 American companies that have established footholds here. But others come to work for nonprofit groups or as freelancers.
For many the experience is also a way of getting away from the difficulties of being black in America.
Junette Pinkney, a former producer for "The Phil Donahue Show" who came here six months ago to do freelance work, said that being in a country where most people are black has been wonderful.
"There is an enormous psychic relief," Ms. Pinkney said. "The American dream never got to be real for me and I'm one of the successful ones. Here, I feel there's the possibility of becoming truly part of this society, of being at home in a way that America will never be home."
Many black Americans do have positive experiences. And in many cases, their color is seen as an asset. One panelist on Mrs. Mabuza-Suttle's program acknowledged that despite his anger at African-Americans he would still rather do business with them than with American whites -- who are also seen as aggressive and insensitive. But the panelist, Peter Luvuyo Ntshona, an executive for Iscor, a major steel producer, said that many black Americans came here with an offensive attitude.
"There is always a paternalism, a sense that we can show you the way," he said. "Now we have a nation and we want them to treat us with dignity, respect and equality."
Too often, he said, the Americans talk about making a sacrifice by coming to what they call a developing country. Mr. Ntshona calls that ludicrous, since most of them live in the fanciest white neighborhoods and have maids and pools.
"They have a wonderful life here," he said. "They are not suffering."
One problem, say some Americans who have been here many years, is that after the 1994 election African-Americans came to South Africa eager to do business. Four years later, many of the projects they touted have not materialized.
"When they didn't happen, people got disappointed and they said African-Americans are all talk," said Julia Wilson, an African-American who moved here in 1994 and started a business, Wilson Global Marketing. One of the services she offers is telling American companies how to behave if they want to succeed.
Mzimkulu Malunga, an editor at The Financial Mail, a weekly business magazine, says black Americans are seen as wanting black South African partners to pave their way into the market here, only to dump them later. White Americans, said Mr. Malunga, might do the same thing. "But at least they don't come here claiming they are home."
In fact, the bond that many black Americans feel with Africa is a source of tension. Ms. Wilson said recently she found herself sitting with a group of South African friends watching a black American entertainer performing in South Africa. The South Africans began betting on exactly when the entertainer would get tears in her eyes and say, "Oh, I'm home, I'm home."
Ms. Wilson says she started to laugh.
"I could see how to them it looks so strange," Ms. Wilson said. "They say: 'But you have no family here. You have nobody waiting for you here. You know nothing about the culture. What are you talking about?' But the Americans are serious. They really do feel like they are home."
Ms. Wilson says that being black can be an asset if you are willing to listen and learn. But she has seen some Americans leave totally crushed. One friend she said cut his two-year contract short after nine months. "He was practically in tears," Ms. Wilson said. "He said,'If a black man cannot be accepted here, where can he go?' "
One especially sensitive point of contention is just how much credit the Americans deserve for bringing apartheid to an end. Mrs. Mabuza-Suttle interspersed her television program with taped interviews with some prominent black Americans, including one with the Rev. Leon Sullivan, who described with obvious pride his role in combating apartheid. Mr. Sullivan devised a set of principles in 1977 for American companies doing business in South Africa; in 1987 he called for corporate withdrawal and disinvestment.
When the tape had finished, a clearly agitated Ms. Mandela said she wanted to make it clear that it was not Americans who were responsible for the end of apartheid, but the children of Soweto who had died in countless demonstrations. The audience, made up largely of South Africans, cheered.
Another criticism of Americans is that while they may be here now, they have no real stake in the success of the country. On Mrs. Mabuza-Suttle's show, Dr. William Makgoba, a professor at Witwatersrand University, argued that Americans needed to leave South Africans alone to decide the future of the country because the South Africans were there for the long haul.
But many of the Americans say that the success of the new South Africa is actually a long-term commitment for them too.
"Where is the hope for us in America?" Mr. Moses said. "We will never be in charge. We will always be 10 percent. We will always be fighting to keep some cop from shooting us in the back. But here it's worth the battle. You can win this here."

(Photographs by Joao Silva for The New York Times); Above, Felicia Mabuza-Suttle interviewed guests on her South African television program recently about African-Americans living in the country. (SABC)(pg. A16)

HEADLINE: After a Good Day, the Nikkei Retreats

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, April 7

 BODY:
Stock prices here fell moderately early today, as many investors displayed caution ahead of an important economic meeting to be headed by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto on Friday.
Despite Wall Street's record closing, the benchmark Nikkei stock average of 225 issues fell 65.83 points, or 0.42 percent, to 15,640.16 points in the first hour of trading. On Monday, the Nikkei index gained 188.21 points, or 1.21 percent, in reaction both to last week's sharp declines and to the latest indications of possible tax cuts to help the economy. Some investors were cheered by a promise by lawmakers of a $118 billion package of spending programs and tax cuts to shore up the battered economy. 
 Over the weekend, governing party officials promised the package would include $59 billion of real spending on public construction projects, the biggest outlay ever in a Government economic stimulus plan. They also called for income tax cuts.
Japan has been under criticism by the United States and other trade partners for failing to stimulate its economy.
Investors also remain worried about the ailing economy and want assurances that the Government will follow through on its promises to help growth.
Traders attributed Monday's rise largely to a technical rebound after the Nikkei average had lost more than 1,000 points since April 1. The broader Tokyo Stock Price Index of all issues on the exchange's first section was down 4.97 points, or 0.41 percent, to 1,193.84. It rose 14.91 points, or 1.26 percent, on Monday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Citicorp and Travelers Plan Biggest Merger Ever
Citicorp and Travelers Group, two of America's biggest companies, agreed to a $70 billion merger, the largest in history.
The deal, which would create the world's largest financial services concern, is remarkable for its brashness. Given the nation's ample regulatory curbs on how actively banks can sell insurance and the law separating commercial and investment banking, the proposed merger challenges regulators and lawmakers to end these restrictions, scuttle the deal or force the merged company to scale back. Page A1. 

Broadcast TV's Looming Conflict
In what would mark a fundamental reshaping of the economics of broadcasting, several networks are trying to redefine their relationship with affiliate stations to help defray the increased costs of programming. Some of proposed changes are likely to cause conflicts with the stations. D4.
 
Mixed Message From Motorola
Motorola said it matched Wall Street's diminished expectations for first-quarter earnings, but any likelihood that investors would take that as good news was dashed when the company warned that second-quarter results were unexpectedly weak. D12.
 
Wild Stock Ride in Biotechnology
In a dramatic display of the sudden fortunes and misfortunes that can roil biotechnology stocks, shares in Cephalon Inc. dropped 21 percent on news that Federal regulators had canceled an advisory panel meeting to review Myotrophin, its new treatment for Lou Gehrig's disease. Shares in Gilead Sciences Inc. gained about 20 percent after the company published unexpectedly good results about clinical trials of its potential new AIDS drug, Preveon. D6.
 
First Test for New Korea Debt
South Korea is expected to bring its first-ever offering of sovereign debt to market today or tomorrow, a $3 billion test of investors' appetite for exposure to Asia as the region attempts to rebound from crisis. D12.
 
Silver Drops on Talk of Buffett Sale
May silver contracts fell 20.5 cents, or 3.1 percent, to settle at $6.37 an ounce on speculation that Warren E. Buffett had sold about a third of his silver holdings. The billionaire investor's company, Berkshire Hathaway, declined to comment. D13.
 
Bell Atlantic Wins Backing
The Justice Department's antitrust chief and New York State's top utility regulator have given conditional support to Bell Atlantic's bid to sell long-distance telephone service. The company now appears to have the inside track toward becoming the first Bell local telephone company to sell long-distance service. B1.
 
Tandy Founder's Protege Resigning
John V. Roach, chief executive of the Tandy Corporation and a protege of the founder, Charles Tandy, will resign at the end of this year. The company said Mr. Roach, shown at left, would be replaced by Leonard H. Roberts, who is considered responsible for reviving the company's Radio Shack chain of electronics stores. D3.
 
South Africa's Whispered Tension
Many African-Americans who go to South Africa with the idealistic aim of helping build its economy have not always been received with open arms by black South Africans, who have tended to view the visitors as patronizing and arrogant. At least one American company has decided to no longer send African-Americans to South Africa. A1.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1390 words

HEADLINE: SHAPING A COLOSSUS: THE REGULATORS;
Financial Services Heavyweights Try Do-It-Yourself Deregulation

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
For two decades Washington has tried and failed to update the Depression-era laws governing the rapidly changing financial services industry. Today the industry took matters into its own hands.
In going ahead with a merger despite the current ban on combinations between banks and insurers, Citicorp and Travelers Group are gambling that they can use their political muscle and the sheer weight of the marketplace to break down the longstanding barriers that have impeded but not completely stopped the creation of vast financial supermarkets. 
 Congress came very close to moving ahead on the necessary legislation just last week. But the Republican leadership in the House pulled the bill at the last minute when it became clear that it would once again fall victim to the Byzantine politics that has afflicted similar efforts since 1979, when Congress first began trying to update the 1933 Glass-Steagall Act and the 1956 Bank Holding Company Act, the main laws separating banks, Wall Street and insurance.
The House is scheduled to take up a modified version of the bill again in early May. Whether it can pass -- or whether Citicorp and Travelers can find ways to make their merger work even in the absence of new legislation -- were hotly debated topics today. But it was clear that their announcement, if nothing else, was forcing Washington to confront the issue anew.
And this time, analysts warned, a failure to set clear ground rules -- whether or not they would allow the Citicorp-Travelers deal to go through -- would hurt the American financial services business in its effort to compete around the world.
Indeed, Washington's stalling has been rewarded by a flow of campaign contributions from all the interest groups affected by the legislation. That has left Congress looking narrow minded at a time of rapid change in the marketplace.
"This transaction places tremendous pressure on Congress to pass some kind of legislation this session," said Peter Wallison, a lawyer at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher who was general counsel of the Treasury Department during the Reagan Administration. "I don't think that will happen because there are still very major issues for Congress to resolve."
Banks and securities firms have been merging at a faster pace in recent years under new, more liberal rules set out by the Federal Reserve, the main regulator of bank holding companies. Banks have also won new authority to get into selling insurance -- although not, generally, the right to underwrite insurance -- in a series of decisions from the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which is principally responsible for regulating the operations of national banks.
Citicorp itself, through a loophole that long ago was closed for others, has the right to underwrite life insurance through a subsidiary in Delaware. Some analysts said today that the provision could be one way for the merged companies to make an end run around Washington if Congress does not change the main banking legislation. Another way might be for Citicorp to abandon its banking charter, relying on Travelers' existing savings and loan operations to handle all its banking while conducting insurance and brokerage work through other subsidiaries.
But both companies clearly hope that the problem will be solved by the type of legislation that is currently languishing in the House, which would generally allow banks and insurers to own each other. Citicorp helped kill the version of the bill that came before the House last week, although it said that it supports the general concept of modernizing the law. Travelers supported the bill.
"We think the odds are very strong that the laws are going to change," John M. Morris, the spokesman for Citicorp, said.
Breaking the legislative deadlock will require considerable work. The process has long been hampered by a regulatory rivalry between the Federal Reserve, which would like to keep control over how the financial services industry is reshaped, and the Comptroller of the Currency, which has granted banks under its purview considerable freedom to get into new lines of business.
Moreover, while failure to act has left Congress somewhat red-faced, the deadlock has in many ways been good for those legislators on the committees that oversee financial services. With banks, securities firms and insurers all battling over how to rewrite the rules of the game -- and looking to deny any advantage to their current and future rivals -- members of Congress have seen their campaign coffers swell from a constant flow of money from companies and lobbying groups.
Citicorp and Travelers began making their case in Washington even before announcing the deal publicly. The two chairmen, John S. Reed of Citicorp and Sanford I. Weill of Travelers, met last week with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and also put in a courtesy call to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. And they notified President Clinton of the deal Sunday night.
Aiding Citicorp and Travelers on Capitol Hill is a veritable army of lobbyists and lawyers on their payrolls. Citicorp's lobbying presence is one of the largest among banks, with a multimillion-dollar operation that employs 15 in-house lawyers along with 7 different law and consulting firms. Citicorp paid $4.1 million in lobbying expenses in the first half of 1997, the most recent figures available.
Citicorp also has a corporate political action committee that raised $784,000 in 1996 and 1997 for campaign contributions and, by the end of 1997, had only $68,000 left.
In lobbying, Travelers spent a total of $629,000 and Salomon Smith Barney, a unit of Travelers, spent $780,000 for a total of $1.4 million during the first half of 1997. And last year, Travelers alone made $239,000 in campaign contributions, with donations to many banking and commerce committee members, while Salomon's donations from its political action committee totaled $192,000.
The Glass-Steagall law was passed during the Depression as a way of trying to keep the problems on Wall Street from infecting the banking industry and thereby exacerbating the nation's economic woes. Congress applied the same principle to insurance companies two decades later, leaving banking, securities and insurance separated by barriers that have been eroded but never removed.
As long as the legislative prohibition on banks and insurers owning each other remains in place, the Federal Reserve would have no choice but to condition any approval of the merger on Travelers' divesting itself of its insurance businesses, which accounted for 47 percent of its operating profits last year.
But the two companies have some time to maneuver. They said they would have at least two years -- and up to five if the Fed grants them extensions -- in which they could push for a legislative change before they would be forced to sell the businesses.
It is still too soon to handicap the prospects for any banking bill to pass the House next month. Even if a bill did pass, it is not certain the Senate would have the time or the inclination to take it up this year.
Although it would be difficult for the Senate to act, it might do so if banks and insurance companies came together to support a single approach, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said today. Mr. D'Amato has previously been reluctant to take up the bill, fearful of becoming bogged down in the same political swamp that has slowed the bill in the House.
"This merger demonstrates that we really should move forward despite the intransigence or opposition of some in the financial services industry to creating a level playing field," Mr. D'Amato said.
Representative James A. Leach, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, said, "This merger underscores the need for prompt Congressional action on financial services modernization legislation to insure that America's competitive position abroad is enhanced, with proper functional regulation at home."
Although there are also restrictions on combinations between banks and securities firms, Citicorp and Travelers should be able to take advantage of the same regulation that has allowed a wave of deals between banks and brokerage houses in recent years.

HEADLINE: SHAPING A COLOSSUS: THE HISTORY;
An Evolution of Pre-Victorian Pin Stripes to One Big Red Umbrella

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
They are two of the most venerable names in American capitalism, but Citicorp and Travelers Group have taken decidedly different paths to the pinnacle of the financial services business.
Citicorp first opened its doors at 52 Wall Street as the City Bank of New York on Sept. 14, 1812, only months after the War of 1812 had begun. It has had only one significant merger in its 186-year history, when it joined forces with the First National Bank in 1955. 
 In contrast, Travelers Group, which was not born until late 1993, would be a mere speck on the corporate landscape if not for mergers.
If Citicorp, today the nation's second-largest bank holding company behind Chase Manhattan, is a byproduct of nearly two centuries of American and world economic history, Travelers is the work-in-progress of Sanford I. Weill, the Wall Street executive who since 1986 has transformed a string of ailing financial companies into powerhouses.
Since its creation, Citicorp has profited from booms and has been the leader among American banks in overseas expansion. It has generated a slew of product innovations, from traveler's checks (introduced in 1904) to credit cards for the middle class (the Everything card, introduced in 1967). In 1929 it became the first bank to open a personal loan department, establishing ties to less-than-affluent retail customers that are a critical element of its success and reach.
But the bank is no stranger to adversity.
Citicorp, which adopted its current name in 1974, has endured market panics, two World Wars, the Depression and, more recently, two financial events that nearly brought the franchise to its knees in the early 1990's: the Latin America debt crisis and a mountain of bad loans in commercial real estate.
Once the world's biggest commercial bank, Citicorp faced financial problems so severe that on Oct. 15, 1991, it suspended dividend payments on its stock for the first time. When the payments were resumed, in April 1994, the bad loans written off and the strategy of Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, to mine retail banking around the world firmly in place, the company was well on the road to recovery.
At its nadir in the early 1990's, Citicorp stock could be bought for $8.50 a share. The shares closed at $142.875 last Friday, before soaring $37.625 yesterday, to $180.50.
"Back then, nobody would have dreamed that John Reed would be presiding over the largest merger in history," said Ron Chernow, the author of several books about the financial industry, including "The House of Morgan."
Mr. Reed is the seventh chairman of Citicorp, a position that did not exist before 1909, when the legendary James Stillman, banker and confidant of William Rockefeller, the president of Standard Oil of New York, assumed the post.
Travelers Group has had only one chairman, Mr. Weill.
Before December 1993, when the current Travelers took shape through his acquisition of the insurer by that name, Mr. Weill was the chairman of a decidedly less august-sounding enterprise, the Primerica Corporation.
Primerica then consisted of the Commercial Credit Corporation, an ailing consumer-loan business Mr. Weill had bought in 1986 from the Control Data Corporation, and Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the investment bank.
Mr. Weill would soon add to his brokerage holdings: in 1993, he bought Shearson, the firm he had built, back from American Express for $1.1 billion.
But rather than continue to operate under the Primerica name, once the acquisition of Travelers was complete Mr. Weill quickly adopted what he characterized then as "one of the most identifiable names in the financial markets."
The Travelers, as it was then known, was founded in 1864 by J. G. Batterson, a Connecticut businessman, and wrote its first insurance policy in a Hartford post office.
James E. Bolter, a local banker, accosted Mr. Batterson, asking what he would need to pay for accident insurance from the post office to his home, where he planned to have lunch.
Two cents, Mr. Batterson quickly replied, and tucked the money into his vest pocket. The two pennies are still in the company's possession at its Hartford headquarters.
In the years since, the company has underwritten more significant ventures and has long lived under one of the best-known logos in American business -- the umbrella it created in its advertising in 1870, only six years after the company had been established, to symbolize protection.
In 1897, the Travelers sold the first automobile policy. In 1919, it issued the first air travel policy, to President Woodrow Wilson. In the late 1960's it issued space accident insurance for the Apollo 11 astronauts in the first lunar landing.
The current Travelers red umbrella trademark made its debut 40 years ago this week at the Masters, the prestigious golf tournament the company still sponsors.
Citigroup, as the combination of Citicorp and Travelers is to be called, will be merely the latest addition under the umbrella.
In what was then his biggest transaction, Mr. Weill stunned the financial world last September when he acquired Salomon Inc., the parent of Salomon Brothers, the Wall Street powerhouse, for more than $9 billion in stock.
With the addition of Salomon, the financial press said that Travelers had entered an elite group of financial companies that included Merrill Lynch & Company, the American Express Company, a smattering of European and Japanese financial companies and Citicorp.
At the time, Mr. Weill said the Salomon deal was the culmination of a lifelong dream, to build what he called "a great financial services firm without parallel."
In retrospect, it seems clear his dream was not yet fulfilled.
"No other merger compares with this," Mr. Chernow said. "This creates a new paradigm."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Gambling Industry Spins From Red to Black

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
After posting a net loss of $257 million in 1996, the state's gambling industry was officially back in the black last year, with a net income of $6.4 million in 1997, the State Casino Control Commission announced yesterday.
Gaming analysts played down the significance of the net income figure; more indicative of the industry's health, they said, are gross operating profits, which rose to $886.7 million last year from $809.2 million in 1996. Mark Grossman, a spokesman for Bally's Park Place, which was the city's most profitable casino last year, attributed rising profits to improved efficiency and the opening of Wild Wild West, Atlantic City's first theme casino. 
 Larry Klatzkin, a gaming analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, predicted that profits would continue to rise. Marvin Roffman, an analyst with Roffman Miller Associates, was less optimistic. He said growth in the total revenue of $4.2 billion in 1997 did not keep pace with inflation.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2146 words

HEADLINE: SHAPING A COLOSSUS: THE OVERVIEW;
IN LARGEST DEAL EVER, CITICORP PLANS MERGER WITH TRAVELERS GROUP

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN and JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Two of America's largest companies, Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc., agreed yesterday to a merger that would create the world's largest financial-services concern. Not since the freewheeling pre-Depression era would so many different financial businesses be corralled under one roof in this country.
The transaction was valued at $70 billion in stock when it was announced, making it the largest merger in history. Both companies' stock prices soared on the news, adding another $14 billion to the value of the transaction by the end of the day. 
 The deal is remarkable not only for its size but for its brashness as well. While banks like Citicorp and insurance and brokerage firms like Travelers have made substantial inroads into one another's businesses, there are still ample regulatory restrictions on how actively banks can sell products like insurance.
Just last week, a bill seeking to end laws dating back as far as the Depression that separate commercial and investment banking and limit the types of financial products that banks can offer was withdrawn in the House of Representatives. This proposed merger challenges regulators and lawmakers to either end these restrictions, scuttle the deal or force the merged company to cut back on what it offers the customer.
Whatever the outcome, the deal promises to ignite an intense legislative battle in Washington over the shape and future of financial services in America. It is also expected to speed the pace of merger activity across the financial landscape.
Competitors in Europe and Asia already have the ability to offer an array of banking and insurance products under one corporate umbrella. Now American companies are aggressively pushing for the same rights, in this case under the bright red umbrella that Travelers uses as its logo.
Travelers and Citicorp are betting that their profits and competitiveness would be enhanced by offering one-stop shopping for a broad range of services, from savings and checking accounts, credit cards, mortgages, stock and bond underwriting, homeowners, auto and life insurance, asset management, mergers and acquisitions advice, commercial loans, and derivative securities and foreign exchange trading.
Citicorp's chief executive, John S. Reed, and Travelers' chief executive, Sanford I. Weill, would jointly run the new company, to be called Citigroup Inc. "Frankly, we're probably talking about a restructuring of the financial services industry," Mr. Reed said of the agreement.
But it is not quite that simple. The transaction would have to negotiate a maze of regulations governing the banking industry that were put in place precisely to prevent the creation of the type of company Travelers and Citicorp now aim to put together. Those laws were enacted in response to public concerns about unfettered financial power and the economic consequences when such giants collapse.
Assuming that legal barriers are overcome -- Mr. Reed and Mr. Weill said they believed that Federal Reserve officials were kindly disposed toward the transaction but regulators at the Comptroller of the Currency still have to weigh in -- there are other sizable hurdles the merged company would face. Chief among those is the challenge of running a global company that would have revenues of about $50 billion, assets of $700 billion and a market capitalization of more than $140 billion.
The new company would vault ahead of other global financial giants, including Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. and Deutsche Bank A.G., both of which already offer the menu of financial products that Citicorp and Travelers are trying to put together. The size of the deal would easily eclipse the largest merger agreement to date, Worldcom's bid to acquire MCI Communications for $37 billion.
The merger of Citicorp and Travelers "creates a big firm but they still have to do something with what they've got," said Peter Davis, a financial services consultant with Booz Allen & Hamilton. "The challenge is managing a financial service conglomerate, adding on new retail distribution and expanding investment banking internationally."
The transaction would also combine two companies with very different cultures and chief executives. Although Citicorp is much more aggressive than some of its peers, it still tends to fit the profile of a cautious buttoned-down bank. Travelers, by contrast, is marked by the entrepreneurial style of its chief executive.
As recently as the early 1990's, Citicorp, currently the nation's second-largest bank after the Chase Manhattan Corporation, was teetering on the brink of insolvency as piles of bad real estate and Latin American loans threatened to swamp the company.
Citicorp, and other big banks caught in the same perilous position, pulled through the crisis largely because of a generous interest-rate environment engineered by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. Mr. Greenspan kept interest rates unusually low, allowing banks to borrow money cheaply and lend at higher rates while they worked to get rid of bad loans.
Citicorp eventually recovered and by the mid-1990's it had emerged as one of the most competitive and profitable banks in the country. The 59-year-old Mr. Reed, as able a corporate survivor as there is among prominent chief executives, managed to keep the bank's board in his corner by never permitting a strong No. 2 to stay very long at Citicorp.
Under Mr. Reed's direction, Citicorp in recent years has emphasized its global consumer business, which includes such things as credit cards and savings accounts, while decreasing the bank's involvement in domestic wholesale businesses like corporate lending. Overseas, however, Citicorp still focuses its energies on corporate lending, because the bank has a competitive advantage in many emerging markets. In 1997, Citicorp had profits of $3.6 billion on revenue of $23.3 billion
For Mr. Weill, a dapper, thick-set executive who, at 65, keeps in shape riding a knobby-tired bicycle through the woods of his weekend home in upstate New York, the deal capped nearly 40 years of scrappy, Wall Street deal-making. He has built a huge personal fortune, but he has talked for years not only of making money but also of building a company with worldwide impact. He took a step in that direction last September with the purchase of Salomon Brothers for $9 billion.
Last year, with Salomon under its wing for the final quarter, Travelers reported net income of $3.1 billion on $27.1 billion in revenues.
More than half of Travelers' revenue comes from consumer finance, individual investments, investment banking and bond underwriting and trading. It sells life insurance and annuities through two subsidiaries, including Primerica Financial Services, which specializes in term or basic insurance without investment features. Travelers is the sixth-largest property and casualty insurer in the country, selling auto, homeowners and commercial coverage, with $8.6 billion in premiums last year.
By adding Salomon Brothers to its Smith Barney brokerage and investment banking arm, Travelers became the third-biggest stock underwriter in the United States and the fourth biggest in the world. It also moved into first place in underwriting municipal bonds, and second in overall underwriting of American and international debt offerings.
Mr. Reed and Mr. Weill first discussed a merger on Feb. 25, during the Business Council's annual economics and public policy conference of the nation's top corporate chieftains. At a dinner that evening in Washington, Mr. Weill invited Mr. Reed to his hotel room at the Park Hyatt. When Mr. Reed arrived, Mr. Weill, known on Wall Street as something of a deal maven, made a marriage proposal.
"Gee, I didn't think that was what you were going to talk to me about," Mr. Weill recalled Mr. Reed as saying. Mr. Reed, who has had a longstanding aversion to the investment banking business, said that the logic of the deal was compelling enough for him to put his reservations aside. Mr. Weill was less successful last year when he approached J. P. Morgan & Company about a merger and was rebuffed.
Oddly enough, in 1996 Mr. Reed negotiated with but decided against completing a merger with Mr. Weill's old employer, the American Express Company, because of power-sharing problems with that company's chief executive, Harvey Golub. Even Mr. Weill, during his American Express days, was once considered anathema at Citicorp, having been portrayed as a feared competitor in an in-house video made years ago at Citicorp.
But Mr. Reed and Mr. Weill have a friendship spanning three decades and both men said they believed that they could make their unusual corporate relationship work if the merger was completed.
Although analysts have been concerned about Citicorp's continued exposure to economic turmoil in Southeast Asia, Mr. Weill was briefed on the bank's prospects there and said he was not concerned that he was taking on any undue risk by merging with the company. Indeed, he said Citicorp's broad international presence, almost unmatched among American banks, was attractive to Travelers, which has been looking for ways to expand abroad. As for Travelers, it offers Citicorp a way to build on its securities and insurance offerings.
Investors appeared to share the executives' favorable assessment; the stock of Citicorp soared yesterday, rising $37.625 to close at $180.50. Travelers stock rose $11.3125, to $73.
With its suggestion that regulatory barriers might be forced down, yesterday's transaction resounded like a starter's pistol to some analysts, signaling the beginning of a great race for the country's insurance companies. "Most life and annuities companies are now candidates for takeover or merger," said Andrew Kligerman, an analyst at Schroder & Company.
Some of the largest insurers, like American International Group Inc., might seek to acquire banks, analysts said. But most said that banks, with far greater assets, were likely to be the more powerful shoppers. The banking industry has already undergone a wave of consolidation in the last few years.
The prospective merger partners proved to be politically astute, quietly lobbying banking regulators and government officials for their tacit support before they announced the deal. This included a conversation by Mr. Weill and Mr. Reed with President Clinton on Sunday night to brief him on the transaction. And Mr. Weill and Mr. Reed kept their negotiations largely between themselves, their boards and regulators, helping to keep the transaction a secret until yesterday's announcement. No investment bankers were retained.
Big job cuts are not expected to be part of the merger, although there will undoubtedly be a serious winnowing of senior management ranks at the combined company. The transaction will be effected through a merger of Citicorp into Travelers, and Travelers plans to apply to the Federal Reserve to become a bank holding company.
Under the Bank Holding Company Act, enacted in the 1950's, all existing businesses, including insurance, can be retained and operated by the combined company for two years, a period that can then be extended by the Federal Reserve for three additional one-year periods. Citicorp and Travelers said they plan to reassess their options once that five-year dispensation ends, but in the meantime they will undoubtedly push hard to change existing laws.
Although Citicorp cannot offer property or casualty insurance, it already has the right to offer life insurance and annuities because of a legal loophole it took advantage of in the late 1980's when the Bank Holding Company Act was briefly amended. The amendment allowed banks to establish separate insurance subsidiaries offering such products. Lawmakers closed that loophole in the early 1990's.
Congress has so far been unable to overhaul the Glass-Steagall Act, the 1933 law separating commercial and investment banking, but bank regulators have moved independently over the last decade to erode the act's limitations.
Analysts said life insurance companies would now be the prized targets of banks on the prowl. Life insurance policies are often seen as a means of saving, and many banks now sell mutual funds that are similar to the variable annuities sold by life insurers.
To be sure, many insurers are likely to prize their independence more than the opportunity for potentially higher earnings as a subordinate unit of a bank. But Steve Hilbert, the chief executive of Conseco, one of the nation's largest publicly traded life and health insurance companies, said that his hat was off to Mr. Reed and Mr. Weill for breaking new ground.
"It's absolutely fabulous," Mr. Hilbert said. "Companies that thrive going forward are going to have to deal in several sectors like insurance, consumer finance and banking."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 216 words

HEADLINE: The Skies Are Getting Friendlier for the Rest

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I read Robert B. Reich's remarks on air travel (Op-Ed, April 5) while flying coach from San Jose to Chicago aboard an old 727. As in so many older planes, the seating was cramped, as compared with newer planes like the Boeing 777, which seems to have greater legroom and wider seats. Service and food in coach is getting better, not worse. 
 Mr. Reich implies that as airlines add more first-class seats, accommodations in economy class grow more cramped. In reality, it just means that there are fewer economy seats on the plane, which is hardly a problem when nearly every airline on average carries less than 70 percent of its passenger capacity.
The airline industry is finally profitable, after disastrous years in the early 1990's. As the airlines improve service in first class, they are able to charge more and sell the marginal seat space in economy for less. Indeed, according to Clifford Winston of the Brookings Institution, deregulation has saved passengers about $12.4 billion annually.
That's a long way from the regulated era when airlines offered only one class of service -- first class -- and the Civil Aeronautics Board regulated the thickness of sandwiches on board aircraft to prevent competition.
 
GARY LEFF
Fairfax, Va., April 6, 1998

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 916 words

HEADLINE: 9,000 Job Cuts To Save Xerox $1 Billion

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation, citing the need to compete against more efficient rivals, announced yesterday that it would eliminate about 9,000 jobs, or nearly 10 percent of its worldwide work force, over the next two to three years.
About half the cuts will be in the United States. While only a handful are expected to come at the company's headquarters in Stamford, Conn., about 1,400 will be in Rochester, where the Eastman Kodak Company, the area's biggest employer, is already cutting more than 6,000 jobs. 
 Xerox said the cuts, combined with a program to consolidate accounting, service and other support functions in Europe, would save the company $1 billion annually. G. Richard Thoman, Xerox's president, said at least half the savings would be used to improve the sales, marketing and other functions aimed at increasing revenues.
"We haven't had solid double-digit sales growth since the mid-1980's, and that's what we want now," Mr. Thoman said. "And you can't grow fast without being efficient enough to have flexible pricing and advertising."
Political leaders in Rochester, and in Stamford, where Xerox has 500 employees, seemed to buy that argument. "Xerox needs to maintain its international competitive edge, and if that means we lose some jobs, we understand that," said Mayor Dannel P. Malloy of Stamford, who noted that Stamford's unemployment rate is only about 3 percent.
The ax falls heavier on Rochester, of course, where Xerox and Kodak together account for 10 percent of the city's jobs, and where unemployment is closer to 5 percent. Few people there doubted that Kodak, whose profits have been plummeting, had to cut back. Xerox, in contrast, is having a strong year.
"There's kind of a bewilderment around here," Eugene Fram, a marketing professor at the Rochester Institute of Technology, said. "Everyone is asking, 'If things are going well, why do they need to do this?' "
Still, since The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle first reported two weeks ago that cuts were expected, there had been speculation that several thousand jobs might be lost in Rochester, making the actual number almost a relief.
"There's no rejoicing when you hear people will lose their jobs, but this could have been a lot worse," Mayor William A. Johnson Jr. of Rochester said.
Mr. Thoman flew to Rochester to personally announce the cuts yesterday. Mr. Johnson said that he had a 6:30 A.M. meeting with local Xerox executives in which he was briefed before the announcement was made.
"I realize Xerox did what they had to do to survive in an eat or be eaten environment," Mr. Johnson said.
Xerox stock had been steadily rising since the first reports of the company's expected job cuts, but closed yesterday at $106.8125, down $1.3125.
Slow revenue growth will continue to be an issue, "but they are doing the heroic things you need to do to get into the double digits," Peter J. Enderlin, an analyst with the First Albany Corporation, said. Indeed, many analysts scrambled after the announcement to increase already upbeat predictions of how Xerox's earnings and stock price would perform.
"A billion dollars is a huge chunk of change," B. Alexander Henderson of Prudential Securities Research said.
Jack L. Kelly of Goldman, Sachs added, "There's a real paradigm shift here, from an engineering-driven company to one that really knows how to rip out infrastructure to get costs down."
The vast majority of the cuts will come out of the sales and general administration ranks. Although Xerox's profits have risen, the company's expenses in these areas have been rather high, amounting to 28.8 percent of revenues last year.
That was less of a problem when Xerox was sticking to high-ticket analog copiers that it sold directly to corporate customers. But digital technology continues to blur the line between computer printers and copiers, and Xerox continues to push into lower-priced, lower-margin products that are sold through retail outlets. Thus, Xerox now must compete with highly efficient concerns like the Hewlett-Packard Company, where sales and general administration expenses are much lower.
"We're where they want to be, and they have a long ways to go before they catch up," Lawrence Tomlinson, Hewlett-Packard's treasurer, said. Mr. Thoman readily concedes the point. "We know our costs are higher than the companies we now compete with," he said.
Xerox said the reorganization would drive its sales and general administration costs to the low 20's as a percentage of sales over time, a move that analysts said was essential. "The idea is to make Xerox more lean and mean so it can compete effectively down the road," Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, said.
In cutting costs during profitable times, Xerox is following a precedent set by no less a profit machine than the General Electric Company. When John F. Welch Jr. became G.E.'s chief executive in 1981, G.E. had 404,000 employees, generating some $27 billion in revenues. The company was hugely profitable, yet Mr. Welch immediately began trimming jobs. "He felt it was best to cut from a position of strength," a G.E. spokesman said. Last year, G.E.'s revenues topped $90.8 billion, yet it had only 276,000 employees.
Now some analysts suggest that reorganizations from a position of strength may become more common. "If the leading companies start cutting costs and restructuring, the No. 2 players can really never catch up," Mr. Henderson said.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Level Surged in February

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Borrowing by American consumers increased by more than double the expected amount in February on a surge in credit card debt, data released today by the Federal Reserve showed.
Borrowing rose by $7 billion for the month, to $1.244 trillion, after rising a revised $4.6 billion in January. Previously, the Fed said January borrowing had increased $2.9 billion. Before today's report, analysts had expected a rise of $3.3 billion in February. 
 The biggest component of the February increase was credit card debt, which rose to $3.9 billion from $2.1 billion in January.
Still, recent increases in consumer credit have been more subdued than just a few years ago, when they often ran into the double digits. Banks and other lenders have been less aggressive in extending credit to consumers after a surge in personal bankruptcies for which credit card debt was partly to blame.
Rising incomes and low interest rates, meanwhile, have allowed many consumers to pay cash for purchases, and consolidate or even retire existing debt.
"Banks are being more selective, and people are paying down debt," said Peter Kretzmer, an economist at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities in New York.
In addition, many people are using lower interest rate home equity loans to consolidate their debt, and that type of lending is not covered by the Federal Reserve's statistics because it is secured by real estate.
Banks, for example, have reported an increase of $13 billion in the volume of outstanding home equity loans the last year at the same time the volume of revolving consumer loans at banks has declined by about $18 billion, Mr. Kretzmer said.
