HEADLINE: New U.S. Diplomat Tries to Speak Japan's Language

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 7

 BODY:
As everyone from President Clinton down hammers Japan these days to stimulate its economy, Thomas S. Foley is being a little bit more polite.
Mr. Foley, the former Speaker of the House who is the new American Ambassador to Japan, is conveying much the same message. But right now in Tokyo, his soft and diplomatic style may make him a more welcome envoy in the offices of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto. 
 Mr. Foley lives in a luxurious mansion, catered to by a domestic staff of 13 -- not including his two Japanese bodyguards -- and enjoys the status and privilege of a minor deity in Tokyo. But even Mr. Foley, who at 6 feet 2 towers over his Japanese counterparts as he exhorts them on weighty issues like the economy, is careful not to drop the full weight of American pressure on the leaders here.
He knows himself what it is like to be put regularly in his place, especially by a small, elderly woman wearing a traditional kimono: his Japanese teacher.
"She has a very acute sense of what the proper Japanese form is," Mr. Foley said. "I'm looking for the shortest, quickest, easiest phrase, and she's, 'No, no, that's not really the best.' "
Mr. Foley is unlikely to be taken any time soon for a native Japanese speaker. But as he wrestles with beginning language classes, he also has an image to overcome as a longtime friend of Japan.
There was some grumbling in American business circles here, and even in the American Embassy, that Mr. Foley throughout his career had been too cozy with Japan and that he might not be tough enough.
His predecessor, Walter F. Mondale, was a tough negotiator, while some trade hard-liners worry that Mr. Foley may be a member of what is derisively referred to as the Chrysanthemum Club, meaning those who applaud Japan a bit too heartily.
They note that Mr. Foley has long been warmly regarded here, partly because of his roots in the Pacific Northwest, where trade with Japan is significant. He was only the fourth American ever to receive Japan's highest civilian honor, the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun, Paulownia Flowers, named after one of Japan's national flowers.
That is an awkward criticism to rebut, and for his part, Mr. Foley does not try to fight it by suggesting that he is unfriendly to Japan. Rather, he says he pays little attention -- and he has been dogged in his first few months in pushing American interests in Japan.
Indeed, since he arrived in November, Mr. Foley has cut ribbons at American trade shows, trudged through snow to offer remarks at a Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet, eaten grilled salmon cooked in American styles and held breakfasts for local American business groups.
Mr. Foley has also tried to use his long friendship with Japanese officials to his advantage. As an American Congressman for 30 years, 5 as Speaker, Mr. Foley regularly visited Japan.
"He has been pretty visible," said Glen Fukushima, president of the American Chamber of Commerce of Japan and a former official in the Commerce Department. "He's built up a Rolodex of Japanese contacts over the years, especially in politics."
Yet Mr. Foley has been a bit less public than some other American officials in twisting Japanese arms to get Tokyo to stimulate its economy. In the last few months, Clinton Administration officials have been increasingly blunt in demanding that Japan take major steps to boost its economy to help Asia out of its financial crisis and avoid a global downturn.
Mr. Foley has argued the same case, but -- at least publicly -- with a bit less heat than some officials in Washington. Still, Mr. Foley met briefly today with Prime Minister Hashimoto, who plans to announce tax cuts on Wednesday. And he held a series of meetings at the Finance Ministry last December just a day or so before Mr. Hashimoto announced a surprise tax cut of nearly $16 billion. It seems that Mr. Foley leaned heavily on Japan to take such a step, but he is careful not to claim credit for determining Japanese economic policy.
"We're not pulling our punches," Mr. Foley said in an interview at his residence. "We're being frank and candid on the economic side. We can give our advice and recommend, but ultimately it's not a matter where we can determine the decision."
Some trade hard-liners have been concerned not just about Mr. Foley, but about the entire leadership of the embassy. The deputy chief of mission is Christopher J. LaFleur, the son-in-law of former Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa.
While Mr. Foley did not criticize the relentless pressure that American officials put on Japan three years ago to open its market to American cars, he did suggest that excessive pressure was not always useful. He cited a complaint from a Japanese official, whom he did not identify, that Japan feels it is being bullied by foreign countries.
"I think people who believe in somehow pounding the table or raising the voice are sort of not in a context that's real either," Mr. Foley said.
In some ways, though, table-pounding is almost exactly what has been coming out of Washington recently. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin; the trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky; the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and Commerce Secretary William Daley have led the chorus of voices urging Japan to stimulate its economy and help pull the region out of its economic mess.
To an extent, the exhortations from Washington allow Mr. Foley to tone down his own discussions with Japanese officials here so they will not feel particularly bullied by all Americans. For some critics, Mr. Foley and his bosses in Washington appear to be performing a good cop, bad cop routine, but for others, results are what count, and the jury is still out.
"When he meets people here, he can be nice and soft," said Yoshio Murakami, executive editor of The Asahi Evening News, a leading English-language daily. "When he reports back home, he could be very, very American."

LENGTH: 1660 words

HEADLINE: Patchwork of School Financing Schemes Offers Few Answers and Much Conflict

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

DATELINE: SANTA FE

 BODY:
If there is anywhere where the struggle over school-financing disparities ought to be over by now, it is in New Mexico.
After all, New Mexico took drastic action back in the early 1970's, when the first round of lawsuits challenging school-financing systems got under way. To level the field between rich districts and poor ones, and avoid the mire of litigation, New Mexico limited the amount districts could spend on their own schools and made the state, rather than local property taxes, the main source of money to operate schools. 
So why, 25 years later, does the school in the fancy part of Santa Fe have a physical education teacher paid for by parents, while the school on the poor side of town has none? Why do the schools on the Zuni reservation have so little money for maintenance and repairs that they have had to lock up the swimming pool?
And how is it that Michael Davis, the State Superintendent of Education, and his staff still spend a third of their time defending -- and adjusting -- the school-financing formula?
"The fight over equity never goes away," Mr. Davis said. "And it never will. I'm very proud of our formula, which I think is the fairest in the nation. The state provides more than 90 percent of school operating funds, so we can give every child in New Mexico access to the same educational opportunities. But it's always going to be a work in progress."
There is no move afoot to abandon New Mexico's financing formula altogether -- and everyone seems to agree that the state's system is far closer to equitable than in the old days. And nationwide, most experts say, there has been real progress in reducing disparities.
But there is an increasing recognition that leveling the field financially is not the only issue, and that it is also important to concentrate on making sure that, even in poor states like New Mexico, each child gets a decent education.
If financial equity was the issue of the 70's and 80's, the issue of the 90's -- and the touchstone for much of the litigation now in the courts -- is the adequacy of the education the state offers children.
"I'm not sure equitable means much if there's not enough money to provide an adequate education," said Allan Odden, a school-financing expert at the University of Wisconsin. "I think maybe we've kind of dragged out our focus on equity long enough and are now shifting to something more substantive. New Mexico's a good example, and California's another one, that sets spending at the state level, and no one can go above that level, which is very low. So it's equal -- but there's not enough money."
School financing remains one of the knottiest problems of education, not just in New Mexico but throughout the nation. Most states have faced lawsuits over financial equity. But two decades of state supreme court rulings -- 18 of them striking down school-financing systems as unconstitutional -- have produced conflicting standards for determining the fairness of financing schemes.
And in many states, the school-financing battles are still raging, both in the courts and in local politics. It is an issue that will not go away, in part because education represents the largest single component of most state budgets.
"It is always, everywhere, an extraordinarily powerful political issue," said John G. Augenblick, a Denver education consultant who has been involved in many states' school-financing debates. "Not every legislator has a hospital or industry in his district, but everyone has a school district, and so everyone will fight endlessly over how much of the pie they should get."
There is tremendous variation in how states pay for their schools. In New Hampshire, where there is a strong tradition of local control and no statewide tax, 90 percent of the money comes from local property taxes -- but that will be changing due to a December court ruling declaring the system unconstitutional. Hawaii, at the other end of the spectrum, has a single school district, which gets 90 percent of its money from the state.
While there is tremendous variation from state to state, the trend since the 1970's has been for states, as in New Mexico, to assume a greater share of the responsibility for school financing -- and to impose some kind of ceiling on affluent districts' spending.
But within these more-equal systems, some schools and some districts are, as George Orwell would have it, more equal than others. In Santa Fe, for example, Partners in Education, a local nonprofit group, raises $300,000 a year, mostly for grants to teachers for art projects, field trips and a literary magazine.
Even within Santa Fe, there are differences. Many years ago, when the state cut the budget for physical education, parents at the Acequia Madre Elementary School on the city's east side, near where tourists come to stroll among art galleries and tasteful adobe houses, raised money to keep their teachers. But on the west side, home of trailer parks and storage warehouses, parents do not raise much money for the Agua Fria Elementary School, and there is no physical education teacher.
In some states, court challenges have led not just to school-finance reform but a whole new system of governance, academic expectations and accountability mechanisms. Kentucky was forced to revamp its school system completely: It increased per-pupil spending by 34 percent in the first three years of reform and, at the same time, rewarded schools that performed well and gave more power to schools.
Increasingly, education experts have been trying to codify just what it takes -- in terms of teachers, curriculum and expenditures -- to provide an adequate education.
And over the next decade, Mr. Odden and others said, educators, state budget officials and judges handling school-finance lawsuits will be increasingly developing standards of adequate education, and then thinking about how to make sure each school has the money to meet those standards, even in poorer states.
"It's a much broader question of school reform, rather than just looking at equity," Mr. Odden said. "It may also be a Federal issue, because if states like New Mexico don't have enough money, they may need extra Federal support. That's an issue that's going to have to be on the table."
The Federal Government, on average, provides 7 percent of each state's education finances. And there has been strong resistance whenever it has made any move to increase its involvement in what has always been a state function.
Legally, the idea that education is a Federal responsibility has been resoundingly rejected: In a 1973 Texas case, the Supreme Court ruled that education was not a fundamental right guaranteed by the Constitution. It was that decision that led to the onslaught of litigation challenging school-financing systems under state constitutions' requirement for "ample," "thorough," "efficient" or "adequate" public education.
In several states, school-financing litigation has become one of the constants on the docket: In New Jersey, Ohio, Texas and elsewhere, there have been generations of court rulings that toss the ball back to the legislature, only to have a revamped system face a new challenge back in the courts. But there is no consistency in the decisions, no single standard has emerged by which to guage how much equity is required, and how much has been achieved.
As has been apparent in New Mexico, it is never as simple as providing the same amount of money for each child, for there are profound differences in children's needs. For example, high school students cost more to educate than third graders; students in sparsely populated areas, who must be bused long distances, cannot be schooled as cheaply as those in cities where the economies of scale come into play. And students who are not native English speakers, or those with physical or mental disabilities, often need expensive special services.
The New Mexico formula has always recognized these differences, with a "rural isolation" factor, for students spread over the state's mountainous desert expanses and a density factor for poor urban children -- a factor that recently, after a court challenge, was converted into an "at-risk" factor for districts with a lot of poor, non-English-speaking children.
But because each district has unique needs, the push to adjust the formula never stops. Right now, the Santa Fe schools are seeking a cost-of-living factor, since teachers in the capital pay such high rents -- on average salaries of $28,000, well below the national average -- that in one recent survey, 8 in 10 teachers reported that they were thinking of leaving.
"The cost-of-living situation is so severe, we have teachers bail out midyear," said Aaron Trummer, the principal of Santa Fe High School, a 22-building campus spread over 90 hilly acres south of town.
This year, the Governor approved a $75,000 study on housing costs in the state, and how they affect teacher recruitment and retention.
Meanwhile, on the Arizona border, the Zuni School District wants more money for capital spending: since the whole district is on Indian land, Zuni has no tax base to finance building and maintenance. Zuni students, taken to Santa Fe in February to plead with legislators for more capital money, told of their school's gas leaks, leaking roofs, inadequate wiring and mildew smell. And in a hot, dry remote reservation with little organized recreation, a beautiful swimming pool in a building next to the middle school sits drained and locked, with no money for the repairs it would take to make it operable.
"We don't want to scrap the whole formula," said Marisa Sanchez, a first-grade teacher at the Dowa Yallane school, whose 14-year-old son, Eriq, testified in the capital. "That wouldn't be fair to anyone. But our children deserve the same kind of schools the kids in Santa Fe have, and the way the formula works, they're not getting it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: New Mexico has achieved some equity in financing schools, but there is too little money to go around. At Santa Fe High School, above, teachers have quit in midyear because of problems making do on their salaries. (Cary Herz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
The airlines may face some new regulations on how to calculate a flight's on-time performance.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
THE airlines' battle for on-time bragging rights, giving the carriers the right to boast in ads that they are No. 1 in flights arriving on schedule, may undergo some wrenching moments if the Department of Transportation follows the recommendation of its Office of Inspector General.
At stake are not just bragging rights but the competition for business travelers, who pay premium fares in the expectation of arriving on time. On-time performance, remember, is the most important factor in the J. D. Power & Associates evaluation of customer satisfaction among business travelers who average 25 round trips or more a year of 500 or more miles. 
 Following a recent audit, the Inspector General, Kenneth W. Mead, made two major recommendations last week: that the department define "arrival" as the opening of the aircraft's passenger door at the gate, and that the department disclose in its rankings whether the arrival times for each airline are recorded manually or by an automated system. Now the department must decide whether to accept the recommendations and turn them into enforceable regulations.
On time is currently defined as the arrival of an aircraft at "the gate or passenger loading area" no later than 15 minutes after the scheduled arrival time. But under that definition, Mr. Mead said, an aircraft could land within 15 minutes of its scheduled arrival yet be reported as late if it did not reach the gate in time. And, he added, the 10 reporting carriers (all the big airlines) currently use five different methods to report arrival: when the plane's parking brake is set, when the engines are shut off, when the blocks are placed behind aircraft wheels, when either the passenger or cargo doors are opened, and when the passenger door is opened.
The investigation was sparked by a complaint from an unnamed airline that two other unnamed carriers using the manual reporting system were submitting falsified arrival times for the purpose of scoring higher in the department's monthly rankings. The only large carriers using the manual system are Southwest, America West and Alaska Airlines, each of which has denied falsifying reports. But since Southwest is always among the top in on-time performance, as well as the carrier whose low fares often drive competitors to distraction, you can be sure Southwest was one of the targets of the auditors.
But after conducting unannounced observations of 372 arriving flights of the two unnamed carriers in January, the auditors said they "found no evidence that either carrier was submitting falsified data." But Mr. Mead added that while manual systems afforded greater leeway than automated systems, the Department of Transportation made no distinction among carriers using the different systems.
Continental Airlines wasted no time hailing the Inspector General's recommendations. It said that since 1996 it has excluded carriers that report manually when it calculates its own employee bonus plan -- $100 for each employee every month Continental ranks first in on-time arrival and $65 in months when it hits an 80 percent on-time rating, or ranks second or third.
 
For Train Travelers
Business and leisure travelers can both benefit from the recently published "Eurail and Train Travel Guide to Europe" (third edition) and "Eurail and Train Travel Guide to the World" (28th edition). Both books, edited by Gena Holle and recently published by Houghton Mifflin, contain fares, timetables and sightseeing notes for cities all over the world. Especially useful is the listing of international rail connections. The books cost $15 and $19, respectively.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New Breed of College All-Star;
Columbia Pays Top Dollar for Economics Heavy Hitter

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The University of Chicago's Sherwin Rosen has been chronicling the "Economics of Superstars" since the beginning of the 1980's. But even he was astounded to learn that Columbia University has just agreed to pay nearly $300,000 a year to lure Robert J. Barro, one of the nation's most distinguished economists, away from Harvard.
The kind of six-figure salary that Professor Barro, 53, will command at Columbia, while perhaps commonplace for economics Ph.D.'s on Wall Street and not unheard of for finance whizzes at major business schools (including Columbia's), is a record-breaker in the market for academic economists who work in more traditional fields like macroeconomics and trade theory. It exceeds by roughly $100,000 the most lucrative offers reported for leading university researchers just a year or two ago. And it is roughly twice the current salary caps for arts and sciences faculty at Harvard, Columbia and other elite universities. 
 "This is a big deal," said Claudia Goldin, a colleague of Professor Barro at Harvard. "It's broken the sound barrier."
An ex-New Yorker with attitude, Dr. Barro has exuded stardom since his graduate school days at Harvard in the late 1960's. He has changed the way economists think about everything from the long-run effects of government deficits to the forces that favor economic growth. A mainstream conservative with a libertarian streak who writes for The Wall Street Journal and Business Week, he has produced scholarly articles that are cited by other researchers as often as those of Paul Samuelson, Milton Friedman and Robert Lucas.
As the bidding for Professor Barro shows, the market for top economists is starting to look like those for movie stars, basketball players and bond traders. It carries all the trappings, too -- complex negotiations, signing bonuses and highly organized raids. And the forces that have turned top economists into what the Columbia provost, Jonathan R. Cole, ruefully calls "free agents without salary caps" are not all that different: lots of customers (rising enrollments), lots of cash in a few pockets (swelling tuition payments and endowments at elite institutions) and a tight consensus on who the most valuable players are.
Add to that the growing feeling among a number of institutions of higher learning that as one academic put it, "If you don't have a good economics department, you can't have a great university."
The focus on money has moved into the uppermost tier of schools, which have traditionally counted mostly on their reputations to lure talent. "At the top schools, there's been a reluctance to play the game, to think that we can score a tremendous coup if we pay a lot for X," said Peter Kenen, an economist at Princeton University who was chairman of Columbia's economics department in the 1960's. "But the pressure to push against salary caps and exceed them is getting stronger and stronger."
In making its dramatic bid, Columbia hopes to break back into the top league, where it used to rank alongside Harvard, Princeton, Stanford, M.I.T. and the University of Chicago. It sees Professor Barro as a kind of franchise player who can not just pull up the team by his mere presence but also act as a magnet for talented young faculty.
For Harvard's highly ranked economics department, which has not lost a senior professor to a rival department since Stanford recaptured Kenneth J. Arrow in 1979. Columbia's coup has come as a wake-up call. The faculty dean, Jeremy Knowles -- who used to brag that "I have never matched an outside offer!" -- is, by all accounts, building a war chest to fend off future raids.
Just as extraordinary as the salary Columbia will pay is the cornucopia of perks and privileges Professor Barro won in months of negotiations. To lure him, Columbia helped place his teen-age son in an exclusive Manhattan private school, offered a $55,000-a-year university post to his wife, Judy, who is just returning to the work force and eased out the prior tenant of a 2,300-square-foot university-owned apartment on Riverside Drive, which the Barros coveted. The rent is subsidized at half the apartment's estimated market rate, with a lavish renovation, courtesy of Columbia, thrown in for good measure.
While Professor Barro also has other sources of income, it all adds up to at least a $150,000 gain for his family.
Other parts of the deal entail even heftier investments by Columbia. Professor Barro will occupy three spacious offices on the impossibly cramped and overcrowded campus. He will direct a sizable chunk of resources at the university's new social science research center. Most important, Professor Barro will have a green light from the administration to recruit a half-dozen promising younger economists.
The whole thing started more than a year ago when Professor Barro, who was feeling underpaid, began dropping hints that he might be willing to move. The first to respond was Boston University, which failed to put together a $250,000 offer last spring. When Columbia heard that he might be "gettable," the economics department and business school teamed up to go after him. Until the deal, which has not been made public, was finally consummated in February, hardly anyone at either Columbia or Harvard expected it to come off. Around Christmas, a Harvard friend offered Columbia's department chairman 20-to-1 odds against Professor Barro's accepting.
The extras clinched it. The Columbia dean, David H. Cohen, made the salary offer at the beginning of the negotiations and hardly raised it. The promise that Professor Barro would have six new slots to fill was made in October.
Soon afterward, however, the negotiations almost foundered because Columbia was unable to find a suitable apartment. But by the time Dean Knowles of Harvard invited Professor Barro to a long, wine-drenched dinner in February to present Harvard's counteroffer -- involving a new research center -- Ms. Barro was already meeting with architects, their son had received his acceptance letter from the Dalton School and a job offer was about to go out to one of Professor Barro's former students, Casey Mulligan at Chicago.
Harvard was too late, if not exactly too little. "If he had offered me in November what he did in February, I probably would have stayed." Professor Barro said.
To be sure, academic recruiting beyond the junior level -- particularly in New York, where housing and schools are major stumbling blocks -- has always been a complex, expensive undertaking. But Columbia's willingness to put together a deal of these proportions shows how much it expects to benefit from Professor Barro's presence. "We're capturing a lot of the surplus that Robert will generate," said R. Glenn Hubbard, an economist in the business school and one of the main flag carriers in the Barro negotiations.
Economics is now the No. 1 major at Columbia. As enrollments have doubled, the faculty has shrunk. The business school, now one of the most competitive in the country, also considers a highly rated economics department vital to its own continuing success.
The business school dean, Meyer Feldberg, consulted Milton Friedman on the hire. "Milton was very positive," Dean Feldberg recalled. "He said: 'Barro's young. He's got visibility. People are drawn to him.' "
Not all of Professor Barro's peers are equally enthusiastic. Some consider his recent empirical work superficial, others feel his theoretical work is less elegant than, say, that of Professor Lucas, who first coined the phrase "rational expectations" and is revered for his rigorous, spare style. Still others point to Professor Barro's prickly persona. (He was known, as a young professor at the University of Chicago, for his outbursts during debates and his scathing attitude toward less stellar colleagues.)
But even his critics acknowledge that Dr. Barro is productive, influential and a "builder," who in the early 1980's strengthened the economics department at the University of Rochester, and he continues to train an impressive number of first-rate students -- Barroids as they are called.
The notion that a big push can restore Columbia's faded glory is a tantalizing one. Columbia once had students like Kenneth Arrow, Milton Friedman and Alan Greenspan. Its faculty included some of the great pioneers of empirical economics -- Wesley Mitchell, Arthur Burns, George Stigler. But by the time Gary Becker, who taught at Columbia throughout the 60's, decamped for the University of Chicago in 1970, student revolts, a dysfunctional administration and New York City's decline were pulling the university down and the economics department with it.
That said, Columbia boasts some remarkable thinkers, one or more of whom could easily win a Nobel Prize. These include Jagdish Bhagwati, Kelvin Lancaster and Robert Mundell in trade, Edmund Phelps in macroeconomics. (William Vickrey, a member of the department, died within days of receiving a prize last year.) But this group is about to retire. Columbia also has some promising researchers recently out of graduate school. What it lacks is a vital middle -- those in their prime years of 35 to 55 -- that normally forms the intellectual and administrative leadership. It is this "great void" that Professor Barro has been elected to fill. As Professor Bhagwati put it: "The students don't care if we get four Nobels. They want to learn the latest stuff."
In the past, great departments were built slowly. But armed with a growing endowment and emboldened by the comeback of New York City, Columbia thinks it might just be able to engineer a big leap up by buying its way into the top bracket. "We saw a chance to jump-start the process," said George Rupp, the president of Columbia.
In one of the earliest rounds of talks last summer, Professor Barro handed Professor Cole, the Columbia provost, a list of 10 to 12 "young seniors" he would like to see at Columbia. (Young seniors are newly tenured professors or those about to be tenured.) They included Caroline Hoxby, Ed Glaeser and David Laibson at Harvard as well as Michael S. Kremer, a MacArthur Fellow at M.I.T.
"It's a great test," commented Kevin Murphy at the University of Chicago. "I'm a little skeptical, but if it's successful, it will change the way people think about the build-or-buy decision: money will talk and blitz campaigns will work."
The trouble is, says Dale Jorgenson, former department head at Harvard, "Everybody's trying to do the same thing. It's happening all at once."
Senior hiring, as angling for stars is called, has been hot and heavy for a while. Princeton has lucrative offers out to "half of the Chicago department," as one Chicagoan anxiously put it. Upwardly mobileschools like Boston University have been making aggressive offers, as has New York University, which is paying one of its home-grown stars, Boyan Jovanovic, a macroeconomist, a cool $200,000.
Well-heeled business and public policy schools are also eager to hire economists. Harvard's Kennedy School, under its dean, Joseph S. Nye, has been on a shopping spree, with handsome offers currently out to five economists, including Alan Krueger and Ken Rogoff at Princeton. .
"Everybody's budgets have been liberated," complains Professor Rosen, the expert on superstars. "Recruiting is getting harder."
Harvard's newfound determination to fight back partly reflects the fact that Professor Barro's departure comes on top of others in the core economics disciplines. Lawrence Summers left to join the Treasury Department; Andreu Mas-Collel decamped to the presidency of a research university in Barcelona. Now Princeton and Berkeley are making aggressive plays for a key price theorist, Drew Fudenberg.
The risks are not all Harvard's of course. Professor Barro will be leaving behind world class students and younger colleagues. "Robert is making a terrible mistake," said Jeffrey Williamson, chairman of Harvard's economics department. "It's a big step down."

HEADLINE: The Chinese Burst Onto the Tourist Scene

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: PATTAYA, Thailand

 BODY:
At a wildlife park called the Nong Nooch Tropical Garden, a gaggle of camera-toting tourists from China jostled for position at a souvenir stand to buy gaudy knickknacks, while others took turns riding elephants adorned with red-and-green silk saddles.
"I need a picture with the orangutan," said Chen Yiren, 28, sounding breathless with the excitement of taking her first trip outside her native China. "No one will believe I came if I don't have pictures." 
 Chinese tourists are flocking overseas, spending handfuls of cash and reflecting a new economic reality. As Southeast Asian nations struggle to recover from a devastating financial crisis, China has suddenly emerged as a major source of tourists, bolstering an industry hurt by a severe falloff in visitors from South Korea, Japan, Hong Kong and Taiwan.
Planeloads of Chinese tour groups now arrive in Thailand each day, filling hotels, restaurants and tourist shops.
At the same time, China is relaxing restrictions on overseas travel, permitting ordinary citizens to go abroad. In 1997, China allowed 2.6 million citizens to leave the country on tourist visas, up from 1.6 million in 1996, and the number is expected to increase further this year.
Not long ago, groups of Chinese officials who traveled overseas were kept in groups to make sure no one tried to emigrate. But tourists are now given plenty of opportunity to roam unattended, and many seem to use their free time to shop.
"The whole situation has changed," said Wu Derong, sales manager of the China Youth Travel Service in Shanghai, counting off the reasons why Chinese tourists now dominate the trade. "The exit procedures are easier, the entry visas to Thailand are easier, the prices are going down, but most of all, Chinese people have money to spend."
Traveling to Thailand has suddenly become one of the hottest fads among young professionals in China's larger cities, but it is also popular among retirees, many of whom are sent by their children.
"Several of my friends came last year, so I wanted to come too," said Wang Liping, 26, a Shanghai marketing executive. "I really wanted to see the transvestite performance."
The high point of a five-day Thailand tour, Ms. Wang said, was indeed a glitzy nightclub act performed by Thai transvestites, whose spectacular costumes, slick stagework and lip-synching to well-known pop songs wowed an audience of Chinese visitors. After the show, the parking lot was packed with Chinese tourists posing for photographs with heavily made-up transvestites.
Thailand is the most popular destination for Chinese tourists, in part because it is the most affordable. China's tourist agencies offer a five-day trip to Thailand from Beijing or Shanghai for less than $500, including air fare on Chinese or Thai carriers, hotel, meals and local transportation.
For slightly more, other travelers are venturing to Malaysia, Singapore and the Philippines. Last year, China approved Australia as a tourist destination as well.
"We'd like to be able to take tourists to Hawaii in the future," said Mr. Wu, the Shanghai travel agent. But the United States is not yet issuing tourist visas to Chinese routinely, and requires applicants for official, business and student visas to produce a letter of invitation from an American host.
On one recent tour group to Thailand from Shanghai, half of the tourists were young professionals, the other half retirees. For roughly two-thirds of them, it was the first time out of China.
In addition to the wildlife park and the transvestite show, the itinerary included a series of state-run shops in Bangkok that eagerly accepted Chinese currency, the yuan, which was shunned until recently because banks will still not freely convert it into Thai baht or American dollars.
No longer shy at spending, Chinese tourists are now among the biggest buyers of gold and other jewelry, leather goods and traditional medicine at Thai tourist shops. Thai officials estimate that the average Chinese tourist spends nearly $40 a day on shopping, almost as much as the $45 spent by the average Japanese tourist.
One required stop for Chinese tour groups is a traditional medicine store. There visitors are encouraged to buy capsules of snake oil and of a powder supposedly concocted from snake penis -- particularly popular among Chinese men, who believe it enhances virility.
At the Bangkok Handicrafts Center, more than a hundred Chinese-speaking sales clerks are at the counters each morning as the busloads of Chinese tourists arrive. In the afternoon, they are replaced by English-speaking clerks, for the European groups.
"We used to train tour guides to speak Korean and Japanese," said Surachai Achasewin, a tourism official in Bangkok. "Now Mandarin is the language we need most."
The tourists lining up to take elephant rides at the Nong Nooch Tropical Garden were easily identifiable by tour tags bearing the names of various travel agencies in the Chinese cities where they originated.
Outside, the tour buses told the story in numbers: of 38 buses in the parking lot, 34 carried tourists from mainland China, 2 were from Taiwan, and 2 carried Germans.
Many Chinese visitors are arrogant about the superiority of their own cuisine and culture, especially compared with that of their Asian neighbors.
"I hate Thai food," said Chen Jing, 32, a factory manager. "I think China has many more places worth visiting than Thailand."
On Mr. Chen's five-day tour, all the arranged meals were Chinese except for a single Thai buffet on the final day. Even then, most members of the Chinese group kept to simple foods like fried vegetables and soup.
Chinese tourists, compared with travelers from other Asian countries, are generally quiet and group-oriented, separating in their free time to hit the Thai department stores.
Before the rush of tourism began in 1996, most Chinese visitors to Thailand were officials on "inspection tours" paid for by local government offices. Many visited sex shows and Thai bathhouses, where prostitutes with a number on their bathing suits sit on view behind a window as they wait to be chosen by a customer.
But since most of today's booming tourist crop are young professional or retired couples, they stick mostly to a daytime itinerary of parks, temples, water sports and shopping.
Bai Guangming, 36, a manager at a privately run manufacturing business in Shanghai, said he had been trying for more than a year to arrange time off to visit Thailand.
"I wanted to get away," Mr. Bai said, sounding like a typically harried executive. "It was hard to get the time off."
Like the others on his trip, Mr. Bai had obtained a special Chinese passport for one-time travel, which cost $35. This was issued routinely after he showed a letter from his travel agent saying he had already paid for a trip to Thailand. In the past, Chinese authorities issued passports and exit permits only to officials, businessmen and students who could provide a letter of invitation from an overseas sponsor.
Only a few years ago, Chinese tourists were largely limited to trips within China organized by their factory or office. But today's travelers are spending their own money, and often seem most interested in finding bargains and value.
At an informational meeting in Shanghai a few days before the tour departed, Chu Yiqian, a 24-year-old graduate student, piped up.
"I have one question," she said. "Can I use my Visa card in Thailand?"

The Chinese are flocking overseas these days, with Thailand the most popular destination. (Seth Faison/The New York Times)(pg. A8)

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRESSES DEBATE ON CHANGE IN SOCIAL SECURITY

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 7

 BODY:
With charts at his side and an array of solutions being debated before him, President Clinton began trying to build consensus today on addressing Social Security's looming financial problems, and he said he thought the job could be accomplished without raising the payroll taxes that finance the retirement system.
Speaking to the first of four regional conferences on Social Security this year, Mr. Clinton for the most part kept to generalities and left open the possibility of sweeping changes, including the proposal to make individual investment accounts a part of what until now has been solely a guaranteed Government benefit program. 
 He all but ruled out increasing the 12.4 percent payroll tax rate, split equally between employees and employers, as a way to close the financial gap that Social Security will face as the baby boom generation retires in coming decades. And he said he would be reluctant to eliminate the cap on earnings, now $68,400, above which workers pay no further payroll taxes for Social Security.
Mr. Clinton said the debate was critical now, when the strong economy and the nation's newfound fiscal health present "a rare opportunity to prepare our nation for the challenges and the opportunities of the 21st century, or in the words of an old saying, to fix the roof while the sun is still shining."
"If we act now," he said, "we can insure strong retirement benefits for the baby boom generation without placing an undue burden on our children and our grandchildren. And we can do it, if we act now, with changes that will be far simpler and easier than if we wait until the problem is closer at hand."
Generally, Mr. Clinton stuck to his strategy of neither endorsing nor shooting down any of the major options for reshaping Social Security and of calling on Congress to leave any future budget surpluses untouched until Congress and the White House have settled on a plan.
Pressed by questioners to take a specific position, Mr. Clinton said that doing so now would inhibit the national debate and that he would put his ideas on the table in December at a bipartisan White House conference.
Mr. Clinton suggested, and his aides later confirmed, that the Administration would be willing to consider individual accounts as part of a comprehensive solution only if the overall plan insured that Social Security would continue to provide recipients with a guaranteed retirement benefit.
"Social Security must provide a benefit that people can count on," Mr. Clinton said. "Regardless of the ups and downs of the economy or the financial markets, we have to provide a solid and dependable foundation of retirement security."
But there was plenty of evidence right on the platform with Mr. Clinton that allowing investments in Social Security would be central to the debate over how to prepare the system for the retirement starting in about a decade of the 76-million- member baby boom generation.
The two speakers immediately following Mr. Clinton in the first portion of the daylong program -- Senators Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, a Republican, and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, a Democrat -- backed the idea of private accounts. A third, Representative Kenny Hulshof of Missouri, a Republican, said the idea deserved study, and a fourth, Representative Earl Pomeroy of North Dakota, a Democrat, said the Social Security system itself might invest in the stock market.
Other options being discussed are cutting benefits, accelerating a planned increase in the retirement age to 67, increasing taxes on benefits received by the affluent and using Federal budget surpluses -- projected by the White House at more than $1 trillion over the next decade -- to extend Social Security's solvency. Without any changes, Social Security will run short of money starting in 2029 and would thereafter be able to pay only 75 percent of promised benefits.
Mr. Clinton said that each $100 billion dedicated to Social Security would extend the program's solvency by a year.
But his aides said Mr. Clinton had yet to decide how much of any surplus he would like to dedicate to Social Security, despite his challenge to Congress not to spend any of the surplus until Social Security's problems had been dealt with.
Republicans have been wary of letting Mr. Clinton manage the national debate. Republicans in the House are pressing for creation of a Congressionally mandated commission to come up with a legislative proposal, but the Administration rejected that in favor of a White House conference in December.
Mr. Pomeroy said he was encouraged that the debate over Social Security as an investment program versus an insurance program had not become a partisan chasm and that there appeared to be broad agreement that the system should retain some guaranteed benefit.
"The rest we can negotiate," Mr. Pomeroy said.
For Mr. Clinton, today's event, held in a gym at Penn Valley Community College and sponsored by the American Association of Retired Persons and the Concord Coalition, a fiscal watchdog group, was an opportunity to plunge into the details of a policy debate and leave behind the scandals in Washington.
Fielding questions in the afternoon from an audience selected by a market research company to reflect the demographic and economic characteristics of the Kansas City area, Mr. Clinton touched on an array of issues relating to retirement security, health care and taxes.
Members of the audience added their opinions.
"I don't know if privatization of Social Security is a good idea or not," said one woman, who identified herself as a nurse, while addressing a question to Mr. Clinton. "My husband and I can afford it. We have an income of over $100,000 a year. There's people in here, though, who don't, and I guess I have several challenging questions."
Foremost among them, she said, was that if the nation allocates some of Social Security's money for private accounts, "then, are we really socially secure and not taking out that security piece?"
Ultimately, Mr. Clinton told the audience, it would be up to the nation to tell political leaders how they would make tradeoffs between options like raising the retirement age, eliminating the income cap and establishing private accounts.

HEADLINE: Pataki Donor Under Inquiry Settled Previous Tunnel Case

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
A construction company that is the subject of Federal investigations into whether it obtained a $97 million state contract in return for donations to New York's Republican Party was earlier accused of mismanaging a related project, according to interviews and state records.
The company was never penalized for its performance on the first project -- repairs to the Queens-Midtown Tunnel between 1993 and 1996 -- and was even paid extra by the state after the company's owner raised more than $100,000 in 1995 for Gov. George E. Pataki and the Republicans, the interviews and records show. 
 The state agency that operates the tunnel, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, reached a settlement with the company soon after the Governor and his senior economic development adviser attended a party for the Pataki campaign at the home of the company's owner. Two years later, donors connected to the company, Silverite Construction, gave another $100,000 to the Republicans around the time that the company received the $97 million contract, also for work in the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.
Aides to Mr. Pataki and M.T.A. officials said there was no connection between the way that the authority supervised projects and political contributions. They said that career civil servants without ties to the Pataki administration made all the decisions on the tunnel projects.
The authority originally chastised Silverite for "serious and material contract breaches" on the earlier project because of a major violation of asbestos procedures in the Queens-Midtown Tunnel. Despite this finding in late 1994, the authority awarded the company the $97 million contract last year.
Silverite's owner, Angelo J. Silveri, is one of the biggest financial backers of Mr. Pataki and the New York Republican State Committee. Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn and Manhattan are investigating the awarding of the $97 million contract to Silverite Construction, and both offices have subpoenaed Mr. Silveri. It is not known whether prosecutors are looking into the earlier project.
The $100,000 that was given last year brought the total contributions that Mr. Silveri and donors linked to him have given the Pataki campaign and the Republicans since October 1994 to more than $335,000, records show. That figure includes the more than $100,000 that he raised in two months in 1995.
A spokesman for the authority, Tom Kelly, said its management had not been aware of contributions linked to Mr. Silveri, which include his own donations and others by his family members, business associates, companies that he controls and a political action committee that Silverite Construction established. "There is no way for anyone associated with the M.T.A. to know anything about campaign contributions," Mr. Kelly said.
He dismissed the authority's criticism of Silverite over the asbestos procedures on the earlier project, saying that it was part of the "contract management evaluation process." Mr. Kelly noted that the authority's final assessment of the project had found that Silverite had done a satisfactory job.
Asked how often the authority accuses a general contractor on a major project of "serious and material contract breaches," Mr. Kelly said that, "it happens all the time."
Mr. Kelly also blamed the asbestos subcontractor that had been hired by Silverite for some of the problems. He said that Silverite ended up working with the authority to insure that the asbestos was removed properly. He said that because of that cooperation, the company was neither penalized nor disqualified from receiving the $97 million contract.
The authority awarded the 1997 project to Silverite and another company, Frontier-Kemper Constructors, after originally determining that the two companies were not qualified.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, acknowledged that the Governor attended a party at Mr. Silveri's home in Oyster Bay, N.Y., on May 4, 1995, along with his senior economic development adviser, Charles A. Gargano.
"It was a fund-raising-related event and it was attended by 20 or so people," Mr. McKeon said. Asked whether Mr. Pataki discussed state contracts with Mr. Silveri at the party, Mr. McKeon said: "It's a ridiculous question. I think that people have more respect for the Governor than that."
Edward M. Shaw, a lawyer for Mr. Silveri, said, "Most emphatically, the contributions had no relationship whatsoever to any issues relating to the contract."
The M.T.A. awarded Silverite a $14.1 million contract in 1993 to repair the roadway and fresh air ducts in the Queens-Midtown Tunnel. At that time, Mr. Pataki's predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, was Governor and controlled the authority.
Early on Friday, Sept. 23, 1994, the authority discovered that workers were removing asbestos from the tunnel's fresh air duct in what inspectors deemed an unsafe manner, according to letters that the authority later sent Silverite. The authority temporarily halted the project and kept one of the tunnel's two tubes closed until 9:45 A.M., creating traffic jams.
A senior authority official involved in the project, who spoke on condition of anonymity, recalled in a recent interview that the discovery of the improper asbestos procedures was an "awful situation," saying that as a result, the M.T.A. had contemplated removing Silverite from the project. The authority considered the potential health risks so serious that it conducted an internal investigation into how such incidents could be avoided, officials said.
The authority ordered Silverite to fire the subcontractor that Silverite had hired to remove the asbestos, a company called East Coast Services. But in letters to Silverite over the next two months, the authority said Silverite was solely responsible for the violations of asbestos procedures. The authority said it had the right to demand "reimbursement from the contractor for extra costs incurred by the authority in connection with these serious contract violations."
Silverite contended that the authority owed it $2 million in additional compensation because it had to hire a new asbestos subcontractor and adopt more costly asbestos removal procedures.
On March 8, 1995, while the dispute continued, the New York Republican State Committee received donations of $25,000 each from Mr. Silveri and three family members, according to campaign finance records.
In late April, Mr. Pataki took control of the authority when he appointed E. Virgil Conway as its chairman. On May 4, 1995, Mr. Silveri held the party at his home, which was attended by Mr. Pataki. On May 20, 1995, the authority reached a settlement with Silverite, said Mr. Kelly, the authority spokesman.
The authority gave Silverite an extra $400,000, rather than the $2 million it had initially requested. In July 1995, in its first formal review of Silverite's performance, the authority gave the company satisfactory marks, with no bad grades, including any connected to the asbestos removal, Mr. Kelly said. He added that since the asbestos problems at the tunnel, the M.T.A. had refused to allow East Coast Services to work on the authority's projects.

HEADLINE: SHAPING A COLOSSUS: THE VISION;
The One-Stop Financial Mall: Is It What Peoria Longs For?

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Though the planned combination of Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc. has drawn superlatives on Wall Street, it gets much of its inspiration from the more mundane confines of the shopping mall.
As the companies see it, consumers who once abandoned the Main Street butcher, baker and candlestick maker for giant stores in the suburbs are now eager to see their insurance agencies, bank branches and securities brokers as financial supermarkets: stocks and bonds in aisle 1, property and casualty policies in aisle 3, mortgages in aisle 5, all passing through the same checkout counter. 
 There is no question that the creation of Citigroup Inc., the behemoth that will emerge if the merger is completed, represents a milestone in financial history. The deal, valued at $70 billion in stock at the time it was announced on Monday and more than $84 billion later in the day as Citicorp's shares rose, would be the biggest ever. Still, some of the initial euphoria among investors waned yesterday, trimming the value to $78 billion. Page D1.
And some observers wonder what is in store in the new world promised by this mega-merger. "If the result of this merger is four insurance brochures on a rack in a bank branch, then it's going to be failure," said Charlene Stern, president of Stern Marketing Group, a Berkeley, Calif., consulting firm. "They've got to learn from the best retailers out there -- and not each other -- about how to sell all these products effectively. Cross-selling has not been overwhelmingly effective at any bank yet."
Indeed, no one should know better the potential pitfalls of one-stop financial shopping than the two engineers of this deal, John S. Reed of Citicorp and Sanford I. Weill of Travelers. Although Mr. Reed noted on Monday that Travelers had had success cross-selling its arsenal of financial products, Mr. Weill was an executive at the American Express Company when that prestigious corporation's experiment with one-stop shopping failed in the 1980's.
Even so, Mr. Reed defended the concept, arguing that superior salesmanship and marketing practices will allow Citigroup to succeed where others have failed.
"It's a business proposition whose time has come," Mr. Reed said, noting that customers in the future will not "want to go from place to place" to manage their personal finances.
Despite the past failures, one-stop shopping remains the Holy Grail for many financial services concerns. Fueled by a historic bull market in stocks and increasing consumer sophistication, financial products have leap-frogged apparel as the third-largest source of consumer purchases after food and gasoline, according to Ms. Stern.
Moreover, Mercer Management Consulting Inc., said that only 10 percent of bank customers deliver about 90 percent of the profits -- and those are the customers who use several products supplied by the same bank.
"If Citicorp and Travelers do it right, they will change the industry," said Scott Birnbaum, Mercer's director of global financial services consulting. "If they don't succeed, somebody else will step up to the plate because there are huge economic opportunities there."
Complicating Citigroup's attempt to create a financial supermarket is a thicket of regulatory issues that the company must still negotiate, as well as public concern about the dangers of financial concentration.
"With one-stop shopping malls like this the potential for abuse is enhanced," said Samuel Hayes, a Harvard Business School professor. "Regulators, especially the Securities and Exchange Commission, are going to have to watch all of this with a particularly jaundiced eye."
Smaller competitors of the merged company also have concerns about financial supermarkets. The Independent Bankers Association of America, a Washington, D.C., trade group that represents community banks, said it was worried that a combination of Citicorp and Travelers might drive out competition and limit small towns' access to financial products and services.
Other than local competition there is historical precedent for large financial combinations opening the door to abuses or risky financial practices. Consider the following:
In 1933, Congressional hearings disclosed that a major bank, the National City Company, had repackaged bad loans as bonds and then dumped them into the laps of unwitting investors who did business with its securities affiliate. And six decades later, Deutsche Bank A.G. was forced to bail out Metallgesellschaft A.G., a corporate borrower in which it held a 13 percent stake, after the company was hammered by losses from risky derivatives trading.
To be sure, regulators are more vigilant and sophisticated now than they were earlier in the century, and the risks of integrating financial and commercial companies may have more to do with lax management than with the threats posed by big mergers. Still, the proposed merger of Citicorp and Travelers would create a corporation of distinctly large proportions. "This is the biggest thing since the creation of U.S. Steel in 1901," said Robert Sobel, a financial historian at Hofstra University. "We're in territory that we haven't seen in a long, long time. I don't know what it means yet."
Beyond the public policy concerns, Citigroup's management will still face a daunting task: proving that as a financial superstore it can deliver a wide array of financial products cheaply and efficiently.
Other companies that have tried to refashion themselves as financial Wal-Marts, selling everything from credit cards to stocks under one roof, have run into trouble. Besides American Express, Sears, Roebuck & Company also failed in its effort to cross-sell financial goods.
Analysts said that even with one of the most venerable retailing traditions in the country, Sears was unable to make Dean Witter, Discover & Company's stocks and credit cards attractive to customers for one simple reason -- customers were not ready to buy financial products in a store they associated with televisions, gardening tools and cheap clothing.
And American Express was so swept up in the notion of assembling a juicy buffet of financial services that the day-to-day management of each business, such as its Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. brokerage unit, was unfocused and therefore unappealing to customers. For example, Shearson was notably scattershot in some of the merger advisory work it attempted to deliver to large corporate clients.
But Citicorp and Travelers said they planned to bring superior salesmanship and marketing to their efforts -- even though Citicorp has already had problems selling financial extras to its credit card holders.
"This is not Sears and Dean Witter selling stocks and socks," said Mary McDermott, a Travelers spokeswoman. "We're not necessarily trying to be all things to all people. This idea of a financial supermarket is a media creation. We're trying to take our capabilities on a global scale."
Other banks are also pursuing the one-stop-shopping ideal, albeit on a far less grand scale than what is envisioned by Citicorp and Travelers. That is most obvious in the flurry of recent brokerage firm acqusitions made by banks: the Bankers Trust New York Corporation's purchase of Alex. Brown Inc., the BankAmerica Corporation's acquisition of Robertson Stephens & Company, and the Nationsbank Corporation's purchase of Montgomery Securities Inc.
But other very profitable banks, perhaps most notably the Bank of New York Company, have opted out of the financial supermarket hustle, choosing instead to tie their fortunes to a narrower range of businesses such as securities processing and old-fashioned, local banking.
Still, chief executives were buoyed by the merger announcement.
"I think this is going to change how we do business and think about business," said Saul Steinberg, chairman of the insurance giant Reliance Group Holdings Inc., who was rebuffed by regulators 30 years ago when he made a bid for the old Chemical Banking Corporation. "There are no limits on our imaginations now."

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
Indonesia and I.M.F. Agree On a New Rescue Plan
Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund reached an agreement on the third plan in six months for rescuing the country's economy, after both sides made concessions to permit Indonesia to continue providing huge subsidies for food and fuel and to close more insolvent banks. A1 

Rescue Effort for Ulster Talks
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain flew to Northern Ireland to try to remove a snag in the peace talks between Protestant and Roman Catholic political leaders, after a Protestant leader rejected proposals. A3
 
Political Schisms in Iran
A growing outcry in Iran over the detention of Teheran's Mayor, Gholamhossein Karbaschi, in an investigation into corruption has exposed deep schisms between the moderates who triumphed in presidential elections a year ago and the conservatives who have dominated the country since the Islamic Revolution of 1979. A6
 
Yeltsin Presses for Support
President Boris N. Yeltsin summoned his opponents to the Kremlin in an effort to show that he has a steady grip on the reins of power and to drum up support for his nominee for Prime Minister, Sergei N. Kiriyenko. The key question appears to be not whether Mr. Kiriyenko will be approved, but what the cost will be in concessions by Mr. Yeltsin. A3

Move Toward Autonomy Vote
A United Nations team has identified 101,772 potential voters in the Western Sahara for a referendum to decide either on integration with Morocco or independence. A previous effort at voting was derailed by disputes over who could vote. Those who favor independence have contended that Morocco has moved people into the area so they can vote. The ballot is set for Dec. 7 under a plan brokered by James Baker, a former American Secretary of State. (Reuters)
 
Bulgaria Pledges to Aid Gypsies
Bulgaria is planning steps to promote integration of its large, impoverished and often ostracized Gypsy population, officials said. After the collapse of Communism in 1989, Gypsies lost access to jobs previously reserved for them. (Reuters)
 
A Former Nazi Is Freed
A former Nazi major, Karl Hass, 86, who was sentenced to life in prison last month for his role in Italy's worst World War II massacre, has been freed from house arrest, his lawyer said. The lawyer said a new Italian military court had accepted an appeal and that Mr. Hass could now move freely as long as he told the authorities of his whereabouts. (Reuters)
 
Site Set for Korean Talks
South Korea accepted Beijing as the site for direct talks with North Korea on Saturday, the South's unification ministry said. South Korea had said it would prefer the talks be held on the Korean peninsula, but the North pressed for Beijing. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A12-17
 
Side Air Bags to Be Offered On More Cars and Vans
Ford, concerned by the death rate of people in cars hit from the side, will announce today that it will offer side air bags on all of its cars and Ford Windstar mini-vans in the next two years, Ford officials said. Ford will become the first mass-market auto maker to offer side air bags on all its cars; it has not offered such devices on any of its United States models. General Motors already offers side air bags on a half-dozen of its 81 models. And G.M. said that it would add 15 more in the next two years. A1
 
Overhaul of Social Security
President Clinton spoke to a regional conference on Social Security as he began trying to build consensus on addressing the program's looming financial problems. He said he thought the goal could be accomplished without raising the payroll taxes that finance the retirement system. A1

White House officials, expecting a report to Congress by the Whitewater independent counsel, are trying to undercut the reliability of witnesses and questioning their ties to top Republican officials. A14

Lewinsky. Mrs. Cardozo has told friends that Kathleen Willey called her hours after a meeting with Mr. Clinton on Nov. 29, 1993, during which, Ms. Willey said, Mr. Clinton groped her. A14
 
Re-evaluating Pesticide Risk
Vice President Al Gore, trying to mollify an anxious agriculture industry, is ordering the E.P.A. to revamp the process it uses to decide whether pesticides are dangerous to children. A16
 
Sonny Bono's Widow Wins Seat

HEADLINE: 'Nanny Tax' Law Should Be Revised;
Unfair Worker Burden

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your April 5 front-page article says that "maids who bring their own tools and cleaning solutions are arguably independent contractors, not employees, and thus might be exempt from the nanny tax." According to the Internal Revenue Service, a maid is an employee and not an independent contractor. 
 You also report that one of the more promising ideas for dealing with tax evasion is to make all household employees independent contractors, responsible for their own taxes. Such a move would unfairly shift the Social Security tax from employers to low-wage workers.
In addition, as nonemployees, maids and nannies would be excluded from unemployment compensation.
 
CATHERINE RUCKELHAUS
MARC LINDER
New York, April 5, 1998
 
The writers are, respectively, a lawyer with the National Employment Law Project and a law professor at the University of Iowa.

HEADLINE: Side Air Bags To Be Offered On More Cars

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 7

 BODY:
Side air bags will soon be much more common in cars on the American road.
The Ford Motor Company, expressing concern about the death rate of people in cars hit from the side, plans to announce on Wednesday that it will offer side air bags on all of its cars and Ford Windstar mini-vans over the next several years, company officials said today. 
 Ford will become the first mass-market auto maker to offer side air bags on all its cars; it has not offered such devices on any of its United States models.
The General Motors Corporation already offers side air bags on a half-dozen of its 81 models. And G.M. said today that it planned to add 15 more over the next two years. Luxury car makers like BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Volvo also offer side air bags, and now Ford and G.M. think their customers will want them, too.
Ford's side air bags will be built into the outer side of both the driver's seat and the front passenger's seat, and will inflate to protect the occupant's neck and head. They will be offered first as options on the new Mercury Cougar coupe this spring and the redesigned Ford Windstar this autumn. Ford had said in 1995 that it would install some side air bags, but never made the broad commitment to do so in its entire lineup. Ford executives said today that as each model undergoes even modest redesigns, side air bags would be added, with virtually all models getting them over the next 2 years.
The side air bags will be standard equipment on Ford's luxury cars, particularly Lincoln sedans. They will become standard equipment on less-expensive models as soon as buyers start consistently choosing them as an option, said Robert L. Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing, sales and service. Ford is still working on side air bags for sport utility vehicles, but safety research has found less of a problem when these off-road vehicles are hit in the side.
Side-impact collisions have in recent years accounted for a growing proportion of all deaths in traffic collisions -- now 30 percent -- as air bags and seat belts have made frontal collisions less dangerous. Nearly 7,000 Americans a year die just in side impact collisions involving two vehicles. Federal regulators, insurance industry researchers and the auto makers' own safety experts have grown increasingly worried in recent months that the spread of light trucks, including sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, may mean that more of the collisions will be deadly.
A report from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in late February found that while sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans make up only a third of the vehicles on the road, they are the striking vehicles in nearly 60 percent of all fatal side-impact collisions. Some full-sized sport utility vehicles have hoods that are nearly as high as the roofs of mid-sized cars, so they tend to strike a car occupant higher than a car would.
New Federal rules now taking effect require greater protection for the heads of car occupants during collisions from all angles. Neil W. Ressler, Ford's vice president for advanced vehicle technology, said Ford could meet the standards by installing more cushioning in the ceilings of passenger compartments. But still greater protection can be provided with side air bags, he said.
"They really work; the way people get hurt in side impacts is almost always that their heads are injured," Mr. Ressler said.
Other auto makers are also looking for ways to improve protection for car occupants. Robert Lange, the top safety official at General Motors, said in a recent interview that the main safety issue associated with the spread of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks was side-impact collisions. He said G.M. would soon be offering more side air bags, and predicted that Federal regulators would soon begin looking for ways to further tighten regulations on side-impact protection.
Side air bags have recently become standard on G.M.'s Cadillac Seville and DeVille sedans and on its Chevrolet Venture, Oldsmobile Silhouette and Pontiac Trans Sport mini-vans, and are optional on the Chevrolet Prism sedan. Kyle Johnson, a G.M. spokesman, said 21 G.M. models would have side air bags by the end of the 2000 model year.
The Chrysler Corporation does not offer side air bags on any of its models, but is reviewing whether to do so, said Michele Tinson, a Chrysler spokeswoman. With the exception of a few models like the Toyota Corolla and Camry, which have optional side air bags, most Japanese cars do not have them. Luxury European manufacturers like BMW and Volvo already offer side air bags as standard equipment.
Ford said in 1995 that it would install side air bags at some point but provided few details then. Its decision could put pressure on other auto makers to follow suit. Ford cars and light trucks consistently score better than other manufacturers' models in Federal crash tests, and the addition of side air bags could widen this gap.
Federal regulators declined to comment on Ford's plans tonight.
The latest cars and most light trucks are already required to carry air bags in front of both front seats to protect occupants from frontal collisions. Regulators estimate that these air bags have saved 3,000 lives over the last decade, but the force of inflation has killed 96 people, mainly children or elderly people who were not wearing seat belts and were sitting very close to the air bags.
To improve overall safety, auto makers have slowed the rate at which air bags inflate and have urged parents to keep children in the back seat. Regulators have allowed air bags to be disconnected by people who request permission for a number of reasons, including shortness, frailty and a need to carry a child in the front seat.
Side air bags are designed to avoid some of these problems, and have been much less controversial. They inflate parallel to a car occupant sitting upright, rather than toward the occupant. Even for models on which side air bags are standard, Ford will allow customers to order cars without the air bags directly from the factory. Or, the devices could be disconnected.
Mr. Ressler said Ford's decision was based on a broad commitment to safety rather than a specific response to the spread of large sport utility vehicles and pickups. Recent tests by the insurance industry have found that side air bags provide a lot of protection for the occupants of cars that slide sideways into fixed objects like trees and bridge abutments. But Helen O. Petrauskas, Ford's vice president for environmental and safety engineering, said last fall that Ford was working hard on side air bags because of concerns about crashes with light trucks.
