HEADLINE: After Compromises, Indonesians Reach 3d Pact With I.M.F.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, April 7

 BODY:
Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund reached basic agreement on Tuesday on the third plan in six months for rescuing the country's economy. The plan is yet another effort to get Indonesia to comply with conditions allowing it to receive $43 billion in aid.
The fund made concessions that permit President Suharto to continue heavy subsidies on food and fuel; the prospect of ending the subsidies has led to anti-Government riots. 
 Mr. Suharto also made concessions, including closing more insolvent banks belonging to his close friends and supporters, according to officials familiar with the document.
Speaking in Tokyo today, Stanley Fisher, the No. 2 official at the I.M.F., gave some details of the agreement but said final language on a few points was still being worked out.
To assure compliance, the fund will withhold billions of dollars from the Indonesian Government until it takes a series of painful steps that it has so far resisted.
Even then, according to officials familiar with the complex negotiations, the fund will give emergency cash to Indonesia in small amounts as the country fulfills its commitments. These include steps to contain runaway inflation and talks with banks around the world over how Indonesia will repay more than $70 billion in corporate debt.
American and I.M.F. officials described the accord as Indonesia's last chance at fiscal redemption. But it also marked an effort to show some deference to Mr. Suharto, and fund officials went to considerable pains to portray parts of the program as Indonesia's initiative, rather than their own.
That is a sharp contrast to when the last agreement was signed, on Jan. 15. At that time Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the fund, stood over Mr. Suharto with his arms folded. The image of the fund appearing to dictate terms brought a political backlash in Indonesia, and emboldened the Government to ignore many of the conditions placed on the $43 billion aid program.
On Tuesday there were no top I.M.F. officials in Jakarta, and it seems unlikely that Mr. Suharto himself will sign the revised agreement. Nonetheless, fund officials and their American counterparts say they are sure that Mr. Suharto, now beginning his fifth term in office, understands that quick fixes to artificially bolster the Indonsian currency will not work.
While the fund had promised Indonesia a $43 billion package, so far it has turned over only $3 billion. And after the bitter experience of watching Indonesian officials sign agreements that they failed to carry out, both the fund and the United States, the biggest voice in the I.M.F., are clearly cautious.
"There will be a period of testing" before Indonesia gets its next injection of aid, Mr. Fischer, the fund's first deputy managing director, said recently. "What the world needs to see is performance, not signatures."
An American official involved in the delicate negotiations said: "We believe this has key ingredients for Indonesia's economic recovery. But what will be key in the days ahead is for Indonesia to carry out its commitments, and there will be a step-by-step monitoring."
There are also disturbing signs that President Suharto's relatives are continuing their search for ways to avoid any of the fund's conditions that threaten their wealth.
On Tuesday the Government announced a new partnership with a company to distribute nonessential goods like soap and toothpaste to Indonesia's 200 million people. But the business selected to do the job is run by Mr. Suharto's son, whose Government-favored car project and monopoly on the cloves were rejected by the fund several months ago.
Aside from financial questions, the subtext of the talks has been whether Mr. Suharto will be forced to surrender economic control over a country that has essentially been run like a family business.
The President could not openly defy the I.M.F., for fear of permanently scaring away investors, many of whom say they will not return to Indonesia until they are convinced that Mr. Suharto's rule will not end in a bloody struggle for succession.
But Mr. Suharto is not the only one with much at stake in how the agreement works out.
The fund is trying to calm opponents in Congress who have questioned why the Administration is seeking to inject another $18 billion into the I.M.F. to bolster its efforts to fight off economic crises like the one that seized Asia eight months ago. How tough a line it takes with Mr. Suharto has become a key test.
In a recent letter to President Clinton, 27 members of Congress argued that the Administration is propping up Mr. Suharto by requiring him to meet certain economic conditions but not to improve the country's human rights record.
"How is it," the letter read, "that we can muster the indignation, and subsequent pressure, to reverse an Indonesian Government decision to implement a currency board, but we are unable to react similarly when fundamental human rights to religious, political and economic freedom are blatantly trampled by the Indonesian Government?"
The fund's decision to back off its requirement that Indonesia immediately end its heavy subsidies for food and fuel was hardly surprising: fund officials conceded that they did not foresee how such a step could lead to social unrest. While the rioting has so far been sporadic, there are fears that it could worsen this summer as food shortages grow more severe and layoffs affect more people.
In fact the new agreement suggests that far tougher times are ahead. The January accord estimated that the Indonesian economy would grow by 4 percent this year; the new agreement estimates it will shrink by 5 percent. The fund now estimates that inflation could hit 47 percent this year.
The agreement also permits Indonesia to run a larger budget deficit than previously envisioned, chiefly to pay for the food subsidies.
And the fund is insisting that interest rates remain extraordinarily high, an effort to lure investors back. But that is also likely to increase the number of bankruptcies.
Perhaps the most complex task ahead for Indonesia is negotiating with lenders, chiefly in Japan and Europe, for more time to pay off a crushing debt. Those discussions are just beginning.
But there is a model: South Korea convinced its lenders to give it more time, and now, for the first time since the onset of its own financial crisis, South Korean Government officials are preparing to borrow billions of dollars on world bond markets. A few months ago, when the country was days from default, that would have been unthinkable.
Indonesia's recovery is likely to take far more time.
"But you have to say that things are better than they were a month ago," said Steve Radelet, an economist with lengthy experience in Indonesia who now works at the Institute for International Development at Harvard. "The fund will never get exactly what it wants, and the Indonesians will never get exactly what they want."

HEADLINE: JAZZ REVIEW;
A Saxophonist's Warm-Up Ends

BYLINE: By BEN RATLIFF 

 BODY:
A decade ago, major record labels yanked promising jazz players out of music school, offered them contracts and asked them to earn a place in history. Such invitations are rare these days, but the tenor saxophonist Mark Turner, who's into his 30's and has only now released his first big-label record ("Mark Turner," on Warner Brothers), is a beneficiary of current jazz economics: he's ready, whereas many who came before him were not.
Mr. Turner opened a three-night run at Sweet Basil on Tuesday and demonstrated his trademarks. One begins high on the horn in a wheezed note and takes the shape of a long, trickling downward run; once at the bottom, he ascends again, starting even higher. Another is his generous use of arpeggios in improvisation, the Bach-like sound of chords cycling around. And another is more constant: he makes his tone quiet and firm, running off even streams of single notes while riding on a rhythm section's most volatile rhythms. When his rhythm section cut up steady time, blurring it and making it Cubist with superimposed ideas, Mr. Turner kept a cool head, going through gymnastics of harmony, limiting his projection. 
 His style isn't based in brashness or conscious understatement, but a maturity in between. At times, he sounds unabashedly reminiscent of Warne Marsh, the saxophonist closely associated in the 1940's and 50's with the pianist and composer Lennie Tristano. At Sweet Basil, Mr. Turner played an original called "Lennie Groove," directly replicating the rhythmic style of its namesake's music: fast, dry streams of single notes played in tandem with the pianist George Colligan, with double-time whirls stitched in.
Mr. Turner sounds natural within this pinpointed, scientific approach, but he can also play a devastating ballad. After three pieces, Tuesday's set broke off into a five-minute solo saxophone improvisation, and then he sounded the five notes signaling "Autumn in New York." He didn't aim for harmonic vertigo but for a pretty tone: he played thick sighs in the horn's high register, fully honoring the song's romanticism.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mark Turner on tenor saxophone at Sweet Basil. (Jack Vartoogian)

HEADLINE: WNET Appoints a New Chairman

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
After helping WNET, Channel 13 in New York, raise $78 million in a capital campaign that was the largest ever by a public television station, the financier Henry R. Kravis has told the station's board that he will step down as chairman. The board has chosen Steven Rattner, deputy chief executive of the investment firm Lazard Freres & Company, to succeed him.
The formal announcement is expected in two weeks at the station's annual fund-raising dinner, and the board's vote to approve Mr. Rattner as chairman is scheduled for its next meeting, in May. 
 "If Henry had to step down, there would be nobody I could think of better to replace him than Steve," said William F. Baker, the station's president, confirming that the board had unofficially approved Mr. Rattner, who was selected after a search by its nominating committee, led by Michael I. Sovern, a former president of Columbia University.
Mr. Kravis said he wanted to devote more time to his role as chairman of the New York City Investment Fund, a $60 million venture-capital fund he founded in 1996 to spur investment in the city's economic development. Having been chairman for eight and a half years, he also said it was time to "let other people have a chance."
"I'm thrilled to turn it over to someone with such a strong background in the telecommunications field," Mr. Kravis said of Mr. Rattner.
Mr. Rattner, who has been on WNET's board for eight years and vice chairman since 1995, has been an adviser on a number of major media transactions, including a $1 billion investment by Microsoft in Comcast, the sale of Continental Cablevision to U S West, and the sale of Paramount Communications to Viacom. Before becoming an investment banker in 1982, he spent nine years as a correspondent for The New York Times.
His experience will be especially valuable, Mr. Baker said, as the station makes the mandatory transition from analog to digital broadcasting in the next year or so, as all broadcast stations must do.
Mr. Kravis said his most important legacy was not just the capital campaign, which he initiated and which gave the station its first endowment to cushion its $120 million annual budget. "No. 1 was that I wanted to change our mission," Mr. Kravis said, "so that everything we did was focused on education, through our programming, through our media lab, through our teacher-training institute and other things. We are not just a television station but an educational organization."
The Kravis Multimedia Education Center, started in 1992 with a $5 million gift from Mr. Kravis, has helped forge new ideas for the convergence of computers and television, and has adapted Thirteen's programs and educational services for new formats like CD-ROM, DVD and the Internet.
"Henry has left the station in much, much better shape than ever before," Mr. Rattner said, "not just financially but in terms of its mission and spirit." He praised Mr. Kravis for knowing "how to motivate management by showing them you're involved, but not de-motivate them by meddling."
Mr. Baker agreed, saying: "He set parameters. He insisted we stay on budget, and he wanted the highest quality programming around, and he was all over us about education being our heritage. But he never tells you how to do it; he gives management their heads."
Mr. Kravis said he had pressed management to improve programming, too, and was satisfied with the results.
"We're winning all sorts of awards again now," he said. "I think we have a superb management team and the station is in excellent shape. It's well positioned for the 21st century."

HEADLINE: The Tobacco Industry's Defiance

 BODY:
Cigarette manufacturers pulled out of the search for a comprehensive tobacco deal yesterday after Steven Goldstone, the chairman of RJR Nabisco, railed against the tobacco bill approved by the Senate Commerce Committee as sure to produce bankruptcy for tobacco companies, the loss of countless jobs and creation of a rampant black market for cigarettes. But the industry's resistance and unrealistic doomsday scenarios should not weaken Congressional resolve to forge ahead with strong legislation to protect public health and curb smoking among youths. This exercise, after all, is not about protecting the financial interests of the cigarette producers.
The bill drafted by Senator John McCain is much tougher than the settlement negotiated between the tobacco industry and 40 state attorneys general last June. Mr. Goldstone and other tobacco leaders want desperately to get the earlier settlement approved by Congress because it is far more favorable to them. It required the industry to pay $368.5 billion over 25 years but granted the companies significant legal protections, including immunity from future class-action lawsuits and punitive damages for past misconduct. In exchange, the industry agreed to end advertising and marketing efforts aimed at young smokers. Although the advertising controls were attractive, the total payment was too low to raise the price of cigarettes sufficiently to reduce teen-age smoking. 
 The McCain bill is a significant improvement. It would raise industry payments to $506 billion over 25 years, and would not provide immunity from lawsuits, though it would cap industry payouts for legal awards to $6.5 billion in any single year. We have argued that cigarette prices must increase by at least $1.50 per pack to make a significant dent in consumption, and many experts think a bigger price hike is needed. To achieve such levels, industry payments would have to be raised even higher than required by the McCain bill.
The industry's decision to walk away from the legislation does not hamper Congress's ability to go forward. Congress can force the price of cigarettes up through a new tobacco tax. It can give the Food and Drug Administration ample power to regulate tobacco and nicotine. It can write into law many of the advertising controls included in the attorneys general settlement, though the industry will fight those in court. That is a chance worth taking.
The fact remains that the industry has much to lose by walking away. Without the legislation it would be back at square one, fighting dozens of state lawsuits over Medicaid claims related to smoking. It would have no control over potentially enormous damage awards. Fatigue and the threat of financial instability drove the industry toward a settlement last year. Those conditions remain unchanged. Mr. Goldstone and his allies are probably hoping that threats and scare tactics will drive Congress to do their bidding, but their defiant posture is a mark of desperation.

HEADLINE: Risky Budget Optimism

 BODY:
After three years of preaching austerity, Gov. George Pataki proposed a New York State budget in January with tax cuts and generous spending increases designed to appeal to voters in an election year. Now the Legislature is proposing even more spending and tax cuts. The lawmakers assume that the money to pay for their programs will continue to flood in from the Wall Street boom, and it is true that the state's fiscal situation is better than it has been in years. But the Legislature's budget is risky. It would saddle New York with multibillion-dollar deficits in future years that will be difficult to close if the economy turns sour.
Most of the Legislature's priorities are worthy, but they drive the budget into fiscal irresponsibility. Spending for child care, education and school construction would be boosted, and the proposed tax cuts would accelerate relief for low-income elderly homeowners and help middle-class purchasers of clothing and shoes. But the cuts, which would cost $100 million this year, would grow to more than $700 million in the years ahead. 
 Governor Pataki has promised to veto any items that exceed his overall budget ceiling of $71.6 billion. His aides warn that simply assuming that Medicaid expenses will go down, as the Legislature did, without adopting measures to control costs, makes no sense. Fiscal experts in the Legislature maintain that their practice of re-estimating costs downward in Medicaid, welfare and debt service has worked in previous years. But obligating the state to programs that generate deficits in the future, and rely on good times continuing forever, has helped give New York State one of the lowest credit ratings in the country.
The encouraging development about the budget is that it is being adopted earlier, with less acrimony, more participation and more openness than anyone can remember. The Democratic-controlled Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate agreed early to their own estimates of how much money is available and hashed out many of their differences in public meetings of budget conference committees. The old scenarios of the budget being decided behind closed doors by two legislative leaders and the Governor, the infamous "three men in a room," have been scrapped.
But openness does not guarantee the right result, and Mr. Pataki should now subject the budget to rigorous analysis and veto pieces of it if necessary. If he does not exercise caution, the next Legislature and Governor will be back to the dismal task of revising their spending and tax-cut schemes in the light of fiscal reality.

HEADLINE: Taking Care of Workers And Business, Too;
When Quality Is Key in Health Benefits

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Four months after multiple-bypass heart surgery, Gordon Kernan, 52, was back at work testing products at the Black & Decker Corporation. But his diabetes grew worse after the operation, so he now monitors his health with the help of a counseling program that his employer helped create.
Every few weeks, Amie Layman, a trained diabetes counselor, calls Mr. Kernan and his wife, Mary, with encouragement and advice on exercise and diet. When one medication caused problems, Ms. Layman suggested seeing a specialist, who quickly switched Mr. Kernan to a different medicine. "If it hadn't been for Amie," Mrs. Kernan said, "I could have lost him." 
 Faced with a backlash against penny-pinching managed health care, more and more companies like Black & Decker are taking a harder look at that care, often sponsoring programs to help employees and their families cope with chronic maladies.
Employers and health plans have long paid lip service to quality, of course, but cutting costs has usually been paramount. "Economists told employers there was no way to differentiate health care based on quality," said Dr. Joshua Freedman, a Los Angeles psychiatrist who developed a program at the Southern California Edison Company for workers seeking help with depression. "So they went for the lowest bid."
But some of that is starting to change. Suzanne Mercure, who initiated the program for Edison, added: "The patient is the customer. Satisfying patients is where the action needs to be."
Companies, while continuing to insist on keeping costs as low as possible, are now pushing for quality in a variety of ways. And beyond the motivation of keeping employees happy, many companies are also trying to appear responsive to such concerns to help avoid more intrusive Government regulation.
Some companies work directly with doctors and hospitals on improving treatments, while others press insurers and health maintenance organizations to offer special programs for conditions like high cholesterol, depression and breast cancer.
The General Motors Corporation dispatched some experts on improving quality to help streamline hospitals near G.M. plants in Michigan, Indiana, Ohio and upstate New York. And in central Pennsylvania, the Fort James Corporation, a paper products maker, prodded local doctors to agree on "best practice" standards for treating the lower-back strain and repetitive-motion trauma that plague factory workers.
In the long run, companies say quality care makes excellent financial sense. Black & Decker began to pay attention to diabetes after discovering that diabetes-related medical costs were growing three times as fast as other health costs, said Raymond J. Brusca, vice president for benefits. So he worked with Healthcare Management Solutions, a privately held company in Roanoke, Va., to put together the counseling program that helps Mr. Kernan.
Big corporations are not the only ones zeroing in on better care. Smaller employers often push for quality by pooling their market power in local coalitions of health care buyers.
Reflecting the widespread backlash against managed care, Congress and the states are considering tighter laws and regulations. And last month, a Presidential advisory commission recommended steps to establish standards to try to narrow the wide differences, from doctor to doctor and hospital to hospital, in treating the same conditions. President Clinton announced that Vice President Al Gore would convene a panel of private experts in June to draft national standards for measuring quality.
Employers, though, want to preempt any new regulation. "Unless we can demonstrate that we are as concerned about quality as about costs, it will be tougher and tougher for us to keep our options open," said Steve Wetzell, an official of Buyers Health Care Action Group, a coalition of 38 employers in four states that is based in Minneapolis.
Defining and measuring quality is far from easy. Even most big companies do not have enough employees to gather statistically valid information. And many insurers and H.M.O.s track only the clinical results important customers demand. Even when there is agreement on the best practices, those may soon be outdated by medical breakthroughs.
Employers must also be careful not to trespass on legally protected privacy rights. And every health plan seeks to stay clear of the appearance of having administrators practice medicine, which is illegal in some states and can open the door to malpractice lawsuits.
"Confidentiality is a major concern," said Kathleen Angel, a benefits vice president at the Digital Equipment Corporation. She said Digital was careful to work through outside firms when it recently offered advice on health questions to employees who consulted an interactive Internet site. "Digital does not know the results," she said. "We just pay the premiums."
Dr. Cris Bisgard, health services director of Delta Air Lines, said the company had "pushed Cigna Health Care to develop care management programs for asthma, diabetes and low-back pain."
Carina Orraca, the ebullient 11-year-old daughter of a Delta reservations agent, was not getting the relief she needed from her asthma medicine, so her pediatrician referred her to an asthma counselor provided for Delta people.
The counselor, Brenda Scott, sent Carina back to the pediatrician with suggestions for more effective medicine and gave Carina a lung monitoring device. "Now the episodes don't happen as often," said Carina's mother, Marta Orraca, a teacher in Peachtree City, outside Atlanta. "We're very pleased."
Dr. Bisgard said Delta was also "leaning particularly hard" on Cigna to help workers who experience low-back pain so they would miss fewer days of work, spend less time in the hospital and help keep productivity high.
Other companies, like Motorola Inc., which has an array of programs to help workers with a variety of diseases, later ordered their own versions of the diabetes program from the Roanoke firm or other insurers.
Some employers tell employees which doctors groups and health plans have the best track records. The California-based Pacific Business Group on Health, a group of big employers, is conducting its second survey of the health status of 58,000 workers who are members of 58 H.M.O.'s in the West. The results, which will be available on the Internet next year, can then be compared with a similar survey two years ago.
A few big companies -- like G.M., the General Electric Company, Motorola and the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company -- have sent their own in-house experts to H.M.O.'s, medical groups and hospitals to explain methods of quality improvement used in the companies' own operations.
Some of the most extensive quality programs are sponsored by the auto makers, spurred by the knowledge that G.M., the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation combined spent $6.7 billion for health care in 1996, a larger cost than all the steel that goes into their vehicles. In the 1980's, when they were losing ground to the Japanese, American auto companies adopted the Japanese practice of helping suppliers meet industrywide standards for everything from brakes to windshield wipers.
Recently they have applied this idea to hospitals. "That approach became a model for us," said James B. Kenney, president of the Greater Detroit Area Health Council.
For example, G.M. experts, though claiming no knowledge of surgery, recently worked with Rochester General Hospital in upstate New York to reduce the time patients spent in the operating room undergoing heart bypass procedures.
Now some steps are performed simultaneously instead of consecutively, surgical procedures are standardized and patients spend a shorter time with an uncomfortable breathing tube down their throats. Though it is too soon to look at long-term survival rates, the hospital said it had reduced readmissions of heart patients and reduced costs.
Ford and Chrysler also have a number of projects to lift the quality of care, and the United Automobile Workers union, which has rebuffed the sharing of health costs that most employers insist on, is cooperating in these programs.
But experts on health quality, like Mr. Wetzell of the Minneapolis buyers group and Dr. Robert Brooks, director of health policy research at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., say the employer-sponsored programs cannot by themselves improve the nation's health care. They say quality improvement should be based on wide-ranging national research, probably requiring Government financing.
"We need a massive ongoing search for best practices," agreed Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University. "We have zillions of groups, and each does some little thing really well. But it doesn't add up to anything authoritative."
The 34-member Presidential advisory commission, which included health insurance executives, doctors and consumer advocates, skirted the question of financing the writing of national standards. Instead, the group recommended that Congress establish a new national council, which would set goals for improving quality, and rely on the Gore panel of private experts to attack the nuts-and-bolts issues in measuring and reporting on quality improvement.

GRAPHIC: Photos: (Naum Kazden/The New York Times); When Gordon Kernan's diabetes worsened, his employer, Black & Decker, called in a counselor to help him. A number of big companies have begun similar programs. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Weighing Employees' Health Care Coverage"
Rather than simply paying for the least expensive health plans and assuming that workers are getting adequate care, many employers are starting to take a closer look at the quality of medical care their employees receive. A 1996 survey of plan members in California, Oregon and Washington found that the plans did a reasonably good job of addressing high-blood pressure, but cholesterol and preventive counseling were not handled as well.
 
PREVENTIVE CARE -- On average, only about one-third of the employees said that they got advice on how to stay healthy. Preventive care services were better, though about a third of respondents said they did not get recommended flu shots.
 
CHOLESTEROL -- About 80 percent of the enrollees had their cholesterol checked. Of the ones who reported having high cholesterol, fewer than half said their cholesterol was now under control.
 
HYPERTENSION -- Almost all enrollees said their blood pressure was checked. Of those who had high blood pressure, about four out of five said it had been brought under control.
 
(Sources: Pacific Business Group on Health; Medical Quality Commission)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Who gets information first on auto sales figures can be critically important, and controversial.

BYLINE: By Robyn Meredith 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
INVESTORS, stock analysts and even Federal Reserve officials eagerly await the release each month of auto makers' sales for signs of the condition of individual companies and the health of the economy as a whole.
Some people, though, wait longer than others. 
 Most of Wall Street's automotive stock analysts, along with the auto companies, subscribe to data services that break out the monthly sales figures. The leading provider of this data is the Autodata Corporation in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.
Auto makers send their monthly reports to Autodata at least several hours before they announce them publicly. "In some cases, we can get it a day early," said Ronald J. Pinelli, president of Autodata.
While the big three American auto makers ask that the data be embargoed until their announcements, the data for others, including Nissan, Honda and Toyota, are plugged into spreadsheets and immediately released to Autodata's subscribers. "Our Wall Street clients are the ones where the timing is really critical," Mr. Pinelli said.
Indeed, sales results can move stock prices. So a window of opportunity exists for a select group of people to use the information.
"We're dealing with a problem of selective disclosure, which is not quite as egregious as insider trading," said John C. Coffee, a Columbia University law professor who specializes in corporate, securities and criminal law. "What we're really talking about is whether there is a level playing field between institutional investors and individual investors."
Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, criticized selective disclosure in a speech in February, pointing to corporate executives' habits of phoning favorite stock analysts to discuss earnings results before releasing that information to the public. Trading in the company's stock may be heavy as analysts digest the information and await the public reaction. Generally, the practice does not raise legal questions unless the person who tips off outsiders benefits in some way. Legal issues aside, the selective distribution of information is ethically wrong, Mr. Levitt said, since small and big investors should have equal opportunities.
The S.E.C. refused this week to comment further on the distribution of auto sales results and whether the practice amounts to selective disclosure. But the issue of selective disclosure "is something that we take an interest in, and it is as much a fairness issue as a legal issue," said Brian J. Lane, director of the agency's division of corporation finance. "We'll be keeping our ears open to persons that have complaints or concerns about particular situations and see how the practices are evolving."
Others said the selective distribution appeared to run afoul of stock exchange rules. Companies "can't selectively disclose material information and not put it out in a press release," said Louis M. Thompson, president and chief executive officer of the National Investor Relations Institute, a Vienna, Va., trade group for corporate investor relations officers, which held a symposium yesterday in Washington on the practice of selective disclosure. "You have to put the release out first."
The rules for Nasdaq, where Toyota and Nissan American depository receipts trade, as well as for the New York Stock Exchange, where Honda's A.D.R.'s trade, require companies to distribute market-sensitive information immediately to the news services before they give the information to others, according to representatives of the two exchanges.
Data companies said they were not trying to give anyone an unfair edge. "There is no plan as far as the companies doing this," Mr. Pinelli said. "It just works out this way.
"We're certainly not in a position here to gain financially or for our clients to gain financially," he added.
One reason auto makers give Autodata the numbers early is that they are eager to get back the entire industry's performance so they can gauge their own, he said.
Auto analysts said they could not recall Autodata transmitting the most market-sensitive results -- sales of the Big Three American auto makers -- before the official release crossed their computer screens in reports from news services like Reuters, The Associated Press and Bloomberg News.
But for the foreign auto makers, "just because it is not out on the wires doesn't mean it hasn't hit the trading desks," said David M. Garrity, an auto analyst at CIBC Oppenheimer. The monthly sales results "could have an impact" on the A.D.R.'s of those companies, he said.
Autodata's stance is that "unless we're told that something is embargoed, we can release it," Mr. Pinelli said. "When we receive it, we assume the information is released, except in the case of the Big Three," he added, referring to the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation.
The most recent sales results for other auto makers, though, were available to Wall Street well before they were officially released. On April 1, some Wall Street analysts rattled off the March sales results for Toyota, Honda, Nissan, Mazda and Volkswagen. For Toyota, Honda and Nissan, analysts knew results several hours before the companies issued releases. Mazda and Volkswagen did not publicly release their sales data until the following day.
In the case of Mazda and Volkswagen, "I don't think that their stocks would really react because their sales are so small in the U.S.," said Nicholas Lobaccaro, an auto analyst at Merrill Lynch. But the A.D.R.'s of the large Japanese auto makers like Honda, Toyota and Nissan "definitely are influenced by U.S. events," Mr. Lobaccaro said. In fact, "their profits are all pretty much in North America these days," he said, because of the recession in Japan.
Mazda does not have A.D.R.'s, and those of Honda and Toyota did not seem to be affected by their United States sales this month, analysts said. The A.D.R.'s of Nissan, whose sales fell 42 percent in March, closed down 5.5 percent on April 1, on triple the trading volume of the previous day.
Nissan said other factors might have been more important than its sales decline. "It was more likely affected by financial announcements coming out of Tokyo," said Gerry W. Spahn, a Nissan spokesman. "The U.S. sales are such a very small factor on what happens on our A.D.R. market -- those are mainly focused on our price on the Tokyo market."
Honda acknowledged that it sent sales data early to Autodata and other companies. "We've never been concerned in the past," said Art P. Garner, a Honda spokesman. "If people thought it were a problem, we would certainly revisit that."
The question is whether "sophisticated insiders have access to more information than others," said Joel Seligman, a securities law expert and dean of the University of Arizona's law school. Equal disclosure would mean "your Aunt Mimi in Omaha will have at least theoretical access to information at the same time" as Wall Street's top analysts, he said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1156 words

HEADLINE: Ruffled, Japan Advises U.S.: Mind Your Own Business

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 8

 BODY:
As a parade of American officials all the way up to President Clinton have told Japan how to fix its slumping economy, the Japanese have grown increasingly offended.
So specific have the American economic prescriptions become that they leave political leaders here little room to save face: no matter what they do now, they will appear to be caving in to "gaiatsu," or foreign pressure. While the Japanese routinely protest the time-honored tactic, it has often been welcomed, indeed invited, by specific interest groups in Japan who use it to press for change. 
 Gaiatsu has in the past been credited by officials at the Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Trade and Industry with wringing much needed change from a system intended to protect the status quo.
But there is a growing sense here that American officials have taken gaiatsu too far, that their demands have become so specific that they border on orders: Pump an amount equal to at least 2 percent of your gross domestic product into your ailing economy. And by the way, be sure to include income tax cuts and think about rolling back the increase in the consumption tax that is blamed for sending the economy into a tailspin.
"Inappropriate!" snapped Taku Yamasaki, the powerful chairman of the Policy Research Council of the governing Liberal Democratic Party when asked what he thought of the specific recommendations made by United States officials.
Koichi Kato, the general secretary of the party, who is mentioned as a potential Prime Minister, was apparently so offended by American demands for a rollback of Japan's sales tax that he began blaming Washington for Japan's growing budget deficit. "We have no intention of organizing our policies at the suggestions of other countries," he said at a lecture recently.
"For years we have been executing reflation measures in response to American demand, and the debt of the central Government has reached a level as large as the GDP."
Even Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, whose political precariousness has made him wary of making even the most tepid comments publicly, is bristling, suggesting after Mr. Clinton's remarks at a press gathering on Friday that the President would do well to contact him directly rather than conduct a campaign in the news media.
Speaking in London on Friday when he announced he would reconvene the panel that imposed fiscal restraint upon Japan so it could reconsider its actions, Mr. Hashimoto testily told reporters, "I'm not doing this because I was told to do it by America."
American officials say they conveyed their concerns to Japan privately -- including at meetings between Mr. Hashimoto and President Clinton -- for more than a year, to no avail. The decision to criticize the Japanese publicly was a calculated one, Mr. Clinton's advisers say, after they had concluded that business groups in Japan who had been pressing for far stronger Government action needed allies. Europeans and International Monetary Fund officials have made similar pleas that Japan pump up its economy.
On Thursday, Mr. Hashimoto is expected to formally announce the details of a plan to cut taxes and increase spending to help revive economic growth. Today, the Parliament approved a $582 billion budget for next year, clearing the way for the Government to consider the Prime Minister's plan.
So hasn't gaiatsu worked in this case?
"If the Japanese people didn't want the economy to be reflated, you could say it was a case of gaiatsu working," said Saadaki Numata, the Government spokesman. "Gaiatsu is something that forces you to do something you don't want to do. We've always been interested in stimulating the economy."
Japan has tolerated an unusual level of United States "advice" since the days when it was under Gen. Douglas MacArthur's administration. But the relationship between the two countries has shifted in the last decade, as Japan emerged as an economic powerhouse and a new generation of leaders took over from those whose actions and words were colored by Japan's experiences in the aftermath of World War II.
"The generation who feels the two countries are completely equal is in charge of politics now," Mr. Yamasaki said.
He is particularly annoyed by specific suggestions about how Japan should manage its economic affairs, annoyed enough to have accepted an interview to discuss gaiatsu when he normally shuns meetings with foreign journalists.
"It is fine to comment on macroeconomic matters," he said. "But we cannot accept all kinds of comments about the contents of policies. It is like Japan telling America when to cut taxes or lower the unemployment rate and ordering it to take this policy for that purpose."
Such comments make American experts on Japan like John Neuffer, a political analyst at the Mitsui Marine Research Institute, chuckle. He worked for the Japanese Foreign Ministry in New York in the 1980's, when Japanese companies were buying up American icons like Rockefeller Center and Columbia Pictures and books predicting imminent Japanese supremacy were a dime a dozen.
"Ten years ago, the Japanese were telling Washington the world needed some real leadership from the U.S.," he said. "Now the shoe is on the other foot."
That sentiment is echoed by the new American Ambassador, Thomas S. Foley. "I think the message has pretty clearly been given, and we've tried to do it politely but consistently," he said.
But many here say that the Americans are failing to account for Japan's political realities.
"The amount of expertise on Asia and Japan is the lowest I've ever seen," said an American economist here. "No one in this administration has a longstanding understanding of this part of the world."
The Japanese budgetary system, for instance, made it difficult for Mr. Hashimoto to introduce a supplementary spending proposal for the economy before the budget itself had been approved. Nonetheless, a number of American officials demanded prompt action while the budget was still pending.
The Japanese have also been reluctant to take bold measures to stimulate the economy because doing so would swell Japan's budget deficit, one of the largest in the world.
Mr. Hashimoto, who has made trimming the deficit a top priority, is politically very weak. Any of the measures the United States has recommended to stimulate the economy would require backtracking on fiscal reform as it is currently embedded in law, and any sign of backtracking by Mr. Hashimoto is sure to result in calls for his head by the party's internal opposition.
"I'm not so sure people realize the sensitivity of the political situation in Japan," said Katsuhiro Fujiwara, a managing director at the Keidanren, Japan's powerful business association, which has itself advocated same sort of stimulus measures the United States has proffered. "Many in the party see this as the best chance to upset the Hashimoto team."

PUB-DATE: April 9, 1998

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 830 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
TWO years ago Social Security privatization probably had no more support in Washington than the legalization of marijuana. Today, the notion is being entertained by such heavyweights as Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the senior Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee. Privatization has become a very real possibility in part because big budget surpluses are apparently available to help pay for the transition.
"Something labeled 'partial privatization' is bound to be included in any broad-based Social Security reform," predicted Sylvester Schieber, an economist at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a pension consulting company, and a member of the Government's Advisory Council on the system. 
 But getting from here to there will be tricky. The seeming convergence on the idea of privatization masks deep differences of opinion. Consider the playing field:
THE LIBERTARIANS For some conservative intellectuals -- namely Carolyn Weaver of the American Enterprise Institute and Jose Pinera at the Cato Institute -- privatization is a matter of cutting Washington down to size. As long as the Government stands ready to play nanny, workers will have little incentive to plan for their own retirement. And as long as pension income amounts to a gift from Government, political coalitions will work to keep the checks rolling in.
This is surely the oldest and most principled argument for privatization. Though legislators talk the libertarian talk, few really walk the walk. The libertarian stance does, however, offer a high-minded rationale for policies based on other considerations.
THE ECONOMISTS -- To many technocrats -- Edward Gramlich, the former chairman of the Social Security Advisory Council who is now a governor of the Federal Reserve, comes to mind -- Social Security's "crisis" boils down to the collective failure to save enough to pay for the retirement of the huge baby-boom generation. Higher taxes, or bigger budget surpluses achieved through lower Government spending, would do the trick. But forced saving in personal pension accounts could prove more palatable since people would rather put away dollars in their own names than send them into the black hole of the Treasury.
This argument for partial privatization apparently carries a lot of weight with the pragmatists in the Clinton Administration. And while he would hardly put it in these terms, the idea meshes with the proposal from John Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, to dedicate budget surpluses to private Social Security accounts.
THE GENERATIONAL PEACEMAKERS -- While Social Security taxes and benefits create a tangled web of income redistribution, most of the transfer is from young to old. Not surprisingly, some politicos fear the losers will eventually take out their wrath on pensioners -- and on Washington. In this scheme of things, partial privatization would serve as a peace offering to the young and the restless.
Senator Moynihan, for example, wants to cut payroll taxes and retirement benefits along with opening the door to tax-sheltered personal Social Security accounts. This would mean lower costs and subsidized savings for those not yet retired, and would make friends for the embattled public pension system.
THE NEW DEALERS -- For some analysts, including the M.I.T. economist Peter Diamond and Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution, privatization is a solution in search of a problem. There is much right with Social Security, they say, and nothing that cannot be fixed with a few nips and tucks and modest tax increases.
But, they reason, if you can't lick 'em, join 'em. The privatization could be transformed into something useful, namely a broader Social Security trust fund that includes private stocks, which have historically generated bigger returns than Government bonds.
Most who favor private investment by the trust fund don't kid themselves that the shift would increase the total size of the economic pie. But it probably would give lower- and middle-income retirees a bigger slice, since Social Security accounts for a bigger portion of their retirement funds than it does of the wealthy. "Why should the rich get all the benefit from the 'equity premium' that comes with taking modest risks in the stock market?" asks Mr. Diamond.
The lure of privatization has turned a no-win political debate about how much to cut benefits and how much to raise taxes into an exercise with interesting possibilities. That fact alone makes a major overhaul of Social Security more likely in the next few years.
But the new form is hardly clearer than it was when privatization was just a gleam in the eyes of assorted libertarians. So much of the support for privatization is purely as a means to an end that policy makers inclined toward big changes will be deeply reluctant to clarify the issues.
Something akin to a consensus on Social Security privatization is perhaps within reach. But the consensus is more rhetorical than real.
